column13: Eh, toi?! Heaven on Seven is a lively loud place to get authentic New Orleans' food and more in downtown Chicago. Head to the 7th floor, put your name in for a table or find empty seats at the counter.Specials are listed on a chalk board and the servers can also cover the specials. They've got all your Po' Boys, Gumbos, Shrimp everythings, Burgers, and more. I've recently loved the Diablo Chicken Tamales, and they're hot and smothered in cheese. Get a local (NOLA) beer here like Abita and you're good to go!Just get there early, as this place is popular (as it should be)!

Ok, I admit I've never been to New Orleans before but I think the Cajun food at Heaven on Seven is really tasty!  The gumbo is so good, make sure to get that for your side.  My son loves it so much, he gets the extra large bowl of it!  The regular and jalapeño corn muffins go great with the gumbo.  The po boys are awesome and huge!  I love the Peacemaker which combines the shrimp and oysters for the po boys; so much good stuff that it's hard to eat it like a sandwich, that's probably why they give you a knife so you can cut and eat it with a fork! The pasta options are are also good as well.I'm sad that they closed down the bigger location on Rush, that was the one we used to go to.  I like this smaller location-definitely a lot more cozy!  The service was top notch and we will continue to enjoy Cajun food at this location.  Like others mention, it's cash only and is found in the 7th floor of the Garland building.

I loved this place!!! They had a long island type of beverage that was amazing!! Their gumbo was delicious!! Side note: they serve gumbo with everything.. Their serving portions are enough to feed a small horse... Okay, Im exaggerating put you get my point hopefully. Parking will be your only headache (thats if you drive).  Be aware and mindful they only accept cash!!CASH ONLY ... ATM is on site.

This is a very good Cajun restaurant. No, it's not as good as many in New Orleans, but it's good. And what makes it special is the vibe, with its thousands of different hot sauces lining the walls (no, there are no repeats) and its perpetual Christmas-garlanded ceilings.I started with a cup of the gumbo, which was excellent, with its generous helping of tender, flavorful Andouille sausage.A jalapeno corn muffin wasn't all that impressive compared to others I've had.My main was a Cajun barbecued shrimp po'boy. The shrimp was very hot, with a slight saffron flavor, and the bread was nicely grilled. The whole mess (and I use the term intentionally) was covered in a flavorful Cajun gravy with just the right amount of spice. At first, as I picked at it with my fork, I thought it was just okay, but once I'd eaten enough shrimp to be able to pick the whole thing up and get a bite of everything, I really liked it.Service was friendly and efficient. A lot of regulars came in and sat at the small, U-shaped lunch counter while I was there. I could tell it's a place many people have been coming to for decades, and I can see why.

Interesting spot. Out of the way, you won't find it unless you are looking for it. (Located on the seventh floor of an office-type building). Food and service were okay. You can pretty much create your own dish from all the options on the menu.Jalapeño cheddar cornbread: super dense, nice flavorsShrimp and corn chowder: oddly sweet and gelatinous.New Orleans BBQ Shrimp po'boy: very saucy, lots of black pepper flavor. The shrimp were cooked very nicely.Overall wouldn't go out of the way to come here

Inside an office building on the 7th floor is this much needed restaurant.  While sipping a Cajun Long Island ice tea our party ordered fried pickles which turned out to be really delicious.  The batter tasted like corn meal, the same stuff they fry their catfish in but wasn't too thick and was served with a big bowl of some kind of creamy ranch-like sauce.  The Cajun long island was a one and done kind of drinks. I'm not sure if it was because I hadn't eaten much all day, the fact that the drink came out in a mason jar the size of a fish bowl, or if the bartender was just being generous that night, but I had one and was nice and buzzed.  Well worth the price.I ordered a shrimp and oyster po boy and had mixed feelings about it.  When I first saw it, I figured it was an open faced sandwich because I couldn't find the top bun and actually started eating it with my knife and fork until I discovered that the tiny top bun was just hidden underneath the 4lbs of shredded lettuce.  The bread that they chose was tiny.  It was probably just mine but the bun was smaller than the average cell phone with sauce on the side.  The taste of the seafood, however, was good with way more fried shrimp than oyster.  I only had 3 oysters but the taste was pretty spot on and was fried perfectly.

At first site I honestly didn't think that this was a  place that served so much delicious food!! The staff was friendly and helpful and gave you a feeling that you were being fed by some family members who really love you!!They have an awesome menu with an abundance of options! If you're not sure about, ask and trust me when I say trust their recommendations!This is a place I'll want to come to every time I visit Chicago.

Delish !! Gumbo was outta this world delicious !!!  I had the shrimp linguine w angry sauce , and boy was it angry !!! Very very very spicey !!!!!  I prob should've done the voo doo.  We also had the jalapeño cornbread. Very very tasty. Fiancé had the chicken po boy. He liked it very much. I will definitely be back !!!  Mmmmmm New Orleans flavor In the heart of Chicago !!!!

Great Cajun food in a unique atmosphere. The corn muffins were fantastic and we only wish we'd been able to try more of the specials.One thing to keep in mind... They are CASH ONLY no debit cards allowed.
We went with a big group, and they were nice but I thought the food lacked the kick I expect from cajun.  To be fair, just about everyone else in the group liked it more than me.

one of the awesome lunch places for lunch in the loop...if it was just judging on the food quality i would consider it a 3.5 stars, but given the other lunch choices in the loop, i would definitely upgrade it to a 4 stari loved the gumbo there, and they are quite generous with the amount of sausages in there, which i really liked...and the spicy taste is just right. the portion is great too, would definitely go back for more!

Came here during lunch with some coworkers... wasn't too crowded, cute place, and very festive.  However, the dish I ordered was not good - The Mardi Gras Jambalaya.  Didn't like the sweet greens, way too much beans, and a small portion of the jambalaya. I couldn't eat it & had to send it back. I gave them 3 stars since the waitress did take it off the bill and had a taste of my coworker's dish, which was pretty good - Grilled shrimp and braised beef over grits.I would give this place a try again, but definitely not the Mardi Gras Jambalaya.

As someone who lived in Louisiana for 6 years, in southern states for a total of 12 years, this was the most disappointing Cajun/Creole cuisine experience outside of "The Boot". The cornbread was incredibly dry, the gumbo unbelievably generic, and the crab cakes I had I gave the leftovers to a homeless guy on Wabash. Unfortunately, Pappadeaux's is far more flavorful than this.

Great food, awesome atmosphere! My sister-in-law brought me here, we were all craving for some good southern food, and I am so glad she brought us here!Pros (+):- Atmosphere is great, a total hole in the wall. You ride the elevator up to the 7th floor, and then as soon as you walk in, you're bombarded with cool decor. The walls are lined with Hot Sauce bottles, many I have never seen, or heard of before.- The crab cakes are to die for. I haven't had a good crab cake in awhile. I live in Seattle where our seafood is fresh. I can't fathom how amazing these were.- The Gumbo is really awesome. Granted I have never had Gumbo before, but it's a dish I am totally down to eat after having it here!- They bombard you with so much food, I swear it's impossible to finish your entire meal!- Service is fantastic. They will help recommend dishes according to taste & preference of heat.Cons (-):- Space is somewhat tight. Tables are very close together. Granted they're in what looks like a Condo Building. I'm not surprised with the small spaces.Overall I had an awesome experience. The waiter was very friendly and the guy who checked the table out was amazing. If I lived in the area, this would definitely be a staple.

I had the Surf & Turf (Fried Shrimp and New Orleans Debris) with gumbo. This was superb, creamy and meaty. It was a big portion, so I packed half to go and had it for dinner.They also have dessert, and I'm tempted to pop in again just for that.Also, if you're a fan of hot sauces, there are probably a dozen on the table (to add to food) and probably several thousand on the walls for display.

Found this gem thanks to a few coworkers of mine who recommended it for lunch one day. I'm not a Cajun man, but I can easily say that the gumbo they serve is by far the best I've ever had. We also got a round of cornbread, each of which was roughly the size of a softball and I ordered the shrimp po'boy as my main, which was crispy, delicious, and perfectly fried.I really appreciate the selection of unusual hot sauces, which were fun to try in turn. My only gripe is that (at lest when we went) Heaven is cash only, which seemed a little inconvenient in spite of the fact that they have an ATM inside. That said, bring your debit card, or your favorite gallery of presidents and this hidden utopia is a must try

Had the oyster poboy with a cup of gumbo and a good size serving of coleslaw.  Loved it!!  All the servings were generous portions and deeeeeh....Lish!!  Service was great...water glass stayed full.  Definitely a place I recommend and will go back to
Enjoyed the Best Cajun Food; Shrimp,  Chicken,  Crawfish Etouffee with Catfish, red beans & rice at Heaven on Seven in Chicago!  We will be back!

Ate lunch in Heaven the other day.  Hmmmm good.The Gumbo was to die for, will be back for more.The Jambalaya was fantastic too.  The food was very filling and provided me with enough energy to last the rest of the day.When I die, I know I'm going to Heaven. I'm going for the GUMBO !!!

This is a happy little place in the Loop for lunch. Hidden on the seventh floor of 220 Wabash, this feels like it transports you to New Orleans, so it is a great little escape from the work day. The food is great, but the ambiance is the selling point. The walls are lined with hot sauce bottles and Louisiana posters. They always have Mardi Gras streamers hanging from the roof, regardless of the time of year.CASH ONLY. There is an ATM in the restaurant, but it is not bank affiliated and charges a $3 fee.The food is tasty and the portions generous.  I got an oyster po-boy ($12.99), which comes with an option of a side salad, soup, or red beans and rice. I chose the soup option, which had the flavor profile of red beans and rice. You could taste the seafood stock, which had a great flavor. It was thickened with some flour, so the soup had the consistency of gravy. Thick, but tasty.The oyster po-boy came on the traditional hoagie with a tomato and iceberg lettuce. The oysters were well prepared- crisp cornmeal crust, but not overcooked to lose that delicate oyster flavor. It comes with a side of slaw and a side of the honey jalapeno dressing. I wished that they had made a strong remoulade available instead of the side of dressing.My escape from work!

Great Cajun style cuisine!  The shrimp and grits were the best I've had since Hyman's Seafood in Charleston, SC.  The gumbo was very good too, and I believe it comes with every meal.   Get it with a jalapeño cheddar cornbread muffin... it's a great combination.  Huge hot sauce collection.Prices are fantastic too... it's a great value, especially for downtown Chicago.  Cash only though... know that going into it.

This place saved the day!  After 2 misses for breakfast we came in here at 10 to 11 and they happily served us a wonderful breakfast with great service!  Thank you so much!  Great breakfast and what a fun find to find a southern Nola theme restaurant in Chicago!

I have been to Heaven on Seven before, but up until last week I hadn't been to this particular location. I've been missing out- I prefer this one to the Rush location. It's a nostalgic place for us, since we had our first date there some four years ago.It's located on the seventh floor (see what they did there?) of the Garland Building, so it's easy to miss. It's much quieter than it's Rush counterpart, which I really found relieving. The decor is cute, with Mardi Gras themed chandeliers and wall hangings, as well as a wall of different hot sauce bottles.My girlfriend and I came here for the tail end of lunch, and it was nice because we were one of maybe three or four tables. The service was really quick and our waiter was really nice and helpful. My girlfriend ordered Southern Fried Catfish, which came with a bowl of their famous gumbo. It also came with red beans and rice and Cajun coleslaw. I think it hovered somewhere around $14. The fish was well seasoned, and was cooked perfectly. The spice didn't overpower the fish, which was great. The red beans and rice had just the right amount of kick. I ordered the Louisiana Soft Shell Crab Po' Boy Sandwich which came with Cajun coleslaw and gumbo as well ($13.95). This sandwich was amazing. The outside of the crab was perfectly crisp, while still being soft enough to eat without problems (a reoccurring issue I have when getting soft shells). The meat inside was tender and delicious. It was also the first time my girlfriend had ever tried it, and it was kind of funny watching her try and eat a claw, shell and all.Chef Bannos was there when we ate, and he was super friendly. He came out and made sure that our food was good, and made conversation with us to make sure we were taken care of. If that isn't good hospitality, I don't know what is.The staffs' shirts all say the same thing: "People who come back from Heaven all say the same thing...try the gumbo!" And they say that with damn good reason. This place is on point, and makes me miss when I got to stay in Louisiana. The gumbo is a must!
This was an amazing find! When I was a kid I had some gumbo in Houston that I still dream about some 30 years later. The gumbo was almost as good as the stuff of my dreams.

Ok so I love Cajun food and especially fried catfish. This place cannot provide either of the two. The food is just gross. My fish wasn't seasoned, my greens were sweet because they add brown sugar to them, and my red beans and rice were bland and extremely pasty. One of the worse Cajun meals I have ever had.The staff is very nice, they took my meal off of the bill. But they need to travel to New Orleans to taste real southern food because this IS NOT it.Don't even get me started on the decor or the fact that they didn't have heat! I guess all the hot sauce is suppose to keep you warm! Never again!

Non Touristy off the beaten path  Hidden almost in the Garland Bldg (which has an old time chicago feel) I'm from the south and this was some of the best southern food I've ever had, was referred by a friend and was not disappointed!   The gumbo was amazing and all of us LOVED our meals.  I'm getting hungry thinking about it.

I ate breakfast here for years while working in liop. Hands down, bare none my absolute favorite breakfast spot in entire UNIVERSE!Jimmy Banos, a legendary chef and his brother George run this long time family establishment and it is outstanding. The trendy Purple pig is owned and operated Jimmy's son and tou can certainly see where he was influenced.Get yourself a texas chili cheese omelette, a jalapeño corn muffin and a cup of their super star gumbo. Its a lot of food but its going blow tour taste bud's mind. I am telling you, you will not be disappointed here my friends.If i ever given q choice of a last meal on earth - i am gettin my Heaven on 7 ON!!!!

One of the only Cajun places I've encountered since I've moved to Chicago so I had to check it out.  Went with some work friends for lunch and it was quite the experience.  The space is very cozy and decorated for Mardi Gras.  We actually went the week prior to Mardi Gras, but I assume the decor is like that year round.  Two of the walls are adorned with different hot sauces from all over, literally HUNDREDS of small bottles.  Very charming and definitely brought the NOLA atmosphere to Chicago.We all started off with the gumbo and it received universal praise in our party.  I got the Oyster Po Boy and it was very good.  A bit too much breading on the fried oysters, but they were still tender and not rubbery at all.  Others in my party enjoyed the Voodoo Chicken which seemed to be a hit.  Our waiter was very friendly and made sure we were taken care of.Overall, decent food - not nearly as good as the Cajun places I've been to in Houston and New Orleans.  Price seemed a bit steep.  For the Po Boy, gumbo, and just tap water, it came out to about $20.  Also this place does NOT take credit cards, but they do have an ATM inside, so come prepared!  Not sure I'd be back unless I had a serious craving for Cajun.
The most authentic Cajun in Chicago.  Great friendly staff and they are quick if you are in a lunch rush.  Jimmy Bannos is the man.  Cash only.

The gumbo was really good. I also got the oyster poboy sandwich. It came with a honey jalepeno sauce which was very good. The cole slaw had a tint of brown. I am not sure if that was the color of whatever they used to dress it, or it was because the cabbage was a little old? Regardless, it was so good I ate it all anyways. If the cabbage was old and I get diarrhea it was still worth it, but I am assuming it was just the color of the dressing in the cole slaw. I would go there again. very very good food.

Heaven on Seven is a must try if you have any connections or liking for New Orleans.This quaint restaurant is located on the seventh floor of the Garland office building.  Just north of Washington on the east side of Wabash.  You will enter the lobby area and someone will direct you to the elevator.Like other reviewers have noted.  This is cash only and only open for breakfast and lunch/late lunch.The menu is straight from New Orleans with gumbo, jambalaya, po boys, you name it they have it.  I had the gumbo as my soup for my seafood jambalaya meal.  The serving size is ample and you may be able to skip dinner after having this lunch.You will be surrounded by everything New Orleans, mardi gras beads, French quarter photos, jazz music, it is awesome.  Hot sauce bottles line many of the walls here.  They actually have a warning on them telling you not to touch them.  Apparently they are so hot and old that they may explode.  Don't worry, they offer 15-20 other hot sauce options on each table.  These don't look much safer but you do get the regular Tobasco and Lousiana's Hot Sauce.When you are finished with your meal you are presented your check and you can leave your tip at the table and pay for your meal at the front register.They have a bar seating area for quick single diners and there were also a few people that came in and ordered items to go.Heaven on Seven is so great that we took a day off just to come try it out.  I am glad we did.  The next time I am here I am going to have to get a hurricane to see if this place is truly New Orleans.  I will just have to remember that I can't walk out with it down State street like I would on Bourbon.

Seriously so good. Better than expected. I'm not a gumbo fan, but got a cup anyway and...wow. I should have just gotten a bowl with the jalapeño cornbread on the side, and I would have been super happy. I also ordered the red beans and rice and it was spot on. Others in my party got the BBQ shrimp poboy and fried shrimp poboy. The BBQ one was better. I'll definitely be back!

My wife and I met family here for lunch. It is a unique atmosphere. It felt good to be there. Fun!  They had breakfast - eggs and bacon. We had lunch - gumbo and corn bread.  The gumbo was amazing!  Corn bread - awesome! (I may have eaten too much though...)We sat by the window and conversation was easy. Good table space and not too loud.It is cash only though :(

I love coming to Heaven on Seven on Wabash, once again our waiter Guido was unbelievably masterful in describing the menu, in fact today he convinced 3 out of the 4 of us to choose a different entree, i of course stuck with my favorite "Angry Pasta" but i think im going to change to something different on my next visit, if you decide to go to Heaven on Seven  be sure to sit in Guido section, so you to can enjoy the mouth watering descriptions of the specials you will not be disappointed.

What a unique place!  Funky interior. Super-friendly staff.  Made us feel welcomed immediately.  Could tell some patrons were regulars, always a good sign.Had the gumbo, jalapeño cornbread, fried shrimp, and Louisiana crab cakes.  Tons of food for the price, plenty to share. Love the assortment of hot sauces.Took home a piece of the chocolate bourbon pecan pie. Too stuffed to try it now.  Guessing that it will taste like 'happy'.(sorry for the Arrested Development line)

Best Cajun spot in Chicago.  I used to go to the Michigan Ave location, but could never get to the Wabash spot due to my schedule.  So I finally returned and was reunited with my favorite gumbo.  The title, "best gumbo outside of New Orleans", does not seem like an exaggeration.  I strongly suggest you try it.
Awesome food! Had the New Orleans BBQ shrimp po'boy. Service was quick and friendly. Will be coming back soon.

I was so bummed when the location on Rush closed recently, and I was sad 7-ish years ago when the location at Clark/Cornelia closed (yes, there was one there, and it was delightfully close to home!). But then someone saved the day & told me this was in the Garland Building right by my office!? How did I never know this?A great lunch option in the Loop... even though it is a "sit-down" type of place, they get you in and out in no time. There is time for this people, I promise.Get the shrimp & cheese grits. Thank me later.Cash only.

I wouldn't have known it was here unless my friend showed me it, it's located on the 7th floor of a building, but it's a pretty cool place with lotsa cool cajun seafood options, I got the fried oyster salad with a side of shrimp and corn chowder, both were really good, my friends got the catfish po boy which also looked good, a little pricy but you definitely get your moneys worth in terms of portion size, and they have a good beer selection too, with a lot from abita which is brewed in New Orleans, I'd definitely return here

You could call this a Chicago staple by now.  It's been here so many years.  7th floor of Garland Building.  Great Po' boys.  Pretty good gumbo-not as good as you'll find in NOLA, but for Chicago it's good.  Very good cornbread.  The fried green tomatoes are great too.  Bring cash, they don't take credit.

Definitely one of my favorite spots to grab a bite. If you can't decide what to get, just grab a bowl of the gumbo, and you'll be more than happy. Po' boys are great and come with a honey mustard-y sauce, but if they were served on fresh-baked bread, it would take this to another level. I never eat cole slaw, but the way they do it here is tasty.The only reason this doesn't get five stars: They have a smaller lunch menu than the Naperville location which has some great entrees (and brunch options). Also, the cash-only (no checks, either, people) thing is a bit of a bummer, but there are ample ATMs in every direction of the building.Stop by for lunch, and you won't regret it.

Hidden Jem. The food is really good. The menu is broad and some of the items are a bit more blend (e.g. burger). But this is a southern place and you go here for the jambalaya, gumbo, grits, etc. And these are all fantastic. I highly recommend the gumbo. Best in town. Specials are always good.

Am I the only one tasting the gumbo? It is not spicy at all and quite flavorless. The only thing saving it is the various hot sauces scattered around the restaurant. The roll that came with the gumbo was not fresh, and even though it was clearly store bought it was quite old and hard. The cole slaw that came with my crab cakes was absolutely repulsive, and the crab cakes themselves were decent, but nothing special. I came here expecting much more flavor, and the food is truthfully kind of bland. The crab cakes did not taste fresh, canned crab was clearly used and the breading was not cohesive, but very granular. The tarter sauce is gross.

This is the original location up on the 7th floor.Definitely the best Louisiana Creole cuisine in Chicago.   Huge selection of hot sauces to choose from.This location is only open for breakfast and lunch.CASH ONLY!

I'd been wanting to try Heaven on Seven for quite some time and finally got the opportunity this weekend. I was not disappointed.Our server Ashley was incredibly helpful in explaining the menu. She was also friendly and gave amazing service. I would return based off of her amazing service alone.H on 7 have a regular menu and also the specials menu which included gumbo, jambalaya & étouffée. Although tempted by all of these options, I went with the southern fried chicken breast. Id been wanting fried chicken all week so it was an easy choice. The meal came with a delicious black bean soup, a side of steamed carrots and mashed potatoes and a side of gravy. Although not spice, there were several hot sauce and spice blend choices on the table. I chose a spice blend for my fried chicken and it paired very nicely. I wish I could remember the name but it's kind of fun to try several anyway. The food was fresh and came out very quickly. Solid 5 stars here.

Been here twice for lunch and absolutely love every bit of it.Best Cajun/Creole/Southern I've had in Chicago.Food we had:Gumbo (possibly best in the world!)Corn BreadOyster Po-boyShrimp Po-boyShrimp & GritsBit of everything from the Bayou (Red beans/black beans/collard greens/etouffee)Ice box lime (for dessert)Everything, absolutely everything was spot on delicious. My Southern friend commented that the gumbo and ice box lime tasted like how her Grandmother would make it. My personal favorite was the collard greens. I had the best greens at "Loveless" cafe near Nashville but this one beats it hands down & is now my number 1. The male wait staff was such a lovely delight.He explained everything on the menu impeccably and even recommended for us to try the shrimp with the house special angel dust.Not to mention, this is "Hot Sauce" haven. Hot sauce of a gazillion kinds everywhere, on the tables on the walls. If you're a hot sauce lover, you just have to come see for yourself.The decor sets you way down south in New Orleans, like it's mardi gras every day!It's a pity they don't open for dinner Mon to Wed and I will be returning over and over again.A must try for Southern food lovers! Even if you're not, you would be a convert.

I'm astounded that there are negative reviews for Heaven on Seven; just recently my friends and I paid our first visit and not only did we leave fully sated, but just plain happy all around. Had a great experience here.The decor and ambiance alone were hits for me, as was our server - wish I could remember her name - but she had a fantastic personally, was fun to be around, and took awesome care of us. We're kind of a rough and tumble bunch, and after the gatekeeper in the lobby sized us up and granted us entry, we were treated like royalty. It was as if we were the only diners there for dinner that night.Beverage-wise, my iced tea was phenomenal. "Well Sol, you can get an iced tea anywhere, right?" Not so. Not like this. Mine came with a lemon wedge that may as well have been the size of my fist. As a confirmed citrusophile, this scored some major points with me. We all noshed on some fried jalapeno cheddar cornbread for our starter, and that pepper gave me a kick in the seat. (That's a plus here)Ignore the haters spewing venom over the Jambalaya, as it was amazing. Fresh ingredients, flavor galore, touch down! Gumbo was also outta this world, they didn't skimp on the Andouille. I also sampled my bud's red beans and rice, which were very pleasing on the ol' palate.Long story short, I love Heaven on Seven, and definitely will be back. Props too for the old school cash register, I was mesmerized by the thing.

One of my favorite places to eat, great service with recommendations on how to make your food hotter or sweeter.The gumbo is crazy good. Try an assortment of poboys and it'll make your lunch fun.No credit cards so bring your cash.

Nobody does chicken and waffles better! We've tried to find better in other places,but Heaven on Seven's take on this southern delight is unbelievable. The chicken is Rice Krispie coated with a hint of bacon and spice and the syrup is mixed with honey. Add any of 20 hot sauces on the table (or ask for some of their too hot handle sauces from the kitchen) and it's a firery sweet ecstasy. Gumbo also very good. Andouille sausage as an appetizer had great flavor, heat, grill, salty, sweet. We have made this a regular stop when we visit Chicago. Now only the original location, which is a little hard to find on the 7th floor of an office building (thus heaven on 7). This last visit the waitstaff was great, but, full disclosure, wasn't busy at all on a Thursday night. Enjoy!P.S.  9/17/16 - SO disappointed. While the gumbo is still the best, they've nixed the chicken and waffles! Go to the Naperville location, strangely, they still have the full menu there (though not the original location)
First time here. Great hole in the wall. Great cajun food. An outrageous selection if hot saces. Great place

Delicious!!!Lots of spices here. The place is pretty fun - I love the set up here. It's cash only so make sure to hit the ATM en route.The food is amazing. I've come here early in the day and splurged thoroughly. The service is nice and quick. I only came here early in the day so tough to judge whether it can be packed or not.Great Cajun food.Recommended.

Love Heaven on Seven! If you want to try a real authentic creole cuisine, look no further! I came here for lunch and took advantage of their lunch special which included a drink, entree, soup/salad and dessert. I ordered the entoufee of the day and man, was it delicious!! And the gumbo is also a must try!Everything from the food and decor makes it a overall fun experience. They also have a wide variety of fun drink options. I would definitely recommend this place and can't wait to come back!

Great daily specials that take me back to a childhood in New Orleans that I never had. The gumbo that comes with the meal is top notch, and the shrimp and cheesy grits was pretty good, although the shrimp was a little dry. Service and atmosphere are top notch, and it's a nice little escape smack dab in the loop.

Best place ever!! We have been visiting chi. for years and every time we come we hav enjoyed hea. on 7!!! We love the ox tail gravy over scallops, but found out this year that they are only served at certain times. So we decided to try the fried oytsers and crab cakes.  They were sooooooo sooooooo delicious!! A must try")

Started the meal with some jambalaya which was really great. Have yet to have some real authentic creole cuisine but I could easily say this was the best I have had. The next was the main course with fried chicken po boy. This was a very sizable sandwich with a side of their home style sauce (jalapeño honey mustard). The chicken was still very moist and the spices on the chicken were not overwhelming at all, very light a flaky. The meal came with a side of coleslaw which is not my favorite dish so I passed. A side that I ordered was jalapeño cheddar cornbread. This was very good and perfect side for the dish. The only problem with the meal was that the rolls (which were complimentary) were very hard. I could still eat it but it did need to be ripped. This was not a huge problem compared to how the meal and service was. The service was very good. The waitress was attentive and very nice.The atmosphere is very relaxed and fun. The walls have hot sauce bottles all over them and they have more than enough hot sauces at the restaurant to use for the meal.One side note, I loved their home style jalapeño honey mustard sauce. The bottles can be purchased and I ended up getting one for salads and as a dipping sauce at home.

This is simply a wonderful restaurant to go tom if you can find it. They have fantastic Cajun food, dozens of different kinds of hot sauce, and the servers are usually pretty on the ball. I go here for lunch fairly often, and I definitely would recommend the gumbo. The only bad thing is that they are cash only.

I should have taken Heaven on Seven's three star Yelp rating to heart.  On a day in Chicago when I had unlimited time and resources, I came here.  And was very underwhelmed.To be fair, the gumbo WAS awesome.  But the jambalaya wasn't anything to write home about.  And neither were the crab cakes.  Total three-star material.The best thing about Heaven on Seven is the incredible atmosphere they have created.  The restaurant is in a cool spot in an older building and is perfectly decorated. If only the food had been good!

So, maybe I'm biased because I work right down the hall, but this place has simply the best gumbo, jalapeno cornbread and pecan pie that I've ever had.  It's so good, in fact, that it's all I ever order.You know how you have a dish that's so tasty that you just can't order anything else?  Yeah, that's where I am with this place.  I'm sure that everything else is just as good, I've just got to get around to ordering something else.Good job, guys.

9 hours later I still feel absolutely ill.  What is debris, the most disgusting thing on the menu and it could only be described as fart meat.  The meat was gray and mushy not authentic Cajun and def not my Nola experience, where's the spice in my meal? The food was plain and the hundreds of 'ass obsessed' hot sauces isn't going to make it any better.  Please be warned do not get the 'Boo Boo' fries, no matter how much cheese is smothered into the fart meat as the saying goes you can't polish a turd!

I'm always down for some good ol' Nawlins food!!!MANY people have no idea this location is even here as it's upstairs in another building near jewelers row (on Wabash).  And guess what??? It's on the SEVENTH floor!!!I've been to the Naperville location too, but never to the other location but I do frequent this one the most during lunch time.They have a decent menu, however a good lunch for me is a cup or bowl of gumbo paired with a corn muffin.  The atmosphere is PURE New Orleans and there is a variety of hot sauces on every table so if you are looking to spice up your food, you will not be disappointed.Keep in mind... CASH ONLY at this establishment and they get crazy busy on Fat Tuesday so come prepared.  Other than that...good food, good service, and you'll feel like you're down south till you walk back out on Wabash!

Was recommended by someone at our hotel. Had a wonderful breakfast and a good cup of chicory coffee. The New Orleans atmosphere was just like home. I was glad we went there while on our vacation to Chicago.

This was my first visit and my last visit to Heaven on Seven. I went with 3 of my friends, and they were short staffed and extremely busy, they told us this but we chose to stay and just order the food to go. Although we knew that they were short staffed and busy, I did not expect us to be IGNORED! we sat near the kitchen and waited for 15 minutes to even be given menus. Then after asking a question about an item, the waitress left to get the information and never returned. We left with our to go food after waiting over 1.5 hours. When we got home, we realized that they forgot items from our take out. We called to notify them and the staff member who answered the phone was rude. Denied that we were charged extra for items we added and was not helpful. She then asked if we had a receipt, which we weren't given. All in all, the food was okay but the service was HORRIBLE! I can understand busy days, I  don't accept inattentive, rude, and dismissive wait staff.
What a find..great breakfast and excellent service...hidden gem on the 7th floor of a downtown office building

I have been coming here for years and today will be my last time.  I keep forgetting every time I come the food is not so good.  I had the fish poboy and it was absolutely disgusting.  It had no flavor whatsoever and was mushy on the inside.  The sauce they give you is delicious. Not sure why people rave so much about the gumbo, it is by far not gumbo.  I will not be back.  I would much rather go to popeyes and get a chicken poboy, instead of coming back here and paying  $13 for lunch that I have to throw away.  If you want a good piece of cornbread with jalepenos, this is your place.  Bland ass food!

This is the original location, and it gets it's name because it's hidden away on the 7th floor.Definitely the best Louisiana Creole cuisine in Chicago so if you've got a hankering for that this is your place. A line up of hot sauces await you on the  but make sure you have cash since this is a CASH ONLY establishment.I've only ever been here for lunches with some people from work, normally once a month. It's good food and everyone else loves it so maybe I just haven't found my item on the menu yet. I typically love seafood so I'm sure I'm bound to find something I like.The Shrimp and Corn Chowder is very good even though most people order the famous gumbo to go with their meal. If you're looking for something different I highly recommend it.

This is a fabulous little gem hidden in downtown Chicago! My fiancé and I recently returned from a trip to New Orleans and were starting to miss the big easy. We headed to this place based on reviews and we are so glad we did. It was like we never left New Orleans! They atmosphere was friendly and the food was amazing. The gumbo here was better than the gumbo I bought at Mr B's in the French Quarter! We ordered the shrimp and soft carb po'boys and we ate every last bite.They also carry Louisiana beer which is a plus in our book :)

Cute little place on the 7th floor.Cash only here!I got shrimp & grits. I was disappointed at its lack of flavor (well, salty was the only flavor).My fiancé got a fried fish po boy and he LOVED it!We both got the gumbo and this is fabulous! very heavy and hearty.Portions are great, there are a million different hot sauce bottles on the table for you to choose from.

I was recommended to this restaurant by a friend who has been here for lunch before. I ordered the special New Orleans platter, salad, iced tea, bourbon pecan dessert. She ordered chicken po'boys, gumbo, sprite, and key lime pie dessert.BAD-We went for dinner at 5:30 pm on a Saturday and I must say the seating is limited for small parties.-The waiter brought out cold, hard biscuits that had obviously been sitting out for awhile. We had to ask for fresh, hot rolls.-The waiter put his arm over my food/reached over my food to get a menu. He could have asked and I would have handed it to him.-The waiter scrapped a dirty plate that had a crumb on it with his fingernail.OK-My main course was ok...two different rices and beans, and andouille sausage. The iced tea was gross I asked for it sweet and the waiter brought me a sugar bowl. WTH. Her gumbo was pretty good but it tasted of rice and gravy...no meat. She really like her food though. We both loved our deserts.GOOD-The atmosphere and decor were great!FINAL-I would never go back. The staff was pleasant but didn't have proper etiquette skills. Overall, the food wasn't worth it.

Ordered Shrimp Voodoo & Chicken Voodoo for delivery. Neither dish had any veggies. Was just protein & carbs. And the sauce was not Voodoo. Was some bland wet crap. This was our favourite dish at the 600 North location. Waste of $40. Oh & the Gumbo was very bland until lots of hot sauce was dumped in. I'm full as there was a good amount of proteins but not satisfied at all. Boo!!!

As a tourist, this is great! It's casual, delicious, somewhat of a throwback, and - you should come up to the seventh floor of this office building for lunch while you're here!It's a lot of fun to play with the twenty or thirty different bottled sauces here, but the easy thing to note is that the dishes are delicious as-is, and you will enjoy your meal here.The service, by the way, is warm, personable, and professional. Don't be shy about asking for sightseeing suggestions!
I get the same thing every time - start with a cup of gumbo and then a Cajun fried chicken sandwich - crispy and tender and juicy.

I was treated to heaven on seven today for lunch by a coworker. I had the softshell crab Po'  boy. This was my first experience with softshell crab. The crab was tasty and boasted a crunchy crust and soft, tender,  buttery crab on the inside. Yum! But the sandwich as a whole suffered due to the cheap-ass, preservative-laced French roll on which it was made.  By preservative-laced, I mean it's one of those mass produced rolls that comes in a six-pack bag and can sit on the shelf for a couple days without going stale. It's not good French bread and it made this otherwise good sandwich suffer!The gumbo was an amazing bowl of chunky, thick creamy goodness! It was full of tender meat, and offered a deep complexity of flavor from what I can only assume was a well-toasted roux. I could eat/slurp this stuff every day. Except its super rich, so I'll save it for special occasions.Looking forward to my next bowl of Heaven on Seven gumbo!
We LOVE this place!  We went for lunch late on Saturday, not packed - food was great!  Get there if you can!!

Perfect setting for what I think is the first restaurant for Jimmy Bannos.  It's located on the 7th floor of a very old and narrow office building.  I can just picture men in suits with narrow ties scurrying to the elevators in the 1940's and 50's.CASH ONLY!  I don't know why this is the case and but I am almost postive the other outlets of this restaurant do accept credit cards.  There is an ATM in the lobby but still this is not a hot dog stand a party of 4-6 can easily rack up a bill that costs more than most of us carry in cash.  With that said, I still really, really like this place.Great music playing, interesting New Orleans artwork all over the place and a gadzillion bottles of different hot sauces on every table.  The menu is short and to the point.  Jambalaya, poor boys, gumbo, beans and rice...you get the picture.  All entrees come with a choice of soup (good and hot and flavorful) or a basic dinner salad.  The desserts looked amazing but all of us were too full to try.They have counter seating for about 8 people.  The counter service adds to the charm of the place.  Servers are attentive, funny and food comes out quick.This is a nice, fun alternative for lunch compared to most other offerings in the Loop.  I recommend it.

This place is perfect and I hope they never change. Love the gumbo, jambalaya, corn bread, poor boy sandwiches, and chocolate pecan bourbon pie. This place serves up nothing less than satisfying comfort food. Service is good and the prices are actually on the cheap side. Without a doubt they make the best gumbo in the Chicago land area. When I crave Louisiana food this is my go to place.
Delicious little gem. Sat immediate. Friendly staff. Corn muffins w jalapeño and cheddar - yum. Exactly what advertised.

Absolutely great spot to get some cajun eats in the Windy City! Their soft shell crab and oyster po'boys are some of the best I've had in the city, along with their gumbo. They also have some of the friendliest staff around, it made me feel like being right back in Nawlins!

Best New Orleans style food in Chicago, in my opinion. Good gumbo and jamabalaya. They have a huge array of hot sauces ranging from traditional to ghost pepper and everything in between. This is a cash only place, so stop by the ATM. They serve brunch and lunch.

For vegetarians this place is accommodating, i got a veggie pasta! It was bland but atleast they were nice enough to try! My husband had the chicken waffles and thought they were really good! The waffle was amazing! Even I had a bite and prob the best waffle Ive ever had! Cute decor with the new orleans theme! Would come back again!

It didn't help that the server was so slapdash that he dumped one of two crab cakes on  me then on the floor.No. He didn't comp me anything. He only replaced my crab cake. They were okay. Not freshly made. Just okay.No refills on drinks. No would you like... No nothing.

Heaven on Seven is a fun place! It has a southern Louisiana feel with southern music and a fun, mardi gras feel. I love a restaurant with a theme! The wall with a million billion hot sauces is very cool. I've gone to the AMC theater here many times and have never ventured inside Heaven on Seven so was very happy when I got the chance.I tried their jambalaya with soup yesterday. The jambalaya was so spicy for me, it definitely did not require any additional spicy sauce. It had chunks of spicy sausage and tasty meat in it. I'm not too sure what the soup was but it was just delicious!The menu here has so much to offer and we don't have a ton of Southern cooking places in the city. I don't know how I've missed ever going here and will definitely be back when I go to the AMC theater. It won't be a destination spot though as what I did try did not completely blow me away.5/13/12 Update:I went here again after a movie and I'm going to say the 3 Star Rating stands. The hostess ignored us and then was not friendly at all when she finally did seat us. Our waiter was fine during our meal but considering there were about 6 tables sat in the whole restaurant, service was shotty and slow. The food here is too expensive for what it is although portions are HUGE! I got the Fried Chicken Steak meal for $16.95. It came with a salad that had the most amazing dressing on it! The meal also came with veggies and mashed potatoes. All in all a good meal but I wasn't blown away and the service was not great at all. I won't be dining here again unless I absolutely have to because I'm watching a movie upstairs.

So the gato told me not to be messin around with no Cajun/Creole food dis far north, but I tell ya... That gato was wrong. Dunno what e was tinkin.Fun place. If you like the hot sauces and the dozen or so ways the old shrimp is seasoned and you're in downtown Chicago, then this is the place for you.If you go, you must be rollin fat with a couple Jacksons. Cad hola only as they don't play with plastic and if you can't pay, you'll be washing big gumbo pots for two days.Yes it's a tall business building.Yes you're in the right place.Just push 7 and go to heaven.
One of the best lunch spots in the loop. Excellent food.

This place was horrible. First we had to drive around to find parking. Then the food was bland we had the jambalaya with gumbo. I've never had jambalaya and the rice was white. They do not take credit which is an inconvenience, but they made sure to have a ATM inside so that you can use....smh. I do not recommend this restaurant. FYI Yelp wouldn't let me post without give a star .

I am very surprised that this place uses the word Cajun and has a New Orleans vibe to it.  I ordered the Cajun shrimp Omelet and it was so bland.  I added almost everything on the table to give it life.  It flat lined upon arrival to the table.  I actually order some red beans and rice thinking I could pour that over it to give it some sense of Cajun I had no such luck.  I asked the waiter what made it Cajun and he said the Cajun sauce on it lol.  The sauce could have went for a cooked pico de GAO.  He sacheted  right on back over to the counter where he just looked bored.  Then I ordered a jalapeño  corn bread and that is what I ended up enjoying.  Maybe I just didn't order the right thing and because I was alone I don't have a party of people to actually judge the restaurant over all but I'm positive the Cajun shrimp omelet never met any sauce, salt pepper or nobody in heaven.

I called in an order for our company team lunch at 10am and told them I needed it ready by 11:45am. I got there at 11:45 and found out they hadn't even started making it yet as they had lost the hand written ticket my order was on. Didn't get my order until 12:30 along with another gentleman who had to wait over a half hour for his order as well. All they would say was "Be patient with us". Also, this place ONLY takes cash...who in 2016 only takes cash?.  Also needed a receipt to expense this (that they didn't provide originally). I called back a day later to a rude person on the phone who said "don't bother coming in today for the receipt, it's Mardi Gras". They've been in business 35 years and still have a cash register that looks like it is over 50 years old. Come into the 21st century and stop using Mardi Gras (the day before) as an excuse for bad service! I will NOT be going back no matter how good the food was.

I stopped in here on a layover in Chicago, on a  friend's recommendation.  She grew up in Chicago and absolutely loves this place.She recommended that I try the gumbo and the jalapeno cheddar corn muffin.  And that was great advice.  The gumbo was just perfect, the best that I've ever had.  And that was a great muffin.  And they went well together.  The crab cakes that i ordered were superfluous.I'm sure there are lot of good entrrees here.  But if I ever go back, I'll be macking on the gumbo again.
Food was actually pretty good and so were the hurricanes
Not what they used to be.  Food was bland.  Gumbo still great if you prefer chicken and sausage over seafood. I remember why I don't go back often.  Disappointing.

picked up red beans and rice to go the other day and not only did it contain a whopping ONE tiny round of sausage but it was pretty blandnow...i like my food with some kick, but id expect cajun/creole to already come that way

I was so looking forward to having shrimp and grits.  But ended up having deep fried shrimp and what seemed like instant grits.  Did not care for the texture -- grainy not creamy.  Just really not good and very disappointing.  Hubby got fried shrimp, which was the same shrimp as on the grits.  "Popcorn shrimp" was an ok size for the grits but was definitely expecting bigger shrimp for a dinner.  On a good note, gumbo was excellent and cornbread so good!  Looking at all the hot sauces was fun.

Since my mother and I were downtown, she insisted that we go to one of her favorite restaurants. The decor made me feel like I was dining in New Orleans. I ordered the Angry burger which came with fries and a cup of gumbo. The gumbo was really tasty and the fries were DELICIOUS probably in the top 5 fries I've ever had. The burger itself wasn't as spectacular. The meat was alright, and the spicy sauce added something extra but the bun was pretty dry and fell apart. I would come back again though for those fries!

My friends like this place.  I wasn't so thrilled.  I had the chicken fried steak.  While the gravy and mash potatoes were good, the chicken fried steak was overcooked and dry.  The breading was really salty as well.I was hoping for a broader menu.  I won't be heading back anytime soon.

Yum ... Yum ... YumMy favorite restaurant in the city of Chicago!  On the 7th floor of the Garland Building ... hence the name.  Today, my selection was shrimp and corn chowder soup, a soft-shell crab po' boy and to add to the delicious indulgence ... a slice of bourbon chocolate pecan pie.The wait staff couldn't be nicer ;)
SOOOO GOOD! Simple Southern comfort food. The fried chicken breast is my favorite with a side of peach pie :).

Living in Chicago I always found it difficult to find a truly amazing dining experience. Nando is it, though!My friend and I walked in on a whim on a Wednesday night. The restaurant was small with ambient lighting and close tables. The first thing I heard were people cheering their drinks in Italian (Salut!) I was a little intimidated but then our host appeared. He was an absolute delight! He graciously welcomed us and asked if we spoke Italian. Neither of us do. He smiled and welcomed us again as he ushered us to our table.We ordered fabulous red wine and our host checked in on us to see if we had questions about the menu. We both ordered pasta dishes that were AMAZING! The portions were smaller than a typical Italian restaurant but I ate everything on my plate and felt pleasantly full.It was on the menu but the host also mentioned that they make all their pasta fresh in the restaurant. I'm definitely getting the Gnocchi next time because there is nothing better than freshly made Gnocchi!We were asked if we wanted dessert which we didn't but the host made us "something a little sweet." It was a limoncello shot! He said they made fresh limon and limecello at the restaurant. It was super sweet and tasty- I love lemon.The whole experience was lovely and made me feel very welcomed. It was like returning home to a big Italian family.

This is a nice little neighborhood trattoria. You can tell that the food, atmosphere and staff is authentic Italiano.One knock on the space is that it is extremely loud. There was a group next to us that made it hard for my party of 3 to hear eachother talking.I order the special seafood pasta. It wasn't the best I've had but it was pretty tasty. If I go again, I'll try something else off the extensive dinner menu.

We tried Nando Milano for this first time this past week and I thought it was good.  Most of the table enjoyed the food, but the service was a little lacking.  For our table of four, we shared the Octopus with pesto sauce and the fried calamari.  Both dishes were good and I would get them again.I had the risotto special which included clams / mussels / calamari / shrimp - and I ate every last forkful of it.  Risotto is a hard dish to make and it takes special care to get the rice just perfect and I think Nando did a good job of that.  My husband was less than impressed with his special Bucatini alla Carbonara as it was too salty for him (and even for me when I tried it).We didn't end up getting dessert that night - mostly because our server never came by to ask us.  We sat with our dinners done for about 15 minutes before we flagged him down...of which he was going to bring us the bill.  It was just confusing how the person who sat us that night became our server and then sort of forgot about us.  That was a little disconcerting.I don't live in the area and rarely venture out to Wicker Park so I'm not sure I would make the effort to return.

This place was amazing and such a great find. The food is prepared fresh and the flavors.....ma'don! Its nothing like you'd find a chain place, which is great. This place is so unique which makes it charming. The staff couldnt have been better. We will be coming back again and working our way through the menu!
If you're ever in Champaign they opened another eatery in downtown here. Pretty much the same menu. Outstanding.
You had me at hand-made pasta! (The Yelp reviews helped too!) From start to finish, the food was delicious! The service was great too. I would definitely come back!

This is as close to Italy as you will get! I have now been 5-6 times and Nando keeps getting better. My family and I call this place a "hidden gem" but not sure if it is hidden anymore. Great date spot on a nice Summer night and right off Division street in a quaint area. The Owners and family consisting of Dario, Chef Alesso and Luka make you immediately feel like their family. Must have dishes: meatballs, Caesar salad, any pasta, halibut special.. All specials will be yummy.Congrats on opening your second restaurant at my old college in Champaign. Cheers!

Excellent service and atmosphere. Sat outside and the kerosene heater was just the right amount to take the chill off. Our waiter recommended wine and entrees...all outstanding. I would definitely recommend the lasagne bolognese.

Loved this place. Food is super delicious.  Extensive menu, lots to choose. Loved the bison carparccio and burrata salad to start. The spaghetti alla pescatora was delicious as was the lamb chops. Donut with Nutella, yum. Dan are server was fantastic. Would definitely recommend.

I honestly can't think of one negative thing to say about this restaurant. It's cozy, with an understated classy decor, fantastic service, and a great wine list. This restaurant has an awesome ambiance, and is perfect for a date night.I had a Mother's Day lunch here, and my mom loved it. We ordered the arancini trio, each featuring a different filling, but they were all equally delicious. I ordered the almond encrusted salmon which was perfectly cooked. My mother ordered a house made pasta with sundried tomatoes which was amazing. I will definitely go back and try some more menu items.

SIMPLY AMAZINGI'm Sicilian & I hate going out for Italian food because it never tastes right. After tonight I must change my mind because this was one of the best Italian dinners I've ever had. The owners were born in Sicily & moved to Milan before finally setting up shop in Chicago. This place is a cozy little gem that will knock your socks off. Save your money for your transatlantic flight to Italy & just drive over here for dinner.A really great friend of mine called & said he would be flying into Chicago & wanted to go out for a great Italian dinner. It took me days to figure out where I should take him. I finally decided to come here because I knew everything was made in house. My buddy had the best meal of his life & he said when he comes back to Chicago we are coming back here for dinner. So thanks to everyone for providing this fantastic dinner for an old friend. You made me look like a Rockstar.When I walked in I was greeted by Jelena who I thought was the hostess but then realized she was also our waitress. This place is small & I think Jelena was taking the orders for every table. She never made us feel like we were waiting for service. She even spent time hanging out at our table & when my buddy said he couldn't see the menu in the darkness... Jelena went & grabbed a flashlight for him to see it. I call that 5 star service. Thanks for making our dinner a memorable experience.There were many specials to choose from. We decided to go with the mussels with saffron, capers & chili flakes to start with as an app. The mussels were incredibly fresh. It also came with two pieces of toasted garlic bread which tasted so good in the saffron sauce. We had to ask for another bag of their house made bread to dip in the sauce. We kept dipping our bread in the sauce until the juice was all gone. When you're Sicilian & something tastes good then you use you're bread to clean your plate & we totally did that.This place makes everything fresh. The bread we were using to dip into the sauce was made in house. In fact, the pasta & the ricotta are all made in house. I must give you some words of advice for Italian food, if the pasta isn't homemade then don't eat there. Anyone can open a bag of dried pasta but not everyone can make a fresh pasta noodle. My pasta was beyond amazing & that is because it was made fresh. I am proud to say that the pasta here is some of the best in the city.I must mention the dipping oil for the bread. I loved how it was presented on the table. The dish had olive oil with red pepper flakes and a few other herbs along with 4 green seeded olives.  The olives were really good and luckily my buddy wasn't into olives which meant I got all four. I was in olive heaven.There was much to choose from on the menu. The apps, first plates, second plates and desserts all looked so good. We started out with a great bottle of red from Sicily. The wine was full bodied with hints of vanilla, chocolate and tobacco. I will tell you I did taste the tobacco but it worked with the sweetness flavor. I wish I remembered the name of the wine because I'd love to order that again.When it came to me ordering the pasta I had a hard time. I was interested in the Rigatoni with house made sausage, peas & a tomato cream sauce. I thought for sure I was going to get that until our waitress told me to order the fresh house made Pappardelle. These noodles are a large, broad, flat pasta noodle, similar to a wide fettuccine. The best part is that all of the pastas are made in house. The Pappardelle came with a Wild Boar Ragu that was simply amazing. This delicious sauce made me want to go home and start making my own version of it. Thanks chef for setting the bar too high even for me to achieve.My buddy who loves lobster ordered the house made ravioli di Aragosta E Granachio. He's an East coast guy, so he knows seafood. He mention his favorite place in Boston for lobster but was quick to recommend this place as his new favorite. Again I was looking like a super hero.As the evening rolled on we met Dario who is one of the owners. We spoke about Sicily and he even knew my Dads town in Sicily was famous for making chocolate.  It was great talking about food & culture. Dario is what every restaurant owner should be. He's the face up front and he keeps all the customers happy. Dario treats everyone like family and that is simply the Italian way.For dessert we did a little table stalking and ordered exactly what our neighbors ordered.  We got the mifreddo al torroncino which is not on the menu but it should be. It had crushed up almonds & hazelnut w/chocolate cake. We also ordered the Torta do Ricotta which is the best cheesecake u will ever have. We had 3 rounds of homemade cello...lemon, orange & rhubarb(Mom's secret), then ended the night on the Espresso Martini.This was a perfect evening of old friends & dinner. The owners, chef & staff served with smiles & I can hardly wait to come back. Thanks!

Love love, fabulous staff, fantastic and fresh food. I have not been to such a culinary experience and such wonderful people in the Midwest. Fresh pasta, wonderful wine. And you must try the doughnuts... yes, I said that, I hate them.... here, they surpassed the tiramisu...(only desert I eat). Make it out before the winter because the patio is perfect!

We recently moved to the neighborhood and were in search in a good, home away from home restaurant. We've been to the other Italian restaurants in the neighborhood and while they were good we were never blown away so we decided to give Nando Milano a try since they are walking distance from my house. We were so impressed with the food and service that we came here for dinner two nights in a row! Between the two nights we tried 3 different appetizers, 5 entrees and 3 desserts! Every dish was more amazing than the last! I highly recommend trying the Polpette alla arrabbiata (meatball appetizer), Polipo e calamari alla siciliana (grilled octopus & calamari), Spaghettoni Di Mare and my absolute favorite the Tagiatelle Con Gameroni (homemade spinach pasta with prawns in a light wine sauce)!

It was Saturday night at about 9 pm and we were starving with no reservations or plan.  After checking yelp, enter Nando Milano. My friend and I were also excited that we were able to score a patio seat on a lovely night.The food was very good. To start, we had share the 3 arancini.  They were delicious and pretty easy to share with 2. The prosciutto or the bolognese were my favorites - both rich and light at the same time. The spinach and marscarpone was good too but the meat ones definitely trumped it. We also ordered a wonderful (and reasonably priced) bottle of montepulciano d'Abbruzzo.  It was nice and big and went well with our meal.The main sources were even better. I had the Ravioli Di Granchio, a crab ravioli with scallops in a lobster cream sauce.  Decadent and very tasty. You could taste that the pasta was fresh and handmade.  My friend ordered the gnocchi with gorgonzola in an aurora sauce (like a blend of tomato and cream). They were light and fluffy. There was a nice balance in the dish and the gorgonzola didn't overpower it. Conversation halted at this point as we devoured the food.Service was great. Our waiter was very knowledgeable about the food and wine. He was attentive but not too pushy.  In true Italian style, no one rushed us out while we were finishing our wine even though it was after closing time. One of the owners sat next to us and was very friendly and approachable.Overall, it was a great experience and I am looking forward to coming back again. It was also pretty reasonably priced given what we ordered (about $55 per person with tip).
I complimented the head waiter's tie, and it was a luv fest from there. Tip top Italian cuisine + atmosphere.

Cozy Italian restaurant.Ambiance: It's a cozy Italian restaurant that is a bit small where tables are pretty close to one another. The decor made it feel like an authentic Italian restaurant. My friend and I came in around 8:30pm on a Saturday night and were able to sit at the bar right away. It's dimmed lighting with candles at the table, while romantic I wouldn't call it ideal for a date night. It was loud and echoed and even sitting at the bar, I had a difficult time hearing my friend. However, I wouldn't make it a reason to deter you from the restaurant. The have an open kitchen as well so that could play into the loudness. With that being said, we didn't reek of food leaving the restaurant either. It terms of dressing code, I would go above casual, but not super formal.Food:HIGHLIGHTSPrice point- main course averaged $20Main course-Ravioli Di Granchio (crab ravioli with scallops and lobster cream sauce) and Tortelloni Di Ricotta in Salsa DI Noci (ravioli with ricotta cheese and spinach in a walnut sauce)Dessert-Semifreddo Al Chioccolat (special that wasn't on the menu)Wine- Pinot Noir and SauvignonDETAILI ordered the the Ravioli Di Granchio (crab ravioli with scallops and lobster cream sauce) and the pinot noir. Portion size was perfect, I was not overly full and finished the whole dish. I didn't taste much crab, but nonetheless still delicious especially the cream sauce. I wouldn't say it's the best crab ravioli I've had, but it was good. They only had one pinot noir, but it wasn't anything special, it was alright and I only ordered one glass. My friend ordered the Tortelloni Di Ricotta in Salsa DI Noci (ravioli with ricotta cheese and spinach in a walnut sauce) and sauvignon. It doesn't look like the square ravioli that we may be accustomed to, so don't be alarmed. This was also delicious. Although, the sauce kind of tasted like a pesto, but not an overpowering one, the walnuts may have balanced that out. She really enjoyed her wine and got two glasses. As for dessert, the semifreddo al chioccolat, AMAZING. Highly recommend. It was like a frozen white chocolate mousse with bits of something crunchy in it as well (not sure if there were wafers or chocolate bits) topped with milk chocolate. So good. I'm salivating writing about it. It did take a bit of time for it to come out, I'd say about 15-20 minutes.Service: It was alright, nothing spectacular. I'm not sure if the host was the owner, but he seemed to really take pride in making sure everyone was having an enjoyable experience. It did take some time for us to put in an order though and I'm not sure if that's because we were sitting at the bar or not. But it was fine.I would go back.

I'm not typically one to eat my feelings, but Italian food, pasta in particular, gives me comfort. I call it sweatpants food. Not because I eat so much of it, I can only wear sweatpants. Not because I wear sweatpants while eating it (except maybe when I'm dining in). But because it makes me feel warm, cozy and comfortable. It was exactly what I craved on a blisteringly cold night.The manfriend ordered the gnocchi alla nonna and I ordered the cavatelli with shrimp and tomatoes in a pistachio cream sauce. Prior to our meals arriving we ate the bread that they I think they make in house. It was quite good. Both of us enjoyed our meals, but I liked his a bit more. The sauce was delicate and the gnocchi so light and airy. The flavors in mine are hard to describe, but the dish was rich; the saltiness of the shrimp helped balance it out. Overall, the food was well executed. Portions were adequate; if you're just there for a main dish, I don't see you leaving with leftovers.We arrived at Nando about 25 minutes before closing; it wasn't how we planned it, it just happened that way. The owner (?) let me know the kitchen closed soon when we arrived. I asked if it was ok if we dined and he said it was. That felt like a half truth because we were reminded at least 2 more times that the kitchen was closing at 9 sharp. When we placed our orders (entrees only, we weren't looking for a long, lingering meal), we were given the option of pre-ordering dessert, which we declined. When we got our meals, we were given a three minute warning on the kitchen closing and yet another chance to order dessert. Again, we declined. Everyone was polite, but it's hard not to feel like we were a big inconvenience on what appeared to be a slow night (only one other table in the place when we walked in). The only other knock was that the music was unnecessarily loud; until it was lowered, we couldn't even carry a conversation while we waited for our food. Aside from the feeling like we should make a quick exit, service was knowledgeable, attentive and friendly.Overall, I give the whole experience 3.5 stars. I'd definitely try the place again and see if we can put that first awkward meal behind us.

I want to start by saying, a trattoria who makes their pasta from scratch has my respect!I just returned from Italy which made me even a tougher critic of Italian cuisine and this place still managed to impress me. To sum up what you can expect at Nando is cozy neighborhood spot where traditional Italian dishes are cooked to perfection!We had a Seafood Linguini and Fettuccine Bolognese, both dishes were flawless from the exquisite handmade noodles to sauces which makes you want to leak your plate. Excellent wine list and surprisingly large variety of desert options (loved Nutella Crepes!!!) completes a fabulous dining experience.However it would not be fair not to mention outstanding service and atmosphere at Nando. It's a cute place with a warm feel and they have a beautiful outside space (for the few warm Chicago nights we get to enjoy:)) The wait staff is friendly, attentive and very knowledgable of the menu. Their chef Alessio Vullo is actually there and he periodically comes out to great his guests. This man doesn't need to hide in the kitchen, he can be proud of his food!
Great location and a gorgeous outdoor patio. The pasta and dessert were phenomenal, but the bread that came with the (delish) olive oil was sorely lacking.

Came here with my two friends who have been raving about this place for a couple of months. After dining here I can totally see why they wouldn't shut up about this place.Excellent service! Everyone in this establishment was personable, friendly and provided first rate customer service.We shared the:- Calamari Fritti: normal calamari, but still good.- Mussels: so so good! I'm so glad our server recommended these- Saffron Rice Balls: these were so good we got two more ordersFor my entree I got the Ravioli Di Aragosta E Granchio (house made crab and lobster ravioli with scallops in a lobster creamy sauce). The seafood inside the ravioli was so fresh and the sauce was rich and creamy. The only downside was that I wish i would have been given 10 more raviolis.I will definitely be going back to Nando Milano Trattoria.
The homemade pasta dishes are absolutely amazing! Also, the service was extremely welcoming and attentive. I'd highly recommend it.

Wow, I am impressed!!! The outdoor seating of this place is to die for, with perfect little twinkle lights and right in the middle of division on wicker park it's both trendy and peaceful! A great romantic vibe. The food was also delicious and reasonably priced considering the service and the location. I loved how portion sizes were reasonable, I got a pasta and didn't feel ridiculously stuffed at the end. The cheapest wine (a Pinot Grigio) was also great! They are generous with their wine servings and the food comes out with just the right amount of time after the appetizer. I would definitely return to this place and recommend it to all my friends.

We were greeted at Nando Milano Trattoria by a young woman with an Italian accent. The interior was dimly lit, rich woods, and intimate. It was sultry in the classiest sense of the word... and we crushed hard.I don't normally go for Italian food, but I saw Anthony M's review and pictures and planned an impromptu date for that same evening.I think the most important thing for you to know is that Nando Milano Trattoria is authentic Italian food served by Italians but different from a typical Italian American restaurant.Typical Italian American restaurants focus on generous portions of familiar dishes: spaghetti, ravioli, lasagna, etc. They have big personalities, big families, sloppy hugs and kisses, and comfortable atmospheres. Nando Milano Trattoria is the refined, tender, smaller brother from Italy. Perhaps a little perfectionist and a little creative... Nando Milano Trattoria is my favorite Italian restaurant to date.M loves it too. We still talk about how we must go back... How we MUST bring certain friends and family members there.After a delicious meal and at least two drinks each, the Italian owner came by and chatted with us. He was a charmer without being pushy. He gave us each some limoncello that was made from his family's recipe. It was a perfect way to end the evening.

We had a group of 4 eat dinner last night, while Do-Division was happening, and this was a Sunday night. Got seated promptly. This was our 2nd time, and what I enjoyed the most last time was the pasta. We ordered the lasagna, squid-ink pasta (kind of like a ravioli), pesto gnocchi, and the pasta with riccotta (closest to a fetticuine alfredo which was requested). BEST part is the pasta - home made, so yummy. Gnocchi has a great texture to it. My mother-in-law loved her lasagna and my brother-in-law who is a bit picky finished EVERY bite.Portion sizes are decent, not overly done, and of course the manager stopped by and was super friendly like last time.Why go to a place that doesn't have home-made pasta and basically pay the same amount? Come here for a nice, quiet dinner. Also has a romantic feel. :)

Nando Milano embodies one of the things that make Chicago such a wonderful city: mom&pop style restaurants. This place is a gem among all the sports bars and coffee shops that make up the wicker park neighborhood. There is nothing cookie cutter about this place. Their staff seems to take pride in what they do and care enough about their jobs to provide excellent service. The food is spot on, although I've never been to Italy so I can't comment to its authenticity (but I have no doubt it's spot on). They have ladies nights on Wednesdays with drink specials and during the summer they have a beautiful outdoor patio.A little bit more on the details:Polenta 9/10Gnocchi Della nonna, 8/10Squid ink sea bass ravioli with clamp mussels 8/10Gnocchi tomato 8.5/10Their vintage industrial decor is pinterest-worthy and they've got a surprisingly good music selection. Despite all the italian places in chicago, I would highly recommend coming here if you want to have a great dining experience.

We really enjoyed our dinner here. I will totally agree it's a date night spot. As mentioned in the other reviews, the host is kind of pushy and too accommodating which makes it too much of a process to find something to order. You get a lot of "I know what you will like" to "we can do anything"...it's a bit uncomfortable. Eventually, you either let him order for you or you have to just be pushy back.The food is spectacular! We ordered the burrata and pappardelle with pork ragout. They were kind enough to split the pasta for us. It was the perfect portion! We also ordered the lava cake rec' by the host - it was damn good. Dinner is a wait - regardless how slow the restaurant is. Be ready to wait and have good company.

The food: 5/5. With so many overrated restaurants in Chicago, Nando Milano is definitely underrated. Although I live a block away, I never noticed this place until I was brought there by a regular. The staff is very knowledgeable about wine pairing and the menu, and the dishes are superb. As a large table, we had a few rounds of various appetizers, which were all good. I had cod for my main, which I had low expectations for since cod is not the most flavorful kind of fish, but it was surprisingly tasty. Several other people in our dinner party had lasagna bolognese, which some said was the best they've had in the city. I skipped dessert and opted out for homemade limoncello, which  was delicious.The service: 5/5. The wait staff was very knowledgeable about the menu and their wine selection.Overall: 5/5. To be honest, Italian cuisine is not my favorite, but I'd definitely come back. Limoncello alone warrants another trip back.

Loved our apps.  The service was amazing at first but then it took us over 20 minutes to get the check after we asked for it and they only had about 8 tables.  I would also stay away from the seafood ravioli, they tried too much with the dish and it just was overwhelming.

I love this place! Especially for the quality of the food and the authenticity of the atmosphere, it is a wonderful deal - I brought my boyfriend here for Valentine's and we had a beautiful meal including desserts and a bottle of wine for about $100. Everything is super fresh, perfectly prepared and well-portioned. The maitre d' was warm and welcoming and the ambiance is calm and relaxed, fancy enough, but not fussy. Also, the gnocchi is the stuff of DREAMS!!!Grazie, Nando!

As a Brazilian from São Paulo I grew up around Italian food. As a server I've worked at an Italian restaurant with really good food and the best pana cotta I've ever had... Until now!Atmosphere wise the place is gorgeous and really romantic. Excellent for a date night.Service was impeccable from both my server and guest perspective. Lucca the manager made us feel welcome and Jelena was spot on!Now let's talk about food!!The calamari was fresh and came with an amazing vegetable/apple sauce.The gnocchi de la nona was amazing. Texture wise it felt like eating a delicious pillow.The mushroom risotto was full of flavor and literally blew my mind!!Now my favorite part of the meal. Dessert!We ordered the pana cotta and the profiteroles both where amazing!!Lucca decided to treat us to some limoncello and semifreddo. I had to take a minute to breath after my first bite of that amazing dessert!!This place is a gem and they will be seeing us many more times after this very memorable first time!!
