Ingredients are very fresh and delicious. A bibimbap is essentially a salad with rice and a choice of meat. I love eating this and I don't feel guilty after eating a huge bulk.I also recommend getting the Kailbi parathas. It's simply Korean marinated meat on a paratha with their special sauce. No veggies or anything, but it taste amazing! I love the simplicity of the flavorings.I tend to ordered both when I come here. Try it yourself!

Food: 3.5/5 I've been numerous times and I always get their sashimi bap. I love all the fresh veggie and the simplicity of this dish, however I have to take a star off for getting fish that was almost frozen a couple of times. Once it melts around warm rice, the entire dish becomes too soupy, which makes it less enjoyable. I also didn't enjoy paratha tacos.Service: 4/5  The owners are very friendly and accommodate allergy requests. However, I don't like that you have to ask to use the bathroom and then wait for them to shut the kitchen curtain when you walk by.Overall: 4/5. Good quality food for what you pay. Also it's a good spot to grab a quick dinner.

En Hakkore is great. I always forget about it because it's on the northside area of Bucktown, but each time I go there I feel like I made the best decision ever.Their menu is pretty simple. You can pretty much either get tacos or a bibimbap bowl. Although the bibimbap bowl sounds scary, it is amazing. It's a huge bowl filled with 12 different kinds of vegetables (mostly pickled) and your choice of protein (I've had both Korean BBQ and Tofu).  They give you a soy sauce type of sauce for the side and you pour it on as your mouth starts to water. So. good. So healthy tasting and so filling.No alcohol and they are closed on Sundays. Seems to be a good place with good traditional values. I appreciate that.Go here for weekend lunch!
I haven't even tried the bibimbap yet, but the spicy tacos alone are worth 5 stars.

Love this place!!! Korean/Mexican fusion.....i literally drive to the city from Barrington so I can eat their delicious tacos.Their bibimbap is good, but its just an ordinary Korean dish that you can get anywhere. They do use fresh veggies and make the dish look pretty so that's bueno.Now for the real food.....the tacos....spicy pork, krn beef, and the veggie one (tofu - i believe this was a special when I was there last time).So to start off about these splendid treats....they use PARATHA BREAD. It's brilliant and a perfect combination to offset the bursting flavors that come from the meat and veggies. They put in kimchi, onion, mushroom, cilantro, lettuce, pickled radish, and a tangy sauce in the tacos with either spicy pork or korean styled beef. There's just so much winning right there you can't give it anything below 5 stars...

Always freshly cooked, always amazingly tasty! True gem!Beef tacos are absolutely must to try!This place rocks with their cold bibimbab, substitute white rice with black rice.We take there all our guests who come to visit Chicago, they always want to go back when they visit.Personally not a fan of sashimi bibimbab , but it is a good option for some people.Keep doing great job!The service is fast, the place is always clean and plays nice music.

I just wanted to thank these guys after last night. As you can see from my earlier review, we love the place. We moved to Michigan about 8 months ago and, while my husband is in Chicago for work and can grab En Hakkore whenever he wants, I've been stranded without it. Let me tell y'all about love and dedication: yesterday my husband brought a full-sized cooler and ice packs to Chicago and brought bibimbap and paratha tacos across two states to feed his hungry pregnant wife. And those amazing folks at En Hakkroe? Packaged everything up for us so that we could reheat at home and have a perfect meal. They even gave my husband instructions on how to reheat the paratha. Pregnant lady over here got all emotional. Thanks for making my day, you lovely people you.

Not much to say about En Hakkore except it is a must try. I came here for the first time with two friends for a laid back Saturday dinner and was blown away by the food.I got the Bibim-bap Bowl with Korean BBQ Beef and white rice. The dish is packed with 16 kinds of vegetables (I'm sure my mom would be happy to hear this) and has so much flavor. The portion size was perfect for my manly appetite and the cost was pleasing to my Visa.Also, the tacos get two thumbs up. My friend got the Paratha Taco (one Spicy Pork & one Korean BBQ Beef) and they were amazeballs. That spicy pork is delicious fo sho!I'll definitely be seeing En Hakkore again in 2015!

Ample seating. Friendly staff. I highly recommend the bibimbap and paratha tacos. The bowl of bibimbap has an exquisite assortment of vegetables (sixteen!) and grilled beef. So colorful. I like to think it's nutritionally well-balanced. Korean beef with paratha bread is to die for too. I tend to order these two items rather than the rolls or paninis. I have not tried to order with an app or online. No line when I visited on a weekday afternoon.

Had the sashimi bowl. It was really fresh and the amount they give you is ridiculous! It's really enough to fill a hungry hippo. The decorations are a bit hipster like but it's cool. Definitely well worth the money and time to check this place out. Come with a hungry stomach!

First time here on a Tuesday evening. As the yelp reviews indicate, the food here was delicious. This is now one of our new favorite places. The menu is limited but what they do, they do right. We'll be coming back here for more.

I came in after the gym and this was the perfect meal! Very light and clean with a good amount of protein. The portion is filling and the price is affordable. This is a great stop if you want something on the healthier side. I could eat here weekly and enjoy it.

BEST. KOREAN. TACOS!!!!!Who was the genius that decided to make a hybrid "taco" with korean bbq meat with a parathra (think super thick roti bread)?  WHO?!  I'd definitely swipe right for you, if you know what I mean.Anyway, this place is super adorable and I am going to keep coming back for the tacos.  They rice bowls are pretty standard to any other korean restaurant but they come in a normal bowl so you won't get the crispy charred rice that is so special to bibimbap.  If you're looking for something delicious, unique, and cheap... stick to the tacos!!!!  I prefer pork over beef but they're both great.

Their bibimbaps are delicious. Most recently I had the sashimi bap which is a great bang for your buck. I've always enjoyed the tacos here as well. Customer service is great, food is tasty and the prices are reasonable.

Very unique idea! Loved the food! I got the Korean B.B.Q beef bibimbap, which comes in a huge bowl! Totally worth the price. The bowl comes with lots of vegetables, about 13 different ones and a choice of white, brown, or black rice. Very good food! The spicy pork is pretty spicy apparently, but still delicious. Would definitely come back again!

More like a 3.5 - scored huge points with a bibimbap that was so colorful and full of fresh veggies, and also a flavorful japchae.The only things that detracted from the meal (minor, really, and some a matter of personal taste) were - the bibimbap turning cool very quickly, a mix-up in our order which resulted in us not getting black rice in the bibimbap, and rather generic mandoo.  I would also say that the tacos were decent, but didn't really impress.Still, I can understand the buzz and popularity of the place - I'd definitely recommend it or return, despite the somewhat limited menu offered.

I wish they had more variety when it comes to their sushirittos. The sushiritto itself it okay. What made me give the 4 stars is the hot sauce on the table. It really enhances the whole meal. ALSO, those kimchi waffle fries are amazing. If I came back, I would come back for the waffle fries. All french fries should be as crispy as these. I have also tried the wings which were solid, but not something I would crave. The portion size is huge which is a plus and I think it is decently priced. I like the decor of the place and the guy who took our table's order was friendly. Would I come here if I had a sushi  craving, probably not...There are better places, but for a quick bite, sure.
This is really good place.  Everytime I visit in chicago, I always stop by here.good tastes,huge portion and reasonable price.Lady behind the counter is also very kind and informative.
Def a fan of the Beef Paratha Taco! Great value for money also!Most definitely will be visiting again :-)

Very impersonal and disrespectful mid 30's, asian, male handling the counter.  He seemed extremely annoyed and uninterested in my person... Business, business business AKA $$$.No matter how good the food is reviewed to be, customer service and respect is the most important determining factor for me. I WON'T come back and will share this experience. I did nothing to deserve his treatment. Discrimination? We don't know, but people shouldn't take feelings out on those uninvolved with the cause. Treat people according to how they treat you pay closer attention.
Hands down the best korean tacos I've ever had. I can't get enough of this place.
Food was fresh, affordable and tasty. The not so welcoming arrogance behind the counter was a turn off.
Good fusion Korean food for americans

Fantastic!! I loved this place. The taco shell was buttery and flaky almost like a croissant. The guy said they do this in South Asia. The Pork is a little spicy but good. The beef was absolutely Delish:)the environment has an awesome vibe. I love everything about this place and will be back. Super friendly and helpful at the register as well!
What happened En Hakkore, you used to have more seafood in the sushi bib. So much cabbage now. Used to be a twice a week family of three. Not going back again...things have changed.

Love en hakkore!Adorable interior and amazing food. I still crave the tacos every day. Both pork and beef are great; although I think I like the beef slightly more. Full of flavor and the taco bread they use is out of the world!Wasn't as in love with the bipimbap. I got the sashimi one. they were upstaged by the tacos for sure, but still not bad.

Yummm...delicious and cheap bi bim bap and sashimi! The sashimi bi bim bap reminds me a lot of poke bowls (without the seasoning on the fish, though), which was a pleasant surprise. I pretended like I was eating healthy as I scarfed down an entire bowl (hey, it's mostly veggies!).They have a ton of fun soda options, including ginger beer.1/2 star docked for the long food wait (about a half-hour), although I think this was mostly due to a high volume of call-in orders.If you're looking for a cheap, somewhat healthy option in Wicker Park, this is the place to go. Hell, if you're looking for tasty food filled with veggies, make sure to stop here.
Delicious! I LOVE this place - my neighborhood go to :)

Walk-up style deliciousness.We thought that the sentence above sufficiently encapsulated the praise that this place deserves. However yelp told us that it was too short to be considered a review. So alas, we added the two sentences that proceed this one.

The bibimbop is definitely not the traditional Korean bibimbop that you might be used to if you're a Korean food lover like me. That doesn't mean it isn't delicious~ I love En Hakkore! All the ingredients are super fresh and the people at the cashier are always very friendly. I got the spicy pork. It was not as spicy as I expected it to be, but that was fine because you can add as much gochujang and soy sauce as you want to fit your taste. Yummmmmy

Solid, Solid, Solid.  3 solids = 4 stars?  Gorilla math.- Solid #1 - Parathas Tacos.  This, my friends, is all about the vehicle.  While most tacos use your typical corn tortilla... En Hakkore makes a bold upgrade to Parathas.  A delightful, fluffy yet firm, wrap that handles the sauteed meat with confidence.  It brings the experience to another level.  It's like a free ride in a Benz Limo to the airport instead of a nappy cab.- Solid #2 - Sashimi Bap. A staple when looking to eat moderately healthy and stay away from any fried/massive carb categories.  Yes there is rice, but you can select brown or black which should help lessen the blow to your gut.  The sashimi is a fair portion for the $12-$13 you pay, but the real bonus is the vegetable variety.  They don't skimp.- Solid #3 - Anything Pork on the Menu.  The pork is marinated with a sweet and spicy tang to it that runs the show.Put it on a parathas.Put it on rice.Put it down on me, put it down on me.My only criticism is they try a little too hard with the rice presentations in the wide-ass and shallow bowl.Riddle me this? When does a bowl become too shallow that it becomes a plate?The identity crisis of the bowl-plate makes it a little difficult to eat the rice dishes or to mix all the componenets of the dish (which is done traditionally with bibimbap... I mean "bibim" means "mixed")Also, the skinny, stumpy wood spoon is not helping...But besides the dish faux pas, the food itself is definitely worth it.They could give it to me on a burlap sack and I'd still come back.Don't get any cute ideas En Hakkore...

This place is small and cute, and when we came in it was before the rush period, so we were able to get our food fairly quickly. My friend ordered the veggie bibimbap, and it came in a HUGE bowl, which she quickly downed because of the flavor. She used the hot sauce on the table, which was a huge hit. I got the paratha tacos, one Korean BBQ beef and one spicy pork, and I was blown away. The tacos are huge so you get full after two, and they were so flavorful I probably could have eaten three more. The prices are very reasonable as well.
Absolutely love this place the Korean beef and spicy pork paratha tacos are delish! Keep coming back for more!

Loved this place!I went for the first time after getting a manicure at ZaZaZoo Nail Salon. Perfect counter style place - the decor is awesome and just oozes "cool."I opted for the Sashimi Bowl and was not disappointed - tons of fresh raw fish and lots of veggies. I went with the spicy sauce and just used a little bit of it & it was enough. A bit pricey for a lunch but so healthy!

Southport just gets better and better. Now you've got chefs from San Francisco's A16 bringing southern Italian cuisine, Neapolitan pizzas and those insane meatballs right to the neighborhood?! Remind me please why I do not live here?These storied meatballs are worth the visit alone! We came here early on Saturday night before the world famous Cubs game. The atmosphere is so upscale, you sort of expect Sophia Lauren herself to come around the corner. In addition to the meatballs, we had the antipasti, a margherita bufalo pizza and two handcrafted pastas. We finished with the coconut gelato and a seasonal apple crostata that was out-of-this-world. It was so good, we ended up ordering a second one. Hey now, don't judge - there were six of us! We all enjoyed every single bite.Everything was so deliciously authentic, perfectly prepared and presented. Our cocktails were wonderful, the wine list is accessible and the atmosphere could not have been more perfect. It was such a memorable, fun night out on the town and I'm so glad Coda Di Volpe is here.

This is my first visit to Coda. I was seated as I arrived and everything flowed from there. My water glass was never empty, staff made eye contact to see if something was needed and my server made recommendations of items to try on the menu, he missed nothing.To start my wife and I had the grilled Octopus, very tasty and the right texture. This was followed by the Pizza Margarita, also very good. We split he Pork Chop which was one of the better cuts I have ever had and an appetizer portion of the Trombette Trapanese, fennel sausage, tomato, almond, garlic, basil, caciocavallo, (yes I copied this from the menu), it was excellent.I also liked the decor and especially the fact they have sound absorption material on the walls and ceiling so you can actually have a conversation. Prices are fair and I am happy to welcome this restaurant into the Southport corridor, I'll be back!.

Wonderful experience at a neighborhood gem. I arrived about half an hour early for a reservation, so I opted to make friends with the bartender. The crowd was still light (it was still early for the dinner rush), so the Negroni I order came right away. The bartender was super friendly, and the drink well made. By time I'd finished, the reservation was up & we were seated.I got the half portion of Bucatini Pomodoro with Mortadella & Prosciutto Meatballs and paired with the Rocca dei Mori. The half portion was a great size to pair with the meatballs, and the two dishes went well together, and came recommended by the waiter, along with a few popular pizzas and the swordfish. After ordering, our drinks came promptly and the food wasn't far behind. Overall great experience and I look forward to going back!

We typically try out a new Italian restaurant every time my brother is in town, usually for carb loading before a half-marathon.  In this case, it was just carb loading post marathon and during the work week while Hubby had to work late.  Coda is listed as one of the hot restaurants to try now, so it was great to grab an early evening reservation and even better that it is walking distance from home.The restaurant itself is nicely decorated and spaced out.  We opted to eat inside since it looked like it was going to rain.  Our hostess seated us in a corner booth in the back that had a good vintage point of the whole place.  Our server was friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  He great drink recommendations.  I thoroughly enjoyed my Stolen Vespa and its complex smoky flavor.  It definitely packed a punch but the quality of the liquor was enough where I didn't have any after effects.The portions were shareable and we split an order of the Mortadella & Prosciutto Meatballs, Fiore de Zuca, and the Roasted Summer Corn.  The corn was the best and most generous amount.  Baby girl enjoyed the large meatballs.  I thought the zucchini was stuffed with too much cheese.  We also split the Prosciutto Cotto pizza.  The crust was crispy on the edges and chewy toward the middle, but was able to hold up the ingredients and was not soggy.For dessert we split the Chocolate Hazelnut Budino which was my favorite and the Brioche con Gelato which was basically a giant pistachio gelato brioche sandwich...it was crazy decadent and delicious...my brother devoured it.  Even our mom enjoyed the dessert, which she usually doesn't eat too much of.Glad to have a new Italian option that is family friendly in the neighborhood.

Visited Coda di Volpe, roughly translated to "tail of the fox", the other night with the family.  Convenient to the Brown Line, this restaurant sits a block away from the L station on Southport.I arrived early, but my sister made the reservations.  Luckily there's a very nice bar at the front of the restaurant.  I had a cocktail while I was waiting and got to observe the early dinner crowd.  Seemed like a mix between business dinners and neighborhood families, but the restaurant had a little bit of everything for everyone to enjoy.  There's a nice outdoor patio section.Lots of sharing happened at our table.  We had the meatballs, roasted corn on the cob, fried zucchini blossoms, and shared a pizza.  We also shared three different desserts:  Chocolate Hazelnut Budino, Pistachio Gelato on Brioche, and Mango Gelato.The staff here are super friendly... hosts, bartenders, servers.  Someone was always by our table to make sure plates got cleared and out waters were full.  Our server Mike was very well versed with the menu and helped with some recommendations.  The servers all had white shirts and an uniform apron - reminded me of an upscale version of the Mario Bro's for some reason, but in a good way.  Our server even put in our food, to fire in a certain order so that the plates did not crowd our table since we were sharing... made for a nicely timed dinner.Overall, I would come back... there were several other items on the menu that looked enticing as well as their craft cocktails.

Upon arrival to Copa Di Volpe I was welcomed my a sharp looking man in a suite. The restaurant has an open layout and has an expensive rustic looking vibe. The one thing I will say is I felt a bit under dressed. I went in jeans, a t-shirt and converse. You wanna dress it up kids, more of a collared shirt kind of place. I even joked with the waiter about it but he said the dress code is causal.Anyway, we ordered the arancini for an appetizer, the prosciutto cotto and paccheri genovese for dinner and had the chocolate hazelnut budino for dessert. Everything was outstanding and delicious. We also each got a glass of wine at $14 dollars a pop which seemed a bit expensive. Overall, it was a great experience and i will be going back again.

While there were definitely some hiccups, I was impressed by how smooth everything ran for a restaurant that hasn't been open long.My boyfriend and I made reservations for 715 and were seated promptly, and immediately had water brought to us.  We ordered wine, which took about ten minutes to get back to us.We started out with the fritti bucatini which more or less, is a glorified mac and cheese bite. While it was tasty, was lukewarm.Onto the pasta we had the Trombette Trapanese. We split the small dish which was a perfect portion for us. The pasta had a lovely texture, fennel sausage was great, and the textures really went well together. It was fresh and well done.Finally we got to the main event, the Funghi Pizza, which is mostly smoke and mushroom. I really enjoyed the flavor - it was exciting and different compared to a lot of other specialty pizza places in the area.For desert, the Chocolate Hazelnut Budino tickled my fancy as a wonderful harmony of caramel balls, crumbly biscotti and heavenly chocolate - a perfect desert we took to go in order to drink through the horrendous presidential debate going on that evening.There were some flaws here and there, but this was a nice experience. Will I choose it again anytime soon? Probably not so much, but I did appreciate what they were going for and would go back.

Stopped by for a late night dessert after finding out  that Jeni's had a mile long snake queue. People missing out on the pistachios gelato here! Ordered a scoop of mint, pistachios and coconut. Pistachios definitely on par with what I tried in the native land.

Tried Coda the week it opened and overall i was fairly impressed. The interior is quite modern and very nice. Great little chef's bar at the back where you can see food preparation.The bar at the front is good as well and the drinks are well made. Got an Old Fashioned and was very satisfied by the drink.The menu isn't as broad as certain other Italian restaurants, but the food items are quite good. The highlight of the meal was the Diavola pizza. It was great and the rest of the pizzas are likely also just as good given the wood-fired oven. We also got the Squid Ink Garganelli which was very good. It was slightly salty but as someone allergic to shellfish, I was very happy the squid ink pasta wasn't accompanied by shellfish which is so often the case.Overall, I'd return but the prices are a touch high in my opinion, so I wouldn't make dinner here a regular occurrence.

To sum it up in one word: Fantastic.I've been keeping my eye on the construction of this place and was curious to see what it was turning into, and I was pleasantly surprised to find out the talent behind it. It was very refreshing to learn that the chefs associated with Coda Di Volpe are well known for their previous endeavours.I made a reservation this afternoon for later tonight, and we were seated right on time. If I had any gripes about this evening, it was that it took a few minutes before we were noticed and attended to. Nothing to remove stars over. We started with drinks and aracini. My wine was delicious, but I felt I wasn't served enough for the price I paid. I got less than half a glass.The aracini: absolutely delicious.We moved onto the funghi pizza and sweet corn ravioli. Both dishes were on point and my girlfriend and I enjoy both. At one point I made the mistake of thinking the pizza was slightly undercooked, and the staff immediately offered to replace the pizza with another one. Recognizing my mistake I apologized profusely and said it would not be necessary. Im including this detail to point out their excellent service and attentiveness to our table once we were seated.I enjoyed the arancini so much I asked our waiter, Austin, to surprise me with another option from their fritti. He brought out the zucchini blossoms which were to die for. To be honest, I could have a whole meal of nothing but their delicious fritti options.We ended the meal with the Budino. A delicious blend of chocolate, caramel, and some other deliciousness that I forget.All in all, Coda Di Volpe is a very, very welcome addition to the Southport Corridor. It is an excellent alternative to all of the boring and mediocre sports bars in the vicinity and I will definitely be stopping by regularly.My only other complaint is that I did not feel that the full portion of sweet corn ravioli was worth a whopping $24. It was good, but not $24 good.Coda Di Volpe, you have to try it!

Lots of "we're short staffed" excuses.25 minutes to get a cocktail, random plates we didn't order brought to our table and then taken away, meals not brought out together, another 20 minute wait to pay.Between the price point and service, definitely not worth it.

Big Billy Lawless fan, love his other 3 concepts but have yet to try Beacon Tavern. When this new Italian place opened up near where I live I was excited to taste the menu. It's really nice on the inside, there's even a bar with TVs to post up. Tons of outdoor seats that were filled for most of this Summer.Unfortunately, the food and service underwhelmed. Our waiter was baffled with wine recommendations and had to keep returning to ask his manager about our inquiries. The food portions were miniscule for the price, and we left hungry. I had the larger portion of the Squid Ink Garganelli and it lacked quite a bit of taste. I also can't imagine what the smaller $12 portion was like because mine was light. Overall it was almost $150 for a decent meal so probably won't be back. Maybe I'd try a pizza to go but I wouldn't recommend it or take a group to dine in.

My friend and I came for the Prosecco slushie (cocktail called Lightworks) and stayed for the food.Our drinks were a perfect Labor Day treat. We ate outside and the drinks were so refreshing. We then split the Proscuitto Cotto pizza which was very good. My only complaint was that it had to be eaten with a knife and fork because the crust wasn't strong enough to support all of the delicious ingredients on top. But that's ok! The pizza comes uncut but the scissors they gave us to cut the pizza worked really well.Everything was going so well we decided to get dessert. we ordered the Blueberry Peach Crostata with a side of vanilla bean gelato and it was excellent. It was the perfect size for sharing with a friend. We left full but not feeling overly stuffed. I will definitely come back here. Shout out to our awesome server Melissa!!

I will admit that the service is very good,but the food in my opinion, the food is sub par. We started with the grilled octopus which was grilled perfectly as the octopus was very tender, but it tasted a little fishy. The appetizer dishes are very small. In their defense, that's why they call them appetizers. Ordered the squash blossoms. Very greasy. When I took a bite, the oil was oozing all over my mouth. Archini (sp?), were smaller than a golf ball and unremarkable. We also ordered a small serving of Bucatini Pomodora. VERY small, just perhaps two very long noodles in a sauce that reminds me of Franco American Spaghetti sauce. Sweet and bland. Prices were good though. But we still think we will not return.
The food here is good but I think the prices are pretty high for what you get. I'm glad I visited but probably wouldn't return; there are better values to be had!

A friend of mine and I had dinner here on 8/12/16.  It was absolutely delicious y'all.Ask for an order of bread; they throw it on the grill and it is served warm and to-order.  You will totally want to dip the bread in the outstanding sauce of the Mortadella & Prosciutto Meatball appetizer.  One of the meatballs was a tad dry, and the other was spot-on.  Not sure how that happens, but I'm just reporting the facts. It came out of the kitchen really fast, so I assume the meatballs were pre-made and maybe had been sitting a while.  Not to worry though, this sauce will rock your taste buds.We shared the Quattro Formaggi pizza.  Seriously, their wood burning pizza oven must be magic.  It was outstanding.  The dough is so fresh and delicious.  As was the arugula on top of this pizza.We also shared the Trombette Trapanese pasta.  Oh boy, was it yummy.  I'm a sauce person, and I feel like it needed more sauce and maybe a sprinkle of course sea salt over the top.  And there really wasn't much sausage in it, which is odd since it's marketed as a fennel sausage pasta dish.  But overall, it was truly delicious.The service was fantastic.  We had several people taking care of us, our water glasses never got half-empty, and we were not rushed in the least.  Even the chef came by to see how we were enjoying our meal.  I have advised him to start selling that meatball sauce by the jar. Or the gallon. Or however they will give it to me.It is a tad loud in the restaurant, but the décor is really great.  There is a bar area as well, and I think I'll go back for drinks with friends.  And I'll see if they will serve me bread and meatball sauce on the side.Go here y'all.

I've been debating on how to review this restaurant since eating there.  I have to admit that the food ranged from very good to excellent.  The service was ok but will improve.  The one thing throwing me is the price.  This is not $$, this is between $$$-$$$$.  Here is the reason that I say that.   It isn't the actual price of the individual items as much as it is the quantity or lack there of.  For the appetizer, we ordered the meatballs.  At $14, I was expecting to have a starter that we (only 2 in our party) could share.  There were 4 meatballs and they were on the average to small size.  Again, the quality was excellent, the sauce and the shaved parmesan were very good.  Then my partner had a small plate of the pasta (at $9 I believe) expecting that to be a more reasonable proportion.  Instead, I would count it more as a child's plate.The pizza that I had was amazing.  It was enough for one but would be hard pressed to share.  Its price was reasonable.  Again, don't miss the fact that the pizza was killer.  I want it again.As far as the location, it is a beautiful restaurant.  We sat at the bar and the noise level was right.  Some music so you didn't hear everyone's conversations but you could still talk.Overall, for 2 of us with an appetizer, small pasta, pizza, 2 cocktails and one glass of wine, the bill was $84 before tip.  Please understand, I don't mind paying for good food and I am not one that wants to gorge when I eat.  (No all you can eat buffets here) But, when I spend over $90 with tip, I do expect to feel comfortably full.  We decided that we would get pizza to go from this place but probably won't dine in again.  It is a good variety for Southport but I think people will find it expensive.

Veryyy good. Prices weren't bad, ESPECIALLY for the service, ambiance, and food quality. Owner even came by and made sure we were good, pouring us a glass of one of their wines on the house while we waited and checking in a few more times. Felt very good. Would highly recommend and I'll be going back again.Trombette Trapanese, Prosciutto Cotto pizza, and octopus were all good. I don't think you can go wrong with any of it. Pasta was a bit heartier than the pizza so that might help you choose between a pasta and a pizza. I think I'm going pizza next time.

Dropped in and sat at the bar. Nice selection of cocktails and beers. I ordered the Quatro Formaggio Pizza and wood oven octopus appetizer. The octopus was delicious but did not compare to the pizza. Delivered table side with a pair of shearing scissors to preserve the quality, this pizza is something I will definitely be returning for. Nice venue, fast service, and excellent authentic Italian cuisine. Be sure to drop in if you are in the neighborhood!

My friend is one of the chefs at this new Billy Lawless location. So naturally I had to go opening day. Let me start off by saying that low light and decor goes together nicely. They have a well lite bar area which goes nicely with the candle lit dining room. My date and I started off with the Artisan cheese plate. Brie blue cheese and Parmesan type of cheeses (I forget the exact names)  paired with almonds grapes fig preserve and some sort of lychee fruit. Delicious! My date had the Spaghetti alla Chitarra (Clam) and I had the Squid Ink Garganelli. Both were fresh and wonderful. They have a impressive wine list split by region of Italy! For desert we split a citrus passionfruit creation (cant remember the Italian pronunciation). It was one of the best things I have ever tasted. Im glad my friend works there because I will be a regular!

Overall our dinner at Coda Di Volpe was a bust. Service was mediocre at best and the food was about the same. I'm apt to forgive one or the other, but it's hard to take a failure on both ends. Especially for what they're asking on the bill.We asked the waiter to explain to us how the menu works. Like how much to order, how big are the shared plates...you know basic questions. The waiter basically just read us the menu again and didn't explain anything. The only useful comment was that the pizzas are sized like appetizers.They have a wood fire oven which I supposed we should have stuck with. The only thing we got that was any good was the wood-fired octopus. Tender, well-seasoned and beautifully charred.Everything else was under-seasoned. Pasta was overcooked and bland. We tried 3 of the 5 pasta's between the 4 of us (small service sizes) and the gnocchi was the least overcooked, but still a bit too soft.This place could have been the first legit high-end place to hit Southport Ave in a while. For the price, this place definitely did not deliver.I may give them another shot down the road. The bar looks cool and the ambiance was nice. I mean you don't really go to an Italian place for the cocktails but they had a few that I was not able to try. There are so many great Italian restaurants in Chicago that it was a shame to see this place fail so miserably at meeting that standard.I hope it was just an off night. Maybe try the pizza and skip the pasta. They said it was house made but when it's been cooked to mush, it might as well have been boxed.And where were the managers?! You've been open for 3 months. You should be at every table checking in on things to make sure everything is perfect. Even when we went looking for a manager to explain our comments, we couldn't find one. Didn't even bother looking at a dessert menu...For the price this place wants to charge, it should have been a lot better. I hope things improve before long. This could have been a real departure for the street of Southport, but instead it's just more of the same mediocre, overpriced food we tend to see on this street. If you're on Southport Ave for dinner, skip this place and head to Sushi Mura or Coal-Fire for better food at a a better price.

As we were walking to another restaurant for dinner we noticed this place had finally opened, so we made an audible and stopped in.It was their first night being open but definitely didn't feel that way. The service was great, and the food and cocktails made their way to our table in a very timely fashion.While the Arancini and the Margherita Di bufala pizza were both delicious and tasted very fresh, I think our favorite was the Spaghetti alla Chittara.The cocktails and desserts we tried were all great as well.We had a great experience, and are excited to have this spot in our neighborhood!

Would be three stars if this place had been open for more than a couple of weeks, but it was great considering its new.The service was spectacular and matched the price and vibe. Not a single complaint there!The food was great as well with a couple of things that you're going to have anytime a kitchen is brand new. I got the pork chop and it was one of the best cuts I've had. The entree lacked a carb which was weird. My date got the braised beef cheek pasta which was good, but it had clearly been sitting in th window for a bit waiting on my meal. Just a kink that they will work out with time.A couple of suggestions - the tables need to have bread. An upscale Italian place without stunning bread is very odd. The appetizers didn't stand out very much and stood out even less considering there was no bread to eat them with. The entrees tending to be lacking a carb or a green element. I felt like I had to choose which one I would rather have and that was a little off putting.I think this place is going to just take off and be our go-to date spot once the kinks get worked out! Highly impressed with our first visit.

Really beautiful interior, atmosphere, and food. My friend and I shared the arrancini (fried risotto balls), the wood grilled octopus, the fried zucchini and the funghi pizza. I had a hard cider and she had a beer, both which were the cheaper side of the alcohol choices and the bill was only $75. Plenty to split between 2 semi hungry people- the portions were not obnoxiously small but were also super high quality.Would definitely come back, sounds like I need to try the bread and meatballs!

Went here for a friend's birthday dinner. I would def return for the pizza, cocktails and atmosphere, those were excellent! The appetizers/pasta were not my favorite - I felt they were a bit overpriced for the neighborhood and for the portions. I spent a lot more than I typically do on dinner in Lakeview. Great addition to the street, but will order differently next time I return.

Coda Di Volpe is the restaurant that the Southport Corridor has been needing for years.The service was welcoming and attentive, atmosphere was comforting and unpretentious, and most importantly, food was very, very good.Don't miss the Pizza Napoletana (highly recommend the Di Buffala) and Swordfish Spiedini - both were excellent. The Baby Arugula Salad and Wood Roasted Carrots were extremely fresh and delivered superior taste.Dessert was on point too; make sure to order the Sicilian Cassata or the Chocolate Hazelnut Budino. Who are we kidding, order both.Glad to finally eat at place on Southport that lives up to the hype and will definitely go back.

We loved this place.  It's about 2 blocks away from our place.  On the corner of Southport and Roscoe.  We had reservations for 9pm but we found a space at the bar and chose to sit there to people watch.  Our bartender, Ron, was very kind and very attentive.  We started with a strawberry spritzer which was very light yet strong.  We then ordered a tomato  and burrata salad, it was excellent!!  The cheese tasted so fresh and the tomatoes tasted like they just came off of a vine from out of a garden.  I have tasted tomatoes like that in a long time!!!  Next, we chose the pork chop dish which was accompanied by grilled squash and onions.  The pork was topped with sautéed peaches and they were cooked perfectly!!!!!  I highly recommend this restaurant for anyone wanting a fun, trendy night out!

Came here on a Thursday night for a belated birthday celebration. I have been waiting to try this place since I read about it in the Southport news. I believe the owners are responsible for Crosbys Kitchen as well so I knew I would be in for something good!Great ambiance though it's a little loud on the inside. I'd say dress casual but on the nicer side- as other reviewers said it is possible to feel under dressed here, unlike many of the other restaurants on Southport. Service was on point! Attentive but we didn't feel rushed. We each had a glass of wine, split a cheese plate and pizza and made it out for $50 total before tip.. Not bad! We got the sweet corn pancetta pizza which I'd definitely recommend. I was split between the pasta and pizza and our waiter advised pizza was their specialty so we went with that and it did not disappoint. Food was really great and not a bad price point for the neighborhood although this may be a 'special occasion' place for me. You could easily make a dinner here $50 a person if you ordered differently.  Regardless, I'll definitely be back!

I've been there twice since, and I'll review these visits separately.    Weeknight visit with 2 others, we met at the bar and had a drink first and the bartender was great, friendly and attentive, suggested a drink we'd like and we did!  We moved to a table and here's where the service went down.  It was fairly crowded, but there were a few open tables on this weeknight.  Our server just seemed overwhelmed, and was slow in bringing us drinks, taking our order and checking back in, etc.  We had to flag down another server (who was very helpful and not annoyed) to help us.  The food was excellent.  Had the octopus which was really delicious, but a tad small for the price. We also had the arugula salad that was very good. Not knock-your-socks-off  but good. I liked the add of the crunch of the almonds.  We also got the margherita pizza, which I rarely get because it's usually boring, but one of us in the party really wanted it.  We all thought it was really good and I didn't find it boring at all.  I like that they serve it with a scissors for you to cut your own size pieces.  Not only unique but also makes sense.   Overall, very good food and a bustling place.  Wish server was less annoyed by us, and we were not demanding at all. 2 glasses of wine, 1 bottle of wine and 3 dishes.  Pretty straightforward.  He also had no personality to be found.  Bummer on the service front.Next visit was a Saturday night bar visit, just 2 of us. I had a different bartender then last time and again, was disappointed in the service.  Just seemed lackadaisical, wasn't very warm or friendly. Did what we asked but again, no personality.  It may sound like I want a stellar server, which I don't!  I just want someone with some personality who can smile, be reasonably attentive and give suggestions when needed.   Food wise, we had the burrata bruschetta which was excellent and we ate every bite.  I'd recommend it and felt it was worth the price.  Had the arugula salad again which was the same as last time.  Good, not great. In hindsight it might have need a dash of salt to liven it up a bit. My friend chose the pizza and we got the spicy one, I forget what it was called.  I can do spicy to a degree, and she has more tolerance than me so it didn't affect her, but I found it too spicy.  I still ate it, but it was just too spicy for me.  No one's fault.  Drinks and wine chosen were great.  Bummer that it was a home Cubs game (playoffs) and they couldn't get the game on.  Men definitely left the bar and women stayed!  The restaurant was full as it was a Saturday night.  I'm assuming they've figured out that they need to change their cable package to get that channel by now!So, a long review for 2 other visits!    Overall on my 3 visits and interaction with 4 staff members, either bartenders or servers, I'm 1 out of 4 which is disappointing. And each time it was concurred by my dining mates, it wasn't just me.  However, the food was really good to great so I'll go back.  If I have service again that is bad, I will definitely nicely mention it to the manager because it's a beautiful restaurant with really good food....ok- to-bad service is not acceptable for that price point.  Or any price point, in my opinion.

Went for my birthday dinner and had a great time! It was a group of eight so we split three pizzas and two large pastas and it was exactly the right amount of food. Staff was friendly, waiter was knowledgable about the menu. The decor is really nice as well. I look forward to returning.

I had been anticipating this addition to the Southport neighborhood given all the recent closings of bars and restaurants. When I noticed the build-out had finished and it looked close to opening, my friend and I made reservations for last Saturday.The anticipation was worth it... completely. We were greeted warmly by lovely host staff  and decided to have a drink near the bar to wait for our table (we were early for our rez). The bartenders were efficient, friendly, and helpful. I had the Negroni, and it was exactly what I expect of a classic Italian standard. Spot on. My friend had Stolen Vesper, which was served in a beautiful rimmed coupe. The drink itself was unique, and if you like mezcal, I definitely recommend.Five to ten minutes before our 9:30 reservation, a hostess came to escort us to our table. The decor is really.... smooth and polished. The room lends an open view so people watching is fun. The windows lining the booths are perfect for taking in the busy street.Our server, Allison, introduced herself and immediately went into explaining the menu. I loved this. She gave a succinct rundown of the portion sizes and the menu items that were already becoming standouts (on the 3rd day of business, no less!) My friend and I decided to share a number of items:- The Octopus - Get this. It's delicious.- Insalata Mista (could be wrong on the name) - Perfectly dressed, and the earthiness from the goat cheese paired nicely with the tangy dressing.- Fritti: Bucatini - Adult swank version of Mac & Cheese bites, two pieces. Just right for that desire for a bit of something fried.- Chicken Diavolo - We both thought the flavor was great and it was cooked perfectly. I had hoped it would be a little spicier, but Allison did explain the honey component, which understandably calms heat.- Squid Ink Garganelli with pan seared tuna heart - We got the smaller portion, which wound up being just right. The pasta was excellent in texture and beautiful to look at. I liked this dish a lot.I'd go into dessert, but this is entirely too long at this point. Just go... you'll have a great time and eat delicious food and be taken care of very well. Allison was simply perfect, and she made my night by bringing out the Budino, even though my friend wasn't nuts about chocolate. Thank you, Allison!

My server was a magician who mastered the art of disappearing... probably practice for his day job. I live in the hood and have wanted to try this place for the last month. Really disappointed. Service was slow. Drinks took forever.  Food was nothing memorable. Pizza was too thin. Almost as good as the frozen section kind. Scissors to cut the pizza unique but they should have supplied a paper cutter instead. Arugula salad was good, steak good.  Expensive, Should be a $$$ restaurant.  Ambiance and facility was excellent. I will take the train next time to Sapori Tratoria or Hubbard street.

Great new place that I've now been to twice.  The space is awesome, with a great bar set-up, some a mix of tables and booths, as well as outdoor seating.  A little pricier than most other places on Southport, but worth it and gives the area some more diversity in terms of eating options.  My wife loved the Trombette Trapanese, and I'm a big fan of the Salsiccia pizza, both of which have their fenel sausage, which is delicious.  Haven't been for brunch yet, but definitely plan on it soon.

I debated between three and four stars, and ultimately settled with three because poor service can't be covered up by good food.My boyfriend and I were excited to try this new restaurant for his birthday. I made a reservation and in the special requests noted we were celebrating his birthday and would prefer a booth if possible. They sat us at a table, which was completely fine, but made no mention that they even saw my request for a booth. I previously worked in the restaurant industry for years and always made a point to acknowledge guests reservation request and apologize when the restaurant could not fulfill one of them.It took our server a good 7-8 minutes to come greet us and once he did he asked for our drink order rather than introducing us to the restaurant. Again, not a deal breaker most of the time, but at a brand new restaurant with an upscale feel should have some sort of introduction. The rest of our meal went really well, and the food was OUTSTANDING. We had the grilled octopus and arancini for an appetizer, swordfish(my boyfriend said was OK) and bucatini(which both of us loved) for entrees. I have read some reviews that complain portions were too small, but I really think they were perfect because I was satisfied but not overly stuffed.After dinner our server presented the dessert menu but then left and didn't return for ten minutes. In that time we had decided we would get dessert elsewhere and I put the credit card on the table. Almost immediately the manager came over and grabbed my card and said "Ill take care of that for you" and was off. I was really put-off by the fact that he didn't stop for a second and ask how everything was, and in fact felt completely rushed. I could tell he was trying to flip tables and wanted to speed the process along. Our server then came back and asked if we had decided on dessert, once we told him the manager was running our card his response was "you don't know what you're missing out on". It felt like the right hand didn't know what the left was doing.Overall, I think my biggest disappointment is that NOT ONE person mentioned his birthday. I even had presents in hand, which usually prompts the question "what are we celebrating tonight?" Now let me make it clear, I did not expect a free desert or even a candle in our dessert should we order one. A simple "Happy Birthday" from any one of the encounters we had with staff would have sufficed and made the whole experience more palatable.

My impression was this was another strictly pizza place, but its more of an upscale Italian neighborhood place that has pizza.  The prices are a bit high for everything. I liked the decor it clean and modern, not your typical Italian.  Good cocktail list. I'd likely come back here for a drink when walking by instead of dinner.  The pizzas were super quick but so thin you couldn't grab a slice, fork and knife almost required.  Good but anything special for the price. I don't think I'll be back, I'd rather eat at Spacca Napoli if you want this style.

The rose and grilled octopus were out of this world. Octopus was cooked perfectly. The pizza was ok. Not enough tomatoes per slice, only two small cherry tomatoes. The salad had too many ingredients in our opinion. The service was excellent. I would return for the rose, octopus and try the charcuterie plates next time.

I live in the neighborhood and Coda or CDV as we call it was just what we needed.  A proper adult hip place with food and service to match.  I have been 7 times now including, by accident, opening night.  Last night we had Jamie serving us, he is terrific and guided us through all the specials.  We started with one of the pizza's, they are all amazing.  Then I had the special pasta.  We found a very cool wine to go along with everything.  Ryan, the manager is also great and stopped by several times.  Joe at the bar also made sure to say hello.  You cannot go wrong here, everything is excellent.  Also a great spot to have a quick bit at the bar.  Well done CDV!!  I will be back on Friday...!

The food was amazing...the service was fantastic too. You can tell they are definitely trying their best to make great first impressions and it's working. Billy Lawless was personally greeting customers and making everyone feel welcome. We even got a round of free drinks as the wait was so long for a table (we did not have a prior reservation). They definitely got my repeat business with their authentic service and genuinely good food!!!

Was really impressed with the food and ambience here. Had difficulty getting a table on a Wednesday night at 7:00. Absolutely packed. Sat at the bar with two girlfriends which worked out fine. The fried zucchini appetizer was to die for! Tried a pizza and the meatballs were also a hit.

An honest rating from an honest connaisseur:Service was slow, unpolished, and painfully unaware to the touch points neighborhood restaurant patrons require.Drinks took forever to arrive, and our waiter refused to make eye contact as we tried to flag him down to ask where they were. Had to get the 2 random dudes running around in Italian suits to check on our order (only random because they did not introduce themselves as the managers, check in, or even smile/say hello.)Food was adequate: pizza was poor.The margarita pizza that I ordered was paper thin, unflavored, and only covered with a thin layer of sauce. Barley any cheese. No basil or greens.Our waiter was so comical. When ordering a steak he blundered by refusing to answer what terminology their kitchen associated with 'lightly pink' and when ordering the pizza he made sure to firmly state multiple times that: "I can't make sure to bring the pizza out at the same time as the salad" per our request.The design of the establishment was delightful.Everything else needs to be reassessed -- and investment from The Prophet wouldn't be a bad idea.

I have never been as disappointed with a hot new restaurant than Coda Di Volpe. We've been trying for a month to get a reservation for dinner that wasn't at 4pm or 9pm. We walk in and the interior is very swank - cool booths and the bar is sleek. Although there are literally two other tables in the entire restaurant the hostess seats us at a 2-top next to one of the only other occupied tables. Next our waiter comes by and asks for drinks or questions. We tell him we need a minute, and don't see him for another 15 mins. This happens throughout the meal. Everything takes forever. The waiter is never around. It takes 30 minutes for a half order of pasta. Vegetable antipasti is the best thing we had. Margarita pizza is undercooked and wet - no. Pasta with red sauce is over cooked and not hot when it comes to our table. Not worth it whatsoever. Save your time and excitement for RPM or even Coalfire. This place doesn't understand good service or good food.

A wonderful addition to the neighborhood-there really is nothing like Coda di Volpe in the Southport Corridor area.The atmosphere is great and the food is delicious and very reasonably priced. My husband and I enjoyed sharing a pizza and a pasta dish as well as a bottle of wine. It was a perfect spot for a date night out.

The place looks great, there's a crowd and a lot of energy so go there for the ambience but not for the food. I have been to Southern Italy many times and my in-laws are from there, so the so-called southern Italian theme is a blatant lie. Between four guests we had a good sampling of the menu. The salads and cooked dishes (pork, beef) were ok, nothing special. And the pizza... A disgrace to call that chewy shapeless blob with ingredients thrown onto it a pizza (we had 2 different kinds). Add to that very small servings of wine and hefty prices, this place is an absolute zero for food when there are great authentic Italian places all around the city. 2 stars, one for the looks, comfort and atmosphere, the other for the pleasant service.

Excellent experience.  Our reservation time was honored immediately even though the restaurant was very full.  Our waiter Mike was friendly, very knowledgable, and helpful in making some great wine selections.  The food was excellent, and the timing of service was perfect.  Also while I love how family friendly Southport is, it was refreshing to have dinner at a restaurant for grown ups, without kids screaming in the background (we had a 9:15 reservations so not sure if earlier times were similar).  Looking forward to many more meals here, this place is a step up for Southport.

Tried this restaurant last night. The food was mixed. The pork dish we had, delicious. The grilled octopus we did not like at all. It was fishy and had too many flavors. Salad had too little dressing and was unsalted. Overall just so-so.Here's the big turn off. The drinks. They advertise great drinks and great wine but the pour size is tragic. The wine I ordered was filled maybe 1/3 of the glass for $14. And my friends vodka rocks was 2 oz!  I don't know what that's about except for making money. It's certainly not about satisfying customers. I felt so ripped off!!!
What an amazing place!!! Simply great service and all the food that we tried was right on point, and we tried a lot! Lol great crafted drinks and thanks Ronn for the great hospitality.
Labor Day treat. Food was delicious. I will definitely go back the next time i am in town visiting. Great local hot spot for those who live in Southport.

5th times the charm? Not quite. Such a beautiful atmosphere, and I love the light works cocktail, but besides the flatbread the food is absolutely inedible. Not a picky eater here, and I live in the neighborhood, was so excited for the open, have given Coda di Volpe so many chances. I have done the leg work here- the octopus is chunky, no finesse or flavor, the pork pasta special was so oily and tasteless I couldn't even take 2 bites, the chicken was basic and dry, the mushroom flatbread was the only thing decent. Today was the last straw, tuna panzanella? Try albacore canned tuna on a grocery store spring mix. Go for the atmosphere and wine, then go home and  order take out.

I hosted a rehearsal dinner for 14 people last week, and was impressed with the experience from beginning to end. The executive staff was most accommodating, our servers were engaging and attentive, and the ambiance of the room is sophisticated and welcoming. Best of all is the food, especially the pizzas. Hghly recommended.

I wanted to love Coda di Volpe. I live in the neighborhood and love the Gage and the Dawson, so I thought this restaurant would be a slam dunk for me, but it wasn't. My husband and I do plan to give it another try as they may need to iron out some of the kinks. We came for dinner last week Saturday with my parents and nephews, so we had a party of 6. The server took our drink order and the drink runner only brought out 4 of the 6 drinks. Our server noted the error and said he would correct it right away. He returned to the table only to 'confirm' the drinks that my Mom and Dad had ordered and not to actually drop off the missing drinks. It took at least 5 minutes for their drinks to show up. Ok, no big deal.. Unfortunately, things went downhill from there on the service. I had ordered a drink and finished it right when the appetizers came out. My husband was also almost finished with his drink as well. No one came by to ask us if we wanted another drink. When the apps were finished, the server stopped by to pick up the plates. I asked him if I could order a glass of wine, he said yes but that he would have to come back. He never came back to take my wine order. I had to flag down one of the managers for her to get me a glass of wine. My husband also had to ask for another drink instead of someone noticing that his has been sitting empty. After we finished our main entrees, our plates were slow to be cleared away. We waited quite some time after our entrees were finished for our server to return with dessert menus. We all ordered dessert, finished the desserts, and were ready for the check. We sat for a good 10 mins. (I checked my watch.) Our server never came by our table and no one even noticed that we were sitting there with empty dessert plates waiting to leave. We had to flag someone down to get our server to come over. By that time, we were all pretty annoyed and my Mom provided her card right away and asked for the check. The response we received from the server should have been something like: Right Away! but he actually asked us if we were sure we did not want anything else.. maybe coffee? Come on. I'm not usually super picky like this, but when your total bill is $350, you expect more than this. I also know that the service at the Gage and the Dawson is fantastic, so I was expecting more. Now I'll talk about the food. The food was not spectacular. The only spectacular entree was the branzino. My Mom raved about it. My Dad did like the sausage pizza and my nephew liked the octopus. The Insalata Mista was good and well dressed. the Broccoli di Cicco was very salty. My husband and I ordered the margherita pizza. It was ok, but the middle of the pizza was undercooked and totally floppy. My nephews each got the steak. They said it was about a 6/10. They also ordered the braised beef pasta and they said it was bland. These are teenage boys who like meat and potatoes, so for them to say it was bland means it really was pretty bland. We asked which two desserts were the best and ordered the buddino and the cassata. They both were pretty average and nothing spectacular. I want this restaurant to be amazing, so I'm going to come back in a few months and hope that these kinks are ironed out.

This place is amazing.  My wife and I have been there twice now and it hasn't disappointed.  It's like being in a nice downtown/river north spot in Lakeview.  I love Gemini and Gauge.  The owners of those spots  know their craft very well and have continued it here. We were also impressed by the fantastic wine recommendations we received from Mike Blanco.  Seems to be the best around.  Try the lemon slushy drink as well!!!  Enjoy!!!!!!!!

My husband and I tried this place on 9/2/16.The ambiance and service were on point.  The interior of the restaurant is really beautiful and luxe.  We sat inside, but outdoor seating also looked great - they have cute lights strung up outside that look great at night.The food was really good.  We started with roasted carrots which were served over a tasty sheep's milk sauce.  The portion was generous, but the dish seemed a little expensive ($13) for the simplicity.  Next, we had the Diavola pizza, which was cooked Neapolitan style and served with kitchen scissors for cutting and serving.  The crust was perfect, thin in the middle and fluffy and light on the edges with great flavor.  We liked the toppings too (cheese and a red pepper reduction), but agreed we would try a different pizza next time.  We finished with the beef cheek pasta which I loved.  The meat was tender and salty and the pasta was fresh.  It was my favorite dish of the night and the only one I would definitely order on our next visit.  We opted to get ice cream across the street because none of the desserts called our name, but I'm hoping the Sicilian cassata makes its way back to the dessert menu because I would love to try it!

Ugh...What can I say. We live in the neighborhood and *really* wanted to love this place. But, we experienced serious service issues. Wine came out AFTER the first app. Entrees came out BEFORE second app. And, grilled veggies (second course) came out AFTER everything. We waited a few weeks to try this place to give time to work out service kinks, but not quite there yet. In sum, food was solid, but service was nonexistent. Only redeeming quality was manager making his rounds.

Yes, yes yes. Wonderfully tasty cocktails. Terrific, friendly, and helpful wait-staff. Delightfully unique and intimate setting. The Violet Hour is everything I ever wanted in a cocktail lounge.My only complaint was that the wait to get in was more than an hour long (it was Saturday at 10:30pm). Next time, I'll come early.The cocktails are amazing and strong. In fact, I didn't even realize how strong until after my second. Phew! Also, they're not super cheap ($13 a cocktail) but damn are they worth it. The menu changes seasonally, I was told, so there's something to look forward to next time I come back... which will be very soon.

Even back in Manila (that's where I'm from), I really like exploring bars and speakeasies where I can hangout with my close friends.Before going to Chicago, I looked up some bars that I have to go to and The Violet Hour got my attention.First, I like its concept. This bar is not easily located because the mural right outside is being changed. When I went there last night, some letters of the alphabet were painted on the wall. I didn't even notice the door, until some people went out... and there was a line right outside.Second, I like how they named their drinks. It was really unique and it makes you think as to why they called the drinks like that.Lastly, I just love that kind of vibe. It's dark inside but it gives you that intimate feeling when you are with someone.I would definitely recommend this place to my friends back home!

I can't think of one negative thing to say about Violet Hour at all.  I love so many aspects about this place.  The ever changing murals on the front of this bar are always beautiful and well done.  The vibe of the Violet Hour is swanky and romantic.  I have come with one of my friends before, but I think that the Violet Hour is a great setting for a date.  I recommend coming early in the evening if you want to avoid a line. One time my friend and I were in the area, and we came about 20 minutes before they opened (first in line, YAY!), and by the time 6pm rolled around, at least 15-20 people were behind us.There are many cocktails to choose from at the Violet Hour, and the servers make picking a drink easier.  I've ordered from the regular menu, but I've also had them create a cocktail for me. One time I was craving a White Russian type cocktail, but there wasn't one like this on the menu at the time. The server went over the ingredients they had on hand to create a cocktail similar to a White Russian, and the drink was great ! They really can accommodate any drink tastes. The ambiance, cocktails, and service makes this place a true gem.

We came in on a friday 7pm  and were promptly seated, service was excellent, drinks superb! Great location with a large variety of drinks, Can't wait to come back and try more!  Drop by if u r In Chicago and into craft cocktails!

"The Big Bang Theory (not the TV show) is the constant expansion of the Universe starting from a point of singularity. If you were to extrapolate this theory to Chicago's vibrant bar scene The Violet Hour (VH) would be that point of singularity. Yes there were bars before VH and there might have even been some that actually used artesianal methods such as freshly squeezed juice-Matchbox perhaps-but it was VH that put Chicagoan's and the nation on blast that we could be more than just an Old Style and cheap whiskey drinking town. Once that was discovered cocktail bars have been popping up in droves. Lost Lake, GreenRiver, Mezcaleria Las Flores, Sparrow, Arbella etc. being the planets and stars of that ever-expanding universe, were all created by that one point of singularity.Who would have thunk that Chicagoans possessed a more sophisticated palate. VH became the playground for those that were looking to experiment and/or showoff these enhanced palates. VH is often described as a speakeasy, which is difficult to grasp considering speakeasys of the time were often small, cramped, dumpy shoeboxes with barely drinkable liquor. However VH is hidden behind a giant handcrafted mural, using local artists, and you wouldn't know it's there unless you know it's there. Additionally it's superdark inside so I guess this qualifies enough to keep the speakeasy trend going. Inside you are transported to a more pre-20's era Parisian style escape from all the huhbub of the close by Milwaukee-North-Damen intersection and the Big Star crowd. Once inside gigantic beautiful velvet curtains, super hi-back chairs, and chandeliers await your thirsty ambitions.Here well-crafted classics along with more progressive cocktails litter the menu. All fresh and top notch ingrediants are used. Currently late August 2016 their summer menu is broken into three columns. Shaken drinks, Stirred drinks, and notable VH Classics. I must say I am more of a stirred drinks kind of fly guy, however the "Sterile Animal" on the Shaken side was quite good. Highlighted by Leatherbee Gin and Rhubarb, it was almost a sour-y drink with a hint of sweetness. Not usually my kind of drink but I really did enjoy it. On the stirred side I tried "Travails of the Swamp Thing" which is a Bourbon drink similar to a Manhattan. Again, excellent but put-hair-on-your-chest strong. Never did try from their VH Classics, however I have been here a few times now and every drink has been spot on.VH may be the point of singularity that sparked Chicago's cocktail revolution, but just like in the world of Quantum Physics where the moon and stars are studied but not the original point, VH often gets forgotten in Chicago's high stakes bar game. The new kids on the block with their themed style bars (Queen Mary) and bars with a spirit speciality ( Mezcaleria Las Flores) get all the accolades and attention. I'm telling you don't sleep on VH, the drinks still rival any bar this city has to offer with an interior that is awe-inspiring after all these years.

The Violet Hour provided one of the coolest cocktail experiences I've ever had. I had heard of Violet Hour in conversations about Chicago, but didn't really know what to expect before going there.First, the door is hidden in plain view. It's basically just a door-shaped chunk of a wall it's in. The bar commissions a local artist to redesign the wall every few months and the door is camouflaged within the art. If you look closely you can see the outline when walking by. There are no reservations taken for the bar, so once you get there you must wait. If there are no available seats, you wait outside the door in a line for people to come out. I kinda like this because it helps to build a little bit of anticipation.It's pretty dark inside and all tables are lit by candlelight, so it's got a swanky feel about it. There are a few "House Rules" to abide by. No cellphones usage allowed (Why I didnt get a picture of anything), no "bombs," everyone needs proper attire. This helps keep the feel in there speakeasy-ish and classy. I'm a fan.As for the drinks, there are quite a few specialty cocktails they have made up, as well as an extensive list of classics you can order. I wish I could remember what all was in the drink I ordered but I just know it was mezcal, was spicy, and was delicious. They can also whip you something up randomly if you want! The servers seem to have an excellent knowledge on the drinks they are serving, too. So if you go in there completely blind, they can lead you in the right direction if you tell them what you like.If you're looking for a fun spot to have a drink that's not loud, hot, and crowded, this is it!

After having this place on my list of places to visit for years, going to other speakeasy type places and going to two of their sister establishments I'm still pretty impressed with it. Sure a lot of their schtick is kind of the new normal now: hidden entranceways, retro cocktails, dim lighting-they've definitely lightened up in there. No pun intended, the lighting was dim but not the pitch black that it apparently used to be.The cocktail list is pretty good, but I asked for something off menu that kind of stumped our server. I gave her the ingredients and she took it and ran, turned out to be a close approximation of what I wanted.I liked it and enjoyed it but having tried other places like this it's not as the overwhelming experience I thought it would be, it's still a good place for drinks.

The Violet Hour is going strong, and it's time for another update.They have changed the menu, and I do NOT LIKE IT. Rather than organizing the drinks by spirit, they're now organized by vague categories, like shaken, stirred, and "classics." What's more, they no longer actually list all of the ingredients in the cocktails, instead giving impressionistic descriptions and analogies like a hip sommelier. Maybe I am being old fashioned, but I would just like you to tell me what you are putting in a glass, and let me decide whether it seems good, bad, or intriguing.On the plus side, if you go from 6-8 on weeknights, they have an absinthe service, which features a fabulous absinthe cocktail (the frappe), and a really really good french absinthe, complete with spider/spoon/sugar/water setup. The french absinthe we tried was so good we didn't really want to dilute it, but the Colorado absinthe was sort of vile, and we were grateful for the apparatus. (It is fair to ask why we ordered Colorado absinthe, but isn't it also fair to ask why the Violet Hour served it?)One thing hasn't changed: the cocktails are still thirteen dollars.Despite my complaints, it's still five stars.

Cocktail bars are all the rage in Chicago it seems and this seems to be one of the hippest places to be on a Saturday night. The door is hidden in a mural which changes frequently with different works of art. Not too hard to find like some speakeasies (thank goodness) because there is a sign outside asking you to wait to be seated - and there was a long line. However, we were seated quickly and the waitstaff was very professional (we had doughnuts and requested that we finished them before we were let in).Service was impeccable here - they were quick and prompt. One of our party accidentally broke a glass and they quickly cleaned and bought out a new one without even being asked (not expected because it was clearly our fault).The one thing that stops this place from being 5 stars is the music. It is SO loud. Hard to hear a few people away which is a problem in a group larger than two. And it detracts from the experience. It is dim inside with gorgeous high curtains which probably absorb a lot of the sound as well. Maybe I'm getting old, but loud music like that gives me a headache.The have an extensive liquor and specialty cocktail drinks which were all priced at 13$. Nice because all cocktails were even.

I literally wandered in here in quite a state and had this more piquant version of my favorite cocktail, the venerable gin gin mule. I believe it had some sort of berry thing going on. My memory fails me though. The vibe of the place is pretty swanky and this would be a good date spot.

Cocktails were indeed quite good. However, I agree with William B. that it is lame that they don't list the ingredients of the cocktails on the seasonal menu. The ones in the regular menu do list them though. I love the ridiculously tall chairs; they make it more cozy and private. :) I had the Circles of Confusion cocktail from the seasonal menu, and it was very light and tasty.

I came here with a group to celebrate a new job, and none of us have been here before so we didn't know what to expect. This is a hidden Chicago bar in that there is no store front or windows; the place is behind a huge mural right across the street from Big Star. To find the door, look for the light above it. Luckily I knew were to go since no one in my party did.Once inside you're held in a dimly lit waiting room. There is a sign that has all the rules of the place hanging on the wall. Luckily, there was only one group waiting ahead of us; we waited only 7 minutes before being seated. You're taken through very heavy dark curtains into the actual bar, and you're immediately hit with the very chill and romantic ambience. They have high back chairs and ottomans for you to sit on around a small table, and they provide you with cold water in a glass flask. The menu lists all the drinks they have, in addition to the small list of foods as well.Drinks: spot on. For what you're paying, you are getting your money's worth. I had the Aviator and my friends got an old fashioned and the Juliet and Romeo. All were fantastic. Everything in his place seems slower and laid back, like you're not feeling rushed to get out of there. This place is perfect for a date night with your significant other.Note: you CAN use your phone in this place, but you're not allowed to take phone calls. You can take pics or play on your apps all you like, but just don't talk on the phone. The host (bouncer?) explained that this place wants you to engage in conversation with the the people you're with, but they respect that your phone is a part of you nowadays.A definite try in Chicago.

I give it 4 stars for the drinks. We enjoyed all of them and each one had the perfect amount of alcohol. One person in our party ended up disliking one of the drinks and they were able to swap it out for one she liked - huge plus! Our waitress had a condescending attitude towards us - which was weird. She also got one of my drinks wrong but I did not feel like complaining on that one.Oh well, that does not take away from their fantastic drinks. The servers were excellent.

Loved this place! Mostly for the ambience but the drink menu was awesome too! It was a wait but that was ok as the weather was good outside. Fun to come with a few people or as a couple if you want to have a bit of romance.Love that you can't use your phone in the bar! you actually have to talk to the people you are with!

This place starting off just from the outside view caught my attention. The door to go inside seems to be well hidden because it looks just like a common mural, but it's actually the enterence. FYI this is a pretty classy place so there is a dress code of no gym shoes and other stuff such as no phone calls once you're inside. But inside starts off pretty dark, but you'll get use to it and notice the din lighting and the location is really nice. A bunch of seats are also around in the area where ur seated so it nice and comfy with old style rich people chair..Servers came around quiet often to get drink orders and was very nice and polite and answering any questions you may have.The drinks are where it really shines!! Many different and what seems to be there very own creations of cocktails are out of this state. Gotta give this place as a go to spot to just a nice get together going out place to be. Seriously.

The Violet Hour has a beautiful ambiance and sitting inside makes you feel like you're transported to a whole new world. You totally forget about the busy streets of the Damen intersection and even all the partying that's going on at Big Star across the street. The door to the Violet Hour blends in beautifully with whatever mural happens to be painted and I've walked by countless times before I even realized this was where the Violet Hour stood.My friend and I arrived in line at just past 8 on a Saturday night. The wait wasn't more than 20 minutes so it was very manageable. The way the chairs are arranged kind of made it feel like mirrors at a fun house or something so I thought that was a bit strange. It's also a little weird that I can hear the conversation of the group sitting right behind me!Drink-wise, anything at the top of each category (gin, rum, whiskey, brandy, etc) is not as strong. I got the pisco kid which was not bad but loved my friend's whiskey based drink.
