Our server did a great job of taking care of our larger group for drinks and making sure we had our kitchen orders in before it closed.There is also a coffee/bomboloni/gelato takeout window on the street, for donuts on the go, how dangerous for my wallet. I love Bar Siena so far and can see making this a regular go-to spot!

Come here because Au Cheval had the longest wait time.We were just going to come for drinks but ended up eating here insteAd.I got the lobster eggs Benedict and loveddddddd it. I highly recommend it. Get it get it!!!!! You have to you will not regret it!!!!!!I also ordered the Bloody Mary. It's straight up a meal.

Part 3 of our West Loop impromptu classy cocktail bar crawl landed us at Bar Siena.  I would really like to come back for brunch or dinner sometime, because the one cocktail I had was incredible!For one thing, I appreciate cocktails without fussy-sounding names.  The ingredients are fussy enough, and the more I drink, the less I can remember what I want.  Bar Siena's menu mimics that of Siena Tavern.  Order the No. 1, No. 2, No. 3, and so on.  I had the No. 1, a cocktail with gin, green tea, and mint.  It was the perfect post-brunch drink.The inside of the restaurant reminded me of a sports bar in disguise.  It didn't scream "SPORTS!" and I loved the comfy, half-moon shaped booth with a view of the bar.Our waitress was great, and the host, Manny, is super energetic and welcoming; he's the perfect personality at a hip spot like Bar Siena.

Was supposed to check out another restaurant near that area but that one was closed on the Labor Day. Instead I decided to give this one a try since it also has decent reviews. Ordered Angel hair and clam with the illusive beer (grapefruit shandy). These two go well together. I would say the pasta was medium not too special. The beer was very light and refreshing, great choice for a summer night. I recommend the beer if you like citrus.

Love this spot. Its on Randolph St. where there is whole load of great restaurants and bars but I somehow always end up here. The atmosphere is laid back. Its owned by Chef Viviani who even came by our table and said hi. Hes been on the Food Network many times, big fan of his. The food is delicious. They basically got your standard Italian fare,  you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu. I think this spots best to day drink or chill on a nice summer day, like on the patio, which fills up quickly.

3 1/2 stars. Really enjoyed the atmosphere. Good service. Started off with the parmesan truffle potato skins. They were very greasy but i liked the consistency it had. It was crunchy like Chicharrones. The dipping sauce was a good touch. For dinner i had the short rib Lasagna after hearing a couple ppl recommend it. Didnt really care for it. The short rib kind of gets lost in the Lasagna. My date had the Gnocchi. That was pretty good. Wish they put a little more sausage in there because the sausage was good. Also tried the Carne pizza it was average. It light, soft and good taste. If i go back it will be for the Sangria and the bombolinis.

A friend & I came in for dinner last Friday night & dined at the upstairs bar where we were quickly greeted by Nora. She was so nice & informative about both the wine we were considering and the food menu. She suggested the meatballs & short rib lasagna which were both absolutely amazing! We also shared a prosciutto & fig pizza which was equally wonderful. We ended our nights with the lemon rose boozy dessert & Nora even sent us out a couple bombolonis! I can't wait to dine here again & will probably choose to sit at the bar as the service was impeccable!

This place is all around great. It's a great place to bring friends for happy hour, great for a date, great for a quick and delicious dessert at the walk up window. My favorite thing on the menu is the Taleggio Focaccia appetizer. So good with a glass of red wine.As far as ambience goes, sitting on the patio is nice and inside they have fun music.A note on the desserts... The gelato is super delicious - variety of yummy flavors. The bomboloni (spelling?) are really good too. My fiancé is obsessed with the Italian ice. Three options, all fabulous.

I came here on Saturday night to celebrate my boyfriends job promotion and kick off my birthday week. We really enjoyed the food and drinks! We enjoyed the food in tapas style so we all had the opportunity to try a variety of items.Our waiter was really nice and helpful. The  service overall was on point. I am knocking one star off because the hosts were not the nicest and I didn't appreciate their attitudes or lack of help when we told them that we did not have a reservation. We arrived at 5pm which I believe is way before hitting the Chicago dinner rush but despite what I think, they told us we had to finish our dinner by 6:30 or wait two hours... We were already dressed up and starving and decided to agree to their time limit. You all know this place is not the cheapest place on the strip so it was hard to thoroughly enjoy our dining experience with the time constraint on our mind. Not to mention that our waiter pointed our "time constraint" twice. Not cool.As we wrapped up at 6:30, there were at least 5-6 tables all empty around us.Make a reservation--lesson learned. All in all, the food was really good and our waiter was very kind and friendly.

I could sit here and write a novel about all the things I loved about Bar Siena but I am going to keep this short. The place is beautiful and I am a sucker for trees inside a restaurant. And by trees I don't mean the ones at Rainforest cafe, I mean well made ones that dont look tacky. I loved the service, from the hosts to the server and the bussers. And the food, ah the food! We had so much that I can't sit here and name all if it but the salmon, duck mac and cheese and kale salad were among my favorites. I definitely plan on returning.

So, I really wanted to love Bar Siena, but it was pretty lackluster for me. :( It wasn't bad, but it was nothing that stood out either.I've been to Bar Siena a few times for drinks and that's about it. Finally returned for lunch on  a Sunday afternoon with my husband and some friends.We started out with the Stracchino Cheese Fritters with the apricot mostarda. These were good, nothing i would crave...but, good. For our entrees, the table got a chicken parm sandwich, meatball sandwich, and the short rib hash. I think we all liked our meals, but nothing wowed us.For dessert, we tried the bombolonis (donuts). They are $3/each and you pick the flavor. I got the chocolate fudge and I honestly didn't like it. :( If you've read any of my other reviews...you know I'm a dessert freak. And this one was disappointing. The donut had a strange after taste. Actually, maybe I just didn't like the chocolate fudge filling. Maybe the other flavors are better?I wouldn't go out of my way to return to Bar Siena. The service was good, but I didn't find the food to be anything special. I think it's more of a drinks type of place for me.

Bar Siena is awesome...so awesome that it's hard to get a reservation at a prime hour,  so make your reservation a couple of weeks in advance and drool over that menu.The restaurant/bar is super cute. I love the décor. I love the atmosphere.For starters we had the Roasted Meatballs pomodoro, hand dipped ricotta, crostini. The meatballs are huge and awesome.We also shared the  Shaved Zucchini and Spiced Chickpea with arugula and farmer's cheese. This salad is amazing! Get it. Spicy chickpeas? What? YES!For our entrée we shared the Prosciutto Fig spiced pistachio, taleggio, local honey. This is my second prosciutto pizza ever and I love it. I'm craving this pizza. Sweet and savory.The cocktail list sounded amazing, but we were in the mood for a bottle of wine...next time...next time.I can't wait to come back.

Hi again... So, Bar Siena. I gave them 4 stars for the over all experience. Service was good, ambiance inside and the patio were lovely and the food was good too. I would suggest for a lunch or casual dinner.I had the Sweet Corn Ravioli, with mushrooms and truffle butter. Delicious! Slightly salty and sweet. I loved this dish, I just wish there was more of it. My biggest downfall with ravioli, I always want more!My girlfriend had the Chicken Parmesan sandwich. This thing was ginormous! This was two meals in one, I would suggest sharing. Note, the house made mozzarella was a very nice touch.For dessert I had a classic Bomboloni and the Lemon Lavender Honey gelato. This gelato blew me away. So refreshing and creamy. I highly recommend trying this paired with an espresso. Perfection!

We tried Bar Siena with two other couples a few weeks back.  It was our first time there - though I had been to Siena Tavern before.  Like most of Randolph Street, Bar Siena is a "happening" place and definitely gets very crowded and very loud.  Fortunately, for us, we were seated upstairs for dinner.  I cannot imagine trying to eat and converse with anyone downstairs.  Even upstairs got a bit loud, however.Drinks-wise, I had a strawberry cocktail that was really good and had a nice kick.  It was very nicely done and I would definitely order that again.As for food, we ordered lots of dishes for the table to share.  We had the Octopus - which I really liked with the shishito peppers.  We also had the oysters (which I did not partake in), two different pizzas (which were both good), Sweet Corn Ravioli (which the whole table loved), Short Rib Lasagna (which was good - but definitely is much too rich to not share with the group),  Maine Lobster Agnolotti, and Skirt Steak with mashed potatoes (both good).  It was a bit too much food for six people - given that we wanted dessert, too, but everyone wanted to try different things.We then finished with several varieties of bomboloni (donuts), gelato, and the nutella calzone.  The donuts are huge - full size donuts.  I could have sworn that the donuts at Siena Tavern were the munchkin size and that's what I was expecting here.  Nope - huge.  I personally didn't like any of them that had filling - I actually liked the original the best.  The donut itself was very sweet and deliciously good.  To me, the cream/inside filling ruined it, but I think I'm in the minority.  The gelato was fine, but the Nutella Calzone was warm and very good.Our server was very good and quite attentive in explaining items to us.  But at the same time, when we were done eating and paying, they were hinting that it was time to go so they could seat other people.IF the place wasn't so loud and busy and if I lived in the area, I would go back b/c I did like the food.  Unfortunately, I'm rarely on Randolph and usually when I'm out to dinner, I like to talk to the people I'm with.  I couldn't quite do that at Bar Siena.
A decent place for a meal but I found the food to be generic Italian without any real soul.  The setting is comfortable and lively.  The bar looked like a fun place for a drink.  A bit pricey too.
Love this place and only been once! Great atmosphere, drinks and food! So excited to try more menu options.

My go to place for girls night! Was there recently and our server Danielle suggested a wine and pizza and apps for us to share. She was right-prosciutto fig pizza was amazing!! I was hesitant to see honey on a pizza but I am so glad we took our servers advice.The place is beautiful, great for people watching and in such a fun area. Service and food were excellent!

4.5 stars for Bar Siena! I highly recommend checking this restaurant out and I will definitely be back.First, I want to give a shout out to my awesome server Mariah. She gave us great insight on the menu, what her favorite dishes were and what was popular with the guest who dine here.Second, the location is perfect. Obviously, everyone knows that 80% of the cool restaurants are located in the West Loop.Third, the food is delicious and the desserts are SO DAMN GOOD I probably would have to think twice about sharing if the Big Guy upstairs asked for a bite.Food*Parmesan Truffle Potato Skins - good, but wouldn't have been worth it if it wasn't for the lemon garlic aioli which made these good. 3.5 stars.*Meats & Cheeses (Mortadella/Dodge City & Truffle Tremor-Goat/Bad Axe-Sheep) - so good. The Mortadella was my favorite paired with the Bad Axe-Sheep cheese. 4 stars.*Short Rib Lasagna - I would have never thought to mix short ribs and lasagna, but I'm glad the creative minds in the kitchen of Bar Siena did. 4 stars.*Prosciutto Fig Pizza - is a must try. The honey they drizzle over the pizza makes it that much more attractive to the taste buds. 5 stars.Desserts*Nutella Calzone - freaking amazing! Get them get them get them. 5 stars.*Bomboloni - an Italian donut with different filling options. We had the maple buttercream filling and it was delicious. 5 stars.

This place is worth the hype! We came in for a late lunch on Sunday and could only get an inside booth by the bar. Minor quibble - hostess had a real attitude problem: initially she insisted she couldn't seat us, despite the 2 obviously empty booths immediately behind her station. Somehow seating us immediately ended up being less of an inconvenience for her than taking our names down for an outside table, so we were seated immediately. Everything was great after that.We shared the prosciutto fig pizza (which just about every other Yelper ordered) and a fennel sausage calzone. I was initially skeptical about all the positive reviews, but this pizza really is the perfect balance of sweet & savory. Only tiny complaint is the crust was a wee bit greasy. The calzone was heartier and not as amazing. This place is a carb-lover's heaven. We were too stuffed for dessert, even though I really wanted to try everything. our server was efficient and attentive, our water & lemonade glasses never less than 1/2 full. The interior was super cool. On the famous restaurant row already filled with excellent destination restaurants, Bar Siena raises the bar even higher.

Trendy restaurant with great desserts and food!Ambiance: I love that it's very trendy and modern. They have booths, high tops, a bar or regular tables that you can sit at which is nice to have all those options.Food:HIGHLIGHTS:Price point: appetizers and food average $20, dessert averages about $5, wine $9 (not as many options for single glasses though), cocktails $13Appetizer: Grilled octopus & shishitto peppersMain course: Fireball pepperoniDessert: Nutella calzone, smores gelato and vanilla bean custard bomboloni (all good for sharing)Wine: Pertinace BarberaFor an appetizer, one pizza, a beer, a glass of wine and two desserts our bill came to about $65.DETAIL:We came in on a Thursday night since High Five Ramen was a two hour wait. Like everything in the West Loop it had a wait, but for a Thursday at 7:30pm 45 minutes didn't seem too bad. They can take your name and text you when your table is ready, which is nice since the bar was packed so we were able to go elsewhere and grab a drink. Everything we had was phenomenal, no complaints what so ever. The grilled octopus and shishitto peppers does have a bit of a kick to it. I don't have a high tolerance for spicy and it definitely lingered, but nothing that water couldn't tame. The pizza was great, although seemed to be on the pricey side, $18 for a 12 inch thin crust, but I guess it's Chicago and West Loop right? In terms of wine, I wanted to try something new, I love malbecs and pinot noirs so the server recommended a Barbera. It was pretty good, but only got one glass so I could save room for the most important part, dessert. The dessert, SO GOOD. I'm a huge sweets person so I'm critical of them. The smores gelato came recommended by the server, but I also love smores in general so was already eyeing it. Good for 1-2 people. The chocolate portion of the gelato was really good, not too rich. I wished there was more marshmallow to it though. There was pieces of graham crackers in it as well that added to the unique texture. We also had the vanilla bean custard bomboloni. It was difficult to choose only one, I love donuts and wanted everything. There was the right amount of custard in the donut, enough to get a taste. The donut itself came warm and had a sugar coating to it. Good for 1-2 people. On another occasion separate from all that was described previously, I've also had the nutella calzone, delicious, you can never go wrong with anything nutella. The crust of the calzone was nice and flakey and you get two decently sized ones, great for sharing between 2-4 people (depending on how greedy each person is with dessert). I had an order to myself.Service: It was good, for a pizza and an appetizer it came out within half an hour of ordering (probably even less than that). Super quick considering how busy they were.I highly recommend and would definitely go back (especially to try all the donuts and gelato)!

Bar Siena (BS) is far from its initials. =)Ana M was our server. She served us and the tables around us as though we were elegantly dining. The scene is amazing and I can only image how things are at night.SHARE SHARE SHARE! We decided to order our own appetizers and entrees but ended up eating off each other's plate. They prepare everything ahead of time. Cocktails are made like everything else, "patch style", which turns out good because each patch is made with to perfection. Well seasoned (balanced) prepared plates. The chef really took time to outline the menu to meet the needs of advanced diners. If you are looking for a great meal, you've found it.Ana M knew the menu well. She was aware of the needs of the table and we purchased things we regularly wouldn't. Her knowledge of the place is amazing. This place has been open for about a year, and in my opinion it's because of her.The "mule" cocktails are served in a unique cup outside of the standard bronze mugs. The restaurant keeps the Euro feel and I'm sure travelers would feel at home. The wine list is perfecto. The lights outlined as a tree that fills the center of the spot is real dope.Come, enjoy a night with your friends, enjoy a great meal for your soul, and enjoy cocktails for your spirit.

Had the pleasure to dine here last night and I really enjoyed it. First of all we went without reservations and were fortunate to be seated within an hour. While the bar area was crowded it wasn't hard to get a drink at all. Additionally this was our first nice weather weekend so everyone was out and about and it made for a nice crowd. Our waiter was really nice and knowledgeable. The food was thebomb.com( I will retire this phrase at some point in my life don't worry). We started out with the Taleggio Focaccia and the Grilled Octopus andShishito Peppers. Both were great but I will say the focaccia is the stuff dreams are made of. It was that good! For a main dish I got the Sweet Corn Ravioli which I really enjoyed. All in all a very good meal. I cannot wait to return.

Move over Prime & Provisions, DMK Burger and Siena Tavern, the new sibling is getting plenty of well deserved attention and props. And this location is becoming even hotter. It could be called Top Chef alum row. Fabio Viviani is giving Randolph street diners a new place to dine and stalk for openings that are not extremely early or late at night.I am too embarrassed to give a listing of every item I have tried in the short time this place has been open, but I will say I have devoured 95% of them. I listed my favorite items in the "tip" section and took few pictures too. You will notice a few of the pictures were taken after we started to eat them. We could not help ourselves. Dine here and you will understand why.What I loved about this place:- the decor is amazing.- seating; everything from booths, a patio, bar top seating, traditional tables and bistro style tables.- the music rocks. There's a DJ!- the staff members are extremely personable and accommodating- portions are small so you can try lots of them. :-)- you can spike the Italian ice for $5!- reservations are available on Opentable.- the no. 5 cocktail! (I'm a lightweight)- and finally but most importantly, the food is very good. There's something for every palate.My least favorite things:- the fritto misto has too much batter. If you like lots of batter, this is the dish for you. The calamari & shrimp were otherwise delicious.- the patio seating is first come first serve, but it's that way essentially everywhere.

Stopped by for lunch today and am so happy I did. The staff was incredibly friendly and the space was great. The lunch menu was a nice mix of pizza, sandwiches, pasta, and small plates. Having eaten at Siena Tavern, some of the menu items were familiar but overall there was great variety and plenty of option.I had the lobster club and it was stellar! The buttery toasted brioche was a great vehicle for a substantial amount of delicious lobster. The green goddess dressing added such good flavor.  The fries were heavy in the salt for my taste but were perfectly crispy.The pizzas I saw coming out all looked amazing and seeing the gorgeous pizza oven really has me excited for my next trip back!

Not a bad addition to Randolph St.  We were only able to get a reservation for 6pm on a Thursday. We were sat upstairs and were told that all reservations were sat up there. I'd have preferred to sit downstairs but wasn't a big deal.Food was pretty good overall. We started with the octopus. We were told it was one of their more popular apps. It was good but I would have liked a bit more char on it. I still think the octopus at RPM is better.We shared a pizza for our main course. I really like that they let you 1/2 & 1/2 on your pizza.  We did the fig & prosciutto for one 1/2 and margarita for the other. The fog was really good with just a drizzle of honey.  The margarita was just average.  I wouldn't order that one again.For desserts we had a bambino & gelato. All great and loved that you could order just one bambino (doughnut).

Flew into Chicago for a 2 day work trip and wanted to find a fantastic little Italian place and treat myself to a drink and pasta. This place did not disappoint! Had 2 glasses of Prosecco, a side green salad and the lobster pasta (hold the chili flakes). DELICIOUS. Savored every bite, will definitely come back next time I'm in town!

I've been here twice and each time I left desiring more. I feel this place has so much potential, but it just hasn't gotten over the hump. The food and cocktails are solid: meatball appetizer is a must, but none of the menu items wow me. Service has varied. The wait staff is awesome. Both gentlemen I had were attentive, helpful and fun. The hostess on the other hand should be more mindful on how they handle situations. The first visit, I had to go up to the hostess after 45 minutes to inquire about our wait and she said she attempted to call and there was no answer. I showed her I had no record of a call and then stated that we were sitting at the bar (which she suggested) and within plain view. The second visit, my group of four was seated outside, but a chair was missing. Instead of grabbing a chair from an empty table next to us, she walked away to find a chair, but ended up still taking the chair from the table next to us. My friend stood up at the table waiting while she figured this very simple fix out. I'm not sold on returning back.
I went here for restaurant week last week and it was great. The $44 dinner was worth it. The short rib was amazing and fell off the bone. I would also recommend the Nutella calzone!

Went to Bar Siena yesterday with a girlfriend.Love their taleggio focaccia - the waitress suggested putting prosciutto inside - mind blown!  Definitely try it this way!We ordered the wings - the wings were good... not the best.... I probably wouldn't order these again.Then we got the skirt steak - really delicious.   The cook on it was perfect.... the flavours were awesome... the only weird thing.... there were whole cloves of garlic just on the plate..... thought that was a little strange as I would not eat a whole clove of garlic.All-in-all.... another successful meal at Bar Siena!

I was pretty underwhelmed. I think Siena Tavern is delicious and I expected to feel that way here but I left thinking I wouldn't come back.Stracciatella (sp?) (fried cheese curds) were a bust- no flavor, just dull fried blobs. No gooey cheesy saltiness. Pass.Husband had the meatballs and declared them passable. The one appetizer that was DELICIOUS (and frankly the one item that was delicious) was the parmesan truffle potato skins. Yes- this I would come back for. Maybe.We had a salad that was pretty good- date and walnut, with endive I think. Tasty but nothing you can't get anywhere else.Lobster agnolotti was not that good. No distinct flavors. I don't know. I just was not feeling it.It's pretty loud (I feel like the oldest 34 year old in the world, saying that) but I just point it out in case someone's looking for an intimate meal- I wouldn't recommend this place based on volume. But it had a cool vibe, nice decor, and nice service. Next time, though, I'll stick to Siena Tavern aka the real thing.
Steven was awesome!! Great drinks! Great company.  Amazing time. Love this place. Food is great ambiance is perfect. Service is 10/10. Highly recommend this awesome place!

Service alone is 5 stars! I had the pleasure of dining here recently with my girlfriend. She was visiting from out of town and we wanted a chill yet happening place for dinner and drinks. Arriving at 7pm in a freezing cold Tuesday evening I thought there would be tables a plenty....wrong! Good thing I walked in when I did and snagged the last high top in the bar. The vibe is cool and contemporary and the giant lit tree smack dab in the middle of the joint is different and definitely something you won't see elsewhere in the city.There were three of us dining so we decided to split a couple dishes. My girlfriend has a dairy allergy so we went ahead and ordered the prociutto fig pizza sans cheese (based on our waitress' opinion). We also ordered the sweet corn ravioli and poached pear salad. Food arrives, pizza looks delicious EXCEPT dunn dun dunnnn...there is cheese on it. My gf pointed it out to the waitress and she apologized and said they would make another one pronto. Ok great thank you....then the manager (or so I thought) comes over to apologize again and see if my friend was ok. He was very professional and extremely nice! He even sent over a free drink to her. To top it all off, they let us keep the faulty pizza with cheese for no charge....which hello I was in heaven because come on who wants pizza without cheese. The kitchen's mistake quickly became my cheesy gain.Oh the ravioli is an absolute must...so very rich and flavorful. A great comfort dish. The salad was equally delicious!Bar Sienna exceeded my expectations with their phenomenal customer service and tasty food. I will most definitely be back when the weather warms up to hopefully snag a seat on the outdoor patio. PRIME Randolph St. location ladies and gents;)

Service: Ana was not only knowledgeable (a very difficult trait to have in this day and age) but tasteful in her recommendations. So many servers these days fluff dishes they've never tried.  She deserves an award for her service. Water was never below half full. Tended to us like good shepherd would her sheep. Kind of waitress that could suggest newcomers the best doughnut flavors. Doesn't hesitate.  6/5FoodAbsolutely amazing pizza. a bit salty, we ordered the fireball pepperoni. Other than that, great flavor. Toasted seared pepperoni is something new I'm not used to. Saving grace. None was left. 4/5Salmon, medium.  Very tender cut, on this outstanding white been and mustard puree/ mash whatever. Great blend of flavors. Waitress had suggested it. None was left. 5/5Brussels sprouts. Wow. Seared in the best of ways, (I love them charred), had these amazing ham/bacon/balsamic/caramelized sweetness tinge. I could probably have an entree of just those bits. I personally made sure none was left. Wasn't up to the table! 5/5Doughnuts. 3 for 9 bucks. Nutella, cookies and creme, mixed berry. Initially ordered a vanilla creme, she suggested to replace it with the nutella. This was probably the MVP play of the night. Wow. Would come back for just these next time I'm in Randolph for a snack.Drinks: ordered #7. Watered down mojito. Not the biggest fan, but not absolutely terrible, probably just wasn't worth the price point for a cocktail. 3.5/5Vibe and general housekeeping: casual dinner. Not pretentious. Clean. Date night-able. Family friendly. 5/5Price is at the sweet spot. Worth the money, overall. I still need to try the lasagna on next run. So good I wouldn't mind going alone for palette sake.Overall: 4.5/5

Asked a gal pal where she wanted to celebrate her birthday, and she chose Bar Siena in the West Loop.   I don't  normally visit a restaurant this soon after it opens, before it has a chance to work out the kinks, but this wasn't an issue here.  Bar Siena already has it all together... the food, the service and the vibe were nearly perfect.The main dining area is upstairs, but it was lunch and we wanted something more casual.  The restaurant has lots of tables outside, but the temp was over 90.  So we chose a bistro table inside the front door, across from the bar.  Not sure the big screen TVs add anything to the experience, but there was no audio so we could ignore them.We ordered three items to share, and I can highly recommend all of them.  Started with the grilled octopus with escarole in a chili sauce.  The octopus was so tender I cut it with a fork, and the sauce had a real kick.  Next, the wedge salad.  Not anything like your typical wedge, this one had pickled red onions and was topped with a generous amount of creamy burrata cheese. Yummy.Finally, the burger.   I consider myself a burger connoisseur of sorts, and it takes something extra to impress me.  Two things set this apart... the bun seemed like it had just come out of the oven, and the roasted garlic mayo gave it a very distinctive taste.  It's not the best burger I've ever had, but I'd place it in the top ten.  The fries were great, too.By then we were full, but I rarely pass up dessert, so we split the mango Italian ice.   There were chunks of fresh mango, but the overall taste was blah.  And before we could get half-way through it, the ice had melted into a solid chunk.  Not worthy of the restaurant.Mariah, our server, was exceptional.  She was not only friendly, but also very knowledgeable about the menu.  Mariah made sure the food came out of the kitchen at the right times, and she checked in with us often to ask if we needed anything.Already have plans to return for dinner in a few weeks.  I'm going to leave room for a Nutella calzone!

Probably a 3.5 star joint - does all the big things right, but all the little things wrong.Food is outstanding - brunch is the best meal to hit them up for (try the short rib hash - to die for!) but also a great spot to pick up some good pizza and a beer at night.Service is slow as all get up - better order two drinks when the server comes because you might not see him or her for half an hour.  Lots of little imperfections - logistical problems seating people, coffee cream that is cursed (gross!), dirty glasses, etc., but the food carries the day.

Food was great, it's the service that needs improvement.I recommend the short rib lasagna and the smoked potato soup.As far as the service, it took 10 minutes before we got seated even though there were plenty of tables open because we came in before the dinner rush on a Sunday. Also, once seated it took another 15 minutes before a server came to take our drink orders then another 15 minutes for her to come back to take our dinner order. It was also a pain trying to get her attention for drink refills and for the check.I think we'll give this place another try because the food was really good but the service needs a lot of work.

We came to check out the new bar on Randolph and decided to make dinner reservations to get the full experience. We got seated upstairs in the main dining room. The decor is great! There is a large lit up tree that extends from the downstairs all the way up through the bar to light up the upper level (see photo). The downstairs has a lot of energy and I'd definitely come back just for the bar scene!Drinks:  Great selection. The house cocktails are good. The No. 1 (gin based) is so light/refreshing and its got a sour tang to it too! My boyfriend loved his No. 8, and thought the number 2 was just okFood:  Delicious! Seriously, I was very impressed. My boyfriend and I ordered the Fig Prosciutto Pizza. It has honey and figs, but also has thinly sliced prosciutto, which combined gives it this salty, yet sweet flavor. We ordered it because our server recommended it, but there were also a lot of good Yelp reviews about it and I totally agree! We also ordered the Burrata Wedge - it has creamy Burrata and crispy prosciutto. The dressing is also amazing, just an all around splendid salad!Dessert (yes we saved room):  We ordered the Truffle Tremor Goat Cheese (which is actually on the dinner menu), it was creamy, yet strong. Mmm mmm  but the best thing was the Maple Buttercream Bomboloni (donut) - a really delicious salty and sweet dessert, I could have had a few more! We got the gelato too, but I'd stick with the bombolonis!I'm really excited about this new restaurant and I think it'll be a great winter bar/restaurant!

FLAVORS (5 Stars)Here are some personal favorites, tips & tricks-1) Sit at the bar if there are only 2 in your party otherwise sit downstairs2) Order the sweet corn ravioli! You can't go wrong.3) Order a cocktail. The bar tenders are phenomenal at their jobs!SERVICE (5 Stars)The staff here has always been nothing but friendly. The bar tender was amazing! She waiting a good while for my friend and I to decide what we wanted and was super friendly. Her cocktails were killer too!ATMOSPHERE (5 stars)It was a magical night, sitting at the bar looking up at the lights. What can I say I'm a sucker for string lights :) The crowd there was in their mid 20s to 30s just relaxing and having a good time. For the first time in a while there wasn't a creeper in sight so you can definitely let loose with some friendly faces.ACCESSIBILITY (5 Stars)Bar Siena is in the heart of West Loop on Randolph Street! 'nough said!

So I really have only had some appetizers and drinks here, a few times.Love their Parmesan Truffle Potato Skins (could eat several of these myself and be happy) and the Duck Mac n' Cheese.Specialty Drinks are known by numbers, I like #3, but just ask your bartender or waiter/waitress.

I wanted to love it, but for some reason it missed the mark with me. The service was spot on- I do want to say that, but the food was hit or miss to me. Apps were better than pizza and pastasWe ordered a TON of food. We all shared:Taleggio Focaccia - I would order this again (have to say Davantis is better)Roasted Meatballs - these were awesomeGrilled Octopus and Shishito Peppers -- deliciousParmesan Truffle Potato Skins-- totally averageCaesar salad -- cant complain about a caesar salad...Prosciutto Fig Pizza - lacked flavorBurrata and Grilled Eggplant Pizza- lacked flavorSweet Corn Ravioli - lacked flavor -- which is surprising because everyone i was with loved thisShort Rib Lasagna - this was awesomeMaine Lobster Agnolotti - this was good

Right under a 4 but I'll round up.Had reservations for 6:30 Friday evening for two and we were seated promptly upstairs. Place was already quite busy.We got the white tuna crudo and octopus with shishito peppers to start. Both were very good, especially the octopus. I got the gnocchi and friend got the skirt steak. Everything was very tasty and fresh. I thought the dishes I had here were more memorable than ones I had at Siena Tavern. While understanding that the plates are on the small side and meant to be shared and obviously a nice place on Randolph, I still thought the prices were steeper than need be or if portions were just a tad bigger, I'd be more content.Our service was good. Food came out when they should and our server was friendly and helpful. She had a trainee on her side and she was delightful as well.Overall, I would recommend for late night bites with some friends and not really as a dinner destination. Ambience was nice. It was a tad loud but still able to converse (at least in the upstairs). Friend also noted that there was a line for the bathroom as there was only one stall at least for the guys, so that's certainly not ideal...

Sorry to rain on your parade fabulous people, but Bar Siena definitely drives the sparkle of the "Bar" atmosphere.......hence the name. Definitely was not impressed with the food presented. The taste was inconsistent in some of the dishes. The only dish I was impressed with was the gnocchi. The staff was definitely sweet and accommodating, for my birthday  maybe I went to soon to this newly opened establishment, will try back at a later time to see if all the buzz is about the food as opposed to a famous Chefs proprietorship.

One star for a nice interior. Another because one of my appetizers was pretty good. But it stops there. I was looking forward to trying Bar Siena to enjoy some dinner and drinks in west Loop. But everything seems way more "big box" than anything in the area. For example, when I asked for a very traditional mixed drink I was told they couldn't do it (even though they had all the ingredients listed on the menu) because their dozen signature drinks are all BATCH made. So don't order outside the list. The food was what I would expect for a pub bar type feel with an Italian twist, but lacked the added touch of care that you can really feel from the rest of Randolph street. If you need a quick bite this might be your place, but I won't be back.

We stumbled into this place on a Monday afternoon (after discovering Green St Smoked Meats was not open) and were seated pretty immediately upstairs. I explained to the friendly waiter that I've been to Siena Tavern and he was very honest that although some of the dishes used similar ingredients, I should not expect the same quality with certain items. Still we decided to try our luck with the Meatball sandwich and Chx Sandwich.Perhaps it's because he set my standards low but I thought both were incredible. The meatballs were obviously smaller than the ginormous one they serve at their sister restaurant but the texture and flavor were equally delicious! The chx was seasoned nicely and juicy especially when wrapped with the mozzarella.Our bill was right around $35 which is a bit pricey for a casual lunch but definitely a nice treat. I would return again to check out their dinner menu.

My husband and I went to the walk-up window and ordered a Nutella Bomboloni and the Stracciatella gelato.The Gelato was so creamy and delicious. The Bomboloni was fresh, soft and sweet.I would come back for dessert anytime I'm in town.

Considering the hype, the business, and the wait times this place has generated, I was not very impressed. It's basically a wood fired pizza place with River North prices.Recommend:-mushroom white pizza-kale salad with green apple and cheeseDo not recommend:-carpaccio - too small and arugula purée on top threw me off, it completely over powered any taste of the beef-oysters - warning that they come pre-garnished with raw onion and a spicy aioli, did not like it as onion over powered all flavorStaff was friendly and apologetic that they were slammed with tables. Cocktails were solid ( we had No 3 and No 4)

Great lively ambiance with excellent service. Especially fun with a small group.  The focaccia melted in your mouth with a slight hint of honey and melted cheese.  We also tried the octopus which was grilled just right with an amazing sauce.Everyone ordered a pasta for their entree and were all extremely pleased with their choices. Great beer selection and I personally enjoyed their take on a manhattan.

I've driven past this place COUNTLESS times, but it took my Bestfriend making a reservation to get me to notice it.I have no complaints about this place. The venue is gorgeous! This is the perfect date or hang out spot for large groups. The lower level is more of a casual bar atmosphere, and the second level is a little more intimate and has a beautifully lit tree as the center piece. We sat at a rounded large booth right in front of the All Star Game (how did they know?!). It was just perfect.Our server explained the menu and was as kind as could be. The plates are all family style, yet you can probably finish a dish with just one person if you were truly starving. We ordered the lobster ravioli, the grilled chicken, a pepperoni pizza, spaghetti and meat balls, a side of both mashed potatoes and the Brussels sprouts. I was too busy stuffing my face to take pictures :(  The lobster ravioli won first place for the entire table, and the pizza may have come last (even though it was still very tasty). Our bill for all of the food listed above and about 7 drinks came to $217... not bad at all.one last thing...Don't leave without trying the gelato!

Bar sienaThe only reason am giving it 3 starts its because the hostess.Walking in with my partner in crime , and he seem  bother that  we came to interrupt he's conversation with he's fellow   Coworker .To the food.Salad. Poach pear and watercress was really goodOctopus. Was good but the escarole seem to be blanched a couple of days ago it had a funny taste but the flavor of the dish was goodLasagna. Was good. Nothing especialPizza. Was great.Bombolini .   I had to order it twice it was so goodGelato.  Was really goodMy server , was really helpful and knowledgeable, but forgot to bring me my espresso , i had to ask for utensils twice , good meal .

If there were a reason for me to up and leave the wonderful East Bay area, which is not at all lacking in great restaurants, De Quay would be one of them.  Now, I might not stay for the Winter, but I would definitely be spending evenings at this delightful Lincoln Park neighborhood gem.First of all, the ambiance is cozy, inviting, and classy with a bit of a brasserie fell to it.  A nice quiet spot where you do not have to shout to be heard.  The front of the house staff are welcoming, pleasant and knowledgeable about the food and drink options.  In particular (Terry?) the Manager is so nice, taking time to explain changes to the menu and talk about the preparation and ingredients of the food.  The bar offerings ride on a great selection of boutique and high end spirits, with a variety of special ingredients that are merged with skill by the bar manager.  I understand he is constantly tinkering to come up with new recipes.The food is of course wonderful as well, based on the intersection of the Netherlands and Indonesia.  Our starter was the Balinese curry shrimp and mussels, vary flavorful with a rich creamy curry sauce.  The heat and spice level was just right, shrimp and mussels (out of the shell) tender, crostini on the side to sop up the sauce.  The seared scallops were also on point, the sear from the hot skillet just right and the interior moist and succulent.  The Kabocha squash with caramelized onions a nice counterpoint with some crispy wonton skins placed on end to give you a crispy bite.  Again the curry sauce was perfect and not a bit left at the end of the meal.Worth a trip across town to get here folks....

I would give it 4.5 if it was an option. It was a nice experience dining here and I'm glad that my friends and I found this place on yelp. We were quite interested in the Indonesian & Dutch menu so we decided to give it a try.Service was over the top friendly, attentive and efficient. The interior is neat, nice and simply chic. It is a beautiful place for a quiet and intimate dinner both for date night and group meals. Their house pinot noir that I had was great and my friend's cocktail was sweet with a good kick! These are the dishes that I have tried at De Quay:TRUFFLE MAASDAM CHEESE DUMPLINGS(appetizer) $12 - the mustard sauce and the pickled peppers were delicious, sweet and sour...the dumplings were good but not great.TAMARIND & SWEET SOY BARBECUED DUCK BREAST SALAD $26- the duck was seasoned and cooked perfectly and the sweet mangoes mixed in gave a great fresh flavor to the dish.SUMMER LAMB DUO $31- Perfection. Tender and perfectly cooked rib chops and lamb sausage, on top of flavorful goat gouda mashed potatoes. My fave dish of the night.BRAISED BEEF SHORT RIB $24- Delicious and very tender meat in shitake red wine sauce.ALMOND SPEKKOEK - Almond cake made to look like slices of bacon were beautifully presented and delicious at the same time. The pandan ice cream was amazing as well :)Overall it is a nice place for good drinks, good eats and phenomenal service. I would go back to try different items on the menu and drink list, if I'm at the Lincoln Park area.

This place is amazing. The service was exceptional from beginning to end. The unique cocktails were excellent and creative and most importantly the food was delicious..The appetizers were ridiculous. We wanted to order all of them but controlled ourselves and ordered the Cauliflower Fondue and mussels. I could eat the fondue three meals a day and be happy. It was addictive. We also loved the mussels.The entrees were also delicious. I can honestly say that I do not like duck. Due to the recommendations of the staff and yelp reviews, I took a chance and ordered it. It was so delicious and I would order again and again. My boyfriend literally killed the lamb duo entree and loved it. This place is a must try! you will not be disappointed.

Truly amazing. A must try...in my opinion.I came here with 7 friends to celebrate a birthday and we had an amazing time. The service, drinks and food were divine. We all thoroughly enjoyed our dining experience and plan to go back soon.What we had (pretty much the entire menu) and everything was amazing. The ones with the double bullet points are a must!!* * Truffle Maasdam Cheese Dumplings* Javanese Chicken Sate* * Oorlog Amsterdam Frites* * Cauliflower Goat Gouda Fondue* * Nasi Goreng* * Grilled Pork Chop & Smoked Rookworst* Braised Beef Short Rib* * Sate Marinated Grilled Lamb Chops* Sumatran Chicken Curry

Dutch and Indonesian?  Sounds like a great combination and when I heard De Quay was now open for brunch, I knew I had to head over and check it out.We arrived at 11am and pretty much had the place to ourselves until 12pm.  No problem for us as we got plenty of extra special service.  I started with a Bloody Mary and their "basket of interesting breads".  Loved this!  On this visit it was a traditional danish, a pound cake, poppy seed cake and a wonderful cinnamon roll, this is perfect for sharing with the table.We then had to try just about one of everything.  The Pannekoken, which was a flat crepe with sugared bacon and apples was probably the least liked of the group but only for it's simplicity.  My Rookwurst omlette was excellent and I had a side of their "sugared bacon" along with it.  Yep.  I was in heaven.  Loved the side of breakfast potatoes too.  My friend had the De Quay Dutch breakfast which was a salmon platter and the other winner of the day was the Nasi Goreng which was spicy fried rice with pork belly.Service was spot on and it was a nice touch that the chef/owner stopped by to welcome us.  Here is a guy who clearly loves what he has created which is beautiful, tasty food.  And know if you are a wine drinker, they have plenty of selections by the glass which was perfect for our discerning group!If you drive, parking is super easy on this stretch of Lincoln (at least on a Sunday morning)I can't wait to go back and try the rest of the menu, for if brunch was any indication, I am in for yet another treat!

Came here for restaurant week and I would come back! The restaurant is dim with close tables encouraging intimate conversations (and unfortunately bad quality foodie pics - besides the point!). Dani was our server and she was super! She helped provide great recommendations, pretty much decided my sister's meal (she couldn't do it herself), and stood the heat with my cousin's difficult question, "Is this Dutch influenced or Indonesian influenced?"We started with a bottle of red wine (can't go wrong there) and steamed muscles as our appi (wasn't part of restaurant week but it looked so good at the table next to us). The muscles was covered in a sauce that tasted like coconut milk. I'm not a huge fan of coconut milk so I only ate a few; the rest of my party on the other hand devoured it - they loved it!.I had the eggroll as my (restaurant week included) starter which was pretty good. My main course was the Nasi Gorang which was the popular fried rice. It was full of flavor and had a strong kick to it - beware to those who aren't into spicy food. For my desert, I had the Stroopwafel which was my favorite! Sweet waffle next to ice cream... yes, please!

The food: 3/5. We started with potato gouda dumplings as our app. They were interesting but had far too many peas and too little cheese, the sauce was very nice. Then we had the the tamarind duck and butter chicken as mains. The duck was done well, it had the right texture, but the glaze didn't stand out at all, neither did the side of apples and greens. Frankly, I enjoyed the chicken more, it was perfectly tender, but again lacked flavor, which was compensated for by the side of rice and curry sauce. While all the dishes were fine, nothing really stood out, so I think they need to work on elevating the spices to add more flavor to their dishes.The service: 4/5. The sat at the bar and while the bartender was very helpful in explaining the menu and checking if we liked the food, the drinks weren't made well. She also never checked on us to ask if we wanted the second round. The manager stopped by twice for a friendly chat and that's the reason I didn't want to give a mediocre rating since he tried to go above and beyond, but that still couldn't compensate for the lackluster menu.Overall: 3/5. I didn't want to give it an average rating, but the food was not memorable.

Absolutely amazing amazing experience all around.  Loved Indonesian food in Amsterdam and having a fusion spin in Chicago is just what we were hoping for in Chicago!Great, diverse, unique & robust flavors dawned every item we ordered.   Mussels, fondue, short rib & chicken were all perfectly cooked, seasoned & portioned.Great front of the house as well.  Our server John and host (Terry) were so friendly and offered great insight into our choices.  Terry was attentive & a gracious host.  Offering comp glass of champagne.  Classy.   Not loud on a Friday night and even in front of the window we were not gold on this chilly January evening.Love this place!Street parking on Friday at 730 was easy!

I had been looking for an Indonesian restaurant in Chicago since the one that I had blogged about years ago closed when the family returned to Indonesia. My sister recenly informed me about De Quay and mentioned that it had a Dutch influence. Well, that was interesting enough for a sampling.The inside is small and that lends itself to being extremely loud. If you can get past that, you'll be glad that you went because the food is so blooming delicious.My sister ordered the lamb that came with basmati rice and vegetables. Think really good Indian flavours. I had the braised rabbit and I am still apologizing to Bugs Bunny for devouring the dish the way that I did. For dessert I had the stroopwaffle with ice cream.Needless to say, I need to return so that I can do a proper blog of the restaurant. It's a "must" for all foodies.

Fail. Big prices, big hype, but the food doesn't deliver. Nasi Goreng - Indonesian fried rice - is hugely popular in the Netherlands. Dutch and Indonesian food is a time honored combination. de Quay's version is slightly strange. No egg? Zucchini? Was there shrimp? The meat was slightly mysterious. The taste was okay, but it didn't push the needle past "Okay." Sort of mushy. The shrimp chips were good, and crunchy, those were fine.The staff was spot on, no complaints, great service from smiling servers. The people were wonderful. They made up for the less than stellar food, and that is not their fault.The interior was strange. Sort of a generic bar looking design, with a few Dutch knickknacks on shelves scattered around.And several of us had a but of uh . . . digestive distress after eating here. That, however, could happen to anyone, any restaurant, any time. So that wouldn't stop me from returning. But, the mediocre food will. I wanted to love this place, from all the hype, but it just doesn't hit the mark, sadly.Try Rickshaw Republic down the street.

Came here for a friend's birthday with a party of 8 on a Saturday night.Excellent service and outstanding food. Everything we ordered was so tasty and savory.We started with the truffle cheese dumplings, Amsterdam frites, Gouda fondue, and nasi goreng.Where to even begin?! From the first bite of the dumplings, with the hot melted cheese oozing out, the addicting Amsterdam frites, and the many flavors of the nasi goreng that just came together. Excellent starters.For the entrees, we ordered the short ribs, and lamb chops. For both, the meat was so tender. It fell right off the bone and melted in your mouth. The flavors were so good but it didn't overpower the meat. The other people in my party had ordered the pork chop and the marinated chicken. I wasn't able to taste either, but both plates were cleaned off and they said it was good!Definitely would come back here. The place is small, not too crowded and intimate.

We visiting De Quay for restaurant week in Chicago with the thought of trying some place new but without a particular expectation in place.  We were thrilled at our find!De Quay is a cozy "gem" of a spot on Lincoln Park.  Unassuming store front restaurant with a warm feel inside both from the decor and the people.  What made our visit outstanding wasn't just the food but the engaging hosts from the general manager to the bartender to the server.The cocktail menu is creative and the wine list provides varied selections.  Most enjoyable were the "special" wines by the glass the GM/sommelier shared with us.  The staff was more than willing to allow us to try wines or beers - just to experiment or to taste.  We got to try a wide variety of beverages (and they sold some too ;-)From the menu, everything that we tried was delicious starting with the cauliflower gouda fondu (great variety of toasts).  The winter salad was fresh and served with a terrific dressing.  The fried spring roles (best description I can make) were very good and we loved the spicy sauce accompaniment.Our main courses of chicken nasi goreng and lamb were very tasty.  Serving sizes were just right and the touch of spice suited our palates.  Throughout our meal, service was attentive and engaging.We finished our meal off with a dessert and some madeira (not commonly on dessert beverage menus).Very enjoyable dining experience and meal.  We will be back!

Came here for my birthday and could not have asked for a more amazing experience! The space and ambience was intimidate, friendly, and lovely. We were instantly greeted by the kind hostess who took us to our reserved table right away. She even remembered that it was my birthday and gave me a specially customized menu with my name on it! Our server was also very attentive, always made sure our water glasses were full, he was also very knowledgable on the menu and answered every question we had.We ordered the Nasi Goreng, Cauliflower Goat Cheese Fondue, and Mussels for starters. The size of these appetizers were more than expected and incredibly delicious! I cannot even pick a favorite, because they were all very good.For entrees, we ordered the Porkchop with Rookworst, Buttermilk Chicken, Braised Beef, Duck with the Pear Salad, and the Lamb Chops. They were all, honestly, breathtakingly delicious! I had to take a moment after every bite to savor the moment and just how happy I was at that moment.For dessert, our server surprised us with the Pandan Ice Cream and Spekkoek! The cake itself was very dense and moist with lovely almond flavor while the ice cream was a creamy vanilla flavor, wonderful compliments.I will have to sure be back to try the other items on the menu!

This is a new spot and an interesting mix of Indonesian and Dutch food.  The number of seats are limited. The restaurant is cozy but still cute. We got the cheese dumplings, the mussels and the Indonesian fried rice for apps. The mussels are amazing!!! The sauce with the mussels we used to put on the fried rice. Entrees we had the pork, the lamb duo and the duck.  All three were amazingly flavorful and perfectly cooked. The desserts were the only lacking entity. We got the almond cake and the Dutch cookie. The cookie was kind of soggy and did not have a nice top crisp. The almond cake just was not flavorful and did not go well with the Indonesian ice cream it was served with. Overall great entrees, poor desserts. Definitely will come back though !

I feel like Chicago has almost any kind of cuisine you can think of but I still have never heard about Dutch-Indonesian food.  I can tell you it is pretty delicious though.  My wife and I got a table on a Friday night and it was pretty busy inside.  Our server was on top of everything as well.As far as the food, I thought they did a really nice job of mixing south east asian flavors like coconut and curry with the more familiar european foods like potatos and cheeses.  We got 2 apps.  The Frites were like thick cut fries and they came with 2 really unique sauces.  My wife liked the herb mayo but I though the peanut sauce was solid as well, I feel like there was some curry in it too.  The dumplings were great too.  They were filled with gouda and it gave a distinctly Dutch taste to something that is distinctly Asian.My wife had the mussels and they came with a coconut sauce, she approved.  I got the grilled pork chop and smoked rookworst.  Everything on my plate was solid and the pan sauce that was added really made it for me.  We got the almond spekkoek for dessert and it was basically like eating a marzipan cake.  I love marzipan so this was a win for me.  The ice cream had a really intriguing flavor though.  We forgot what it said on the menu so we were guessing pistachio until the server reminded us it was Pandan.If you're sitting at home debating between Chili's and Outback Steakhouse, I'm guessing you wouldn't be looking at my review anyway, but stop that, you know they are both bad. Make a trip to de Quay.

This place was recommended to us by some friends whose taste we respect. It also got good reviews here. It didn't live up to the hype.We started with the shrimp and mussels.Tasted exactly like a Thai  curry I could get anywhere but all sauce and no substance.My wife had the short ribs. They were fine but, once again, a dish I have had better in 100 different French and Italian restaurants. They were served with a bean fritter I rather liked though.I had the De Quay "Nasi Goreng". It's an Indonesian rice dish and I believe a house specialty. It was basically the rice you get in every Mexican restaurant although the Mexican rice doesn't overuse cumin in the recipe. The egg on top didn't really belong even if it is traditional. I did like the pork belly because, ya know, it's pork belly.Service was lackluster. Parking was difficult but that's not really their fault.

thought this was an authentic indonesian place when we saw the high review on yelp, but it turned out to be more of a indonesian/dutch fusion, i guess we should have guessed that from the name of the restaurantcame here during restaurant week for dinner, and the place is packed, luckily it was still intimate and our waitress made sure we are having a great time therethe food is nothing extraordinary, it is worth trying it out once. it does not taste bad, but it does not leave a lasting impression either.

We loved it here! The service is so friendly and attentive. The food was fabulous- we had the dumplings, lamb duo and nasi goreng. The nasi is a little spicy (which they warned us) but really good. Wine list is also great and has a variety of price points. The sommelier Terry is so nice. We can't wait to come back and try more! Great addition to the neighborhood.

Drove an hour and a half for dinner at de Quay. It was worth making the drive!I have had Indonesian cuisine before, but, this is by far one of the best Indonesian restaurants in all of Chicago. The fusion of Dutch comfort foods with the influence of Indonesian traditional flavors really makes this restaurant stand out. They also have some tasty beers worth trying out.More importantly, the staff is friendly, helpful, and  knowledgeable. All of the staff knew the menu like the backs of their hands and made excellent suggestions.Would definitely come back here in a heartbeat!

Amazing service, prompt knowledgeable and accommodating for dietary concerns (celiac and gluten free).The food was so tasty, Indonesian mussels where they toasted my GF Bread. (Honestly the best mussels I've ever had).I had pork and sausage(house made).....too good for wordsMy bf had a special.....it could've been short rib....The desert was a fusion halo halo/pot bing seiu.We felt cared for/taken care of and valued as customers. 5/5 for service, food management  (they had no problem with modifications) kitchen staff (was quick and efficient even though my order was likely annoying) and the owner was genuinely concerned with our enjoyment and satisfaction. (Which was a lovely touch)I work in the service industry and i was genuinely impressed with every aspect of the meal from start to finish...and to top it all off it was on new years eve.I've recommended de quay to many people since my visit!

I came in with my husband and his family for dinner.  The atmosphere was very nice and the staff was beyond professional.  The server really knew his stuff and the manager went above and beyond for us.  The food was like nothing I've tried before..soooo delicious.  Who knew Dutch and Indonesian food would be such a nice fusion?  I would have to say my favorite out of everything I tried was the braised beef short rib --OH MY GOSH it was the tastiest piece of meat ever.  The truffle cheese dumplings were also to die for.  I highly recommend this place for a night out.

The Yelp 5-star bandwagon really made me want to try this place. Indonesian-Dutch? As far as I know, pretty rare in Chicago. And literally a 4-minute walk from home? A dream come true for a convenient date night spot.And yes, the food was delicious. And it's a great date night spot. A solid four stars. I just don't think it blew my mind.Service was really great from the beginning. The restaurant feels very casual and neighorhoodly, but they really pamper you with the service like you're somewhere rillllll fancy. The manager went around checking in with diners and offering tasting pours, they wipe your crumbs between courses, and you get an explanation of the ingredients and components when the food is brought to the table. Everyone was super sweet and made our experience really fun.Kitchen seemed to be a bit backed up when we went on a weeknight, so it took a while to get our food. We had a smoked trout salad and nasi goreng as appetizers. The trout salad was nice and refreshing. Nasi goreng came with condiments that on their own I could nibble on forever, but the rice itself didn't have much flavor except for spicy and a bit sweet.Our entree pork chop was awesome. Delicious and hearty and the chop was cooked to a nice tender pink inside. Our shrimp entree was ... really freaking tiny. For almost the same price as the chop, you get literally a little salad, 4 pieces of small shrimp, and an eggroll cut in half. Even though that lumpia was definitely the best thing we ate all night, I would feel completely ripped off if it took me literally 8 bites to eat my dinner while my dining companions were enjoying hearty pork chops (or looking around, delicious looking short ribs).I would definitely recommend people here to try for a casual date night with your SO. But Chicago is so big and full of good spots, it might not make my "return soon" list until I've made rounds to a few of the others.

Absolutely divine. My mouth and body were left completely satiated. I cannot give this restaurant and its chef and staff enough praise. And last but not least, order dessert.*Anyone who gives this restaurant less than five stars is out of their mind. My Dutch boyfriend agrees!!*

I really want to like the place. I found the restaurant from couple of magazines on chicago's new & hot list. Service was great. Food was just ok (very average for us)We started off with nasi goreng for appetizer (indonesian fried rice). It was nothing like the one i had back in indonesia. Having some shrimp crackers on top of fried rice didn't qualify it to become a nasi goreng. The dish was very much like a hot veggie fried rice at ~$13 (no meat in it: pricey!). It had a good flavor but we were disappointed as it was not nasi goreng as what we expected.I had the duck for my entree. It was ok. My husband had the braised beef short rib. It was very salty, so salty that we couldn't eat it. We asked them to remake it. They were very nice and asked us to pick some other dishes instead. My husband picked the chicken curry which was tasty & comforting.We had panda ice-cream and almond cake. the portion was small. the cake was dense. You really need to eat it with ice-cream in every bites. I can't really taste pandan in the ice-cream. It was just an ice-cream with a strong green food-coloring.The place was not terrible, but clearly not 4-5 stars. We won't go back there again

All-around amazing experience. We were greeted with a personalized menu for our anniversary and complimentary glass of champagne. Everyone was so down-to-earth and friendly. Food was delicious, unique - nothing I could make at home, which I love! Can't wait to go back.

Wonderful meal last night.  The place has class without being pretentious, wait staff attentive and pleasant without interrupting, quiet enough for conversation, and delicious.  Unlike any other place in Chicago it joins Dutch and Singaporean which is apparently more common in Holland.One more tip: Erwin Helfer and Barrelhouse Chuck, Chicago Jazz institutions, play for tips in the 'secret' and lovely lounge in the second floor of Barrelhouse Flats two blocks north.  Great place for a date - you can chat, enjoy great drinks, and hear some nice piano renditions from one of the greats.Food btw was terrific - we had a chicken dish with Indonesian flavor sand a sauce that we needed extra bread to finish off. Lamb chops were awesome and the two apps (a rice with sing. spices and Gouda goat fondue) plus sides (mashed potatoes with Gouda and a type of kale salad) were all great hits with us.I am definitely going back and will leave enough time and room for dessert.

We had a 10:45pm reservation for last Saturday night and I was surprised how empty the place was.  There were only two occupied tables in the entire place.  I wasn't going to stay, but it was a $17 Uber ride over from the Theater District, so we decided to stay for dinner. The staff was a bit icey, which I understand no one likes a late reservation, but then again why was that time slot an option on Open Table if you want to close right at 11:00 on a Saturday night?The manager was the exception, he was warm & very inviting and even sent over a couple of drinks.We had the dumplings, which I thought were just okay.  Boyfriend had the chicken with curry and I had the duck.  The entrees were wonderful and saved the whole experience.Go for the food, but not after 10:00.

My boyfriend and I came visited for a Sunday brunch to try something new. We thought the combination of Dutch and Indonesian would be interesting but were a little disappointed to find the brunch menu with mostly typical brunch dishes with a hint of Dutch influence and one or two Indonesian entrees. We both decided to go with the Nasi Goreng since it seemed to be the most unique. We both agreed that it was quite good and filling but it wasn't amazing. In terms of service and ambience, we both enjoyed it but shared the opinion that it was a tad too dark. Since we did visit for brunch, the options might have been limited so I would be tempted to come again for dinner to see more fusion and creativity in dishes.

Amsterdam is where I had my "white meal." Everything on the plate was white--halibut, mashed potatoes and cauliflower, and they topped it off with a white sauce. No treat for the eyes and a tad bland. The next night I headed to an Indonesian restaurant (a former Dutch colony) where a 25 dish rijsttafel (rice table) is served. This meal could not have been more different--exotic, spicy, and varied. Now, here in Chicago, we have De Quay, whose chef aims to unite these two polar extremes of Dutch cuisine on every plate.And to a remarkable degree he succeeds. My entree, flavorful beef short ribs in red wine sauce, came with a rendang croquette and pea shoots. Rendang I gather is an Indonesian spice mixture that provides a nice degree of heat and makes the croquette memorable. Gouda mashed potatoes were on the side. For dessert there was a stroopwaffel with vanilla ice cream. Stroopwaffels are as common in Holland as oreos are here and twice as delicious, a combination cookie and miniature waffle with a caramel filling. The version here is addictive.There is a great beverage program at De Quay. Guided by the terrific bartender, I sampled The Woodsman, a Manhattan-like cocktail that combines whiskey, walnut bitters and several other high quality ingredients. When it was time to choose wine, Terry recommended riesling. What's even better, he organized an impromptu tasting of several varieties to let you choose the one you preferred. As many have stated, the service here is exemplary.Now if only they would add herring to the menu (but not eel). They could even have a herring festival come spring and fly in new herring from Holland like the Oyster Bar in NYC does in June. One can only hope! Meantime we welcome De Quay as it is.

Great modern Dutch Indonesian food in Chicago.  This is a must try as it is unique with very good execution.  The food here was better than any meal I had in Amsterdam where I did check out some fancy Dutch cooking and a couple of Indonesian rijsttafel.Tried several starters and my favorites were the chicken sate, green bean salad, and nasi goreng.  Chicken sate may sound mundane, but their version here is probably the best version I have tried anywhere.For entrees, I tried the chicken, shrimp, and beef short rib.  All were good.Since we came for my mom's birthday, we tried all 3 desserts.  Stroopwafel came out still warm.  Better than any Stroopwafel I had in Amsterdam.  Chocolate cherry pudding was awesome as well.  I love pandan and enjoyed the pandan ice cream that came with the almond spekkoek dessert.  However, the other first two desserts I mentioned were even better and in a league of their own.

I would give this restaurant more stars if I could.  We found this on Yelp because we were going to Lincoln Hall for a show. From the moment we walked in the door to the personal goodbyes from the staff, every detail was perfect.  The staff was so friendly and very knowledgeable. The cocktails were unique and wine selection was amazing. I can not say enough wonderful things about the food.  We tried 4 appetizers and 2 entrees between our group and every thing was perfect. We will be back again soon and bring more friends to share in this amazing experience.
Delicious, unique, accommodating, hospitality forward. A gem in any city and a standout in Chicago, which has many lovely restaurants.

Nights like tonight are one of the reasons I love living in Chicago so much. Rewind to 3pm this afternoon when I'm chatting with a friend about grabbing a low key dinner, I offer to find a few suggestions from which to select for tonight. Wanting to checkout something i haven't had I peruse Chicago magazine's Hot List and see a few suggestions, one of which is this very random sounding "Dutch Indonesian" restaurant.Imagine my surprise when my friend's response is "oh yeah, believe it or not I've been saying Dutch Indonesian would eventually become hot in the US". She's enjoyed it in Amsterdam before, whereas I was a naive soul in 2006 when I visited A-dam and had no idea it existed.Scoring a reservation online was not a problem and we were seated promptly. It's a nice space with good energy - not crazy loud but not quiet either. Would be a great date spot or a dinner with a few friends.They have a great selection of rieslings, we enjoyed one from Alsace that was on the drier side. They actually recommend sweeter rieslings than we selected to pair with it due to the spices/seasonings.The food was delicious all around, but I would have given it a 4.5 stars if I could instead of 5 - taking a .5 demerit for the food not being quite as uniquely flavored as I might have expected.Chicken Satay starter - Super moist and tender, not dry like most satay. The peanut sauce was really interesting and there was a nice slaw served on the side.Braised Short Rib Entree - I was told by the server this was one of the more unique dishes, but I actually found the flavors to be pretty similar to most braised short rib dishes I've had over the years. It was delicious with very nice meat, extremely tender but not overly fatty and a beautifully balanced sauce. There was a croquette that came on the side that was more uniquely seasoned (Indonesian seasonings) that I liked a lot too.Side of Gouda Mashed Potatoes - These are reminiscent of Rubochon style mashed. They were a nice pairing with the short ribs.Dessert - the waffle cookie thing with vanilla ice cream. This was sooooooo good. Perfect for sharing with 2 people and not too heavy.Overall a great meal, prices felt reasonable. Nice, attentive service too. It wasn't as unique as I expected but is a nice addition to the Lincoln Park food scene. I loved not having to head all the way south or to Lincoln Sq for a great meal.

Me: How hungry are you?Him: Not very, why?Me: Well, if we want to eat as planned, I have to go to the restaurant now to start the clock on the 2 hour wait for the table.Him: Screw that.The manfriend and I do a lot of planning and coordinating in our respective jobs, so when it comes to our personal time, to say we fall down on the job is an understatement. When our original plans fell through, I took to the Yelps to find us a suitable alternative. Enter deQuay.deQuay caught my attention based on their cuisine alone. Dutch-Indonesian sounded like such a random pairing; turns out it is not, kind of like French-Vietnamese cuisine. deQuay's cuisine is not the only thing that is unusual; it sits in a stretch chock full of sushi joints, bro bars, and carry out places. I'm not sure what used to occupy the space, but my money's on some form of bro bar.We arrived without reservations, but bar seats are first come first serve. I'm glad we didn't get a table, we learned so much about the restaurant from the staff behind the bar. I never caught our main bartender's name, but he was fantastic; extremely knowledgeable of the food and drink menus and not afraid to point out his favorites. His descriptions and recommendations were not only spot on, but so eloquently phrased that it often made our decisions harder. We chatted up a few other staff members during our meal as well; everyone was so friendly and welcoming. Even if the food hadn't wowed us, the service did; it was flawless - friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive.To start we ordered a few drinks and gravalax starter. They have a nice selection of beers, craft cocktails and spirits. The dish came with the salmon wrapped around the beets and the creme fraiche and radishes adorning the top. It was recommended that we take a bite of just the salmon to savor the flavor of the house smoked fish. The salmon was excellent and the pairing of all of the ingredients was delicious and well balanced.For our meals, he went with the short rib and I went with the mussels and a side of the gouda mashed potatoes. If I had one knock on the place, it would be that the menu is very meat heavy (but that's my issue, not theirs). The mussels, generous in portion, were good and the sauce flavorful with sliced chiles and lime. The mashed potatoes sounded so good that I couldn't pass up ordering them; I didn't think mashed potatoes could be improved, but the gouda proved me wrong. The creaminess and saltiness is divine; they could be a meal on their own. We finished our meal with dessert; per usual many of the items sounded tasty, but we went with the stroopwafel - mainly because the manfriend loved the name. The dessert was simple, but good - a large, flat waffle cookie with caramel in the middle accompanied by homemade vanilla ice cream.deQuay is a fantastic addition to the neighborhood; perfect for a nicer meal and a good stop before seeing a show at the Apollo. Just don't forget to make a reservation.
This was an enjoyable meal.  Friendly and attentive service, some good booze, and very interesting dishes start to finish.

A really awesome meal. My roommate and I went for brunch, I got the Dutch breakfast and she got the French toast, we got the beef Rendang as the starter. Everything was pretty great! The Rendang was the only thing I was slightly disappointed in, I thought it lacked a little spice for the type of curry dish it was supposed to be a tribute to. The French toast was by far the best, the perfect amount of sweetness and the almond coating is to die for.

Chicago does not have that many Dutch / Indonesian style restaurants so there is a lot of hype and anticipation with de Quay. Chef David de Quay brings a unique style of fusion with Dutch and Indonesian ingredients and spices. We started with Black Pepper Gouda Dumplings which had potato, peas, bacon and a side of mustard sauce which was amazing. I know I could eat just the Black Pepper Gouda Dumplings all night long. We also had the Nasi Goreng which is a fried rice with vegetables and tons of amazing Indonesian spieces. The Nasi Goreng does have a little heat to it and comes on slowly. Though it sounded amazing there was just something that seemed missing from it like some texture to the dish. The mains we had the Buttermilk Marinated Chicken and Tamarind and Sweet Soy Barbecued Duck Breast and Leg. The Buttermilk Marinated Chicken was perfect. Cooked just right and the Indonesian spices along with the basmati rice and curry sauce was a great combination. The Sweet Soy Barbecued Duck Breast and Leg with Asian pear, fennel, and ginger croutons was good but not great. The flavors were there but the duck with slightly overcooked. It was not horrible to send back but if you are going to serve duck to an Asian specialty Chinese, you better get it right. The drinks were good as well. The one that stood out was the Bee Sting which was Chairman's Reserved Spiced Rum, Bull Run Temperance Trader Bourbon, Honey Syrup, Lemon, and Ginger Beer. This is a small space so large groups may not be easy though the tables can be placed together.
