I did feel like we were placed on a spotlight as the 2 way tables are all in the middle of the restaurant. It is still a quaint place great for dates. I know there were a few other things I wanted to try including the Grilled Pork Chop and Smoked Rookworst, Braised Beef Short Rib, Stroopwafel and Almond Spekkoek. I will be back and maybe GM Terry McNeese would avoid running into my chair the next time. There are some tweaks I would recommend but great early start for being one of Eater and Zagat's top anticipated restaurants of 2015.Food - 4Décor - 4Service - 5

Like another Yelper, I found de Quay onchicago.eater.comand am so glad I did!  The idea of Dutch-Indonesian comfort food caught my attention.  Stopped by for an early Sunday dinner with the wife on our way to see Book of Mormon.  Only a few tables were occupied when we arrived at 5:30, but the place was pretty busy an hour or so later.We started with the Amsterdam frites which were delicious with both the spicy peanut and herb sauces.  My wife asked if the herb sauce had raw egg because she's pregnant (yes, it's mayo based) and was slightly disappointed she couldn't try it.  That disappointment was short-lived, as Terry (manager/wine director) brought over a complimentary non-alcoholic cocktail with ginger beer.  My wife loves just about anything with ginger, so she was thrilled and loved the drink.For our entrees, I had the tamarind and sweet soy barbecued duck while my wife went with the buttermilk marinated chicken thigh with Indonesian aromatics.  I thought the salad with sherry dressing paired really nicely with the richness of the duck.  The chicken was the real winner though.  My wife kept commenting on how aromatic the basmati rice was and cleaned every speck of curry from her plate.Our meal ended with the almond spekkoek (almond cake and a scoop of pandan ice cream made in-house) and coffee (Sparrow Coffee Roastery).  We were expecting deliciousness and weren't disappointed.  It only got better when Terry stopped by again with a complimentary glass of dessert wine just because (aged Riesling from 2005).If you're even remotely interested in their menu, you should definitely give them a try.  The food was delicious and they treated us like royalty.  I'll definitely be back!

Really different and really good.  The Gouda goat cheese app was excellent.  The duo duck breast with a duck confit salad below was great.  Don't remember the last time I had duck but I would order this again in a heartbeat.  My wife had the theories chop with Gouda mashed potatoes and sausage/kraut.   Excellent as I swiped a few bites.  Finished with the waffle and ice cream dessert and Color me happy.  I can see why Chicago Mag rates it # 3 new restaurant in Chicago.
Nice atmosphere, excellent food, great service!One of the few places that also serves premium wine by the glass.Highly recommended!

Had a delicious dinner, food was done really well, awesome Indonesian flavors with a wine list that Terry McNeese, The GM and Wine Director, put together is very impressive.The service staff just makes you feel like a regular and it's easy and flawless. Cool little vibe going on. Great place to hang with friends to enjoy great hospitality, delicious food and awesome wines. I will certainly go back and experience more of it all with more people so we can and will order one of everything on the menu...Thanks Terry for your hospitality and all you do!
Loved it, unassuming restaurant with amazing food and even better service.

Despite being a restaurant apparently housed inside of a working furnace, de Quay has excellent food, drinks and atmosphere.On just another average Friday night of eating Dutch-Indonesian cuisine, Meg L and I set out to meet Jason M's number one Yelp fan/high school friend, Amanda N and her husband/Meg L's middle school acquaintance, Rob N. Confused? It doesn't really have an effect on the restaurant, so don't worry.Things didn't start exceptionally well when we forgot the parking pit of hell that de Quay is a part of. Honestly, the 2400 N block of Lincoln is just a miserable place to try and park a car. After dropping off Meg L and walking 4 blocks back to the restaurant, I was greeted by a restaurant that seemed to think 80 degrees was an appropriate temperature.But...that's all the bad stuff. And, to be honest, the temperature found its way down to normal as the meal went on.The cocktails were inventive and well made. The wine and beer list are very solid. The food was interesting and terrific all around. At the table, we tried some dumplings made with gouda and a chicken sate. Both excellent, and the dumplings were like nothing any of us had ever tried before. As entrees, the pork chop was terrific (and fairly Dutch-seeming) and the fried rice (apparently the national dish of Indonesia) was unique and outstanding both as dinner and as my breakfast the next day. The spice level of the fried rice was about as perfect as is possible for a dish of that ilk.It's not a huge menu and likely not somewhere you'll end up going frequently, but we'll definitely be back.

Mediocre at best, the nasi was bland, light on the meat, no hint of shrimp, and NO EGG. If this is Indonesian Fusion, it outright sucks. The overbearing condescension here is off-putting. I'm Dutch. I grew up on this stuff. When I get a hard time about wanting Sambal Ooolek for undercooked Basmati rice with odd things like zucchini in my Nasi, my eyebrow gets ticked. Doing it wrong, not coming back. The service was terrific overall, but the product is not. They do make good kroupeouk, but a six year old with a vat of boiling oil can make that. Trust me. I know. Man, was my mom pissed about that.

Found this place onchicago.eater.com.  And well, since it wasn't even on Yelp yet, we had to go and try.  DELICIOUS.Sat at the bar, because I feel like with new establishments, the bar staff is generally the most knowledgable.  Katie took great care of us.  She walked us through the menu and we decided to do lots of small plates.The Nasi Goreng, Javanese Chicken Sate, Black Pepper Gouda Dumplings and Baked Cauliflower Cream were the flavor of the evening and EACH ONE was fantastic.  Chicken not over cooked, all the different spices flavorful in their own right with out being over bearing.A couple great cocktails including the Woodsman.  All great stuff.  This is the only Dutch-Indonesian place I can think of in all of Chicago.  Take some time and check this place out.

We went for dinner. Everything was great. The was very interesting and new. The food was very enjoyable and we can tell that a lot of thought and effort went into creating each dish. We had the chicken satay which is by far the best I have tasted. The main course was also very good we had the nasi goreng and butter milk chicken. Although, the flavor is on the milder side, the food was excellent.In addition, the service was great. The restaurant manager and the wait staff was very attentive. They always check on the us whether everything was good (which it was). Overall, we are very impress with the service, the food, and the atmosphere.

Looking for new date night spots in Lincoln Park stumbled across this new gem. Food was fantastic, service personable and well coordinated, and decor fitting for the Dutch-Indonesian style. It's gezellig - those that are Dutch know what I'm talking about.After living in Amsterdam and understanding the cuisine, this spot delivers on the right combination of flavors. We started with Gouda filled dumplings which were creamy and perfect for the rainy day. The short rib was delicious as was the duck with gingerbread croutons.Overall, neighborhood gem for date night or dining alone (there's a nice bar to sit at as well).  The banquet could use some pillows to soften the back, but otherwise really enjoyed.  We'll definitely be back for another date night.

It was SO good!! My friend John works here so we made a reservation to check it out. SO HAPPY we did! Everything we tried was delicious and had a different flavor profile than anything I've had before.The chicken sate, fondue and buttermilk chicken were SO SO GOOD and we finished with the almond spekkoek. I don't even eat dessert but it was delicious.You can see right into the kitchen (which to me is always an awesome way to show you're proud of your food/staff/etc).The drinks were also delightful!We'll definitely be going back!

Elegance in dining. Lovely understated decor fits the Dutch theme. It isn't big so I'd highly recommend advance reservations. We dined on the nasi goreng with great homemade sauces, the curried chicken and duck. Since it was my birthday they not only included a happy birthday notation on my menu but also gave a complimentary dessert. The owner is very hands on and servers are extremely attentive.

de Quay just recently opened, relatively quietly, and I happened to walk past it about an hour before close. Our server gave us the rundown: some dishes are exclusively Dutch, some exclusively Indonesian, and others a very well calculated mix of the two. We discovered this to be the case; we started with the very Dutch black pepper dumplings. They were quite tasty and the mustard sauce added a nice touch. For the main course, I had the tamarind glazed duck breast and leg, with a pear and Dutch breakfast bread crouton salad. The flavors all married well together, although the duck could have been a little more rare than it was. It was not dry, but there was little pink left in the center. My date also enjoyed her dish, the braised beef short ribs with an interesting Indonesian take on croquettes. All in all, a delicious meal with some pleasant and subtle surprises; I'll be back!

Very modern Dutch IndoMy wife and i went early. The place was pretty empty. The interior is very nice.The service was great.Wine was ok. Red selection better than whiteThe fries not quite cooked enough for us, but had 2 great sauces.The chicken satay was awesome .The nasi goring was good though not like home. A more modern version and a little too spicy. We prefer to add the sombal.The desert of spec kook was awesome and went well with the ice cream. Best desert I've had in Chicago this trip!Will return again

Went to de Quay recently for Restaurant Week with a group of girl friends and we had a great experience. The staff was super knowledgeable about the ingredients going in to their foods and the flavor profiles of each dish. Everything we had tasted amazing and was such a unique combination of flavors.I had the lumpes - like an egg roll - the lamb curry and the peanut butter/chocolate dessert (obviously missing the real menu names). I'm usually hesitant to order curry because while I like spice, the particular flavor usually doesn't do it for me, but this one I loved. It was subtly spicy and flavorful.Our waitress was sure to make sure we enjoyed every course and was super attentive.  Thanks, de Quay!

Pretty excellent restaurant for its price point. Partner had the lamb chops, a new addition to their menu as of 12/29/15. Cooked really well with a delicious glaze and served with special Indosian spiced rice which highlighted flavors of peanut and coconut in a balanced way.Had the curry chicken which was cooked wonderfully moist and well seasoned (not too salty or bland), only negative would be the sauce lacked the bold flavors that I think of when I think of Indonesian.Owner (or manager?) was very friendly stopping by throughout meal to check in and making suggestions for the menu and chit chat. Wait staff very responsive and attentive.Would recommend this place for a mid range dining experience.

One of the best meals I've had in a long time! Terry, the in house wine guy, was excellent and the service he provided was impeccable. He was committed to helping us choose the right wine and when we didn't like our choice, he accommodated us and allowed us to choose another bottle. Very much appreciated. I had the duck and it was cooked to perfection with a sweet, bbq glaze. Our smoked Gouda and cauliflower 'fondue' was unique in texture and not my favorite and the coffee after dinner was extremely bitter. Otherwise, this place is excellent. Very impressed, especially with the service.

Great service and delicious food! Loved the mussels, the truffled thing, and the nasi. For dinner, we shared the short rib, lamb and chicken curry. All were great. Dessert was delicious too but not as "wow " as the main meal. Would def go back.

I believe service, even more than the food, makes a restaurant. And Terry and his team have simply TREMENDOUS food combined with some of the best service we have received world over! Excellent ambience, friendly staff (Danny is awesome!) perfect service! We came here for my wife's birthday and Terry and team made it a joyful celebration!!We WILL be back for more, esp. with the Sunday brunch now open!

The food was really incredible. Highly recommend the gouda dumplings and the chicken.It is a pretty small space, and our table was kind of crowded by other customers waiting for seats and hanging around the bar area. I don't imagine it is standard to have a group of 14 waiting to be seated, so I won't dock them a star.

Wonderful surprise - this somewhat hidden spot on Lincoln Avenue is worth finding. Unique menu, lovely space and then there's Noel, our server, advice-giver and guide for a very special meal. We were on our way to Victory Gardens theater but next time we'll allow more time to appreciate all the many unusual selections.
Really delicious. Beautiful and thoughtful presentation. Duck leg and pork chop are highly recommended need. Flush with white ordered the bartender can recommend.

I love this place! We came here by recommendation of a coworker and have since been again.The first time we went, we started with the Cauliflower Cream appetizer which I thought was very tasty, bf didn't think it was anything special, mostly because there are so many other good options. We ordered the dumplings both times we were there, they are just great.The first time he had short rib which he liked but he liked my dish better, Nasi Goreng which I got again this time and it was, again, excellent. He got the Sumatran Chicken Curry and loved it, the sauce was coconut curry-ish... very savory and flavorful.The best part was their staff is all participating in your experience so you are never waiting for someone to be attentive. Both times we were there, a guy came over and let us try a variety of wines, on and off menu, to make sure we had the right wine for our meal. Such a great experience and will obviously be back again!
Fantastic service and superb food. Will be going back soon!

Tried this restaurant during restaurant week with a group of fiends and loved it. The service is friendly, accommodating and knowledgeable. The wine selection is great and there are many options to accompany your food selection. Our only feedback for improvement is that the pork was slightly over cooked but has excellent flavor nonetheless. We're looking forward to coming back! Thanks for such a great evening.

Delicious food that took me back to Bali.  The cocktails were interesting - a savory gin martini?  It was very good and $8 rose wine was a refreshing summer drink.  I loved the pork sate entree served with a peach salad and crisp plantains.  The rice dish started was delicious with a little bit of heat.  The waiter was funny and sharp.  We really enjoyed it.

Serious, fantastic food in a quiet, comfortable, and unpretentious spot. Chicago is overloaded with ultra high-end restaurants or trendy joints made to look like Edison-era industrial lofts, so de Quay stands out for its combination of modesty and ambition. There's nothing else like it in the city. I've had Indonesian food before served at warungs in Bali and a random spot in Philly, but I've never had Dutch food and certainly not in concert with the former.Why on earth did chef/owner David de Quay hide his talents at the Hinsdale Golf Club of all places?! Good God, I want to believe he was trying to raise capital to open this gem of a restaurant. If so, the wait was worth it.For appetizers, a friend and I ordered the frites, crispy and light and that come with a peanut satay sauce and mayo with dill; the nasi goreng, spicy fried rice packed with heat and roaring with flavor; and the black pepper gouda dumplings, rich and creamy and gone in two seconds once you taste them they're so delicious.We decided to order one entree to split because of all the appetizers and we were happy with our choice. We got the buttermilk-marinated chicken on jasmine rice with red curry. It tasted like chicken, whereas chicken typically tastes like nothing. Considering how tender and juicy it was, it made me question the quality of chicken I've been eating all my life. The dish was divine.For dessert, we got the stroopwaffel with vanilla ice cream, a light, perfect confection to top off a heady meal.Service was lovely and attentive throughout the evening. I've rarely encountered people who were more excited to work at a restaurant. It's clear they're passionate about the place from our waitress raving about taking her friends there to the general manager who brought us free glasses of riesling. We felt totally at home.Our total bill, including two beers, came to $71 before tip. Super reasonable for a restaurant of this caliber, underpriced even. I tipped generously. So should you.I don't know how much longer this restaurant will remain low-key before word gets out as to how outstanding it is and reservations become a pain. Go now.

Ive been to the Netherlands where I first fell in love with Dutch-Indonesian food.  There are not a lot of options here in Chicago for this kind of cuisine.  When i heard about this place I was super excited.  Its good but it doesn't take me back to the Netherlands.  I think the dishes here are more of a fusion to adapt better to the American palate which is unfortunate since the Indonesian food I've had was really delicious.  Im not saying the food here is inferior im just saying that if you had dishes in the Netherlands, this is not exactly the same.We went there on a Sat evening and the place was packed.  The appetizers were very good, we had the chicken satay which was my favorite.  Not your typical chicken satay.  The smoked trout salad was also a winner.  For the main dishes, the shrimp lumpia and the buttermilk chicken did not disappoint.The service in this place is very good, our server never stop refilling our water and is always there to attend to our needs.In terms of value, this place is on the expensive side.  You get 3-4 shrimp and a couple of lumpia for 23.  The chicken dish is reasonably portion.  In terms of value I think you get a better value with Rickshaw Republic but if you dont mind the small portions at a higher price, this place is worth it.The manager Terry gave our group free appetizers but it ended up in our bill.  I called Terry and he took care of this right away.  This is why you need to check your bill all the time people!

De-best. De-licious. Okay I'll stop now. But we love this place. We've been for brunch and dinner and both were amazing. The flavors are so good.  The sauces...are just perfect. We love Terry - the wine guy. All of the staff are wonderful actually. You should go. But not too many of you. Because we want to become regulars so don't make it too hard to get in.

We're coming back.  We stopped in for a drink before a show at Victory Gardens without knowing anything about this restaurant besides the fact that it was between our car and the theatre.  (We're parents of two young children, we just don't get out like we used to.  SOMEDAY!)  What a fantastic find!First, the host and servers were superb.  Just the right amount of friendly and helpful, we felt at home immediately.  The beers on tap are just the right selection to go with the food (we only ordered the delicious black pepper gouda dumplings and desserts, but read the entire menu) and I had a gorgeous Alsacan riesling that couldn't have been better suited to a warm summer evening.  The desserts were on point and unlike any we've had.  A layered almond cake with pistachio ice cream and a divine chocolate rice pudding with cherries and a sprig of thyme.  If we hadn't had to leave for the show I would have stayed all night.  Thank you, chef, and thank you FOH staff.  It was perfect.

Excellent food. I came across this restaurant through their Reader review. Highly recommend the Gouda dumplings, nasi goreng, and buttermilk chicken. If you like Asian flavors, this is a refined and creative version. Mixed drinks are also good. The staff is  very helpful with recommendations. Will be back!

Had such a lovely meal at De Quay this evening. Nice ambiance with dim lights and cute decor. Delicious cocktails, loved the dumplings and the whitefish (kaffir lime remoulade was so good!). The almond spekkoek with pandan ice cream was the perfect end to the delicious meal. Service was excellent. Will be coming back!

First, shoutout to Terry the house manager for being one of the best hosts I've ever come across after our reservation had an error.  He helped work it out, and thankfully we got to enjoy de Quay!  Give that man a raise because he knows how to make people happy.As a couple that loves the Chicago foodie scene and see is as our main "entertainment" in the city, we've seen a lot - and de Quay is one of those few 5-star spots.  We came for restaurant week and also got some classics off the menu, and everything was great.  Most notable were the drinks and the balance between food portions and taste.  We've had that experience of delicious food but small portions at a restaurant, but the portions at de Quay were hearty enough to fill you up, and their blend of Dutch and Indonesian is one of kind.  Our server was quick, attentive, and helpful navigating the menu of options as well.  Comfortable ambiance that allowed for us to hear each other easily at the table but also laugh loudly without any worries.Well done.  Add this to our list to bring out-of-towners.

This place is great. We stumbled upon it in between errands on a Friday and I'm so happy we did. The food was amazing, the wine list is awesome and the service is the best. Top notch and will definitely be back!

They use good quality ingredients. But what the miss on the food was putting all the ingredients as a dish. There is a lack of flavor complexity. Service was excellent otherwise. Good starting point for fish development. it requires further fine tuning to put all these flavors in concert. For the quality of food overall, I find the price too expensive.
Super innovative food! Chef is reaching from left field for this concept but it works out great? It's a little small inside for me but that doesn't matter b once you try the food.

Food:For our appetizer we split the black pepper gouda dumplings. They came with a dijon aioli, which was unexpected, but paired wonderfully with the creamy dumplings, especially when eaten with the peppers.For our entree we had the duck and the braised beef short rib. Unlike some other reviewers, I did not find the duck to be overcooked. The short rib itself was outstanding, but the croquette was just OK.For our dessert, we shared the almond spekkoek, which was great with the pandan ice cream.Drinks:The highlight of the meal was the Bee Sting. It was a great balance of flavors, and surprisingly not too sweet for a ginger beer drink with honey. We also tried the Woodsman, which was good but nothing exceptional, and an orange juice based gin drink (the name is escaping me) that was good on its own, but a little sweet for my tastes. (I should have figured that out from the orange juice based, but took a chance.)Service was attentive, and my mother had a good time with the server being ridiculous

The food is astounding. I took a friend for her birthday dinner and in her thank you note to meshe said "It is definitely one of the best meals I have had in Chicago."The dumplings are my favorite appetizer but you can't go wrong. Great service, too.They have brunch on Sunday's starting on Sunday the 18th. Can't wait!
Went for restaurant weekEverything was delicious. Had the shrimp sate and lamb curry for entrees.Very nice service and atmosphere

One of the worst eating experiences I have experienced in the last 30 years of great restaurants in Chicago.  I read some of the reviews. I don't get it.  The food quality was bad at best.  Only 5 entries to select from off the limited menu.  I got the "Nais Goreng" or it should be renamed the "Nazis Goring". This is basically fried rice with a two poached eggs and 5 1" square  pieces of pork belly for $19.  Come On, My local Chinese restaurant could do better for $5. The scallops for $28 were hard to find on the plate, There were like 5 sliced in half. I also got the "Gado Gado" salad. Once again miss named it should be be " God oh God where is my salad" It was 5 thin strings of greens with a peanut vinaigrette dressing that was non existing.  We had to ask for some peanut sauce to add some favor.  All this for only $10. In general stay away.  poor quality food, over priced with micro sized portions. It also took over 60 minutes to delivery this feast from the time our drinks and salads were delivered.

Once upon a time, there was a Dutch American undergraduate student (me) who studied in Maastricht, the Netherlands for a semester to get in touch with her Dutch roots. During that time, the undergraduate student fell in love with frites met satesaus (French fries with Indonesian peanut sauce), which she could purchase for a mere five guilders (about $2.50 at the time). Upon returning to the United States and graduating from college, the young woman searched and searched for frites met satesaus throughout West Michigan where many Dutch Americans live but to no avail. Although she was able to order French fries with a side of peanut sauce meant for other dishes on occasion, it was not until she discovered de Quay more than twenty years after her return to the States that she found one of her favorite flavor combinations on a menu in America. When she visited de Quay with her husband, they created their own rijstaffel (rice table) by ordering the frites met satesaus, nasi goreng (Indonesian fried rice), Gouda cheese dumplings, and a homemade stroopwafel (syrup-filled waffle cookie) with ice cream. The frites were crispy of the outside and soft on the inside, and the satesaus was perfect! The peanut sauce was just as the now-not-so-young woman remembered. The nasi goreng was flavorful, fluffy, and moist all at the same time. The Gouda cheese dumplings were unusual as well as outstanding, and the stroopwafel was warm and gooey in the most tantalizing of ways. Lekker! (Luscious!) In addition, the service was outstanding, which means that this food fairytale was a dream come true. To de Quay, the hero in our story (me) says, "Dank U wel!" (thank you) and to her dear readers, she says, "Eet smakelijk!" (Enjoy your meal!)

My boyfriend took me here for my birthday, and I've been raving about this restaurant ever since. Upon arrival, the staff welcomed us by wishing me a happy birthday as they took us to the table. Shortly after, the general manager stopped by our table and thanked us for choosing D'Quay. As we looked at our menus, I noticed the top right hand corner had "Happy Birthday, Ashley" printed on tonight's dinner menu. I'm a sucker for personalization and I really enjoyed that I was able to take the menu home. This is all about the service, I haven't even started on the food.My boyfriend had the duck, and I had the salmon. The salmon was prepared in a fall style, with a butternut squash base. The duck was very tender and flavorful as well!!Thanks for making this experience a memorable one!

Heard about this new restaurant from a friend. Was intrigued I'm  from  NY and have never had Dutch Indonesian fusion. Decided  to explore a bit and try it out. Located in a nice area the restaurant is nicely appointed.  The menu was interesting and the food was great. Every bite was wonderfulWait staff was friendly and on top of service. Would definitely recommend this place to anyone.

De quay did an incredible job tonight. Everything was so delicious for one, and when I let them know I had a gluten allergy they were extremely attentive. They offered me a dish that I actually couldn't have because it wouldn't have been gluten-free and they went above and beyond, giving me a special entree and an extra glass of wine. So grateful - but even beyond that stellar service I would recommend this place to anyone!!

I've been meaning to come here and I'm so glad I finally did! Everything was amazing...especially the Gouda mashed potatoes and chicken curry! I suggest sitting at the bar and getting advice from the bartender. They know what's up! Will definitely be back.

I write this review with some hesitancy.Hesitant that so many people will discover this culinary gem, that I will not be able to get a table in the future. I cannot say enough good things about the food, and the people who make you feel welcome and comfortable to be there. Described as a fusion of Dutch and Indonesian cuisines, the flavour combinations are just sublime. Sophisticated comfort food with as sophisticated of a palate. Noel behind the bar is knowledgable and eager to help with your drink and meal pairings, Terry working the floor and front of house makes you feel at home. Tonight we feasted on  the lamb curry and the pork chop and it was just divine. For desert the chocolate peanut-butter mouse pave was decadent as well as delicious.  For us this is an exquisite addition to our neighborhood and soon to be a second home.

Great service --the owner came around asking each table if we enjoyed our food. Wish there were more Indonesian flavors in some of the dishes. Everything was well cooked. Overall, very much enjoyed our experience!

De Quay is a much needed oasis in a food enthusiast dead-zone on Lincoln Ave. I can't believe it took me this long to come here given the stellar reviews from Yelp and local critics. From the first drink to the final spoonful of desert, our experience was 5 star. Danny, our waitress, was amazing, helpful and friendly throughout our 2.5 hour meal. Terry, the sommelier, helped us make excellent choices with the wine and introduced us to a very interesting "safe word".  Bottom line - come here.  Mussels, lamb chops, short rib and duck are all highly recommended. The cocktails, wine, service, food and dessert were all amazing and I can't wait to come back.

Dutch-Indonesian you say? Yes, please! Great hidden gem of a restaurant in Lincoln Park. Perfect date night spot as the restaurant is small and cozy. Well made cocktails and approachable wine list. The mussel appetizer was the highlight of the night. The coconut curry sauce was some of the best I've had. We also had the gouda dumplings and tamarind bbq duck, both of which were delicious and well prepared. Service was fine, but after reading the rave reviews I was a bit underwhelmed. Yes, it was a busy Friday night, but I would have a hard time believing this place isn't always busy. Overall, an absolute must try if you're looking for something unique and different.

I am not very adventurous with restaurants and was very skeptical about having Dutch and Indonesian food.  Whatever spices and seasonings were used, it was absolutely delicious!We started with several appetizers.  My favorite was the fondue type cheese dip.  Like heaven on bread!The salmon entree was great but the short ribs were amazing.  No, I didn't eat both meals myself.  I shared with a friend.The Frittas (french fries) were awesome as were the mashed potatoes.Service was great! Would definitely go back but it was a bit pricey for the portion sizes.  If you have a big appetite, this is not the place for you!Yummy!!!

I had a lovely New Year's Eve dinner at this cozy restaurant in Lincoln Park. I started out with the Black Pepper Gouda Dumplings which came with an ample side of mustard sauce. This were not my favorite item of the evening, but they were good. I like my dumplings to be soft, but al dente and these were hard and somewhat crunchy. My next course was the Nederland Winter Salad with Shaved Butternut Squash, Frisee, Raisins, Cumin-Chili Spiced Pecans, Granny Smith Apple with a Mustard Vinaigrette and this was delicious. My entree course was Grilled Salmon with a Shrimp Sambal Vinaigrette with Roasted Winter Vegetables and Toasted Curried Pumpkin Seeds. I loved this dish. I also had the Vegetarian version of the Nasi Goreng which is an Indonesian Fried Rice. This dish is quite Spicy with the Indonesian spices that is in it. This was my favorite of the evening and unless their menu changes drastically it will be ordered each time, even if most of it is going to be packed up to take home, as was on the night I was there. What would New Year's Eve be without dessert? For the finale I had the Almond Cake with the Pandan Ice Cream, which is reminiscent of Pistachio Ice Cream. The manager came be my table a few times to check and see that I was enjoying my dinner and even offered a glass of sparkling wine on the house. This is a wonderful neighborhood restaurant that offers a unique blend of two cuisines Dutch and Indonesian and I highly recommend dinning here.

We've been to hundreds of restaurants around downtown Chicago and this is seriously a top 10 of them. The Dutch/Indonesian menu is so different than anything else you can find, and the sauces and sides compliment the dishes so well. The Gouda dumplings, chicken with peanut sauce, and duck were done perfectly, as well as the almond dessert.  And the waitstaff was amazing and super helpful and friendly! The guy behind the bar was so knowledgeable about wine pairings. Will definitely be back and telling our friends about it!
The service was great and the food was surprising. I enjoyed flavor combinations that I had never experienced before.

The world could use more Dutch-Indonesian restaurants. Loved everything about this awesome find during a weekend in Chicago. Great wine list and cool bar. Wish I could eat everything with the peanut sauce we had with the A'dam frites and chicken sate starters. Apparently the Nasi Goreng wasn't everything my dutchie hoped for, but I enjoyed trying it. My buttermilk chicken did the trick and if you don't order the Stroopwafel you should just consider ending your life.

We have enjoyed both dinner and brunch at de Quay with excellent experiences each time.  A cool Euro bistro atmosphere with very very friendly service.  We lived a few months in the Netherlands and our meals at de Quay exceeded our expectations.  The Nasi Goreng is very good as is the Tamarind Soy duck.   Cool cocktails, great Belgian and micro brews on tap, and a smart wine list.  A really enjoyable experience.  We will be back!!

It often seems that I visit a new restaurant, really enjoy the experience, write a positive review -- then visit the place subsequently and am disappointed. I hope this will not be my experience with de Quay, because it seemed very promising on a recent weekend dinner visit. We loved the food and beer, the cordial & attentive service from both our server and the manager, and the cozy Dutch ambiance. But I fall in love too easily, and I can't bear the thought of heartbreak...We liked the compact menu -- it features a blend of Dutch and Indonesian choices that I haven't encountered before. The gouda dumplings were a tasty start -- and comfort food of the highest order. My pork chop entrée made me happy; possibly brined, sous vide and flash grilled, it was tender & delicious in a Dijon sauce served with gouda mashed potatoes, smoky rookworst sauage, napa cabbage slaw, and fried kale. Great combo of flavors and textures. My companion's short rib was simply the best I've tasted -- so tender, so flavorful -- and nicely plated with a couple of short rib croquettes and a fluff of pea shoots. Our plates were clean and we were all grins! Dessert was OK, if a little low-key: we had almond spekkoek (like a dobosh torte filled with almond paste) and pandan ice cream. The coffee was excellent, fresh & flavorful (nearly as good as Julius Meinl). There's a nice selection of beers and wines, too.I am already planning to return. This could be the real thing. A boy can hope...

My boyfriend and I have been to De Quay for dinner and brunch. The food is interesting and delicious and the staff could not be friendlier. Dinner was definitely the better meal due to its options -- we had the Nederlands salad, the mussels, the chicken curry, and the dumplings. Brunch is a good off-the beaten path option and the potato side dish is really delicious. But again, the ambiance at night cannot be beat. It's such a cozy restaurant, great for comfort food in the winter.

The food at this place was fantastic (the duck was unreal), but what really convinced me to write a review was the service. They were extremely attentive but not pushy, and went out of their way to please - from splitting our shared portion without needing to ask, to allowing us to order a side of croquettes when that wasn't a menu item. Great restaurant.
Broccoli cheddar soup delicious could be a little more thick but they have 12 kinds of soupsEmployees really peppy lol

Ok, I'm probably not going to make any friends by writing this, but, I think Soup Box is a little overhyped. Don't get me wrong, it's good, I've been to both locations lots of times. But, I'm not sure it's worth all the rave reviews.For about $6 you get a cup of soup (maybe 10-12oz) and a hunk of bread. The soup is always scalding hot. It takes at least 5 minutes for the soup to be an edible temperature (don't come here if you're in a hurry to dig in). I've burnt my tongue and the roof of my mouth every single time. The restaurant is also always blazing hot.However, the soup is good. And the staff is always nice. You can sample the soups (again, they're usually so hot it's actually difficult to taste them). Both locations have outdoor seating which is nice on fall and spring days.I'll keep eating here but I don't think it's a food destination.

This is really good soup!  The very friendly staff encourages trying samples.  They have a variety of toppings including extra lobster for their lobster bisque.  My wife got the potato soup, and kids got chicken and wild rice.  The portion size is large, so it is great for hungry vacationers.  Four people were stuffed with soup, a large piece of complimentary bread and sodas for about $40.The place is a little hard to find.  It's a little doorway off Chicago Ave. but finding it is worth it.

Stumbled upon this place while looking for some comfort food. It's a little hidden right now due to the sidewalk construction. The lobster bisque was AMAZING and they were more than happy to provide samples of their soups. They also had Beatles music playing so another great touch. My only minor complaint is that it's very hot inside of the restaurant. Then again, it was an unseasonable 80 degrees today. I will definitely return!

5 stars and then some.Honestly, even if you aren't the biggest soup fan this place is worth it based on the customer service alone.While I'm a fan of soup, I was honestly blown away by the guys who worked there. All extremely nice, helpful, and seemingly loving what they do. They offered us samples, helped us mix concoctions of different soup flavors and even made us laugh. Genuinely good guys.The soup. The soup is great too which makes the experience even better.They come in multiple sizes and you can even get your soup in a bread bowl or a baked potato bowl- amazing, right?I tried the broccoli cheese in the bread bowl and devoured it. The soup was hot and the bread was very fresh.Next time I'm in Chicago I will be back here for sure.

Great soup for those cold, windy Chicago days.  The staff is super friendly and they let you sample different soups before making your decision.  Plenty of toppings/mix-ins.  The grilled cheese is also delicious and perfect for dipping.  Small, cozy shop, but ideal for a quick lunch.  Somewhat pricey, but it hits the spot when you're craving something warm and comforting.

This place (Chicago ave) is right around the corner from my job so if I have s craving for soup at lunch time it's a go to, especially if I feel like I'm coming down with something! Any way, the soup is usually always good, I appreciate the vegetarian and vegan options. I only have 2 concerns, as a vegetarian I would eat always taste the tomato before I got it because more often than not it seemed very watered down. Also the soup is a bit under seasoned some times... But to add to that they have a complementary spice wrack so you can add some zest! I just wish it was not so pricy, I know it's the Gold Coast, and everything is pricy, and I know they "home make" the soups, but I paid 9 dollars for 1 bowl of vegetable soup today... That's crazy to me!  As a vegan now the veggie chili is great, the bean soup is good, the fire roasted veg is excellent and the chipotle sweet potato was the bomb. I like that you can mix soups also. If you ever want extra bread, they will give it to you, the staff is super friendly, those items make the price seem a little more legit.

Was on vacay in Chitown and actually double dipped on soupbox in the same trip. So ridiculous I know.Anyway I tried the chili with a bread bowl. Chili was thick and tasty. Bread bowl was okay. It's not necessary but good to try.Second trip I tried the hearty beef stew. Really enjoyed it but wish they put a little more meat in there to be honest. It was very flavourful though.Overall, soupbox is worth a try. I'll be back to try the different soups one day!

I was looking forward to Soapbox - my throat felt a bit scratchy and the wind was pretty heavy on the day I stopped in for lunch. There was maybe two veggie soups of their ten or so soups available, so I went with the veggie and bean soup. They give you one free topping and bread or crackers with your soup. I went with onion for the topping, thinking it'd be caramelized.I got my soup to go and brought it back to my hotel room a block away. The soup was just okay, not a lot of veggies or beans and quite oily feeling. I opened the onions and saw they were raw, so I was only going to add a few. By mistake, most of the little container went in, and the soup was pretty much just overpowered by onion. With each soup, it would be nice if they listed a recommended topping.Overall, service was friendly enough, though not super attentive. The place itself has a salad bar-type area too, but it didn't feel as nice or clean as a Hale and Hearty, for example. It was overall a 2.5 or so, but I was generally underwhelmed.
Awesome soup and they let you sample everythingStaff is amazing and more helpful than any place I've ever been!Whole grain bread is greatThe regular size is bigger than it seems

Soupbox was a lifesaver the first time I was here several years ago!!  It was a cold Fall night, and my wife was feeling awful.  I exited our hotel in search of some restaurant with chicken noodle soup.  As fate would have it, I found Soupbox a couple of blocks away.  Mind you, I was not using Yelp back then, so finding this little gem was pure luck!!  Got us both their Classic Chicken Noodle soup, and it was the bomb!  Tasted awesome on that frosty Fall evening.  Wifey felt much better within a couple of hours.Fast forward several year later.  I had to make a return visit here while we were back in Chicago.  Circumstances were now different because the weather was quite hot that afternoon day.  Did not stop us from enjoying some of their soup.  The crew was helpful and friendly.  They suggested we sample some of their offerings which we happily did.We shared a cup of their Signature Creamy Chicken and Wild Rice soup and their Thick and Rich Potato and Bacon soup.  Both were so yummy!!  Wouldn't hesitate to order these soups again.Highly recommend this little Gem especially on those chilly Chicago days!!

I ended up here after a quick Yelp search showed it was within walking distance from my hotel.They had a dozen soups to choose from with a few vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free options too.  The rotation changes daily but they have the current lineup posted on their website (soupbox.com) after 10:30am.An employee said that the Lobster Bisque, Chicken Noodle and Chicken & Wild Rice were the most popular flavors.  I liked that they had sample cups (about the size of a tablespoon) to let customers taste the soups before ordering one.They have mix-ins like tomato, bacon, onion and mushroom you can add to any soup for .50 or $1 extra.  They will also let customers mix together any two soups if they're feeling adventurous.My pick was the Lobster Bisque.  It was nicely seasoned with a good seafood flavor.  I would have liked to see a tiny lump or two of lobster but I guess they can't work that magic at a $7.25 price point.  At least the soup came with a nice chunk of bread.I made it a combo with a Grilled Cheese although I should have ordered a salad because the sandwich was too much with the heavy soup.  It was a regular grilled cheese, the kind some college students make using an iron.My meal was ok but I think I would have appreciated the experience more on a winter Chicago day.

I really like Soupbox.  How fun to find a place that specializes in soups! Who doesn't like a good soup during the winter?They have a variety of soups to pick from. Vegan options too! If you order the soup in a bread bowl, the bread is vegan as well. Yummy and filling for an affordable price.The place is small, but with a good number of tables.  Very simple.  The staff is super nice and helpful.

Not only do they have delicious soups their customer service is great! I have gone about 5 times and every single time I am greeted and welcomed into their shop. They offer you soups to sample and I never feel rushed. Now on to their soups. My favorites are lobster bisque, chicken wild rice, and chili. So so good. Perfect for a chilly day. Definitely recommend!

It's a very nice little eatery on Chicago Ave. The staff is very friendly and helpful. They let you sample any soup before you decide which one to get. There is quite a selection of soups, including clam chowder, chicken noodles, etc. We ordered the lobster bisque soup. It was rich and creamy with a good taste of lobster. For veggies, we chose the apple berry salad. They put together the romaine lettuce, cranberries, apples, etc on the spot. It tasted very fresh and fruity. The only thing I felt could be better was to serve the salad on a plate rather than putting it in a small plastic container.Overall, we enjoyed the food, as well as the homey and cozy atmosphere.

Hidden upstairs is something that Chicagoans crave on a cold winters day.  Wipe the snot off your nose and have some soup.  Behold caldrons of about 12 selections.  Let's see about how this broccoli and white cheddar soup stacks up.  To be extra edgy, I opted to top mine with shredded cheese and bacon.  Because bacon my friends, well it just makes everything mo betta!  The sourdough bread bowl fits a healthy sized helping of 2 1/2 ladles full of creamy goodness.  It's enjoyable, I only didn't give it a fifth star as the broccoli is lacking.  More stalks and no real florets.  This cruciferous veggie is vital to my fiber and detoxification process. Lol

First time at Soupbox and will certainly be back! The employees are genuinely friendly, greeting every customer with samples. The soups are beyond delicious. And I read the story of the business and love it! Having creamy mushroom soup this time and can't wait to try their other soups.

So many different varieties of soup from chowder, tomato, chicken noodle, broccoli cheddar, orzo, and more. In addition, they have tons of toppings options for soups. They also make grilled cheese sandwiches which go great with the soups!There is a lot of table space if you want to eat in. They are friendly and I definitely recommend as a great lunch spot!

I was suppose to meet my biological dad here; he left my mom and I when I was really young. Mother eventually remarried Kevin (a true son of a bitch) and he also had a few kids from a previous marriage--total fuck ups. The soup was kinda gross, it might have tasted better if my dad showed up.

Awkward ordering process. Salad dressing is just a plastic packet filled with preservitatives. Feels like there is no adult supervision. Go somewhere else for your salad. Sanitation practices questionable - employees leaning elbows on cutting board.

I had the chicken with wild rice and it was the very tasty. The staff was really friendly and let me try samples of the various soups as this was my first visit.  I would definitely recommend a visit.

Seriously, peeps?  Complaining about price in this neighborhood is pretty nuts.  I mean, look at the meters; that's a pretty good gage to see what a meal is going to cost.  Some others have had gripes about not being full, amd that's surprising too!  The staff is fantastic and will gladly donate more bread to your grumbling stomach if asked nicely!On to the food.  It's awesome.  From the homemade bread to salads and grilled cheese.  I obviously have to mention the soup, since it's in the title!  I've had just about every soup from here and the location further north, amd I've not a single cpmplaint.  My favorites are the lobster bisque, cream of asparagus, and minestrone or veggie.  The bisque and cream soups are pretty rich, as the names hint at.  They're the perfect quick and savory lunch I enjoy, and because they offer so many variations, they're perfect to bring to a client's office for a quick bite over talking  shop.

I mean...the soups taste alright I suppose. I actually am rather fond of their creamy chicken and wild rice, and their potato and leek. But for a small bowl(even if you order a larger size, I still find myself walking away hungry) of soup and some bread...after tax it's running you ~$10. The soup is good, but not that good.

The ONLY reason I'm giving the Soupbox a 3 star is for the price for a large soup and a piece of bread $9.37 and it was Tomato Bisque at that.I love soup, I could have it for breakfast lunch and dinner. I stopped by to warm myself up with soup at 11:30 on a Saturday. Place was empty I was greeted immediately. I chose the large Tomato Bisque to go. Service was great.  Soup was hot and very good along with the fresh sour dough bread that came with it. It's just really difficult to get by the price for Tomato Soup.

Super friendly staff! I found this place on a rainy evening and it was perfect. Hot soup (lots of kinds) and warm bread. They have a small salad bar too. A few seats looking out the window are good for people watching. A nice experience. Reasonable prices.

Was feeling under the weather and Stopped in for soup with a friend. Had the lobster bisque and chicken with wild rice along with a grilled cheese sandwich.  The soup was phenomenal as was the service.  If you're in the neighborhood definitely a must try!
Every bit as good as the location on Broadway. Outstanding food, outstanding service, outstanding prices. Can't recommend it highly enough!

If I could bring back anything to California from Chicago, I'd bring back deep dish pizzas... and SoupBox!  What a terrific and comforting idea to have a restaurant specialize in high quality, daily-made soups.SoupBox is nothing like Souplantion and the differences begin with how the soups are presented.  They're all placed in mini-black cauldrons that remind me of the magical world of Harry Potter.  Then there's the 12 extraordinary, unique flavors that are available to taste and enjoy.  Each one is hearty, fulfilling, and wildly flavorful.  They also have vegetarian, vegan, and gluten free options!My favorites were Signature Lobster Bisque ($7.25), New England Clam Chowder ($7.25), and the signature Creamy Chicken & Wild Rice ($6.95).  I can only imagine how satisfying each one can be on a chilly, Snow-filled day in Chicago.  The only downside is that all those prices listed above are expensive for such a small bowl of soup.  I also wish there would be more clams and chicken, in the respective meals.  While the lobster bisque is the best I've ever tasted (outside Mastro's), it could use real chunks of lobster meat to add some texture. I'd recommend adding turkey for an extra $1.Each bowl comes with your choice of cheese and complimentary bread.  You can buy grilled cheese sandwiches with any soup for only $2.99 too.----Conclusion: A fantastic concept that would be a hit across the US! During those Winter months, this place would be a godsend.  At first taste, you'll easily see why it was voted the best soup in Chicago by locals.Extra Notes:-Accepts credit card-Brilliant and extremely patient service-Decor could use some changing as the floors are dark, and walls need to be repainted--Kind of seems like a dreary and gloomy place-Tables are uneven and rock, be careful-Located on top of Streeter's Tavern.  A small flight of stairs will lead you to SoupBox.-No restrooms

If the review was for the Lobster Bisque, this would be a total 5 star experience! But, after finally telling myself to give the other soups a chance, the ones I've tried were a little meh.Definition of my personal 'meh' being that it's good soup, but it's not worth that price. The last few times I was there I stopped getting drinks with it just so I could tell myself I saved money. Call me cheap, but prices that make me talk myself out of getting what I want is not really something I look for in a fast casual soup place. It's soup.I tried three different soups besides the Lobster Bisque, three different times, but I stopped going here for now. I'm sure I'll return in a year or so when I get that craving for the Bisque, but other than that, I've lost my excitement for this place.I mean, at least you get free bread.

Today I ordered soup from SoupBox via GrubHub for delivery to my office.  It turns out there was some sort of glitch in the website that allowed me to see and order a soup that is not actually offered at this time.  Clearly, I would have no way of knowing what I ordered wasn't available, but the individual who received my order at SoupBox did know that.  They received my order, saw that it was for a soup they don't have today, and then proceeded to make a series of lazy, anti-customer choices, including:  choosing a random soup to send me rather than taking 30 seconds to call me and ask what I'd like, packaging up this random soup I had no hand in choosing, and sending said unknown/unwanted soup off with a delivery person.After that they continued this stream of non-accountability by providing me with no help when I called to ask why I had received the wrong soup.  The guy I spoke to on the phone told me he wasn't sure how I would have ordered a soup they don't have today - in a tone that insinuated I had perhaps manipulated the GrubHub website to make this soup option appear.   When I asked him if it said on their end the same name of the soup it said on my receipt, he danced around that and just repeated they didn't have that soup right now.  Useless.SoupBox should work on ensuring all employees possess and utilize common sense and customer service skills.  You can't go around selling soup at such incredibly high prices and not do your best to provide quality service.If you've ever had soup from Chuck's Southern Comforts Cafe (best soup ever at half the price if not less!) you would agree that paying these wildly inflated prices for the soups on offer at SoupBox is simply not worth it, especially when lacking in customer service.

I once came here years ago and had amazing soup. No idea what kind it was, just remember it was amazing. Found myself over here today at lunchtime (well, 2:00, but lunchtime for me). I had been thinking of lobster bisque, so I ordered a regular size and it came with choice of sourdough or multigrain bread. I opted for sourdough. It was quite tasty. The lobster bisque was also really good...Only thing, there were NO lobster pieces in it!I just looked it up - bisque do not have chunks, chowders do, so that falls on my lack of soup knowledge! So, no loss of stars there. I give four stars instead of five simply because the price seems way too high for a cup of soup. People were friendly, service was quick and I left full and happy!Oh and they do samples, I tried the cream of mushroom as well - really good, with chunks of mushrooms (if you're into that kind of thing!)

Soup was amazing! A lot of different flavors and definitely hit the spot on a cold day.I would have given 5 stars if the price was more reasonable. We bought two soups...no drink, no sides, nothing extra and it was $20. Yikes! For two "regular" size soups thats kind of ridiculous.Also, the service was pretty poor. The girl doing the ordering had no smile and looked like she was having the most miserable day, kind of a downer being a tourist but the soup made up for it.
love itcan enjoy outside ! there are some place like a patio ! clam chowderwas good!

I always seem to stumble along this place when I visit and never disappoints.The soup is piping hot, full of flavor and you can sample before purchase! Brilliant!Love the mix and match possibilities for the indecisive want to have it all person like myself.Lobster bisque is magnificent and I got mine paired with creamy asparagus in a bread bowl. Was so full after soup but so worth it!

So many soup options! The lobster bisque is my personal favorite and you can get your soup in a bread bowl if you choose. They also make a great custom grilled cheese. Soupbox is perfect for a quick lunch stop, especially on a cold day.

Perfect place to come for a wide variety of soups. The people here are so nice and helpful and let me try samples of soups before I chose the one I wanted. I chose the chicken noodle soup which was delicious. I will definitely be back for the broccoli and white cheddar soup next time!

I've been sick with the flu for the last few days and have tried every chicken noodle soup that's available for delivery to my apartment. DoorDash was great. Easy to order and sent me texts with updates.The soup, on the other hand, not so great. I've tried five different chicken noodle soups around my location of River North and both Pret a Manger and Cosí were MUCH better. It had a very strong onion taste and not many chunky vegetables. I paid extra for the bread bowl which was soft and fresh. But there was no butter. I guess I had to specify that I needed butter with my bread.Also, my husband had the clam chowder which was fishy. Yes, I know clams are seafood. But this was fishy to the point where I questioned it's safety. Even my husband commented that it was really fishy and he eats seafood soups all the time. Personally, I think some bad clams might have hopped in the pot.The grilled cheese was very thin, similar to a panini. It wasn't anything special.I won't be ordering again, but I may give it another shot for dine-in.

I love the idea of a soup shop with twelve varieties at the ready--but I'm disappointed by Soupbox's execution. After sampling three or four soups, all relatively bland, I settled on the premium Italian Wedding Soup, pricey at $10 for a regular-sized bowl and a slice of sourdough. I was disappointed by the dime-sized meatballs, which didn't add much flavor or texture, and the watery broth. Two stars for free samples, complimentary bread and a nice concept.
Hmmm...let's see...instead of Soupbox...I want a hamburger. No, cheeseburger. I want a hot dog. I want a milkshake. I want potato chips...

This little gem came highly recommended - and did not disappoint! As a reprieve from the bitter chill, we entered to find a row of cauldrons (we were warned there would be cauldrons, but we thought our recommender was exaggerating - he wasn't!). Immediately I thought a witch would pop up from behind to try and stuff me in an oven - only to be pleasantly surprised to be greeted by the clerk who would prove to be very helpful by offering samples to solidify my choice.I went for the lobster bisque and grilled cheese. It was exactly what I needed to warm up and everything I hoped it would be and more. Reasonably priced and great when you're looking for something that doesn't take a long time to prepare!#comfortfoodsogood

Yelp makes another home run! Unlike the Cubs ever will.Found this on Yelp when BF said "I feel like soup." Find "soup". Soupbox pops up. It's a winner! I have never heard of mixing soups before. How interesting. I shied away from such a thing, but BF mixed 2 and said it was awesome. I got the cream of asparagus. You can't get cream of asparagus soup just anywhere. Delicious! I was not disappointed. And the employees were just outstanding. They were kind, helpful, respectful, genuine. The employees are the reason we will come back every time we go up to see the Cardinals beat the Cubs.Management, please let your employees know they're doing a great job!

They've increased their prices which makes eating there a rather ridiculous affair. Regular bowl  12 oz of soup is now $9.50 with $3.99 for grilled sandwich. I never thought that I would say this but.... Whole Foods pricing is looking very reasonable compared to this!
Best soup I've ever had!! I had the broccoli white cheddar soup with a chicken grilled cheese! Friendly and welcoming staff and a must do for lunch if you're in the area !
You want soup? $12.No soup for you! Come back NEVER!

Wish we could give this a half a star less but I am being generous and rounding up. The soups were very good as was the service. However, the place could use a good cleaning especially the bathrooms. Additionally, we found it to be a bit overpriced.

When it's cold, the sound of soup, as simplistic as it may be, just makes my body warm.Soup Box offers a lovely variety, I think 12ish options from potato leak, beef stew, to chicken and wild rice. The witch like kettles that they all brew in brings a wonderful mystic vibe.Ask for samples, and don't be afraid to mix soups up. Who knows, it may be the next big hit!

Ordered Soupbox for lunch today. I should have just waited until I was home to eat.Ordered: Premium - Italian Wedding SoupI was so excited because I love meatballs in my soup.Meatballs were half the size of a doughnut hole (like brown "pebbles") and the broth lacked flavor (it was missing something).Two stars - Postmates delivery was FAST.Minus three stars -- large ordered soup was quite small for $10.- Felt ripped off.- The Pebble meatballs was the biggest disappointment.- Not filling.Guess I'll still be on a look out for great soup place.

Ordered the creamy chicken wild rice soup in a bread bowl. The soup was so good, dare say best I've ever had! The sourdough bread bowl was on point too! A little pricey compared to others but the few extra bucks are worth it.

here I sit.. in the middle of summer.. eating warm soup.. listening to Bob Marley.. and it can't get much better than this.with 12 different cauldrons of soups, one is sure to find the perfect one. AND they give you free samples. WHAT?! it's true. I got the creamy chicken & wild rice with multigrain bread AND a la croix. I imagine heaven serving these types of goods. if you're trying to be healthy, maybe steer away from the chicken wild rice soup, as I'm pretty sure it is 3.75/4ths cream based. if you don't necessarily care about health today, go for it! you won't be disappointed and you'll leave the restaurant feeling like the world is a better place with that soup in it.the cashier was super helpful & friendly. my tummy is fully satisfied. good location.you should go.

I was very unimpressed. It was just not my cup of tea...err soup. I sprung for the lobster bisque because  I might as well pay $7.25 for a cup of soup if the only other thing I was interested in was $6.50 or so. It had a good flavor, but I only got 1 tiny bit of lobster in it. I've definitely had better for cheaper. I tried my friend's broccoli white cheddar, which was light and had a strong broccoli flavor. It's good if you prefer light soups, but I like my thick heavy soups. I also tasted the Florentine tomato, which was alright. The soups each came with a good chunk of sourdough.It was a cute place to hang out and keep warm, but I couldn't get over the bar with live music playing downstairs. The vibrations got on my nerves, but I'm guessing this is just at night. My friends totally enjoyed their soups and the place, so it's just a matter of preference.
Great soup grouping. Perfect for visitors who need something warm for the cold Chicago weather
Every time I visit, my tongue and stomach are happy but my wallet is sad.Never did I think I'd rationalize paying $10 for soup, but I do. I may be an idiot, but that Lobster Bisque is insanely good.

I got the Chicken and Wild Rice and my husband got the Cheesy Baked Potato. We both really enjoyed our soups, however, we had to wait quite a bit to enjoy it because it was so freakin hot. Complimentary bread comes with the soup which is awesome. We also got a grilled cheese - american on sourdough. It was okay. Nothing special. Not sure if it was worth $3 honestly.Staff was friendly and helpful - we were able to try whatever we wanted before we ordered which was really nice.The chicken in my soup reminded me of the chicken you would find in Campbell's canned soup. There wasn't a lot so I was able to pick it out. I still enjoyed the soup - just really think the ingredients need to be better quality if your going to charge $7 for 12 ounces.

Did I really just spend $11 for chicken and rice soup in a bread bowl? Yes, yes I did. After receiving said soup, I follow the sign pointing to the "free topping" area. A girl behind the counter rudely tells me I should have told the guy who got the soup (despite their signage saying otherwise). The bread bowl was dry and cardboard-y. Just go to Panera and save yourself the hassle.

The staff is comprised of fun-loving, youngsters who always have a smile on their face. Delicious Lobster Bisque but quite pricey. You can add more Lobster as a topping and don't forget that you can sample these soups before investing in a pricey cup.

I got the New England clam chowder & it was awesome. I got the piece of bread that comes with it but I could go without it, it's not that great of bread (I rly love bread so I judge people based on their bread). To recap: soup is AMAZING. Bread is not. I'm definitely gonna go back and try the other soups. Also I wish they had bigger sizes. The bread bowl they offer is def not happening, & the "large" isn't big enough. When I eat soup usually that's all I eat so I like to eat a lot of it. I guess I could just get two next time...

Amazing soup and you can mix soups together. However, there are different levels price wise and I got the regular size of veggie sm chili (delicious and bread included) but it was $10.50! So probably will bypass this place next time and go to Chick Fil A next door.

column4: East Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA
column13: I don't know if the cold weather or what, this probably one of the best soup places I've ever tried. Came here on vacation with friends and we were so full from lunch that Soupbox was a snack for us. Super HOT soup that made my heart super warm :)Environment - Although this restaurant is small, it gives off a very good vibe when you first step foot into it. There is one counter when you walk in and there are literally barrels of soup right in front with a server in the back. There are plenty of chairs and tables for you to sit comfortably. There's even a nice bathroom for you use when you drink too much soup :)Service - The servers give good recommendations when you ask them. There was always a smile on the workers' faces and never did they seem impatient while my friends and I were making our decisions on which soups to get.Food - I don't think you can go wrong with any kind of soup here. Whenever I am given the option to have soup as a meal, I ALWAYS choose chili. However, since I already had chili earlier today, we got other of their many fine options:- Lobster Bisque - although there weren't chunks of lobster or any for that matter, there was very good lobster flavoring in the soup. It was very smooth, creamy and flavorful. It wasn't at all too seafoody nor salty. It tasted really good with sourdough bread of course. Although this one is on the more expensive side, it is a very good one to share with a friend :)- Broccoli White Cheddar - two words: light and smooth. I think if you're to eat a soup alone, this would be the perfect choice. There was a good blend of both broccoli and cheddar, not one over-powering another.-Tomato Florentine - I don't think i've ever had a tomato soup that went wrong. With that said, this soup was perfect and the chunks of vegetables inside were very soft. I ordered the grilled cheese with the soup because, come on, why wouldn't you eat them together. Add a grilled cheese to any soup fro $2.99 I took advantage of that.- Grilled Cheese - on first glance, the sandwich looked a little greasy.... but I looked past that. The grilled cheese was super soft when I bit into it and the butter and crunch from the toast were the perfect touches that topped the whole meal off.In conclusion, eat here.The end :)

Just what I needed feeling under the weather on a December afternoon.My little peanut gave me her cold, so I decided to seek out some soup. A few coworkers recommended Soupbox, and so despite the 6-block walk (which is long enough to Divvy) I decided to give it a go.I sampled the clam chowder, which this day was served Manhattan-style. It was good but I prefer my clam chowder white, so I went with the wild rice and cream of chicken soup in a breadbowl.The breadbowl is excellent. I grabbed a sourdough breadbowl (I can't remember if there's any other type) and it was fine-crumbed, for a sourdough, and very flavorful. Then soup itself had discretely chewy rice and good chicken chunks and flavor. Better than anything I could pull together at home, that's for sure.Next time I'm feeling under the weather, I'll be willing to give Soupbox a spin.

Great concept! There's so many different soups, and they let you try before you buy! But don't burn your tongue on the samples like I did :PI sampled the potato/leek and lobster bisque. Both were good, but I went with the potato/leek because the bisque was just liquid and I needed some texture. Comes with a piece of bread, and the sourdough was really good! Also, had a side salad which was decent but nothing special.There's an option to mix 2 in a bowl which I will do next time. The regular size (which is their smallest option) was actually pretty big and I got a little bored eating one soup. I ended up adding cayenne at the end to jazz it up.Tip: Do NOT sit at the tables with your soup! All of the tables are not balanced for some reason and can dangerously rock at any sudden movement. I almost got doused with my piping hot soup before I even ate. Eat at the bar stools or take it to go.
The soup is really good. The staff was also very nice. Only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is the price. It is expensive for what you get.
Had the brocolli and white cheddar soup in a bread bowl. That will fill you up and some. Very good.
Nice staff and soups are great :)I mixed 2 soups: fresh broccoli with white cheddar and cheesy baked potato. Try it ;)
Tried the potato and clam chowder. Both really good. The place is small so might be tricky to get a table if you go at peak times. Friendly staff

I was really excited for some warm soup on a cold windy day of touring chicago, but they did not live up to the reviews. The soup selection was ok, the service was confusing and a simple grilled cheese sandwich took forever. There are only 2 vegetarian options and not many healthy ones.

Randomly in the mood for soup on a summer night and chose to come here. It's within walking distance of many hotels so that's convenient. Now, I'm a huge soup lover. This place has a wide variety of soups to choose from but they were sold out of the chicken and wild rice and the lobster bisque when I arrived.So I picked the clam chowder and it came with sourdough bread on the side since I didn't want the bread bowl. The soup was nothing special. Panera Bread and Marie Callender's are much better and taste more fresh. Soupbox is also really overpriced which I guess is to expect in the city. However, if I'm going to be paying that much for soup it better taste up to par and this didn't.I'm not from Chicago but I definitely wouldn't recommend this spot and I will not be returning.
Really great service. Make sure they tell you you can taste soups and get one free topping on each soup and grilled cheese!

I love soup, and I really love me some bread bowl action...thus, I am most definitely a fan of Soupbox!Seriously, what could be better than a hot bowl (bread constructed or otherwise) of soup on a blustery Chicago day? Well, it wasn't too chilly on the day that I visited Soupbox, but I was still satisfied by the experience nonetheless.With a dozen or so soups to choose from, you probably have to worry more about deciding which one soup you are going with rather than being able to find a soup that fits your tastes. From the creamy to the stock based and the meaty to the vegetarian, this place has it all. There are also vegan, vegetarian, and gluten free options. These fresh soups come in three sizes: regular, large, and bread bowl. One downside of Soupbox is that the prices are a bit steep (ie, my bread bowl clocked in at over $10), but I reckon you can argue that these price tags are on par with other spots in downtown Chicago and the bread bowl is a lot of food.For my visit, I went with the vegetarian chili and was definitely pleased. Fresh, hot, and just the right amount of spiciness, this most certainly hit the spot. Combine the soupy goodness with the fresh and voluminous sourdough bread bowl and I was heading straight towards a delightful food coma.Note to the customer: Once ordering at the first counter and receiving your food, then proceed down to the register at the back end of the store to pay.The only other negative of this spot is that there could easily be a lack of seating when it's poppin'! And I do believe this place gets busy. So it may be wise to snag a seat as soon as you can or take your food to go when the crowds dictate so.Soupbox also offers salads, grilled cheese! (which I definitely would have gotten if not for the bread bowl), and gourmet cookies for your dining pleasure.If I lived in Chicago, I know I'd be a frequent visitor attempting to try as many soups as possible!
A cold day? 10 different varieties of soup? Soupbox to the remedy rescue. It literally screams fall/winter heart hug.
Delicious soups, we have them delivered once a week to our office. Always make sure to get that grilled cheese on the side, but stay away from the salads...not their specialty.
Love love love soupbox! They generally have 12 flavors and let you sample before committing. You can also mix flavors, always a yummy treat. Parking is a pain but worth it if you have time.

My wife and I have a tradition that we see the Christmas decorations Downtown and walk from Marshall Fields to Millennium Park and up Michigan Ave.  We always stop here for dinner before we had back to our car.  The soups are great and enjoy picking our own grilled cheeses.  It is one of the highlights of our trip every year.

This place is awesome!!!  Great soups with a variety of about 10 daily.  Nothing better than a hot soup on a -15 degree day in Chicago. I had the creamy chicken and wild rice and it was delicious. You can sample the soups before you commit which is also nice. I wish there was a soup shop like this closer to my home but is a great pitstop when in the Chicago redline area.
Good soup for a quick meal on a cold day. Friendly staff. Fast service. And they're very patient with letting you try different types.
Perfect rainy day food! lots of options, all good and the staff was really polite. Would def eat again. Grilled cheese with bacon was great, and shaped like a heart! wwwhat?
This is a must stop for me anytime I am in downtown Chicago. Love this place. Outstanding soups and grilled cheese. You can't go wrong here.

Although the service is pretty friendly and the chicken and wild rice soup I had was tasty-- the prices are way too high for the food you get. I could easily make soup at home for $1 and have it taste almost as good.

Soup?  Awesome.  Soup+Grilled Cheese?  Awesomeness to a "whole...'nother...level".*Yelp review break to watch MadTV clips on Youtube - who knows the reference??*Ok I'm back!  So Soupbox, here you start with your choice of 12 different soups.  Not sure which one you want to try?  Sample them!  Can't pick between two soups?  Mix them together (at your own risk)!Ok now onto the grilled cheese!  What?  You get to pick your bread AND your cheese?  And your meat and veggie?  Can't pick just one type of cheese?  Do a combo with two different cheeses!Want some salad?  Who comes to a soup place to eat salad?  Okay, I guess if you want to be healthy like that, there's salad here too.Anyway...the soup I tried here was really good, seasoned very well and not too salty.  The grilled cheese was good & cheesy.  Although it was not really grilled, more toasted in the panini press.  Still tasted good!  The service was really friendly and helpful, very accommodating considering my indecisiveness.  When you force me to make all these decisions, it is going to take some time.Price-wise it's a little more than I would expect for soup & grilled cheese, but still very reasonable.  And good service is always priceless.  If I lived in the area, I would definitely be a regular.
Best soups ever! Potato and leek. If you're ever in Chicago you need to try this place. Can't wait to try clam chowder when it comes back in August.

LOVE this place! They always have a great variety of fresh soups. And they really are FRESH!  I also love how it's super fast and easy.Free samples too, which is a must, makes it great for trying something new. If they are running low on the soup you want just ask for fresh and they will make up another pot!The small is a good amount and with the free side of bread it always fills me up! Friendly employees and great atmosphere. Wish there were more places like this around the city.Prices are pretty decent at about $8 for a soup, side of bread, and a beverage.

I used to come here all the time, as the soup was always delicious, and prices reasonable.  I moved far enough away that it was no longer convenient to stop by, so haven't been here for a couple years.  Today I had a chance to go in, and although the soup is still very good, the sizes, of both the soup and chunk of bread included, and the prices, are ridiculous.  I understand inflation, but this is pretty outrageous!  The large is about the size the regular used to be, and the bread they give with it is about half the size it was in the past.  The prices have gone up a lot!  I bought it for nostalgic sake, but next time I'm in the area, will not be coming here again.

"no soup for you"We all know about the seinfeld episode. But this could apply to you if you went between 11:30 and 1PM during the weekday.Hold on.
