I live a block from the Breakfast Club and I am so lucky to do so.The food is very inventive and every dish that I have had always has a little surprise flavor in there somewhere.Get here during the week if you can as you will be able to walk straight in. Come at the weekend and you could find yourself waiting outside for a seat.Always be sure to check the specials, there are some gems on there.Highly recommend.

This place never fails to impress. The staff is very friendly and attentive. Karina the hostess is the sweetest girl and goes beyond what I believe her duties are to attend to the other customers.The food is very fresh and prepared very quickly! 5 stars does not do justice to what this place really is... I love it!

This is the best breakfast restaurant I have ever gone to. The food is exceptional. I have yet to have something I don't like. The severs are all friendly and the atmosphere is very positive! I have a hard time saying what my favorite is but the breakfast burrito is awesome. Yesterday I had the Carnitas Skillet which was amazing! This was the best meal I have ever had there. They out did themselves on this one!!! There is a wait on weekends but it is well worth it. I hope Manny and his crew are here for many years!!!

Been here twice for breakfast on a Monday. Our first visit was unfortunate in the sense that it was a holiday, they had just had their Check Please episode aired and it was the coldest day of the year. There's not a whole lotta standing room in this restaurant. My mouth was watering as we watched plate after plate of yumminess get devoured. Kudos to them for getting what seemed like 40 people seated withing our 20 min wait. For the record I don't wait, this was worth it!Delicious, fresh, well presented is the least I can say for our meals. I'm a waffle lover and my date is a skillet kinda guy. It was all excellent. Good coffee as well. Service was attentive. Love the decor. My mouth is watering just thinking about this place. I wish it was closer to home, we pass at least 9 breakfast joints/family restaurants on the way here.Fair warning: No free parking in the neighborhood. Metered parking on Bryn Mawr, but its only a couple of $.

Came here on a Saturday morning there was about a 20 min wait (brunch in Chicago). But it was well worth the wait. I was pleasantly surprised as it's an unassuming location, not in a busy area.  The service was great I believe the young man's name was Adrian he was awesome! Now for the food, we ordered the mango blueberry pancakes for the table, this dish was to die for, and I usually appreciate savory over sweet but it was just the right sweet/tart balance. I had the crab cakes, I love crab cakes and they are always a hit or miss, but they hit them out of the park. My friend ordered the steak skillet and it was delicious the steak was cooked beautifully and taste was perfect. Will go back again and again.

Amazing AS USUAL!! Do not leave here without trying the bread pudding French toast! The portions are always great and I typically leave with enough for another meal. My sister and I both got skillets and shared the bread pudding French toast  so good!!I clearly have a problem I've been to this place more times than I can count
Was pretty good.  I had the chorizo scramble and the wife had the stuffed french toast.  I'd try it again.

Good food and unique menu. My omelette was good but they were kind of skimpy on the ingredients. No major complaints, though. Our server was super nice and the wait was quick for a weekend brunch time.

In the future, YELP will eventually establish star rating criteria..  After seeing this on Check Please, I went WAY out of my hood to meet someone here (note--this very interesting neighborhood seemed to have tons of interesting places to eat).  As fellow yelper Tricia D noted In 5 words: not as good as expected.Place is fine--nothing special--PLUS MY CLOTHES SMELLED LIKE GREASE WHEN I LEFT--fine neighborhood spot--very expensive for what it was--Don't believe the hype.  Also, no free parking on side streets.

Friday brunchin' is the best here! Came here around 10 it was slightly busy, but babe and I got seated right away. All the servers are so sweet and attentive which is an A plus in my book. I ordered the stuffed sour dough French toast and babe ordered the bread pudding. Sweet and savory for both of us to try. The bread pudding was to die for along with the citrus liquid on the bottom of the toast, my sour dough French toast was amazing especially with the kick of heat from the potatoes. I loved the ambience and the decor of the whole place! I will definitely be back for more eats

BUZZ- Chorizo Skillet (7/10)I ALSO TRIED- Pork Sausage Gravy Biscuits (5/10)An old friend was visiting us from Korea, so another one of our friends scoured the internet to find a place for us to eat, and somehow came up with this place. I've never even heard of this place, and the word "club" had me thinking there was actually some kind of membership required. Well, luckily there is no membership.The place is not that big, but it's apparently pretty popular, because there was a 30 minute wait when we got there on Saturday morning at 10. By the time we left, the line was just as long. I checked up Yelp to give me some guidance, and even though there weren't that many reviews, most were pretty positive. Problem is, I didn't really know what to get, since, like most breakfast places, their menu is pretty big and everyone has their own favorite.CHORIZO SKILLETThe item with the just slightly more mention than most on Yelp was the Chorizo Skillet, and on top of that, the ingredients were really close to the Mexicana Skillet at Wildberry in Schaumburg, which is one of my 10/10 dishes. Obviously, since I love that dish, every bite of this was going to be in comparison to that.Let's start with what's in it: chorizo, onion, tomatoes, black beans, avocado, sour cream,  chipotle sauce, roasted potato hash, 2 eggs, and cheddar cheese. I replaced cheddar with Chihuahua cheese in mine, which is what I do at Wildberry too. Now, a few of the differences here were the addition of black beans, diced potatoes instead of hash browns, and chipotle sauce. It also was missing the jalapeños. They did give a few leaves of cilantro, but it was more like garnish than it was for actual flavoring, which was a problem. Cilantro really helps flavor the dish with a flavor of freshness that only it can provide.Now a thing about chorizo...it's salty. It's delicious, but too much uninhibited chorizo and it just because a salt mine. It's the job of everything around it to balance it, but not to snuff it out (like omelettes usually do). The loss of cilantro hurt it a bit, but the black beans, while I think of as sort of a neutral addition to the dish, cut it a bit too. The potatoes I think were seasoned great to eat by themselves, but if the goal was to cut the saltiness of the chorizo, it actually made it worse. The avocados and sour cream helped quite a bit too, but there was just a little too much chorizo at the end of the day, and it ended up being a bit too salty for my taste.Now the biggest thing is this chipotle sauce. Wildberry gives you the spice in the form of jalapeños and salsa. That gives you a nice clean spicy kick. The salsa and cilantro in Wildberry's skillet give you the air of freshness and the salsa and jalapeños add a little bit of sour instead of salt. The chipotle sauce here gives it a little too much bold and salty flavors and just sort of ends up dulling the peaks of the chorizo, but again, adding salt.I can probably explain it like this. If you like the taste of Tabasco (clean, spicy, pointed, sour, sweet), you'll like Wildberry's better. If you like Cholula (bold, salty, smoky, steady) then you'll probably like Bryn Mawr's. I for one am definitely still Wildberry!BISCUITS & GRAVYI only had a taste of this, but while I can't say a whole lot for the gravy, I can say that the biscuit tasted too doughy for me. Not really a fan of that flavor. I want more buttery and creamy flavors. McDonald's biscuits I think are pretty top notch.BEING BAD FEELS PRETTY GOOD, HUH?I dunno...not so creative right now. That's a line from the Breakfast Club. Anyway, the place has a lot going for it. The menu is pretty decent, so I'm sure you can find something to eat here. I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to come back, but if we happened to meet here again, I wouldn't complain. I'd definitely try something else though.

Came here for brunch the other weekend with a few girlfriends. It was a long wait, almost 30 minutes. Honestly, the food was just okay and wasn't really worth the wait.I wasn't a huge fan of anything on the menu (which was a little limited, in my opinion), so I just got the two egg breakfast. Two eggs, scrambled, with breakfast potatoes and toast. I subbed pancakes for toast. They charged an extra $4 for this. I've never been up-charged for subbing pancakes for toast at any breakfast place I've ever eaten at before...Like I said, food was just ok. Eggs were ok, nothing special. The breakfast potatoes were pretty good, but mine were cold by the time I got them, which was a little disappointing.The pancakes were super delicious! Very light and fluffy, served with a few fresh blueberries and some powdered sugar. However, was 2 small pancakes worth an extra $4? Probably not.Overall, I wouldn't go again. My meal was $15, and I don't think it was worth it. My girlfriends said the same thing, that their food was just okay but nothing super special.Overall, probably not worth a long wait on the weekend.

If I could give this place 10 stars, I would! Everything was unbelievably great from the moment we walked through the door.  The place was jam packed at 8:45 am Sunday, but we got seated right away, which was a surprise! The wait staff was so on top of everything that they brought what we needed before we even realized we wanted it. In fact, the service was so excellent that it was shocking in today's day and age.  Besides the fantastic service, this was THE BEST breakfast I have had in I can't even remember Werner and we eat out at least five times a week!. I had the bread pudding French toast and I would drive all the way from the far north burbs to have this again any day.  I also tried the chorizo skillet. I'm not a big skillet girl, but that also was amazing!  The coffee was always full, the food fabulous, the wait staff friendly and on top of it. I will definitely tell all my friends and be back again and again!!

We went there with recommended hopes.I had the veggie burger which was tasted great but crumbled upon being cut in half !! No neat way to eat it ! Next time I'll try the turkey burger.  The waitress was very nice.

A cute small restaurant...We went on a weekday around 12 maybe? It wasn't busy. Staff wasn't anything extraordinary...they have specials so I got the salmon Benedict....the bread pudding French toast was also really good. My friend got the steak..he thought it was over cooked. Not a restaurant I'll crave to go to. But definitely worth going to at least once.

What a great little place!  The food is fantastic and service wonderful.  They've recently been featured on an episode of "Check, Please!", so it seems to have brought in a good amount of business.We've been there two times, and both have been great.  They have a wonderful selection of breakfast specials (black bean cakes with poached eggs and avocado, sweet potato hotcakes, waffles, omelets, etc.).  We went recently and tried their spiced banana waffle...OMG.  It's hard to get a waffle right, people, and this place has it down to a science!  It was perfectly crispy on the outside, but also tender, moist, and super flavorful on the inside.  Heaven.  Service is wonderful, attentive, and genuine.  If you're looking for a delicious local breakfast spot, this place is it!

Woohoo! My friends and I made the voyage over to North Park after eyeing Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club on Check, Please. And thank goodness we moseyed in because it was a phenomenal experience.Making it to Check, Please typically pushes an establishment to the brink of collapse due to the onslaught. However, the entire staff handled it with such grace that I was truly astonished.  We went on a Tuesday late morning and it was reasonably packed. We were greeted immediately and grabbed seats at the communal table in the rear. Before sitting down, I took a photo of the specials board at the front, just in case we didn't get the entire spiel. Service was on-point: coffee/water was promptly refilled, waitress was highly knowledgeable of the intricacies of the menu, and appropriate condiments were delivered to the table before even asking for them.We got the chorizo skillet (overwhelming amount of deliciousness), chilaquiles verdes (yummy, perfect for hangovers), and rancheros borrachos (literally demolished in mere minutes). The first and last dish features chorizo and it was marvelously seasoned and hot. The rancheros came with a side of the plantains and they were just luscious. Price point was perfect. Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club is an international diner-esque food in a wonderful setting.

This is an amazing neighborhood breakfast spot.The food can be best described as standard American breakfast fare kicked up a notch (or three).The coffee is sourced from a local roaster and is excellent.The service is outstanding.   The servers are all on their game and you can flag down any one of them (not just your server) to get you anything you need.It doesn't look like much from the outside, but the inside is all deep grainy woods and is very homey.

Excellent food. This is a nice restaurant with great service. We had the lemon crab Benedict and the banana spiced waffles. Both dishes were excellent and well prepared. I highly recommend this place for brunch.

Someone must of slept in this morning. Drove in from Naperville to find the restaurant locked and unoccupied by anyone at 7:15 am. Assumed they changed their hours, but called later to learn the hours didn't change. I found Pannenkoeken nearby was open, it was a blessing in disguise. We'll see if I give them a 2nd chance, after looking at the expensive menu. You would think they can afford an alarm clock.

This AM was our first time there.... Featured on CHECK PLEASE.30 minute wait.... But well worth it.We were a party of 4Fresh squeezed OJ other juice choices available too.Friendly and attentive wait staff.Our meals were delicious a repeat for sure.

Unique menu and the food and service was outstanding. I had a hard time choosing from the menu but got the biscuits and gravy--definitely the best I've ever had. My boyfriend got the pancakes with peach and cherry (possibly seasonal) and said it was phenomenal. Not sure what kind of coffee they served but it was also delicious, and I really dig the retro style mugs they serve it in.We went later, around 1:00pm and got the last table, so be prepared to wait if you're going at peak times. I would definitely return and try everything on the menu!

Went here for a brunch on a Friday and had a great time.  The hostess was very welcoming and it wasn't too crowded.   Our waiter was also very accommodating and moved efficiently.I had the pujan pancake without brussel sprouts.  It was very savory, not too sweet or salty.  The side of potatoes that accompanied the meal had some red pepper garnish cooked with them, adding a little bit of color and flavor and complimenting the dish perfectly.  My meal was cooked perfectly and I didn't wait too long to receive it, which is always a plus in my book.Really nice place and I would definitely visit again.  Not the best food I've ever tasted but still worthy of 4 stars.

I love this place! The food is so delicious and beautifully presented. The coffee keeps coming and the service is pleasant. Their French omelet and specials are awesome. The owner was a former chef from M Henry. Love the neighborhood too!

Open 7 days a week from 7am to 3pm. Breakfast , brunch and lunch. Would have gotten 5 stars easily if the service was a bit faster. Every dish is creative and picture perfect. Omelettes are huge and filled with a tremendous selection of fresh fillings. Stuffed French toast, eggs benedict with nova were highlights. Bottomless coffee cups. Get there 30 to 40 minutes before you want to dine on weekends. Parking on the street. Definitely worth the visit.
Wow I was in heaven eating the turkey club and the pancake. For the price it was totally worth! Very filling and fresh will definitely be going back.

So I'm visiting my friends in Chicago and my cousin wants to have breakfast with me. So Im looking on Yelp to find a breakfast place and I see Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club. The menu looked great. So I'm about to tell her that I wanted to go there when she tells the cab driver to go to the corner of Bryn Mawr and Kimball. I'm thinking "Hey, that's where Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club is!" So we stop and sure enough, this is where she wanted to go too!The place is pretty small, but the food was grand! I had the skirt steak breakfast skillet. It was great! It had juicy strips of skirt steak, fried potatoes, pico de gallo, Gorgonzola cheese, avocado and tour choice of eggs. I chose poached. It also came with your choice of toast. I chose sourdough. Delicious!I would highly recommend this place if you want to take visitors to Chicago for a great breakfast. Their menu is amazing and they have an amazing staff!

Well I've come back to this breakfast place craving for their out-of-this-world bread pudding French toast! This is the best thing you can get here. Me and my cousin decided to try other options on the menu for a change... The steak and eggs was the best plate we got... On my previous visits here, they can't seem to get the potatoes right! However, this times some of the potatoes werent as well done! The salmon plate club was alright not salty smoked salmon although I wasn't crazy about the capers and the Sourdough stuffed french toast felt like a "grown-up Mc Griddle" but wish they didn't have the arugula which was probably too mature since it was extremely bitter! Of both dishes, I'd say as with the last time I came here the best part might have been the orange slice and pineapple wedge both of which were sweet! They weren't packed but it felt busy since it took a long time for them to prepare our food... Maybe next time I'll have to get my favorite Bread pudding french toast to go!

Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club is a really amazing place to eat at! Their chocolate milk is probably the best one i've ever tasted! Their sourdough french toast is FANTASTIC. There are also a good amount of sweet options that you can have. Like bread pudding. The service was pretty good, and the people were actually really nice. In fact, I don't know how it's not that well-known! For me, it's better than IHOP! Definitely coming back here!
Get there early, this little sweet spot gets packed. I can't wait to go back and try their Pajun Pancake plate. Everything looked delicious!

Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club is a misnomer; they serve lunch, too. My friend Linda and I wanted to try something new, and I told her how well-reviewed this place was on Yelp. She agreed to try it, based on the Yelp reviews, and we are glad we did. We had absolutely delicious, very filling breakfasts with good service in a cute place.The restaurant is on the corner of Bryn Mawr and Kimball Avenues. Writing in April 2015, I'll warn you that Bryn Mawr is undergoing construction, and is a great big mess. We came up Kimball and parked on the street, just north of the intersection. Until construction is completed, you may encounter traffic delays and parking challenges. Bryn Mawn Breakfast Club is good enough, though, that you should consider those challenges as testing your appetite. Pass the tests with patience and diligence, and you will be rewarded with good food.There is a standard menu given to everyone, and a list of specials written on a chalkboard in the front area, just north of the kitchen. The kitchen/cooking area is located in the middle of the restaurant, along the west wall, so you can clearly see the cooks at work. This is good for those customers who are nervous about food preparation. The food is cooked where everyone can see, so you can be confident that food is prepared properly.The coffee is listed as coming from some place in Michigan. It tastes just fine. The Michigan provenance doesn't mean much to me. Maybe it will to you.I ordered an omelette with leeks, asparagus, mushroom, and gruyere cheese. It typically comes with spinach, too, but I hate cooked spinach, and the staff was absolutely willing to forego that ingredient for me. It came with fried potatoes and a choice of bread; I took the sourdough, based on the server's recommendation. Wow! That was a fabulous omelette, and very filling. I ate the whole thing, and, no lie, I had no appetite until the evening, when I had an apple. I probably (probably???) overate, but it was so good, I just kept shoving the fork in my face.Linda had the panjo pancake with scrambled eggs. This is a Korean-style item. She thought it was made with rice. It had loads of scallions, and some kim chee in it. I took a bite of it and didn't care for it, but that's just me -- I really don't care for the flavors of Korean food, and this was Korean food. Linda, on the other hand, likes Korean food, and she ate her breakfast with as much alacrity as I did. At one point, I got up to use the washroom, and Linda was saying she'd probably take half of her breakfast home with her. When I returned -- and I wasn't gone very long at all -- she'd finished all her food. The next day, she called me and said she'd been full until dinnertime, too. It was that good.The only odd element was an elderly man who was wandering down the street in front of the restaurant. He'd stop, look in at us and stare, and then pace back and forth again. At one point, he came in as far as the entry, and just stood there for a moment, looking around. He didn't appear to be homeless or lost, and the servers just ignored him. All he did was stare and hang out, but still, it was kind of weird. This is nothing to do with the restaurant itself, of course, but it was part of the experience we had. For that reason, I include it here.Prices are pretty standard breakfast prices. When we were driving back to our homes afterward, we drove east on Montrose and passed a couple old-Chicago style places that advertised a full breakfast for $6.95. That's not what you'll get or pay at Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club. Our entrees cost either $9.75 or $9.95. We got a lot of food for that money.Bottom line: we loved Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club and will come again.

Long wait for brunch on Sunday but worth the wait. Food is fresh and delicious.  I ordered the cinnamon pancakes and a side of hash browns. The pancakes were nice and light and nice and sweet but not overly so.  You could tell they used more natural ingredients rather than artificial sweeteners.  The potatoes were great as well crispy and very flavorful.  Service was friendly and attentive as well.

If you are in the mood for breakfast and you happen to be in the Kimball/Bryn Mawr vicinity, Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club should do just fine for your appetite. Be forewarned that the portions are substantial.Mini hotcakes with berries. Chorizo skillet.The hotcakes are so moist that you may think they are not cooked fully. And not only are they moist, but they are so fluffy. The chorizo skillet is indeed a heavy dish. Either you tackle it on a completely empty stomach, very slowly, or in part with some to take home.There are no complaints about the services, given the time I went was not overrun with patrons. There isn't anything fancy about the breakfast offerings, so don't expect chi-chi dishes coming to the table. Noticing how breakfast spots tend to pack fast in Chicago's, I recommend going early to avoid standing outside or right at the door if the restaurant gets too crowded for immediate seating. The restaurant seems to be accommodating so far since it's relatively new. But once words get out, there will be a wait in the near future.

Everyone elses' order looked fantastic, but I ordered a skillet with skirt steak.  They somehow cut the steak WITH the grain on two separate orders.  Is there anything more basic?  Otherwise everything tasted fine.  Price-wise, at 13.50 it was priced a little high for what you get and the drinks were the same.The narrow tabletops used some sort of reclaimed wood to add character, but you can tell they absorbed more than their share of grease over the years...

Superb local place! I agree with all the 4/5 star raters. Our favs are the Pajun pancakes and the stuffed French toast! The decor, if you care, is also very rustic and most of their pieces are upcycled or repurposed. Love everything about this place. Servers are fantastic too!

Been there twice. Their food is pretty good. I've tried their Carribean omelet and chorizo skillet! So delicious! I better try their bread pudding toast next time I eat there! They got a great selection of breakfast items! Also, service is friendly and understanding.

I love this spot!  Keep coming back over and over again.Over all the food is wonderful.  Must try the French toast, (all of them).  As a real coffee snob, I know most people have different tastes, wether it's dunkin doughnuts, Starbucks, whatever? The intelegencia coffee here is real good!!  Which means the beans are fresh.  I have had a lot of the dishes here for breakfast, and I'm always surprised at how good it is here.I have no doubt you will enjoy your experience here.

Amazing menu options!! I ate the guava pancakes (a special), and they were delicious but not overly sweet! Great service too. All around definitely a crowd pleaser, but make sure to go for brunch early on the weekends since the place itself is a bit tiny.

I think what I enjoyed most here was the genuine Latin hospitality. We sat at the counter and watched the chefs face to face. "Manny" the owner was most definitely the ring leader. He read the orders off in Spanish and his assistants to his left and right were fervently yet precisely creating meals.I ordered chilaquiles with green sauce. The flavors and toppings were typical of the central region of Mexico or Potosino meaning from the state of San Luis Potosí. A tasty interpretation. I enjoyed the sweet Plantains which are traditional fare.I asked to try the Sausage gravy as I was surprised to see see this being served here. I think most folks will appreciate their biscuits and gravy but I'll have to say that the absolute best gravy I've enjoyed is at The Town Baker in Idyllwild, California.As we sat right in the trajectory of all meals I did lots of interesting plates. Id be interested in their French toast pudding bread.This is definitely a tasty joint worth checking out. I'll add that their location is perfect. It's an authentic Chicago neighborhood. No chains anywhere in sight.Adrian our server was great too.Great decor too!!#nakedtravel #idyllwildCVB #Chicago

Great service awesome food! We went on Sunday at 1pm the wait was 15 min for 3 people. We were greated right away by host, servers were quick in refilling my coffee. We love what we ordered. Ill be coming back to this place!

My experience was an excellent one! Had the bread pudding French toast + basic eggs & bacon! It was all magnificent!!! Will go again! Only wish they had a bigger place for more tables. Gets packed quickly so get there early! Bon appetite!!

First time coming here and I am definitely coming back regularly! I'm so glad theres a nice little place in the neighborhood. To start, the decor is my favorite design, sort of a mix between industrial and rustic but very cool. I loved the atmosphere, it was down to earth and comfortable. We were greeted immediately by a friendly hostess and she let us sit at a bigger table with no problem even though there was only two of us. Our waiter was very nice and accommodating. Even the other staff members had no issue helping us and everyone was very friendly. It makes a huge difference!The menu is delicious and satisfies different taste palettes! We ordered the french toast with berries and cream as well as the veggie skillet. AMAZING!!It was packed and we still got our food at a pretty good time and we never felt rushed or anything. I can't wait to try the rest of there menu!

I really enjoy this new discovery for me. The ingredients are fresh and the food is savory. I've taken my daughter's and gone twice. The servers are very friendly and make you feel at ease. I've had the Rumba French toast. It had bananas,  caramel and marscapone cheese, garnished with mint, strawberries and blueberries. Delicious! I also had the breakfast burrito with chorizo,  avocado and potatoes. I could only eat half and later enjoyed the other half for dinner.  Which is odd, because I usually hate reheated eggs. My daughter had the green chilaquiles and they were delicious too. I strongly recommend this place. It is quaint and the menu is something I'd expect to find downtown for a higher price.

Just ate here this past weekend after being denied expedient entry to other brunch places. Dude, it's so hard to have tasty brunch things in my belly when starting out at 10 on a Saturday.  Luckily, this place is close to home and offered seating for two in under 15 minutes.We had so many things-- a steak skillet, a Caribbean-inspired omelet, french toasts, waffles. Everything was good, some things more amazing than others, but I wasn't disappointed with a thing we had. Thumbs up for relatively reasonable prices, fast service, and creative options that are filling. I'll be back.

My friends and I were looking for a new breakfast location. Driving by in the North Park area we saw this breakfast joint Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club and decided to try it.Breakfast food presentation - Awesome!Not to mention the food - delish!You have to try it. There is a waiting line but it's  worth it.

Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club is off to a fantastic start. Definitely off the beaten path, the boyfriend and I were incredibly pleased with our experience. The menu is much more unique than the average brunch restaurant and we couldn't wait to try it out. There was no wait on a Sunday morning and our waiter came over right away to give us menus.After much deliberation, I went with the skirt steak skillet and the boyfriend had the pajun pancake. We were both incredibly pleased with our dishes, mine was a large portion of skirt steak over a very flavorful potato hash. The eggs, pico de gallo, avocado, and salsa rounded the dish out perfectly. Definitely order this is you're feeling hungry, I had no shot of finishing it. The other dish, the panjun pancake, was pretty phenomenal. The scallion pancake was cooked perfectly and provided a great base for the eggs and pork belly. Additionally, the brussel sprouts that came on the side rocked. They were in a soy/garlic sauce that added tons of flavor and made for a great pairing with the rest of the dish. If you're looking for something other than the typical breakfast fare, panjun pancake is the way to go.At the time that we visited Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club, it was cash only which is important to know. Prices are normal, maybe even a little below average with each dish coming in around $10.50. I anticipate that word will spread about this new spot and there will surely be a wait on a Sunday morning! Overall, I highly recommend brunch at Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club!

BMBC is a nice neighborhood spot. I had the skirt steak skillet and it was okay. It wasn't horrible, but it wasn't exceptional. I agree with Phil S.'s review that it was beautifully presented, but the meat was chewy. If it wasn't for the Cholula, it would have tasted bland to me. Maybe next time I'll try something sweet instead of savory.

Walked right in at 11am on a packed, chilly Saturday. Sat at the counter. Once again, a perfectly delicious experience. This time we had the lemon crab cakes (which are more like an eggs benedict) with fried potatoes/bacon and the root vegetable hash with chicken sausage/polenta. Again the fresh squeezed orange juice was incredible. Both breakfasts were perfectly cooked, lots of interesting flavors. Hash was heavy on the beets and combined well with the sausage, crepe, and sweet polenta. Crab cakes were moist and flavorful. Perfectly poached eggs. Bacon was great. Keep it up, BMBC. You continue to impress.

I am so happy to have a wonderful breakfast spot so close to the house. The country decor is comforting and adds to the relaxed atmosphere. The food and coffee are delicious! I've ordered different items from their menu and their specials and have yet to be disappointed. I love the presentation of the food.Weekends, especially on nice weather days, can be busy. But if you are able to go during the week, there is little to no wait. I've definitely recommended this place to my friends and they loved it as well.

**They now accept credit cards**Originally, Rosa J had an intention to get her full "beauty sleep" in before her epic shift began (in retail jargon: Super Saturday weekend, known as the weekend before the advent of Christmas, when clueless Americans are scrabbling to get their shopping done before this big day arrives).  Unfortunately, hubby's co-worker disrespected his privacy by calling his personal cellular device at 0900 hour, sharp!  Well, I chose to treat it as a blessing in disguise and have some nice breakfast at somewhere new.  And you, co-worker (as you shall remain anonymous): we will have a serious conversation with you very soon...Let's shift the topic on the Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club.This place is fairly new and located at the northwest corner of Kimball/Bryn Mawr.The items on the menu are pretty reasonably-priced; the most expensive item I saw was $11.50, which was on the special menu written on the chalk board.The server promptly offered coffee and water.  I could not remember his name (sorry, I'm usually good at remembering names, but today I was tripping), yet he was super friendly and genuinely introduced the special menu items for the day.Out of the special menu, I ordered the Ranchero burrachos (might have mis-spelled this, but this is yelp, not the spelling bee competition).  It's like a Mexican-style Benedict: the top layer was over-easy egg, covering the avocado and ground chorizo, supporting with fried tortilla chips on the bottom.  It came with rice and beans on the side, along with two (2) tiny pieces of sugar-coated plantain.On the other hand, hubby ordered the veggie skillet out of the regular menu.I highly recommend the ranchero burrachos.  It was creative, unique, flavorful, and well-constructed.  To be honest, I wasn't sure what this was, but there's a virtue for being adventurous with food, and today I surely proved that point.Hubby also enjoyed his veggie skillet.  The server(s) continued to top off the coffee the entire time while we were dining.  Hey hey, I had no complaint!The total after tax came to approximately $26.  I thought it was fair, for the quality of food we happily consumed and service we received.We now have another option for breakfast/brunch other than the Kronor on Foster in the North Park neighborhood.  You will see me at BMBC one of these days in the near future.
This place has very good food and good service. But the tables are gross. Wood top rustic tables and they always feel slimy, sticky, & grimy.

I really like this place. Its too bad its soo small. It was about a 45 minute wait, which was fine since it was nice outside. Everything our table ordered was great - I had the veggie skillet and it was amazing.I will be back again.

Love this place for a breakfast on the weekends. It's a blend of classics and new ideas. I've been here a couple of times and highly recommend the skillets and the omelettes. Both are fabulous, especially the caprese omelette.The service is fast, the coffee is good, and it really is a local business through and through. Lovely to be able to support such an amazing place!!One tiny recommendation: I think the sausage, with how many amazing breakfast sausages are available, should really be reconsidered. It's ok, but nothing special at all.

The 4.5 star average is well deserved. Came in for a quick breakfast on a Wednesday morning. Wasn't too busy. I was warmly greeted and the guy even explained how to adjust the chairs at my high top table and pointed out the hooks for my purse and coat. My food came out really fast. The coffee is solid and they provide an appropriate amount of cream so I never had to ask for more. And refills were provided in a timely manner. I had eggs, bacon and potatoes. Yum! The eggs were fresh and perfectly cooked. The bacon was crispy as requested. And the potatoes were really tasty. Bottom line -- excellent food and service for a very reasonable price in a clean and cute environment.

We arrived right before 11 to a 15-20 minute wait, but you could tell the early crowd was wrapping up and the lunch crowd was about to show. We were the first people waiting, and it was a mess as they just tell you congregate around the host stand/entrance/exit.  This is poor planning and as we left it was a crowded mess. The servers showed little urgency to clear tables to drop off checks, it was annoying as there were lots of tables ready to leave.There are too many items on the menu, I felt like I was at a mini Cheesecake factory. It leads to confusion.  Brunch, breakfast, sides, lunch but on Sunday, etc, not well thought out.The content of the menu seemed interesting as there was a lot of unique blending of ingredients and styles.  However, the looks were deceiving as nothing tasted as good as it sounded.The steak skillet was a bountiful amount of food, but in the end was just kind of forgettable.I asked the server for help between the pajun pancake and the sweet potato hotcakes. The sweet potato was described as sweeter over savor so I chose that. What a let down. Literally the most boring hotcake I've ever had. They were basically grain flavorless pancakes with chunks of sweet potato in them. Terrible dish.  The blueberries and pecans didn't go with this.  Total miss. The apple maple sausage was pretty good, but too expensive at over $1.30 per link.Maybe we got the wrong items but this is nothing more than the average generic brunch spot in Chicago, except its at least a 20 minute drive north of Chicago in the middle of nowhere.This is a skip.

I visited Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club the Monday after Independence Day. I originally wanted to go to Lula Cafe, but it was unfortunately closed! Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club did not disappoint and was probably just as good as Lula Cafe.I noticed that a previous reviewer described the ambiance as "urban rustic." I definitely agree. The restaurant almost looked like a modern barn.I ordered the bread pudding French toast. It was the perfect serving size. It was on top of delicious orange syrup that was probably the highlight of the dish. The French toast was covered in fresh berries and powdered sugar. I think the flavor itself was sweet...but not overpowering.My boyfriend ordered the sourdough French toast. It is a must if you are into savory breakfast dishes. It came with potatoes.The staff was very attentive. They kept giving us coffee refills and asking us if we needed anything.The only downside of Bryn Mawr Breakfast Club is that it was busy, so it took us a while to get our food. But I really didn't mind the wait at all!

Did a search via AroundMe app and found it. Love trying new breakfast places and are we glad we did. The blueberry multi grain pancakes were amazing, the chorizo skillet was great, the food was fantastic. Some places have great food and watered down coffee or vice versa. This place was the perfect mix. The food was flavorful. The decor enjoyable, clean and pleasant if you like OHenry in Edgewater then you'll love this place double.
Love the food here! Had the chorizo skillet, as well as French toast, amazing meals, great presentation and comfortable environment. Servers very friendly.

Really great breakfast experience.   Nice diverse menu.   (I had the chorizo skillet and really enjoyed it.)   Prices are reasonable.  Very good service (although it took the food a bit longer than expected to come out of the kitchen).    Kid friendly.   Opens early (7 am) and the place had plenty of seating available when we were there from 7 to 8 am on a Sunday.

Food and coffee was delicious! We tried the chilaquiles, so good. Only negative thing was our waitress, she was a bit rude. She had an "I don't feel like working" sort of attitude. Besides that I enjoyed everything else and will definitely be going back.

This is my favorite breakfast spot right now which makes a lot of sense considering M Henry, in Andersonville, used to be my favorite (same chef)! Such great food combinations that you don't find everywhere. Creative taste mixtures with a Hispanic flair. I have had everything from the Benedict to specials and it is all great. Their plates are alway beautiful and clean which is a nice touch since the price isn't out of control. Barn modern inside, lots of fake animal heads and reclaimed wood. They have these cute little egg paintings that are just adorable.

This is my favorite place to eat. Every thing is amazing. There is so much love and warmth in this place. You can tell the people who work here are proud of the food they serve. This place deserves to be on the list of the best breakfast joints in the city. Reasonably priced. Kind attentive staff. Food comes up pretty quick. Rarely a wait to be seated. Great ambiance and decor. Favorite place to eat. Hands down!

Stopped by here with my bestie for a beer and some Bears action last Sunday.  They offer a stellar beer selection and a great game day environment.  The place was crowded but didn't feel packed, if that makes sense.  We had just had brunch so I didn't check out the food menu but the few plates I saw pass our table looked pretty great.I would definitely call this one a neighborhood gem.  Reasonable prices, great service, and perfect for a game day in the South Loop!!!

Although the manager (dressed like he works at a bike shop) was working his A@@ off trying to keep things under control, the staff fails at every level.Upon entering the packed restaurant I waited 5 minutes to be greeted and was seated at a "communal table". My server came be after another 5 minutes, returning (after circling my table a dozen times) to get my drink order, then went back to chatting with the other staff, as was the scene the rest of the night. Me trying to get her attention, her passing right by, waitresses chatting and ignoring customers - slow service-.As for the food it was typical bar fare, but very salty. Fries where lukewarm when they arrived and didn't do any better throughout the meal. 21 day burger was cooked as designated (med rare) but not with the cheddar requested (standard American) and in a standard burger bun, despite being sold as brioche, very salty. It tasted like it may have been good if it was not so salty. I've had better meals at Burger King.On the positive the beer selection was good  (in appropriate glasses) and there was plenty of TV's with multiple games on.They were packed (likely because the slow service), but most were drinking and watching the game.I will not be back, unless it's the only place open (there's a 24h subway and dunk'in doughnuts across the street).

First time here and we had a very split experience.The service was the best service I had ever had! The waitress was friendly and attentive. There was never anything we needed to ask for because she just knew!They have an impressive beer selection and we tried several (Octoberfest and Pumpkin ones) that were very delicious.The food was another story. While we did enjoy the fried cheese appetizer (seriously try it! I almost never like fried food) and the beer cheese soup, the rest of the food left something to be desired.The caesar salad was drowned in kraft caesar dressing; I could not even finish it because it was swimming in the stuff. The jerk chicken sandwich was not very flavorful and the chicken was so dry.The mac n' cheese side was not bad but not a reason to go back. My husband was not impressed with his buffalo chicken burger either, saying it was over cooked.If you go here, I would recommend going for a happy hour and not for a meal.

Craft beer lovers rejoice! Oh, what a draft list! Oh, what a bottle list!Thankfully the bar is open late so it was our first stop in Chicago. What brew to have first? Thankfully the bartender was friendly, knowledgeable and willing to give suggestions.They always carry Zombie Dust, which was a pleasure to try. There was a great variety of local, regional and nationally recognized treasures. Oh how I wanted to splurge on the Goose Island bottles.The staff had a great relationship with each other and seemed happy. That helps for atmosphere. There was a mix of locals just looking for a bar, and craft beer enthusiasts.They had the Cubs game on most of the TVs and the crowd, especially the staff, was watching intently. That adds positively to the atmosphere.I didn't eat but it's a great spot for beer for sure.

A solid place to stop to grab a beer and some food around Printer's Row.  We were in town for a concert and staying in the south loop area and decided to check it out.  First Draft has an amazing beer list with 64 taps and many more in a bottle (menu is conveniently stored under the table top) and I was impressed with the wait staff's knowledge.  In addition to a great beer list, they have an impressive menu.  Appetizers, salads, pizzas, sandwiches and burgers round out the list.  I opted for the eponymously named burger.  With maple-glazed bacon, beer cheese, caramelized onions and an egg on top, the burger is not playing around.  I am always skeptical when a restraurant asks how I like my burger (medium rare) as many just cook it medium and call it a day, but FD did it right.  The only thing missing was I felt the burger could've been seasoned a bit more.I typically stay a bit more north when I come into town but if I am ever back in the area, I would hesitate to stop back in.

I have been walking past this place every day for the past 2 months on my way to and from work, and have been meaning to stop by the whole time.I mainly came in here to try the porkcicles, which I had seen on the online menu on their website. Well, first of all, the menu was different from what was on the website, but the porkcicles were still on it. However, when I tried to order them, I was told they were out.Great, so then I asked if they had any drink specials, which they didn't have, even on a Thursday night. So I ended up paying $9 for a small glass of cabernet.I ended up ordering the buffalo wings, which was pretty standard, as well as the fried Brussels sprouts. I expected the sprouts to be breaded, but was pleased to find that they weren't; they were actually pretty good!Unfortunately, that was pretty much the only notable part of the visit. The service was slow and it took forever to get the check when we were done.I wouldn't necessarily avoid this place in the future, but they didn't really give me a good reason to come back.

$5 bombers! 'Nuff said.My friends and I stumbled in here for some drinks and man did I fall in love with this place. Possibly for silly reasons, but doggoneit, they're my reasons!There are menus under the tables! Every restaurant should invest in this genius idea of having a little compartment attached to the table for menus. It's great so we can keep them out of our way when we're enjoying ourselves and it encourages us to keep ordering those dranks.First Draft has quite an extensive beer list. Color this beer chick impressed. Most impressive to me are the $5 bombers on their chalkboard. That's cheaper than liquor stores for some cool @$$ bomber flavors. Our server told us they ALWAYS have a couple of $5 bomber options they are clearing out. Holy schnikies! Well I will ALWAYS be coming back to First Draft to check out this amazing deal. The night I went the offerings were No S'more Imperial Stout (9.1% solid double stout) and Imperial Pajamas (9.8% realllllly good imperial oatmeal stout).You can do beer flights of any 4 on tap for $14 which is a cool deal. CheckBeerMenus.comfor their latest draft offerings.I truly enjoyed myself here. Who knew I could love a sports like bar?! I plan to go back in the near future and also try some of their food offerings, as well.

I haven't had a bar that I could call home since my beloved Moonshine closed shop in late 2014 and as I lived Uptown, I frequented Uptown Lounge and while it was ok, it just didn't feel like home for me...plus they didn't serve food.Fast Forward to Spring 2016 as I moved to Printers Row/South Loop. I was introduced to First Draft by a good friend of mine. We grabbed a hi-top and had dinner as I finished moving boxes in my new place. I had a chicken parmesan sandwich that was recommended by the server that wasn't on the menu and it was good. They also had one of my favorite Belgian tripels on draft; Tripel Karmeliet! Awesome!!! I have come back numerous times since the first visit and I usually grab a seat at the bar. Servers Kelly & Chevy pretty much take care of me when I show up. They have so many good beers on draft in addition to my favorite Belgian Tripel. Some of my other favorites are on tap such as Kwak, Delirium Tremons, Founders Kentucky Breakfast Stout, Kasteel Rouge (mix it with Founders chocolate stout which is also on tap) among many others. They have all the top shelf spirits as well.The food here is pretty good as I have tried the First Draft Burger which includes maple glazed bacon, beer cheese, fried egg, brioche and caramelized onions. Pretty good burger here! The Grilled Cheese is good as well as it includes maple glazed bacon as well...one of the best grilled cheeses I have ever had that I didn't make on my own...LOL. There are TVs from all angles for sporting events and sports talk shows....they play decent music here too! Love this place and nice to find a new joint I can call home that I can stumble to my actual home from
The wait staff were energetic and checks on you frequently.This will be my to go sports bar in Chicago.
Cool neighborhood bar with lots of TVs but loud, rly dark, and maybe a bit on the pricey side.Another review mentioned $5 bombers though, I'll have to come back to try those!

My girlfriend and I decided to give this place one more chance, and I'm glad we did. It was last Friday around 6 PM -- we decided to get some food and beer after work. We once again got off to a rocky start -- there was nobody at the door and the place was a little over half full, with plenty of open tables, so we grabbed one. It took about 5+ minutes before anyone acknowledged we were there. We didn't complain, but the server was apologetic about the oversight. I didn't catch her name, but she took our drink order and explained that our server (Bree) was just about to begin her shift, and would take over soon.Bree was a great server and checked on us often. We ordered honey sriracha chicken wings, mussels, and beer cheese soup. The wings were very good -- hearty and not too spicy. The soup was simple but good. The mussels were a disappointment. The meat inside each mussel was much smaller than other mussels I've had. Also the mussels were very gritty. I mentioned this to the man who cleared our plates and he apologized and said they would try to do a better job of cleaning them in the future. I had also previously asked him to put a specific baseball game on the TV nearest our table, and he went out of his way to ensure I got the correct game--I really appreciated that.I enjoyed all the beers I tried. My girlfriend tried to order a Bockor Kriek Des Jacobins, but Bree returned to our table and told us they were out of it. We explained that she liked sweet beers, and Bree recommended the Lindeman's Framboise. That turned out to be an excellent recommendation -- I've never seen her drink a beer that fast.By the time we left, the place was quite busy, with a line at the door. People pounced on our table as soon as we stood up. I'm not sure what the solution is, but I think this place needs a better system for seating. Servers are busy and can't always keep track of who just sat down. This has been a problem all three times I've stopped in here, so I feel confident that these weren't just isolated incidents. The food is definitely a step up from typical bar food, but works better as appetizers than a full meal. But the beer list is where this place really shines. This is definitely a bar first and foremost, so I probably should manage my expectations about the food and service. The employees really are great despite seeming a little overworked most of the time, so I'll give it 4 stars despite some of the frustrations I've outlined here.

I paid First Draft a return lunchtime visit yesterday.  Lunch was their poutine, which has changed for the better since my previous trip to Chicago.  It's now made with pulled pork rather than beef, and there's a tasty gravy made with Left Hand Milk Stout.  Still melted cheddar rather than the traditional cheese curds, though.I tried three new beers:- Whiner Le Tub.  6.6%.  From a new production brewery in Back of the Yards.  Slightly cloudy gold, light head.  Nose is almost salty.  Tart/salty taste, with a lemony note.  Said to be a blend of two saisons, aged in Cabernet barrels, fermented with Brettanomyces.- Allagash Confluence.  7.4%.  Clear gold, medium head.  Minimal nose.  Taste is sweet malt, something floral, and ethanol, with a noticeable Brett presence.  Some bitterness in the fade.  Style resembles a Belgian golden ale.- Founders ReDANKulous.  9.5%.  Clear root beer color, heavy head overflowed the glass.  (What a waste:  sober children in China, y'know.). Moderate hoppy nose.  Intense piney Chinook, Mosaic, and Simcoe hopping well balanced against toasty malt.  The producer describes the effect as "dank," a description which wouldn't have occurred to me.

This bar is awesome! Lots of big TVs, nice servers, and great attention to detail. The littlest things make me happy, and I was instantly impressed by this place because their tables have a wire shelf underneath them that holds the menus. You're never far away from the drink and food options! Also, their hightop tables are super solid and have a large base ledge to rest your feet. Amazing!! I was doubly impressed that they had so many awesome craft choices, including 4 different Three Floyds options... and YES, everything they had listed was actually still available!!! YAY!I had one beer and tried their Sweet Bee cocktail- whiskey, ginger, bitters... YUM. It was a sweet and refreshing drink.My guy and I can't wait to go back and eat. Everything that went by looked so good. We will be back soon!!

I want to like this place more than I do, simply because they have really great food. Everything I've ever eaten from here has been delicious, ranging from Sunday brunch, to late night pizza and wings. They also have a great selection of draft beers that literally has something for everyone.One problem I have with this place is it is SO loud. Like, all of the time, but especially on game days. I have been here for Bears games before and it's literally like so loud you can't even here the person sitting next to you talk unless they yell in your ear. Even my boyfriend who is die hard sports anything and would choose listening to any game over listening to me thinks it's too loud. And not to keep hammering, but it's loud in the piercing kind of way.Now that I've made myself sound like a crotchety old geezer, let me continue the trend by saying that prices are pretty steep here. While you do get good quality of food, and there are many craft beers here you may not find everywhere, I still find it kind of crazy that every time my guy and I come here for pizza and beers we somehow always end up spending $70+ after all is said and done.Service goes either way. Sometimes it's really great, sometimes it's less than stellar, and generally everyone kind of seems to have an emo attitude - not that they are bitchy or rude, just they don't exactly seem excited to be there.All in all, definitely good food, and could be a great place with some changes, but regardless, since it's in the 'hood, we continue to visit First Draft for a change of pace.

I visited here twice in a matter of days recently, as I was looking for a good beer bar and a place to have lunch before Lollapalooza in the South Loop. This proved to be an excellent choice.The beer list is massive, and both times I went they had Zombie Dust on tap. That's a victory. They have just about every style imaginable and lots of great breweries, including local ones. Service was prompt and friendly as well.I only ate here one of the two stops in, and I had a turkey burger with fries. The turkey burger was kind of blah, but then again, they all kind of are. That's mostly on me. The fries were excellent and crisp.This is not a huge place but there are TVs literally everywhere you could possibly move your eyes. So if you're looking for a place to watch a game, or just have a great beer and chill, you could do a whole lot worse, especially in a rather nondescript area of Chicago.

So glad to say I've found my new neighborhood watering hole! There are 3 key things I look for when searching for my next favorite sports bar: good tap selection, good menu(bonus points for a buffalo chicken sandwich), and large TV's to watch Chicago sports. Needless to say this place has it all, even the buffalo chicken sandwich of my dreams! Their beer selection is definitely the best of the bars in the immediate area, and everything on the menu looked great. They also have menus tucked underneath each table, so you can sit down and get lookin' right away.See you again soon, First Draft!

First Draft is a bar located in Chicago's South loop, close to the red line, not to difficult to find parking and close to other restaurants.I came here with a small group of girlfriends after dinner and we had a nice time. It was open very late, there were a ton of industry folks in the crowd.We were easily able to find a table and we had no problem getting more drinks. It was pretty average, run of the mill, late night bar, nothing special. If I ever venture to the South loop again, I'll for sure come back.

Amazing happy hour Tuesday special for food. 1/2 off wings, with minimum order of 10. I ordered the honey sriracha and it was delicious. I will say it was sauced on the heavier side but for those that like saucey wings, these were bomb. Nice selection of beers, clean, spacious, friendly staff. The service was slightly a miss when i first arrived. I'm not sure if they thought i was waiting for someone (i went solo), but it took a good 5-8 minutes till i even got a "hi" and offered to get a drink.Not sure if they did this on purpose, but under the bar has outlets! I was able to drink, eat, and recharge my electronics. Really glad i found this spot which was near my hotel and it wasn't touristy at all.

Was craving a burger on Easter and it was raining so I didn't want to drive too far. This was the closest pub near my house! Lol can't believe I've been living hear for almost a year and it's my first time trying this place out ! I ordered the first draft burger (minus the bacon) lol love the fried egg on my burgers . I ordered my burger medium n it was delicious ! Fresh pretzel bun and the fries were great too! They had a good price on draft beers as well and it was a clean environment for a pub! Will definitely be back when I have my next burger crave !!

Great draft selection... unfortunately they were out of my first choice draft!Burger was solid, sweet potato fries were excellent, and fried fish (on fish and chips dish) was great.tip - sweet potato fries better than the chips (from fish and chips)

Stopped in for a few hours before our movie. It was our first time here.  It's a sports bar, but not obnoxiously so.  There are TVs plastered to the walls, but they let people play music on the TouchTunes machine even with sporting events going on.Great beer selection. The food wasn't very good. We both chose a Cobb salad, which sounded great on the menu. The salad was small, and had a large pile of very raw, very stinky onions. I've made plenty of better salads at home. We should have gotten bad-for-you food. The wings at the table next to ours looked great!
Great food and service was excellent.  Very fun sports bar, especially with the Cubs doing so well!

Once I saw zombie dust on tap, I was just ordering those all night, but they have a very extensive draft selection.  I was pretty impressed.Service was great, the vibe was very chill.  It's a typical neighborhood feel bar where everyone is friendly.Good place to watch games since there are a lot of TVs per sq ft.  Will definitely be coming back!Just don't expect much from the food.  Wings came out cold and not very crispy.  The sriracha honey wings barely had a hint of sriracha.  The fried chicken sandwich was very dry and bland.

Great beer selection, and occasionally they'll have unbelievable deals on bombers. Like bombers that should cost around $14 and instead cost $5. So you drink 5 of them with a couple friends and hope they make it home safely while one of them falls asleep in her Uber ride home. But everyone makes it home safe and you keep thinking "I really need to go back there and see if they have any $5 bomber specials".
Excellent local spot. Great selection of draughts.  Cubano Draft sandwich recommended by bartender was a hit.

My dad and I had a mixed experience here last evening. We arrived around 5:00 and found a half-full, welcoming space with plenty of room. We were offered a window seat and quickly got full menus, which boasted day-of specials for Bulls and Hawks games. Several TVs showed a variety of sporting events, and our high-top table was surprisingly roomy and comfortable. The bar filled up later, so I recommend grabbing a table before 6 on Friday nights.Our server was friendly but confused not only about when the specials happened (she wasn't aware there was a Bulls game that night) but which beers were offered at $4. We asked her to list them and she mentioned a few then vaguely pointed to our menus. Most of her sentences ended with sound effects. She seemed to infer that any 16oz beer would be offered at $4, so some of the ones I ended up ordering were full price. Not only that, they were served in 12oz glasses, which was confusing and disappointing.The food was worth our time, though. The honey-sriracha porksicles were tender and lovely with just the right amount of heat. Our salads were packed with spinach instead of what most restaurants do - iceberg - so they were a really great pick. And the pizza came out fresh and hot - they even modified it slightly so we could get the spicy condiment on only half!Overall, this is worth a try. Just do some hard-core investigating on the specials so you're not surprised when the bill comes.

Between hitting the Art Institute and heading to Northerly Island for a concert, my boyfriend and I had several hours to kill. Normally we'd wander and see where we ended up, but it was pouring outside with no sign of stopping. We ducked under a construction awning and pulled up Yelp, and First Draft sounded like an excellent place to kill time.When we arrived, there were only a couple people at the bar and a large table full at the back, so we didn't feel like we needed to rush at any time to clear the table.We started with a couple of drinks and poutine - fries, beer gravy, queso, and brisket. The fries were a bit undercooked but the rest of the dish was tasty. We had another drink and chit-chatted and watched the ten TVs in our vicinity - this would be a great place to watch a game. After another hour or so we decided to put in our dinner order. My boyfriend built his own burger, and I went with the Southern Fried Chicken sandwich, subbing cheddar for American.Delicious. The chicken was moist, the cheddar melty, and the pickles crisp. The fries were much better this time, though I only ate a few due to my previous poutine gorge and being full from the large sandwich and drinks beforehand.Customer service at First Draft was great - our server was attentive but wasn't pushing us to order or move along. On our way, I flagged down a bus boy and asked if he could get us two large trash bags for the rain. He did, and they were a life-saver until we found ponchos (and, frankly, a boon even after - the poncho/garbage bag combo ended up being crucial).If you have time to kill, First Draft is first choice.

Came to Chicago on business and just wanted a night to chill without a big fancy dinner. Yelp this place and not disappointed. Great hang out. Very good beer selection, pizza is quite good and service was great. Bartenders Danny and Chevy were friendly and had no issues holding conversations. Will return.

Love this place! It's our "home bar" and never disappoints. Great beer selection, great food (must get the squeakers), great service. I love that First Draft is a cool hangout---not divey, but not pretentious at all. Highly recommend.
Wow you can't fit more tv's in a sports bar than this! Great vibe, huge selection of brews. Go there

What a great bar! I came here back in Nov 2015 for a quick lunch and a flight of good beer and I found both of them here. The beer selection is really great and they have a lot of dark, heavy, flavorful brews and I was quite impressed with the selection. My turkey sandwich was also very good and was a great compliment to the beer. The service was great and I would definitely recommend coming here if you like good beer!

Numerous reviewers seem to indicate that this place has the best draft list in Chicago. If that's truly the case then it doesn't speak well for Chicago, as where I'm from in SE Michigan there are a number of bars with more extensive lists. With that being said, the list here WAS quite solid and the prices were reasonable considering the location. I would not hesitate to drink here again. In fact, I drank here no less than three times during my recent weekend long trip to the Windy City.The service was always cordial and one late night bartender was extremely friendly. The kind of guy you could easily shoot the shit with all night if things were slow. I dug the decor as well. Kind of like an unpretentious sports bar with lots of hard woods a la a converted prefab Irish pub.I ordered some lunch one day of the food menu. The "first DRAFT". By the menu description I thought it was going to be some sort of BLT-like creation with a fried egg and beer cheese and some other over-indulgent crap on it. As soon as I ordered it the bartender asked how I wanted it cooked. Then it dawned on me I had just ordered a freaking 1/2 lb burger loaded with everything but the kitchen sink. It was pretty darned tasty but truthfully would have been better suited to the end of the night, too soak up the tail end of a bender, than it would have been as a lunchtime gut bomb. Duly noted for next time.

We decided to hit up the First Draft on the way to the Bears game. Since we were staying in River North we decided it would be best to get a few drinks closer to the stadium. It is about 1.5 miles to the stadium but I wanted a good selection of craft beers and this place came up on yelp.It has an expansive list of craft beers that I have not had a chance to sample before so that made me happy and all at a good price.The food was good, but nothing spectacular as I had a fried chicken sandwich.If you are in the neighborhood and want good craft beer might as well check this place out.For more information and pictures check out our site :thegreatcubeescape.com

I popped in here after a game at soldier field just based on the yelp ratings it got. So, thanks yelpers! This is a really fun bar! There are TVs everywhere, and on a Saturday night I didn't know where to look there were so many games happening at once. A host took our name down for a table which is better than most bars where you have to stake out and fight for a table. While we waited we grabbed a few beers. Bar was a good amount of people, but not people on top of you so it was fun but comfortable. There was a huge beer list to choose from, like several pages, but was surprisingly affordable with lots of beers in the $5-$6 range.Once we were seated, the waitress was super nice. We ended up ordering a few more beers and got the wings and brussel sprouts. The wings were very good, they fry them and grill them I guess so they have a good semi crunchy feel. I'd recommend the Chicago flavor, kind of a sweet bbq. The brussel sprouts were pretty good, but I dunno I thought they were pretty average contrary to popular yelp opinion. The waitress suggested Wisconsin spiggetes (spelling?) which are a fried cheese type thing, so you might wanna try that.I'd definitely recommend this place, especially if you are a sports fan. Friendly staff, cheap, good beer, good food, TVs everywhere : )

Pricey beers, they charge tax on top of cash drink purchases which is lame, my 16 oz beer as advertised on the menu was served in a short glass (~12oz), and to top it off I got a dirty glass with something brown and sticky stuck to the inside of it.  Not great at all.Edit: Owner contacted me to remedy the issue so I appreciate that.
Really enjoy this neighborhood hangout. Good bar food, kind service and the ability to select any flight you like. (Try a pizza, any pizza - delicious!)

Here on business from NYC and this place was perfect. Great craft beer selection, excellent Cobb salad (other semi-healthy to traditional bar food choices) and plenty of TV's. Cubs were in the playoffs and the camaraderie was fun. Good, long bar and the bartenders were professionals.

So we wanted to find a place off the highway for friends coming from Indiana and so we ventured to this spot. The staff was super nice and WOW to their beer selection. The ambience was great and the decor of the bar was classic. Very lovely and well kept. The food was very yummy, we had the pretzels, onion rings and pizza. They all hit the spot. We watched the Blackhawks there and truly enjoyed the experience.Go check this bar out! :) it's a great spot!

Thanks Yelp.Some friends and I headed to Soldier Field to get tickets to the Bears Raiders game.  After getting there and seeing the ticket selection 2 of my friends decided to go to the game and me and another friend decided not to spend the extra cash so we grabbed a cab, opened yelp and found this sports bar right around the corner.  When we walked in it was not crazy busy and we were able to get a table in the center of the bar where we could comfortably see 5 different games.This place has not only an extensive beer list but a very good whiskey menu as well.  I would recommend it if those are your drinks of choice.  We stuck to the beer as we were drinking for the long haul. I really like that their menu is broken up by styles and what is popular in the bar at the time. Also the beers are served in specific glasses for the style of beer which will enhance the flavor and experience.The only food item we tried were the fried cheese curds and they were pretty good.  Large curds with a heavy batter but it was suitable for the size of the curds.  Decent ranch but not spectacular.If I end up in Chicago again this would probably be my Sunday sports bar of choice.

Solid sports bar type place, with a pretty above average draft beer list, there were several options that I'd never seen before, not too packed or loud, but not dead either. I'd be down for coming back
waitress very unprofessional. made rude and inappropriate comments. I can tolerate most things but for someone to be rude and insulting to a party for no reason is ridiculous

Great beer selection here covering just about all pallettes. Chicken wings were good, grilled after they were sauced so they were not soggy. Caesar dressing could use a little more lemon to cut the mayo base.I sat at the bar, which was the perfect place to watch a Blackhawk game. The bartenders, Amanda and Ashley rocked it, making great beer suggestions. I'll be back for the Stone Brewing event next week.

I dare someone to try the Black Stout which contains 17% alcohol and you have to send me a pic(or it is not true) that you actually drank it and I WILL personally buy you 3 rounds of drinks and I'm by being sarcastic .Anyhow, the beer selection is quite enormous with many Local beers on tap, and they have Mikkeller beer which is a good highlight to have in tap. I have NOT tried the burgers but I hear good things about it but I figured one burger taste like any other burger but I will try it next time.I enjoy the theme of this tavern, big bar stools nice and clean bar and restaurant area. They have tvs to watch football/basketball/baseball and if any restaurant doesn't have a tv to watch sports they don't belong in Chicago... Plus Cubbies adding to World Series!

What a fun neighborhood bar. The beer selection of "draft" beer is amazing. I was here in December and enjoyed a couple off their 12 Days of Christmas list. Santa's Little Helper was a perfect draft to enjoy the ambiance and glace over the menu. Once my food order came,  I switched over to a very refreshing Christmas Ale.The special of the night was a Meatball Sandwich with a side of Mac-n-Cheese. I was in the mood for a burger, but being a fan of MnC I choose the special for my dinner. The sandwich was a fairly typical meatball sandwich. It was five hearty balls on a lightly toasted hoagie bun with marinara sauce and melted mozzarella cheese. The sandwich was so filling, I finally had to give up on eating the bun and just pick out the balls with a fork. Very tasty. I normally don't order a meatball sandwich, but I wouldn't mind having this one again.The star of the nightly special was the side of Mac-n-Cheese. I knew ahead of time and the waitress told me, they are known for their MnC. Once it was in front of me, it had me with the noodle they use. Skroodles as I call them, the curly spiral spared noodles are my favorite. They were heavily and evenly covered with a cheddar cheese sauce. The noodles were done al dente and served up in a black cast iron dish. This was what I think of when I want Mac-n-Cheese.The staff was attentive and friendly.  Which truly gave First Draft the old school, neighborhood feel. If I'm ever in the Printer's Row neighborhood again, I'm stopping by First Draft for a good cold craft beer.
Just moved to the area with my fiance and Danny welcomed us with tequila shots and awesome beer! Thank you Danny!! This will be our new watering hole!
Neighborhood bar with a good selection of beers on tap. They have half price appetizers when we came in.Will come back if I am in the area next time.

First Draft's first impression was a really shitty one, which has made it easy for me to say I've also had my last draft there. Well, I would have if the server could have been bothered to serve me.My group of friends went here on the Fourth of July after our Booze Cruise. I know, I know, drunk obnoxious idiots on a holiday. The worst. I completely agree. However we are in our 30s and have learned a thing or two about booze and sun and day drinking. That being said, we came in waves and sat at different tables. The owner approached me and three of my friends and pointed out that one girl was too drunk and couldn't be served. I agreed with him, said I'd put her in a cab. We seemed to have a dandy understanding and went about our business. He also mentioned another two friends of mine looked over-served too, which I brushed off because they hadn't even had as much to drink as me, yet he saw me as the reasoner.With McDrunky in the cab, my friends and I joined another table of friends and chatted. The owner comes over to me and says he told me my other friends were suppose to leave, too. Sorry, but I don't work in your bar, bud. I'm not your bouncer, and don't think for a second I'm going to be. I sent my drunk friend home because I'm a good friend and she needed to leave. But my other friends were fine. He started raising cane and said they wouldn't be served. Well no problem there, sir, because no one could get served!My friends at the table had already ordered food, so I flagged down the server and asked her if I could place an order. With the snottiest attitude she could muster, she responded, "I already took a bunch of orders." Okayyyyy.... congratulations? What the actual hell. I mentioned I got to the table late and would appreciate putting in another order and said I didn't mind if my food came out later. No silverware, no water, no drinks, and no check back to see if everything was okay later, and I was dying of sodium intake because all of the food was so overly salted it was inedible.I checked with friends at other tables, and they all agreed their meatballs, pizza, sandwiches and fries were all grossly over-salted. We took that as a sign were not welcome there, paid our tab, and hit the door.The South Loop comes up scarce on good bars, and the corner of Clark and Harrison is just as desolate in my opinion.

Visited here recently and we left very disappointed. My husband and I stopped in for a quick bite and a drink. It took about 20 minutes to get our first drink and an appetizer of hummus. Then, we waited almost an hour for our entrees, a sandwich and a salad. No one was really ordering food, and there wasn't much of a crowd, but all of a sudden four tables worth of food just come pouring out of the kitchen. Including one table that ordered their food maybe ten minutes before their food was delivered.To top it off, his sandwich was not cooked properly. Our waitress could tell we were disappointed and took it back. She came out abut five minutes later with a totally fresh sandwich. Not sure why it took an hour the first time.The manager was drinking at the bar. The servers and staff were sipping from Starbucks cups, standing around. And we never got a decent apology.It was our second time there after a very pleasant first trip. We won't be back and unfortunately this seems to be the case with several bars in the area: poor service and very overpriced bar food.

Fantastic neighborhood sports bar with food and drinks that will surprise you, (in a good way!)First Draft has a great vibe and definitely fits the south loop feel. I was amazed by the extensive beer list, especially the amount of beers on tap. There are also great selections of spirits to choose from.But don't miss out on the food, which is above average. And if you're there during a Hawks or Bulls game, it's half price pizzas and $4 beer specials.Mix all of this with a friendly, helpful staff and you've got yourself a winner.

This is a pretty neat spot with lots of TVs and decent food.  We tried a ceasar salad, some wings, and brussel sprouts.  Everything was good.  The bartender was the only waitress but she seemed to be able to catch up.  There was a special board to the right of the bar and on that day it offered $3 Tripel.

Beer snobs asssemmbllee!! Seriously, this is your spot. First Draft has tons of beers on tap that will please any pallet. In addition to all the beer (as if any place could ever need much more than copious amounts of beer), their food was delicious.
