I have been here a few times now.   The food is very good but the bartender cannot get the signature drinks down.  The interior is also way too bright.  Too many many great places just a 10 minute walk away to stop here that have it all together to stop here.

Bernie's was just fine.  The service wasn't great, and we had to wait past the time of our reservation.  We also felt very rushed as we were finishing out meal.  Last complaint:  Bernie's is EXPENSIVE for what it is.  There are a lot of similar places that serve similar, tasty food, that strike me as a little less expensive.  For that price, we should have been sat on time and the service should have been a little better, and we should not have been rushed out of there.We went to Bernie's to celebrate me passing the bar.  My husband made the reservation.  When he did, they asked if we were celebrating, and he said yes and told her the celebration.  She responded, "Oh I'm so sorry!" and hung up.  Weird.  Maybe she heard, "my wife passed ON?"  "my wife is behind bars?"  Either way, kind of weird.  Not a big deal though!The food was good, but not amazing.  The hummus with lamb was totally tasty, but the bread that came with it looked a bit greasy.  The tomato salad was also good.  Some of us were given the wrong menus, but we figured it out.  I had the turkey burger and really liked it.  Some people had the falafel, which they said was hard to eat.  The grilled chicken was a little dry but otherwise tasty.  French dip was fine, not outstanding.  The brussels sprouts were good.

Started the meal at a 4, with the buttery, fluffy homemade pita that accompanied the hummus (smooth, nice tang from the za'atar) probably one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth, but as I'm still nursing an agro salt burn inflicted on my mouth due to sky-high sodium content of our fries, the inconsistent bass crudo (alternatingly bland, fishy, and mango-liciously pleasant, it was confusing), and our straight up heartbreakingly un-noshable cookies, that like the stock market most recently, Bernie's closed down a few points for the day.Showed up early for our 745p res so got seated at a bar high table, which was okay for the first hour, however somewhere after that our collective tushes fell asleep due to the unforgivingly firm chairs (which, PS, if your BMI is over 30, you will not be able to fit into....a weird choice for a Chicago resto) - open-ish kitchen, white brick walls, kind of old school feel - and a hopping bar that would be lovely if not for the anachronistic, giant sports-tuned TVs along the back wall.Started with the marinated olives (garlic confit, citrus, rosemary) and the veal meatballs (pomodoro, whipped ricotta) - per report, meatballs were tender and flavorful - good enough that KFG obviously debated ordering round two, but before that could happen, we were gifted the hashwi (hummus, ground lamb, pine nuts, pomegranate seeds, za'atar) - I didn't hit the lamb aspect, but the hummy was wonderful - and if you're with a less carnivorous group, they can leave the lil sheepy off entirely.Bass crudo came next - I actually liked it, finding the cilantro vinaigrette light and invigorating, but as it wasn't a team winner, I'd say look elsewhere on the menu for your meal indulgences. The beets/burrata was decent - you can't really go wrong with either of those ingredients - but for my veg sitch, I preferred the carrots/avo (romesco, almonds, grilled scallions, spinach) - the romesco was a nice, hearty touch.Despite the fact that we were all fairly stuffed by now, Ghill demanded that the table finish with the french onion sando, which was apparently v heavy on the mustardy/horseradish - for $19 it was petite - $15 would have been more fitting. The aforementioned fries also came at this point - a mound no less than 6inches high - could have been more consistently fried, with some flaccid and others quite crispy - two words that should never be used together - too salty to be enjoyed in servings larger than 7-10 potato bad boys.Ended with truly sad cookies (ginger spice, choco chip) - hard and luke warm, I didn't even want to nibble. Hard no.Service was aces - Jeff was an absolute star - super friendly, made good recommendations - though as the place got busier he kind of ghosted, but made up for it in spades when he did pop over.Ample din for 4 with 7 drinks, 9 dishes, and 1 dessert clocked in at $270ish - could be done less expensively, but when dining on the Greenhill meal plan saying no to the 7th course is never an option.Small plates $8 (olives) to $23 (gnocchi) - the $19 for the crudo was steep - should have been $15-17 - salads $11-15, veg sides $9-12 (patatas bravas, sweet corn, fries, crispy chokes), large plates $18-30 (pea falafel, striped bass, strozzapreti, roasty chicken), sandos $15-19, wood fired plates (salmon, prawns, oysters) $16-29, desserts $9ish. Overall, maybe I'd return for brunch, but for din it's too all over the place - there is probably no reason that a turkey burger, cote de boeuf ($90), pickled mussels (chevre, jalapeno, basil), prawns w/ black rice, and any dish with labneh belong on the same menu. Needs more focus before I'll return for anything other than a drink and to tattoo watch on all the artfully inked waitstaff. Oh, and gets loud. Leave grandma at home.

The thing I remember most from my night is my friend sitting on the 30ft teal velvet bench surrounded by designer bags, hers, the 4 girls to our left, the two girls to our right. Take from that statement what you will (that nothing else was memorable, that the crowd is attractive brand conscious 20-30 somethings.Bernie's seems to be on point with the latest dinning trends, from kitchy name to rustic interiors and craft cocktails.We split a salad and vegetable dish... yes fries counts as a vegetable, Bernie's wouldn't lie to us. The Heirloom Tomatoes were good but at $14 I thought it was a little pricey for a dish that was over 60% tomatoes. The Hand Cut Fries are $7 and the oversized portion did little to help with my self control, I left the meal feeling like fry oil was coming out of my pores.I hope that they continue to grow and learn, I didn't love either of the dishes we tried, but I will give them another try if not only for a glass of Rose and some rooftop hangs.

As residents of River North, we have been waiting patiently for a restaurant such as Bernies to open up. This area of RN needed it (there isn't a whole lot west of Orleans). Bernies turned a once abandoned looking black building into a hip, bright and exciting atmosphere. With summer ending and the last of the warm nights winding down, the hubby and and I decided to dine al fresco at Bernies rooftop this past Thursday. We were seated right away, to a table with views of Orleans and Erie. The rooftop not only had tables for dining, but also a full bar. Unfortunately, our weather took a turn and it began to drizzle. Luckily we (and a few other tables) were able to just move over to the bar located under a roof. Food can be described as eclectic Mediterranean. We had the lamb hashwi & the heirloom tomatoes on burrata. Wow- both amazing!! For dinner we weren't too hungry so we split the cheeseburger. Really good, not thee BEST burger I've had but definitely up there.Can't wait for them to open for lunch! Welcome to the hood, Bernies. Excited to try more good stuff during our next visit!

Bernie's was alright. The food was good but nothing amazing. We went on a Friday night and where seated right away without a reservation.I felt like the wait staff was a little too pushy, he told us all about the cocktail and then said, so which one do you want to order as opposed to asking us if we would like one or not.

Had brunch here last Sunday, and was a bit underwhelmed. The menu is somewhat limited, and the prices a little on the high side. When we first arrived, the music was so loud that we could barely hear our soft spoken waitress. (Halfway through our time here, they did lower the volume) It took about 45 minutes to get one omelette and 2 egg sandwiches. (They did apologize for the delay) The food itself was okay, but given that there is no shortage of good brunch places nearby, there really isn't much reason to return.

Bernie's opened about a month+ ago and their rooftop opened in the last two weeks.  I've had the pleasure of sitting on the rooftop twice in those two weeks.  It's a wonderful feeling up there and they have a full second bar up there.  During this past Friday's rain storm, we had pretty much the entire rooftop to ourselves b/c nobody wanted to be up there - for the threat of getting wet...even though we were covered.  It was a wonderful night and feeling.I'm going to start with the drinks b/c they know what they are doing there.  After recommendations from both our waitresses, we've tried the Aviacion - which is a great tequila drink, Ain't No Cure - which is great Maker's Mark, but the best was the Southern Decadence - which had a unique, molasses type tasting Blackstrap Rum.  All very delicious!The food is just as good.  Over the last two dinners there, we tried the Lamb Hashwi - a hummus dish with scrumptious pitas.  Their lamb is really good and you just wish they had more lamb dishes on their menu.  We've also had the veal meatballs, which were also good, but maybe needed a little "kick" in the meat.  Sauce-wise - yum!For entrees, we've had the Strozzapreti - a pasta dish which was good.  Not quite Mediterranean in my eyes, but for those who are a little leery of middle eastern food, it's a great alternative.  My husband also tried the cheeseburger but did not think it was as good as others raved about.  The Pea Falafel and Roasted Chicken with patatas Bravas were our stand out favorites.   We could not get enough of either of the dishes.Unfortunately, we've been too full from dinner to try any of their desserts, but one day we will.Our servers on the rooftop were both great and help you get thru the menu and give great recommendations - something that many places do not today.Our only fear is when it gets cold out soon because as we've walked thru their dining room to get to the rooftop - it's extremely loud there.  The dining room does not seem a good place to have a nice dinner conversation with people.  So maybe they will add heat lamps upstairs so we can continue eating up there until November / December!

Cocktails start at $13 but they are definitely super yummy!Had small plates including the steak tar tar, roasted brussel sprouts, beets and burrito salad, roasted acorn squash, and caramel popcorn/apple ice cream sundae all of which were delicious.Will definitely come back for a proper dinner and update this review!

Discovered this gem walking by - delicious food and great fast service, all in a beautiful space.Stuck with small plates, all four were great, would particularly recommended the mussels.Awesome add to River North, can't wait for the patio to open up next week!
Great location and service. However the food is average. Great place to go with friends for drink .... For DRINKS!!! Roof top has a great view and not to crowded.

Had a great time at bernies this week, trendy yet comfortable new spot with a Mediterranean influenced menu.  Went with a group so was able to try several things:- meatballs: delish, flavorful with great texture, not overly dense- lamb hashwii: very good with a creamy hummus and well spiced lamb mixture.  Only drawback on this one was the slightly oily bread that (despite the oil) was good to mop up the hummus with- steak tartare- this one was fine, not my favorite.. The meat was chunked a little too big and the flavor was missing something- bass crudo - another one that was good but not great, flavors not distinctive enough, but the plate looked very pretty- tomato salad - winner with creamy burrata tossed with a bread and heirloom tomato salad.  Flavors were bright, well seasoned and great combination of creamy/chewy/crisp textures- ricotta gnocchi- liked but didn't love... Flavors were a little tame but the gnocchi were light and the crunch from the walnuts were a nice contrast- roasted oysters - very good, decadent, definitely one to share- roasted brussel sprouts- yum! These were a great side dish, crispy and tender- roasted chicken - ftw... surprisingly delish, simple but very flavorful and served with a side of patatas bravas that were also great- cheeseburger - so good burger, but not what I would go to bernies for ( ordered it per waiter's reco)... Cheese was nicely melted and even the bun was pretty good- chocolate cookies, blueberry cobbler sundae, olive oil cake and pie were all good and ranked in the same order as listed...Nice addition to river north, just sad i missed the rooftop, will have to add it to the list for next summer...

Hosts/Hostesses - ZERO stars.Happy Hour Deals - 4 stars.The attitude of the host staff is probably the worst I've seen of any place in Chicago. Very rude, completely unwelcoming. We've been here at least 5 times and each time the host staff has been terrible. I'm not sure what their deal is, but it's always the same miserable style that seems to want to do anything except help you.Once you get past the hosts....it's a great rooftop! Happy hour deals are rock solid, $5 mules, $5 wine, and a selection of $3 beers - both craft and Hamms/High-Life. And a $3 draught cocktail.Wait stuff upstairs is pretty efficient, and although they not all that personable either, they are certainly better than the hosts.If management gets around to reading this, you should talk to your host staff because it's a very bad first impression for your establishment.

I've only been once for drinks and bites so perhaps it was an off day?  But It was not a good experience.  They have a 'rooftop' which is only the second floor.  Although it is decorated pretty nicely and seems like it would be a good happy hour spot.  We had a reservation for a larger group during an off time on a Saturday (4pm).  I will tell you it's packed at that time so good thing we had a reservation.  Upon entering, we were not greeted politely and were told we could not order food. Well, we weren't planning on it but that was just an off way to be greeted.  She said we had to wait because they had to find chairs.  That was strike number two and I'd been there for about 14 seconds.  So we went upstairs and she went to another group that must not have had a reservation (and in all fairness I'm sure they were warned that when the reservation came in, they'd have to give up their seats, which they likely conveniently forgot) and advised that she would need to take their chairs.  So we needed two more chairs; she took one.  We stood there waiting for another, which never came.  So one of my companions walked over to another large group where there was an empty chair and asked if he could take it and they politely obliged.  The other group was clearly not happy about the chair situation.  Fast forward to now we all have seats and are comfortable.  We ordered drinks, which took a while but about the expected amount of time for how crowded the place was.  What was strange is we got the happy hour menu and decided on some snacks and got the lamb hashwi, fries and chicharonnes.  The chicharonnes showed up in about 2 minutes before we even had our drinks.  The fries show up a few minutes later, once we had drinks; but the food came so fast that it seems like they are trying to get you out of their quickly and I didn't care for that.  Then two other servers tried to bring us fries, and we told them that we already got our fries but we were waiting for the hummus.  That finally came.  So the service was very spotty and disorganized.  The food was actually very good though.  I'd put that at a 4, service at a 1 and ambiance at a 1.5.  The ambiance took a bad turn when I got up to go to the restroom.  You know the type of place where every single person there thinks they're better than every other person there and lacks completely common sense and courtesy?  That's this.  If you say 'excuse me' because you are trying to get by, this is the crowd that won't apologize, won't move, won't even give you an eyeroll as if saying 'how dare you interrupt me when I'm blocking the only route to the bathroom?'  They literally won't even acknowledge you.  I can't stand that type of crowd and have only encountered it at a hand full of spots, thankfully.  It's such a disappointment really because the food was really good.  The lamb hummus is outstanding and the fries are better than average.  And you can't go wrong with chicharonnes.  If only the service and crowd matched the food...

This place is amazing! They are always so nice. My favorite would have to be the the burger and the French dip they took it off the menu I only hope they bring it back. The express with ice cream and a waffle cone chip is the perfect adult treat! They even remember your face that makes it that much more rewarding

Overall, very impressed by Bernie's! I've been wanting to try this place since it opened last month, and this past Thursday evening was my first opportunity. I made a 7:45PM reservation, grabbed my boyfriend and headed over.When we arrived, Bernie's was packed! The entire place was bustling and actually quite noisy, like a diner would be. For this reason, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it for a more romantic or date night kinda thing. Instead, it feels more relaxed and upbeat, could be a fun dinner before heading out on the town actually.  The space is really cool-- big bar in front, and one large dining space further back. Ceilings are high and kitchen is open, which makes for a fun experience. There's also an upstairs patio which looks great.We arrived early at 7:20PM and checked in with the host. The greeting needed some work-- neither host was thrilled to check us in, and when we asked about sitting upstairs, their answer was unclear leaving us confused. Not to worry-- there were plenty of open stools at the main bar and we were immediately greeted by bartender "Felix." We ordered the whiskey drink with blackberry and this was delish and very creative.Eventually, we were seated about 15 minutes after our reservation time. Hosts made no apologies. However, our server Justin made up for it entirely. This dude was awesome, obviously passionate about the restaurant and it's food and very well informed on ingredients. We followed his advice entirely and ordered the tomato and burrata salad, the veal meatballs, lamb, and pan con tomate. Everything was very very good and more importantly, unique!The star of the night was the tomato and burrata salad. For starters, I was very impressed with both the quality and freshness of ingredients but also in the large quantity served. Really unique spin on a burrata salad as they also incorporated sliced apples, basil leaves, and the most incredible homemade croutons ever. Second favorite was the veal meatballs, which just melted in your mouth. Throughout the meal our server Justin checked in on us and was attentive and friendly. Loved it!I'm giving them 4 stars, as we loved the experience overall but felt there was room for improvement from the host stand (mostly from a training perspective and how to politely great guests and answer questions). I will definitely be back, next time with some girlfriends!

So... if we were only looking into food and not service i would have given it 5 stars. Unfortunately the service was just that bad.Lets start with the good things: the food was spot on and we loved each dish we got.1. Fries-- huge portion and delish. Thinly cut, salty and came with a great aoili2. Lamb and hummus- tasted just like israel. so fresh, amazing spices and the bread/pita was tasty also3. Heirloom tomato- just perfect. We got 2 for the 6 of us and that was the right decision4. French Dip- bread was perfectly toasted, meat and ju were amazing and had a great mustard or horseradish on it5. Chicken- i never order chicken out and this was incredible. so moist. skin was perfectly crispy. also large portions.6. Ricotta Gnocchi- this was good too, but our least favorite. Pasta was a bit dry. Good flavor.7. Blueberry cobbler- tasty and different. good texture8. strawberry-lime sorbet- so refreshing!To sum-- food was surprisingly large portions and everything was fantastic.Service.... well it was 90 degrees outside and somehow it was hotter in the restaurant. While I know it was unexpected and the staff was upset by it as well, absolutely nothing was done to make the experience more enjoyable. We were served lukewarm water (which i usually prefer) and had to wait to have it refilled for long periods of time. We said multiple times how we were incredible uncomfortable. They kept apologizing,  yet did nothing actually for us. We thought they would comp dessert, but no not even that. They also added another drink to our bill which was already paid for previously at the bar. Just a lot of hiccups. At the end of the meal, the manager continued to apologize when we finally blurted out-- " you know we live around the corner and would like to come back here..." They got the hint and handed us a gift certificate for small amount. A little can go a lot in these types of situations. I do plan on coming back because the food was perfect. I hope the service improves. Our waitress, Anne, was very nice about the entire situation we just felt like they should have done more from the beginning.

Bernie's opened across the street from our house in late summer, and my husband and I have been quasi-addicts of Zack Sklar's incredible food ever since. Sitting on the corner of Erie and Orleans, I imagine this is a tough place for a restaurant. I've lived a block down the street for a couple of years, and it's kind of an unwritten rule that people looking for dinner and nightlight in River North don't cross Orleans - hence the demise of places like Pranzi, Zocalo, etc. But Bernie's seems to be cracking the code and winning the neighborhood over!Here's why - the FOOD! It's amazing. A few of my favorites: Do not go to Bernie's without having the lamb. It's an appetizer sized portion of lamb and hummus with naan on the side and it's to die for. The paella is amazing, rings true as a Cuban dish. My favorite recently has been what's listed on the menu as red snapper, but for the past few months has been subbed with sea scallops. Scallops on a bed of cauliflower and farro makes you think you're eating healthy even though deep down you know you might not be.Great service, always. Brody is one of the best servers in Chicago and the team always remembers us as locals. Nice to have in our neighborhood!

This place is a favorite of mine.  They had drink specials that are the best in the city during the week and the food is fantastic.  The drinks are also great - the Moscow Mule while on special is offered at a fantastic price and has a great taste.  I've sat at the rooftop and at the bar - both were excellent.  Highly recommend this place

Impressive. The menu is quaint and inventive, the decor is fresh, service was attentive and friendly. The ambience at dinner was a little confusing for what was assumedly meant to be an old-timey "supper club" while a hockey game played on tv and The Clash's "London Calling" quietly raged on in the background. Otherwise, if not for dinner, it's probably a solid choice for a drink or two during the week. The drinks (pronunciation guide included, only somewhat side-eye inducing) were good, mine featuring a sour Japanese whiskey concoction that did not disappoint. There was a "Z" somewhere in the name.The food was excellent. Per the recommendation of "Zac" our lax yet amicable server, we started with lamb hashwi; a hummus-like dip with warm pita. This was an excellent precursor to the rest of the night's dishes. Fried oysters and beet/burrata salad to follow. Curious among Zac's recommendations was the cheeseburger and roast chicken, which, at first glance seem rather plain dishes amongst a menu with what we imagined were well-rounded and robust options like sweet potato gnocchi or red snapper. The cheeseburger was a solid choice, as was the paella we eventually ordered. We finished with a simply satisfying "s'mores" dessert.I'd go back; it's classy and bold yet accessible enough that you aren't puzzled by the options you have or left wishing you'd gone elsewhere. Good for a party with varied tastes. Not exorbitantly priced or stuffy either, though, just filling enough with the right balance.

My wife and I stepped into Bernie's early Saturday afternoon for lunch at out daughters suggestion. We were immediately greeted by the host who showed us to the dining room and asked us where we would like to sit.We were seated and immediately greeted by our waiter Brody. The lunch menu is relatively short and I asked our waiter for a recommendation. He recommended the cheeseburger or the croque madam.I chose the cheeseburger and my wife had the croque madam. Both were wonderful and tasty, excellent recommendations.If you go, ask to be seated in Brody's section. He is a friendly waiter who provides excellent service. The food is very tasty and the dining atmosphere is delightful. We'll be going back!

I never write Yelp reviews but the terrible service inspired me to write my first one. We reserved part of the rooftop for a party. Very rude bartenders and servers. I worked as a server and bartender for years and could not imagine acting that way to people. Food is good but the poorly trained servers and rude bartenders devalue the whole thing. Food was served 2 hours late as well. Trust me, don't do it. Can't express enough how terrible the service was.

Had a great week day lunch here recently! This place has a really cute vibe and I would definitely come back for drinks or brunch.We got the hummus and fries as appetizers which were really good! I had heard the burger here rivals au cheval so naturally most if us went with that. A few of the burgers were a little undercooked but delicious none the less! I ordered a medium rare but would probably get just a medium next time. We also ordered the warm cookies for desert which was a great call! This place is definitely worth checking out

Awesome restaurant. Great hostesses and managers who are very friendly and polite. You really feel Welcomed at Bernie's.The food is out of this world DELICIOUS~!!! This restaurant is Very Upscale. Great place to bring family and friends. Great restaurant for business meetings lunch and dinners.I can't wait to return to Bernies.

It was my second time visiting Bernie's and they have vastly improved from when I visited shortly after them opening. I was greeted and seatly promptly by the hostess, and was quickly greeted by our server. I ordered a Bloody Mary before my party showed up, and was extremely disappointed when I received. The Bloody Mary was watered down and tasted different than every Bloody I've ever had (and I've had a number of Bloodys). I sent it back since I would not drink it and ordered a mimosa instead. The waiter said they could try to fix it and seemed upset when I sent it back and ordered something else. Once my party showed up we ordered food, and I ordered the friend egg sandwich which was delicious.My only real complaint is the bloody Mary and that fact that I was charged for the Bloody. Most restaurants typically take off the item if it was not to the customer's liking, but not in this case.The ambiance of the restaurant is really neat, but overall I thought it was definitely overpriced for what it served. I'd come back if my friends wanted to go.

Came here with an out-of-town visitor on a romantic date, and loved it.Interesting and classy decor, like a fancy diner with open kitchen and lots of exposed brick. It does get loud and the tables are packed together, but that's part of the fun.I'd love to try more things on the menu, but the lamb hummus dish we tried was exquisite. Also tried a seabass dish, which was very tasty and interesting but not what we expected (served cold with cilantro and mint, as a small plate to share). Wine menu offered plenty of great options, of which we took full advantage. Service was excellent, friendly and attentive and happy to explain the menu and offer suggestions.Came in the wintertime, but would love to be back to try new dishes and check out their rooftop patio, which looks like a lot of fun also!Bernie's is worth a shot if you're looking for a new place to try for a small group or romantic date - you won't be disappointed!
Our first time at Bernie's and we loved the food and atmosphere. Service was good but not great. We had to wait a while for our food but once served...WOW. This is your next brunch date!

Service is slow, it took over an hour for the lamb hashwi, & management and staff could care less about their customers. It's sad because they have a nice space and a good happy hour. But whats the point in going when the service is just awful.

After visiting Chicago restaurants for 5+ years, I am writing my first ever Yelp review in an effort to document just how poor of an experience I had at this place relative to the hundreds of other dining experiences I've had in this city.Long story short, I was given a 30 minute estimate for a rooftop table for two upon arrival. 2 hours, 2 (very polite) check-ins with the host desk, 3 drinks and 2 small plates at the bar (all while watching several parties that came in after us get taken up), and absolutely zero explanations later, we left having never stepped foot on the rooftop. As we left I (politely) checked in again with an offensively unapologetic host who simply told me it would be another hour or two before they could seat us upstairs.At the very least, Bernie's, don't trick patrons into spending money at your bar under the guise that they will soon be given a table you never intended to have available in the first place. It'd be nice if you could train your hosts to be even minimally decent to customers walking out after unsuccessfully waiting for two hours for a table they were told would take 30 minutes, too.

Bernie's never fails in delivering scrumptious foods, note-worthy drinks and impeccable service. All of the restaurants under the Peas and Carrots Hospitality Group (Gus's World Famous Fried Chicken, Social Kitchen) are worth exploring. Try everything on the menu NOW!

I was for the third time there and final was super disappointed everything was super salty, the Brussel sprouts so salty and oily, I got a simple salad dressing on the side it felt like the leaves were tossed in salt!!! I also got 4th time the vegan version baked falafel it was terrible the manager said we have different t chef so that's why t was done different as a customer we want the same taste same look same amount of food, I mean the plate was three times smaller than what I had the previous times! And I was telling all vegans about this amazing place, very disappointed! Oh and after sending the food back they did not even took anything off our bill one drink was also $16!

Food: 4 StarsService: 2 StarsCame here as a group of 8 to celebrate my birthday last night. Original server was giving us information about the restaurant and then said, "I guess no one is listening to me", and just ran off mid-sentence. We were all shocked. Eventually, drinks all came out unevenly spaced and my friend received the wrong drink. He told her to try it and attempted to get her to keep it, but finally said that he would get her the correct drink order and took the original drink away. 1st waiter came back to tell us he would no longer be serving us and that we had a new waiter.Food was great. I want to come back for the Lamb Hashwi and the Beets and Burrata.Service was so bizarre, but the food made up for it. On the fence about deciding to come back or not.
Avocado ciabata was great. Nice frittatas. Coffee is not good.

I would like to preface this review by stating that the large party I was with loved the ambience  and the food was pretty decent; however, conflict was not handled professionally and management is incompetent.  This is not a dig at the waiter, who did the best he could considering the circumstances.Although we enjoyed the food we received, there must have been an issue in the kitchen which stalled the turnaround time, at least this is what we were told.  Tables around us, however, were receiving food and cashing out much before us and even ordered the same dishes.  Half of our table had finished eating while the other half had not received over half of the dishes ordered.  We were told multiple times that the food was coming... it didn't.  We escalated the issue to management, who was completely mute to the issue, unapologetic, and quite flippant.  The incapable GM sent his employees to try and butter us up only after we had complained multiple times over the course of an hour (still not receiving the food we had ordered long before).While we were understanding and calm, we were starving and ready to move our birthday celebration to the next location.  Finally, after much back and forth, the waiter helped us cash out and did not charge us for drinks (which we greatly appreciated, but did not request).Overall, management is not equipped to run a new restaurant in Chicago.  One of the guests is close friends with a Rep for the restaurant and made sure they were aware of the inconvenience and poor handling of the situation.  The food was pretty good, but not good enough that any of us plan to go back.  There are too many restaurants in Chicago to pay for dinner and then not receive it...

Thank you Bernie's!  We needed you in our neighborhood.  I've been twice now and can't stop thinking about the Lamb Hashwi.  It's like nothing I've ever had before.  The first time I went to Bernie's we devoured it for an ap and then immediately ordered another one.  The French dip sandwich is quite good too.  Looking forward to hanging out on the rooftop one day.

I really wanted to like this place because it's around the corner from my office. Sadly, it misses the mark. The menu is geared towards small, shared plates which, in theory, means that your party can sample different flavors and tastes. Unfortunately, the small plates ($9-15) are so small that with a party of 4 people you're each getting just a bite or two. The small plates are probably 30-40% too small to be practical. Then on the other extreme are entrees sized portions that are $25 to $30. But there are very limited choices of full entree sized plates.The food was pretty good but very skimpy on things like meat.  I was just kind of left feeling as though they were out to maximize profits and push drinks rather than give you a good meal. For a table of 6 people we ended up spending $250 and we each had only two drinks. I came home and had to hit my fridge because I was still hungry.Try it once sure. But you'll find yourself going to better value places in the neighborhood such as the Franklin Room.

Went to Bernie's for lunch today and it was amazing! We started with a lamb hummus and yogurt with quinoa and fruit. I got the build your own frittata and my husband got the turkey burger. We finished with avocado toast and a homemade muffin. The patio is beautiful on a nice day!

Memorial Day lunch not as memorable as I would have liked.  Sat on the outdoor rooftop deck and looking forward to a good meal on a beautiful Chicago day.  Unfortunately, the nice weather must have wiped out their food and drink.  No cheeseburgers left and two of the beers we wanted were sold out.  Service was also spotty.  High expectations...not met.
Happy hour here was great!! Service was definitely on the slow side, but really fun place to go!

the student discount is like $1 off lol.it's fun to make your own meal. they put us in the corner even though it was pretty empty, called it VIP area. i would have rather been in a booth.so filling, the roti is amazing, my mixture of ingredients was questionable (noodles, pork, broccoli, carrots, egg, kale, spinach, and some spicy thai-themed sauces) but that's on me. good service except i don't like when waiters talk to me for more than 2 minutes.

Flattop is whatever you make of it. Literally. You get a big empty bowl, fill it with all of your favorite contents, and pass it to the chef. BE STRATEGIC. Fill your bowl to the tippy, top; I'm talking to the point where one more kernel of corn would make your whole tower of veggies fall over. Throw on a couple ladles of sauce (or five) and let the magic happen. I always have enough for leftovers the next day so I'm a happy camper!The reason I think flattop is 4-stars instead of 5 is because of their pricing. Charging $9.99 for lunch is totally reasonable and worth it. Charging $12.99 for dinner FOR THE SAME EXACT BOWL AND PORTION is a disservice to your customers. There's no added benefit except coming before 4pm for lunch prices, or after 4pm for dinner prices. Charge a flat price for the bowls all day.Other than that, I'm sad to see so many closing down around the city! I loved my neighborhood one and don't frequent flattop as often since now the only one near me is downtown.

I ate here while in town for business and it was great. I sat at the bar since I was alone and the bartender was pretty cool. He explained to me the method behind the madness of Flat Top Grill and helped me along the way while selecting my sauces. This is a Mongolian grill type of place and reminds me a lot of other places I've visited in the Midwest.Overall, the chicken potsticker appetizers were great, as was the main course. This place has a great atmosphere and the staff is super nice.I will return.
Not too sure about this place. The food was good but it was very confusing figuring out how to order and create your bowl if you've never been here before!

Interesting concept for a restaurant. Patrons choose from an array of ingredients, the cooks cook them on a grill top and the finished dish brought to table by the wait staff.I particularly like the incorporation of roti as choice of carb in addition to tortillas, noodles and quinoa.Thoroughly enjoyed the roti quesadilla especially the hot sauce that came with it.Notable mention - we received excellent service from Cedria Watkins who was attentive, warm and came across as genuinely interested in giving us the best dining experience. Thank you!

Friggin scrumptious! That's what it is :O)This is a newer location than the one I used to frequent near Oprah's studios. I got lucky on this visit as there was street parking available right across the street. Anyone who has been to downtown Chicago knows that parking can be a chore, parking fees are a beast and the personnel writing parking citations take their job seriously.There are lunch specials for food and drinks as well as a military/fire/police discount if you qualify.Some areas of the restaurant are kind of dimly lit and others brighter. There is eclectic art boasting the local teams as well as the how to if you are a newbie to Flat Top Grill.Previously you could add your protein (meats such as fish, chicken, sausage, or vegan options) to your bowl. To cut down on cross contamination they ask at the table and you go up to the cold bar and fill your bowl w/rice, noodles, veggies and many of the other yummy items. Pick a few sauces based on your flavor profile and take it to the grill to have it returned to you piping hot with a serving of roti bread. That roti bread is life! I got some to go and it goes great with honey and peanut butter as a snack with some tea.The options here are always fresh, the establishment stays clean and the waitstaff are fun to be around. A few of the staff are animated but it made the experience that much more enjoyable.Plenty of seating so you can sit for a while and catch up with old friends, dates or your lunch crew.I haven't been let down yet by Flat Top Grill, it's a solid option for lunch or dinner.

Flat Top has been the one place in Chicago that I always visit when I'm traveling. Last time I was here it wasn't as good as it used to be, but I went with friends this week and it was back to its usual standard. They were not serving alcohol, which was a bummer. Hopefully next time I go back they'll have their license again. All in all, I love the food here.

2 beers, 2 dinners, $47 with tip - oh, and we used the student discount. There are better places to spend your money. But, meh - if you're indecisive, it's not the worst place to be.It's similar to mongolian BBQ except that they now no longer let you physically pick up your own meats/protein. Additionally, they got rid of the filipino sausage and replaced it with androielle sausage - bummer.Anyhow, for $9.99 at lunch, or $12.99 dinner, you get to pick upward to 3 proteins: I normally go with beef, chicken, and sausage. You then get to go to the veggie/carb bar and load up in this small bowl with toppings and various sauces. They got rid of their "all you can eat for the same dinner price" option so if you want a second round, you can get it for $4.IDK - it was just OK. The veggie selection was whatever, the garlic spoon had fallen in, the service was lacking, there was a layer of dust on my beer bottle - It just seemed like the plethora of minor things just the whole experience blah.

It was okay. I'm not a fan of buffets, but I gave it a shot anyway.Basically, when you get seated someone will give you a wooden paddle to write your name on. The waiter will ask you what kind of protein you want after which he'll hand you a bowl. I ordered three proteins: white fish, chicken and andouille sausage. You then go over to the buffet with said bowl and load all of the veggie ingredients and sauces into the bowl. Stick your wooden spoon into the bowl and leave it at the cooks bar (I thought that part was gross, seeing as how folks off the street are leaning over and around your food in order to place theirs on the bar, too). After about 10 minutes they'll bring you your bowl all stir fried up (unless you got tacos or something).The ambiance was casual. Dress as you would at a food court in the mall -- i.e. nothing to get dressed up about. I noticed that when I went to the buffet table it smelled like there was a WOMEN'S bathroom nearby that had the door opened. I'm trying to think of a classy way to say it smelled like a woman with a not so clean cat. I swear. As far as I could tell, though, the only door wide open nearby was the main kitchen. That was a tad unsettling to think about. Were one or more of the female staff hanging out in the kitchen the ones with the sour cats? Ew. I hurried past the area closest to the kitchen and made my way to the end of the buffet table with lighting speed.The total price for this entree and a coke was $18. The waiter sucked. He didn't come by to refill my coke not once and was nowhere to be found until it came time to collect them coins.Would I return? - not sure. The cat smell was off putting.
I really appreciate the waiter here on our visit.  Dwight was AMAZING and hilarious and made us feel extremely confortable.  When I go back he has to be my waiter.

Upscale fast food with lots of options for everyone.I created a noodle bowl with chicken and a peanut sauce. I do have to say it was an excellent peanut sauce and the excellent was tender.I sat at the bar and bartender was great.It is a casual restaurant but certainly above average.

The Flat Top Grill here in the loop is a great spot for lunch. For $10, you get a huge stir fry! You can choose one, or a number of meats which include Filipino sausage, pork, beef, calamari, chicken, and shrimp/ fish (these last two will cost you extra). You then get a plastic bowl where you fill it to the brim with veggies, rice, quinoa, noodles, and whatever sauces you like.I came today for lunch at around noon with a friend and got a bowl with sausage and calamari with a bunch of veggies and noodles. I also added in eggs and a side of their roti bread, which is so good! I love that everything is really fresh- none of the veggies I saw were frozen.I double checked the menu today and I believe it has been altered slightly. Instead of having the choice of unlimited bowls, you are limited to two bowls for an extra $4, so be mindful of that if you were planning on coming to this location for the all you can eat option.Other than that, good service, friendly staff and tasty food! Left happy and full!

You are the driver of your own destiny... Be prepared to make choices here!If it's your first time, you probably won't have a clue what's going on. I think initially this place started out as a Mongolian BBQ spot, but if you're indecisive like me or have no idea what you're doing you'll end up with a jumble of styles of food. I had originally been to a flat top grill in Old Town before it closed, but it seems like they do things differently at this location. For meats, you no longer pick and choose from the bar area but all of it is handled by the cooks in the back which means you preorder which meats you would like in your bowl. All you have to worry about is the assortment of veggies, rice, noodles, sauces, etc you would like to accompany your selected meats. MAKE SURE TO PILE THAT STUFF AS HIGH AS YOU CAN. GET YOUR MONEYS WORTH. After this you can choose to have it served as a burrito, roti tacos, veggie wraps, and additional assortment of styles. Hard to pin point what kind of food I'd even call this place but maybe Asian Mediterranean fusion?Judging from my one pic I snapped while I was there, I'm still kind of scratching my head at what I had assembled last night. I remember beef, chicken, and sausage with noodles and potatoes an array of veggies and spices/sauces half of it assembled in roti tacos and the other half left as stir fry to consume. For $12, it's probably good for two meals, but some how I consumed all of it in one sitting. I think I was motivated not to have to carry around leftovers to the Sox game. For drinks, they slang some pretty fruity lookin' cocktails as relatively reasonable prices ($8~) and bottles of beer ($6~). I'd probably pass on ordering drinks and just come for the arsenal of food. Come hungry!'Til next time, cheers!

Flat Top was solid food and nothing to write home about. It was a good atmosphere and my server, Dwight, was absolutely fantastic. The set up for the buffet line was fun and flowed nicely from both sides.I almost went with the All You Can Eat option and was told by Dwight to slow my roll and that my eyes were bigger than my stomach. I headed his advice and boy am I glad. The one trip through was more than enough food, and my table mates didnt even finish the food they had.Its a good quick stop in for a bite to eat and something a little different than what you are going to be used to.

This is the only one remaining in Chicago! I like going here since you can pick whatever ingredients you want and it's all fresh and tasty since well you made it. ^___^ I hope this location remains here for a long time since it's refreshing to find a restaurant like this, which is uncommon especially in the "loop" of Chicago.

This place is known for being a great option for those with food allergies, and this is why I am giving this restaurant only 1 star. I understand my dietary restrictions are difficult, but you can not promote "gluten free," "dairy free," and offer allergy sticks to have your food prepared separately if you will not ensure that the food will not be contaminated. My boyfriend found beans in his bowl, which he did not select, and I found a couple of noodles, which I did not place into my bowl either (I am certain because I have a very sensitive intolerance to gluten.) The service was fine and the restaurant was clean, but how I felt after I ate was not.Speaking for everyone with food allergies, please take your promises seriously and ensure that there is no cross-contamination.
amazing vegan place! Nice stuff! Very cheap and taste. Thanks waiter Jose the big guy and bartender  Daniel!

I can't stop raving about this place. My boyfriend brought me here thinking I'd like it, but I absolutely loved this place! I can't wait to go back. We went on a Saturday night and even though this place was busy we only had to wait about 10-15mins for our table.This place is a little tiny, but the ambiance is amazing and our waitress was extremely friendly. This place is great for meat eaters and vegetarians alike. I liked the wide variety of selections they had for preparing your dish. I made a stir fry style dish with salmon and the fish was great. Not fishy at all. The choice of sauces is almoat overwhelming. So many to choose from I almost couldnt decide. Next time I go I want to try making a noodle soup.As you may have guessed, I highly recommend this place and I really can't wait to go back.

I guess it's okay if you've never had authentic Asian food.  I'm also not a huge fan of raw meat sitting out in the open all day but apparently it's safe.If you're in college and trying to get dinner for $13 go for it.

I had visited this place a number of times when I worked in downtown Chicago...I visited again last week, and they did make one change.  When you sit down to order, your server will ask what kind of meat you'd like added to your order (pork, chicken, beef, etc.) prior to this, you were able to add your choice of meat to your meal before submitting it.  I'm guessing sanitary reasons made this particular change, which is fine.  This change didn't decrease in the amount of meat added to the meal.So basically, you get a bowl...choose your rice (brown or white) thought leave room for your veggies.  At the end of the line you choose your flavoring and at the larger table where you submit your dish, you can add "sticks" with add ons like cheese, or sticks that indicate restrictions/allergies.One tip is to get in EARLY because it does get crowded.

I was looking for a vegan restaurant. They do have vegan options, but it is create your own. I was disappointed because that was not what I was looking for, but the food was okay and service was great.I'm upset at YELP, not the restaurant. Nothing was "wrong", but I wasn't looking for a Mongolian Grille...if I would have been, then I could have given 5 stars.

Flat Top is a great choice if you're the loop and looking for a place to eat. I usually come here after visiting Millennium park. It's pretty fun making your own bowl, but it's overpriced. They made a few changes in the last few years that limited the amount of food you can get and there is no longer an "unlimited" option. Granted, one bowl is usually enough for me, but it was kinda fun to think that there are endless bowls of food you could potentially eat..It's still a good meal, especially if you're picky about what goes into your food. Oh, and the roti is the BEST. Always add the roti. Good choice for the loop, but I think there are better choices close by in River North.

It's a Mongolian BBQ. It's ok. Tons of choices when it comes to sauces but restricted Asian veggies. Was not bad but as I know the real ones in Asia, this one is not to compare. Very friendly service. I paid 20$ tip included for one bowl with no options + one sprite

I was in the city for a forum located at the Palmer House Hilton. After I was done, I walked out onto Monroe street and felt really hungry. I had a few choices, but ultimately decided on the 9.99 Lunch special at Flat Top.I was seated quickly, but it took a while to be 'served.' Another woman was solo dining as well, and she experienced the same issue. After a few minutes, I was asked which protein I wanted (Chicken), and went up to the serving line.Flat Top offers Mongolian BBQ (I think that's what it's considered). Pile on as many veggies, starches, and sauces as you can. They also had tofu, which was unique. Once I set my bowl in the cooking line, I received it relavitely quickly after returning to my seat.I know the restaurant also offers soup, appetizers, and other entrees. They also feature their famous Roti bread with each bowl.I wasn't overly impressed by Flat Top. My total was 11.02; I guess that's typically for a city lunch? I have no idea.Not a destination restaurant, but I could see myself here again someday.

Service was great and so was the food. 9.99 bowl lunch special and desert pear drink was great. Have been here multiple times. Parking not available in front due to construction but really close to brown line train station.

Server number 36, Dwight Neal started out nice, however when he found out we were not going to go up for more food (the unlimited option for $4 more) he basically decided he was done with us. He even had the nerve to tell me, "hey brother, sign the check for me would ya"? I was so in awe that I almost said something to the manager, however, I figured this review would be enough. Even as I'm writing this in the restaurant, I can see he's wondering why we're not leaving yet. He wasn't done for the evening as he was taking more tables as we were sitting there. This literally was only 5 minutes after we finished eating that he wanted us to leave!! I've never seen such an attitude from a waiter!!In addition to this, the host and the cooks barely spoke English and it was all we could do to understand and figure out how the process works. It was more of a Mongolian style where you put a plate of food together from a raw buffet bar, gather your sauces and then give it to the cook where they make it in front of you. However, this place didn't seem to understand anything I was asking in plain English!! It also wasn't a very smooth process. They make you leave the food and they bring it to you instead of letting you watch them make it, unlike most places of this nature. Also the decor was dark and such a confusing process from the moment we entered the place, even the layout of the restaurant was frustrating!The food was good, but not great! I didn't feel as if I'd want to go back again. It was really just ok. I've had so much better at other places and the fact that they could not communicate in clear English and we were treated so horribly by the waiter, this was enough to give it 2 stars.

First-time visitor as of a week or so ago.  Interesting concept, and very friendly and attentive staff.Overall the food was decent though the meat choices I had (chicken and pork), both of which seemed very dry though perhaps it was my own fault for not adding more sauce.  That said, in all honesty I probably wouldn't gravitate to this place as there are other stir-fry Asian places which I prefer.

I've been here twice- dined in for dinner and got a to-go for dinner.Dining in experience- 5 stars! I had a great experience- very prompt and attentive service.Carry-out experience- 1 star. Hostess asked me to order with the bartender. I sat at the bar, looking at the bartender for about 5 minutes before he even acknowledged me. He then gave me a menu and ignored me for another 5 minutes. My food came, I waited another 10 minutes after the food was delivered to me to get the check and cash out.

I had been to Mongolian grill style places in the past, but this place definitely takes the cake! Lunch was super affordable, and we had great service. There were so many options, it was hard to pick among the plethora of ingredients and sauces. I appreciated that they had mock duck which I always love. I was also impressed by the existing systems they had for accommodating food allergies. My food took a while but was super tasty. I wish I took advantage of more stuff to add, but it was good and fresh on its own.

My friend and I were looking to try someplace new for lunch. She has a peanut/soy allergy so our first step was to see if they could be accommodating to that and they assured us they could be. Now I consider both of us to be very bright individuals, but the whole time here I was very confused. We sat down and our waiter asked us if it was our first time. We said yes....and from there on it felt like we were speaking a different language with the instructions we were given. I will apologize in advance, but this will be a lengthy review...First we were given a stick and a pencil with our menu. We were told to write on the stick our names and up to 3 meats we would like to come with our meals. Simple enough I figured (I chose sausage, shrimp, calamari). Then we were given this huge explanation on how things worked. They come back to your table with a bowl and then you are set free to navigate the ridiculous array of sauces, veggies, rice/noodles and basically put the meal together yourself. We held on to our little bowls and gave each other reassuring looks that we got this.So first stop we had to decide rice or noodles and then fix up your bowl with whatever condiments. I went with the brown rice, noodles, and added broccoli, mushrooms, onions. (There were seriously about 15 other items, but I tried to keep it simple). Then there are about 10 sauces to choose from. I went with the garlic black bean.After that it's time to "Transform your meal" You go over to this area where you are met with another set of sticks to choose from. You can Transform and add to your creation. The transform sticks you can choose between having them change the items you have in the bowl into either a burrito, wrap, soup, roti taco, or stuffed sandwich. I went with the roti taco. Also you can choose from the other side of sticks to add to your creation tofu, eggs, cheese, or a white stick to mean you have some form of allergy.Once your done with all that it's time to hand them your bowl so they can "create" your meal. By that point we were exhausted and went back to our tables praying we did somewhat well in choosing the right items. I also needed a drink by this point (I know it's lunch time...but I felt I worked hard enough for it ). I went with the FTG Punch...sweet and fruity and I couldn't taste the alcohol so I liked it. About 5 minutes later we get our creation and honestly we didn't do a bad job in our item selections. The problem to me is it tasted like something I could have ordered someplace else and had the chefs do all the work. I'm not big on specialization of my food and having to pick so many options, but if you are this is a great place to go.

Was a little intimidated by the concept - seemed overwhelming at first, but our server (Jose) did an amazing job of explaining things to us and even came up to the fixings bar to make sure we understood what to do.First timers be sure to overfill your bowl with goodies before delivering to the kitchen section... You can add on things like bread or broth by adding sticks to your bowl (color coded).The portions were big and filling.

LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!! I ordered a vegetarian stir fry with Chill Garlic sauce, hot sauce and some veggies with Noodles. And ordered their Naan for bread, oooh and Naan is AWESOME, but eat it hot, it is made of all purpose flour so might become rubbery if you wait for too long before you eat it.The service is good, I'd say they manage crowd very well, atleast when I went there during a weekday lunch. The wait was 1.5 hr but it was well worth it. Edamame for starters is very good too.As for the decor, it is pretty decent, casual and nothing you would not like. It is very clean, cozy. It is nothing extra ordinary but nothing too bad either.Definitely recommend this place to anybody.

What a system!  Great food, fresh, liked watching them cook it!  They  have a system in place that works. Pick out your own favorites for them to cook salad bar style, send it back, and they match it up. We had a party of 4 got it all right and I heard no complaints from other tables. Don't know how they keep track!Place was packed too. Busy Saturday night!  A worthy vegetarian venue in downtown Chi town

We loved our server, Manny. He was SO friendly and and helpful. He took the time to make sure we were ok with our experience and even charged my phone for me. He was just great. The manager, too, was excellent. He was running around the whole time making sure everyone was happy and telling the cooks to improve their work when necessary.The food itself was, ok. It wasn't the best thing I have ever tasted, but it was fresh and it was tasty. I don't really like do-it-yourself places, and I'm not the biggest fan of stir-fry so the problem could just be me. We also had a brownie dessert. It was a little dry, but we ate it all up regardless.Overall, a solid place.

The staff was incredibly accommodating. This place has an amazing culture of accommodating food and allergy/dietary limitations. I am doing whole 30 (whole thirty) and so there is a lot I couldn't have. They have a wide array of vegetables and they have beef with no marination on it, so I didn't have to worry about what they might be putting on it.Additionally, they have little sticks to indicate additional food concerns, they cooked my food with olive oil when I stated I could not eat vegetable oil, and I just skipped the grains.I DID find a soy bean in my food, but I just took it out.Overall, great experience, and allowed me to go out to lunch with my colleagues.
Not what it used to be Forsure. staff is not what it used to be at all as well.Veggies. 3 sauces. 2 rotis. Yum

Sat at the bar for 10 minutes......bartender couldn't have missed me. Never said a word to me. I walked out.Their food never got a chance because the service was so poor.Both still do count these days, yes?
Love this place went there last week with my sister brother in law and father for lunch. It's very clean and the staff is friendly and helpful when it came to ordering.

So I used to really love this place but recently they changed the pricing which really threw me off. The concept of the restaurant is great though especially if you're the type who loves picking and choosing for yourself!I'll start off with the positives in that it still has a great selection of fresh vegetables, meat, sauces, and toppings; ranging from cilantro and garlic to squash and zucchini to literally over 20 sauces.Onto the not so impressive. Our waitress asked us if we had been before and we said yes but it had been a while so a refresher would be great. She didn't tell us that now you aren't able to go up for seconds/thirds for the same price (used to be $15) so we just assumed that hadn't changed. A friend of mine is vegan so she wanted to try small portions of different stirfrys since it was all included in the base price and didn't get tofu the first time around so she got a relatively small bowl. After we found out going up again would be an extra $4 (which is a great deal if you already had a full meal especially because you can get it to go) she had honestly felt a little cheated.Just be aware before you go but other than that miscommunication it was pretty decent!!

It's like YogurtLand for stir fry! Hadn't ever experienced this place before when in Chicago on a work trip - I stumbled in late on a Friday night and had been bummed bc there were only super expensive or super unhealthy options at that hour. Not here! Felt good to get a huge plate of veggies (and prob way too many noodles) w a solid sauce served by super friendly people.

I stopped in here for lunch one day, just randomly, while exploring the city and had an enjoyable meal.Décor: The dining area feels like a bit of a cross between a P.F. Chang's and a club (both are good things!). There is a lot of space, a bunch of tables, and even a small bar area for loners like myself. The food stations are very well lit and very well labeled so you know exactly what you're getting. They have changed things a bit from when I have dined at a Flat Top in the past (for example, the meat no longer sits out...) but much has also stayed the same. Everything, given the style of dining, is kept very clean as well, which is nice when you think about it.Bathroom: a typical bathroom that continues the décor of the main restaurant, nice and cleanStaff: My waiter left a bit to be desired as he was not very present after I started eating my main course. However, the cooks were great and my food was fantastic.Food: I started with edamame (it was pretty good) and then moved right to a build-my-own-bowl, which I loaded up. To be honest, I was a bit worried to discover that the meat is no longer "self serve" but they gave a healthy serving in my bowl. Everything tasted fresh and delicious!Value: It's not expensive by any means, but it is, when all is said and done, just a bit too pricey. I couldn't, as much as I'd love to, come here regularly for lunch.I've always been a HUGE fan of Flat Top and, after this visit, I shall remain. I can't wait to come back again!

We usually love this place but this time it was just ok.  The downtown Chicago locations make you choose your meats with your waiter(shrimp and a couple of other meats/proteins come with a surcharge), wait for them to bring your bowl and a receipt stating what you're getting, then you can go to the bar and make your dish. Also, it's not like other Flat top Grills that are 1 bowl for a price then it's all you can eat for a couple more bucks. THIS one has a charge for 1 bowl then it's  $4 more for 2bowls... that's it.Our server, Ms. T. P. (I don't want anyone to loose her job... unless I go back and the service doesn't change), made us feel mostly abandoned. Especially since we had to ask multiple times for our children's drinks and I had to seek out a manager on my own to address a couple of promotional issues (Which he took care of VERY quickly). I'll admit, we had a large party but I'm used to having a little more attention when that's the case.  We saw our server when we made our order and when she brought the check and even then, it seemed like either she really didn't want to wait on us OR maybe her day wasn't going well because a few of the people in my party felt like she had a bad attitude towards them. Either way, I hope the rest of her day was better.To sum it all up, the combination of our server's attitude, her absence, and how different the flow is at this location vs ALL other locations I've EVER visited... I may not visit it again...

Not a new concept. They have been doing Mongolian BBQ in the UK for about 20 years. But unlike Mongolian BBQ this actually tasted good. Man I am such a good chef! I went for shrimp with a flat roti on the side. I loaded up with goodness: broccoli, pepper, beans, kale, tomatoes and a load of Thai sauce. It was SUPER tasty and probably pretty healthy ... bar the salty fish sauce. Service was good. Price was good, nothing not to love about this place.

Decent price for a good amount of food. I've been to other places like this one (Genghis Grill) but never this place. The major difference between them is that at Genghis put the meat you want in the bowl and they cook it, whereas at Flat Top you put the starch in the bowl. I feel like that might prevent the diner from getting as much meat as they would otherwise because they fill the bowl up with noodles. The also offer soup, burrito and salad options, but I'm nor really sure how those would work out.Overall, the food was good and the portion was more than I could eat. The waiter was helpful, but the service was a bit slow and it wasn't that busy. Good experience, in general, though.

I'm really sad that I need to drop this down, and don't let this be indicative of other Flat Top Grill locations. I still love the idea of filling up a bowl with tons of veggies, meats, and sauces and having a fresh hot bowl of chow customized to your liking.Unfortunately there have been changes implemented here (maybe because it's in the Loop so they have higher traffic) that put it below the bar especially compared to other locations of theirs.Before, you got a little bowl to pile your proteins into, and you were limited only by your ability to stack. It was great because they had a large variety of them so you could mix and match beef, pork, chicken, fish, squid, longganisa...No more here. Now you can only get up to three different ones, and if you want to "double up" on one of them, they'll charge you $4. Oof.They've also removed their hot and sour soup option which was pretty darn tasty and my girlfriend's favorite. And to top it off, our service last night was pretty lacking. You'd think at 8:30pm in the Loop you wouldn't have to be waiting around to get water/get the check/pay the check.I really hope this doesn't extend to other Flat Top locations, but looking on their website it seems that they're showing the same $4 upcharge and lack of soup options. It's a sad day, but for now I'm going to go to the West Loop one and hope for the best.

I've been here several times, and most of the time have had a great experience. Love the concept, love the food, veggie-friendly, etc.However, I did not have a good experience the most recent time I was there, however. I put my allergy aware stick in my bowl, like I always do, because my body freaks out every time I eat shellfish. This is supposed to mean that they cook my food in a separate wok to ensure that there is no cross-contamination between my food and other people's which may contain potential allergens.  My food came back, it was delicious as always. HOWEVER, maybe a half-hour after I finished my meal my intestines made it abundantly clear that I had eaten shellfish with a very specific type of pain that I only get when I have consumed it (or something contaminated with it). I was in pain and on the toilet for several hours.Now, I know that they were busier than they normally are that night, and that mistakes happen, but it was just lucky that I do not have an anaphylactic reaction to shellfish. I understand that it is harder to keep track of these things when they're busy, but in my opinion, it's not okay. For me, cross-contamination just meant a miserable few hours, but for someone else it might have meant an epipen, a trip to the ER or worse. It's just not okay.I feel bad writing this, because before this visit, I have loved Flattop. I still do. But I will be very carful in the future, especially when they're busy.

Interesting concept. You choose the ingredients and they cook it for you. Staff is friendly and helpful. The outcomeOf your meal depends of course on your choices. Any combination is possible so for those who do not cook it might be challenging.

GREAT place for a filling, affordable, and relatively healthy lunch! Make your own stir-fry by piling up your bowl with whatever veggies, rice, and sauces that you want. Select your meat, and the Lunch Special total comes out to $10.The stir fry ends up being a huge quantity of food, and depending on how much sauce you put on it, it can be a very satisfying, healthy lunch.TOURIST TIP: It is about a 4 minute walk away from the Art Institute. I definitely recommend it if you get hungry and need to get re-fueled!

Very friendly. Very clean. They do a good at helping you around and explaining how it works if it is your first time. Very attentive and polite ever visit :) make sure you download their app because you get free stuff :)

I love getting food here. Me and my boyfriend love eating here, there's a server who recognizes us when we walk in and he always says hi to us and that makes us feel very welcomed. We recently went yesterday and we had Manny as our server he was great. He was very nice, friendly, welcoming, and checked on us to see if we needed anything but didn't overwhelm us. We've never had a bad server here or a bad experience here. Highly recommend it, good roti tacos, good lettuce wraps, good drinks (their tea and cocktails). The dessert here is also very delicious. Good job flat top!

Not a place for allergy sufferers!!!The concept is cool--you order exactly based on your preferences because you scoop the food as it comes to you in whatever weird creation you want. Terribleness is that despite having a hundred signs about allergies an the ability to specifically make your bowls as allergy issues, the guys behind the lines still use just one set of utensils to stir everyone's food. I don't know about the flat top cleanliness but the sharing of utensils definitely bodes ill for us with allergies especially since the sauces have components of egg, peanuts, and soy.Flavor was okay but it was an overpriced and allergy problem experience. Service was also terrible--grumpy servers and really slow considering the kitchen was finished cooking and plates sat at the pass for 10-14 minutes before being served.

The stars all go to the waiter. He was fast, friendly, and overall excellent. I've been to this place before but in a different location.My previous experience was far better. When we got our food, it was really dry even though we went with the recommended 3-4 ladles of sauce (which is what we did last time and had good results). We also seemed to have lost a lot of the noodles we added to the bowl and collected ingredients that we didn't want (or didn't add) like beef and potatoes. I was making a pad Thai dish.I'll take some of the fault as I didn't check the food receipt they hand you when you request your proteins. But I still think the guys grilling need to slow down and pay attention to what is in the bowls they're grilling. Seriously...where did those potatoes come from??

I've been to this Flat Top a handful of times for large group lunches with co-workers. They are super accommodating in this regard and the servers are always friendly and helpful. This is a great spot for people with all types of eating restrictions and/or preferences. Plus, they honor birthdays!Flat Top hasn't exactly improved as a concept/restaurant over the years, but it's still solid. Make-your-own stir fry is full-proof; if it tastes meh, you blame yourself for making a weird combination. I tend to go with the Flat Top Grill sauce, Korean BBQ or the sweet and sour sauce and tend to never go too wrong. And of course the roti bread is a guilty pleasure that never gets old.

Food are good, cheap and create my own.  The waiters were so busy all the time. Try the appetizer like juanbing soooo good! Add blue tag when you create your own. You won't regret it, better than tacos and sandwiches!

I was at an event at the Palmer House and was happy to find this place open at 9:30 pm. The customer chooses a protein and places all the vegetables into a bowl. You then add sauce and seasoning and take it to the chef for grilling. The host and server were very kind to this newbie and made my experience a pleasant one. I came up with a good combination and cleaned my bowl.

I honestly don't eat in the loop very often because of the price but coming here during lunch hours is definitely worth it. For 2 I only payed $23 and man I was incredible full. Great/fresh ingredients that make this place great.

If you've ever been to a flattop Grill before, great, you know exactly what you're getting yourself into. If you've never been to a flattop Grill before I strongly recommend going to their website and reading the how-to or reading the Yelp reviews that explain exactly what you're about to get yourself into.My biggest complaint with flat top is always how long that takes but that simply the nature of the beast and if they change the process to make it faster I'm sure it wouldn't be nearly as fun.My one criticism is that I was sad at the evil towards the front of the restaurant. They were on be misaligned. The three tables appeared that they should be lined up directly under the lights above them, instead, they were off-center leaving some very strange lighting conditions and placing The person that I was with directly under the air vent. It was probably a one time oversight, and could be easily fixed.

I have been there twice and the first time was fantastic, it's a overall valuable lunch, you may register for free appetizer and use the student discount as well. The waiter was nice and patient to introduce. It suppose to be a great start but the truth is the second which is probably be the last time I will go. We felt "cold" when we got problems about the payment. I understand they may be tired to serve too many guests but when we ask for bags for boxes. We will told to get it in the front desk... absolutely different from the first time. But anyway, our waiter is good. BTW, I ordered two eggs but they didn't show up, at all!
Great meal. Love the variety and the char taste from the grill. Any place in jewellers row on Wabash is good with me. Great service also. Served the exact purpose of what we where looking for.

A fun meal concept. And coming from SF, a $9.99 lunch seemed incredibly cheap, especially when you can really get a giant bowl out of it!They're good at explaining how it works if it's your first time, but it's also useful going with friends who've bene before so they can tell you their own tricks of the trade.Here are some tips:- Stack even more in your main bowl but doing veggies first, then putting the noodles on top. The noodles act as kind of a net that holds everything in place. Then the sauce just soaks into it.- Add PLENTY of sauce. Even if it seems like overkill, your bowl will taste really bland without enough sauce! I did about 4 scoopfuls (between the tomato, thai peanut, and a curry one. It was fantastic).- MIX your sauces! Test it out by adding your combos into the little plastic containers getting it mixed thoroughly by and pouring back and forth between to containers. You can ask someone to help you out with choosing a sauce, and that's what they do to taste it!- GET THE ROTI it's delicious!!! You have to add an extra stick.- The lettuce rolls are a nice option - you just get an extra plate of lettuce and you can wrap some of your into those and eat it in a different style!- MEATS: The Filipino Sausage was fantastic. The beef was really great too.Here's my delicious bowl:yelp.com/biz_photos/flat…

The idea is there but it's in dire need of a better execution!It's lunch time at 1pm on a Tuesday. My friend and I were told to wait 10 minutes. When our table was finally ready, I noticed there were a lot of empty tables as we walked in. So...why the wait? Do keep in mind, most people only get an hour for lunch.We quickly picked up our bowls and went to the buffet section. Select your rice and/or noodles and top it with a bunch of vegetables, sauce, and meat. It's the same price no matter how much ingredients you toss into the bowl. And here is where you need to be extra cautious! The staff are refilling the containers as they find necessary. They pour the sauce in while neglecting the customers' presence. I was wise enough to back up two steps before they splattered the sauce across my white blouse. Beware of your surroundings!We left our bowls by the grill for them to be cooked and returned to our table. It was another 10 minute before we finally received our food. The Chinese yellow noodles were good and the roti prata bread is a must-order. That's where I applied my two stars! The rest of the contents were slightly charred and overly salty. The meat was rough and dry.The check also takes a while to arrive. My tip to lunch diners is to immediately ask for the check when they arrive with your bowls. This will get you out of there in a more efficient manner!
Good food n good place for groups. Get to choose your items, amount of sauce and there is quiet a variety of sauces. Food really taste good. Good for veg n non veg people

Great place to go to "HAVE IT YOUR WAY!" You really can't complain about what you eat here, since the food is fresh, and you are the one picking what goes into your own bowl!
