There are just too many ingredients in the soup.I get that the restaurant is trying to be creative, but tradition is tradition for certain reasons. Please honor the traditional way and try to understand the cuisine better before make any changes. Otherwise the food would be confusing and nasty. It borders on humiliation calling this kind of food "ramen".For real ramen nearby, please go to NYC.

Our weekday lunch didn't start off that well: we got there around 2pm, and more than half of the tables were empty. We walked right up and asked for a table. "Do you have a reservation?" "No..." "Ok, we can seat you in about 5 minutes."Wut.I get the need to clear off tables, but there were plenty of clear tables, and I think seating patrons should be the first priority before busing tables, especially when it's not super busy time. I asked one of the main guys what was up with that, and he gave me a pretty nasty look the rest of our time here. So that was a pretty bad intro to the experience.The express lunch is a good deal if you're not getting the ramen. Seriously, the ramen (both types offered for lunch) had minimal flavor, and the noodles did not taste fresh. I like that it came with some other side dishes, like the salmon over rice, which was much tastier and satiating.Chill vibe overall. It's not all hip hop, so think liberally in your definition if you're coming for the music.I'd suggest going to Slurping Turtle down the street if you're looking for ramen, hands down. The variety at Ramen-san is good, though.

Called at 1130 to ask when their kitchen closed.Host: Well... we close in 30 minutes so...Me: alright! See you in a little bit!Lol. She was a good sport about it and when we got there, there were still people eating and drinking and others coming in after us. For being 30 minutes before closing, our waitress was not rude, which made us not feel rushed, even though we scarfed our food down like we were. We were just so. freaking. hungry.2 tonkotsu w/ chili oil and fried garlic - Idk if my bf and I were just really hungry, but this ramen was soooo good. Bf did comment that it was a little salty though. The noodles were the perfect texture. The broth was warm and a good enough amount of spice. There was 4 pieces of chashu in my bowl, which was more than enough. And even though they don't have it on the menu, there are bamboo shoots and nori (maybe?) in the bowl. Oh yeah, the egg was perfect, better than perfect.Pork belly bao - very dry and kinda sweet. Took one bite. Don't get.
I've only been here once at 1am after a lot of drinking at Three Dots... forgive me...Had lobster fried rice and a beer. It was good as I remember...! I think it cost me $30 though...?!

Tried this out with a visiting friend, we were very pleased.   The lunch rush slowed down the service a little but we were in no rush and they were very attentive to our table.   The ramen bowl was huge and filling in itself, they asked for a "noodle refresher" if we needed one for the ton of broth, but that wasn't needed.   Family styles seating, long active fun atmosphere!

Even though Ramen-san is one of the most reviewed ramen spots in the city, it was never really high on my list of places to check out. Being part of LEYE, I figured it would be solid but nothing special. It wasn't intriguing enough to go to over any of the other hot new ramen restaurants in Chicago. I just happened to be in the area and it wasn't that crowded, so I figured might as well give it a shot.Ambiance: Being right on Hubbard and next to Paris club, the atmosphere was clean-cut, dimly lit, and trendy as expected. It didn't really give off a Japanese vibe, but I'm not a stickler for decor. The layout was almost like a school cafeteria, with rows of high top tables and bench seating. I ended up just grabbing a stool at the bar. I'm not sure if they always do this, but they were projecting the olympics on one of the walls behind the bar, which was nice for people just grabbing a quick bite.Food: There were definitely some interesting items on the menu I wanted to try, but considering this was my second dinner, I just stuck to the basics and ordered a classic bowl of tonkotsu.Broth - I gotta say that I was pleasantly surprised with the broth. It had plenty of porky flavor and a good amount of saltiness. The best part was the strong garlic flavor, especially since I wasn't expecting such a dominant garlic taste based on the menu description.Noodles - The noodles were pretty generic. Not bad, but didn't have the nice chew of a hand made noodle. They were pretty generous with the portion though, so that's a plus if you come hungry.Toppings - Again, I thought the toppings were solid but not too memorable. The pork was a thicker but leaner cut of meat and didn't really have that melt in your mouth texture that you'd get with a more marbled piece. The egg was great, with a melted yolky center, but they cheaped out and only gave half an egg. Like I said before, the best topping for me was the huge amount of roasted minced garlic sprinkled on top. Every spoonful of broth just packed little bursts of flavor.Overall, I thought it was a solid bowl of ramen. It probably wouldn't stand out among some of my other favorite ramen joints around the city if compared head to head, but I'd come back if I was in River North and craving ramen.

Their gyoza is likely the best I have ever had. The poke on chips was also pretty tasty, if not laden with too much Avocado.Their Ramen, however.... is terrible. It reminded me of when you bought Ramen at a drugstore on your way home from a party and drunkenly let it sit too long.Soggy, bland and honestly, from a package you buy as a student at corner store in a caloric emergency.Perhaps I am spoiled coming from LA, where we have great Ramen shops, but this is the red headed stepchild of Ramen.In name only.

As one of the Ramen places mentioned a lot around Chicago, I was pretty excited to try Ramen San. I ordered the Roasted Vegetable Miso Ramen and the Shiitake Mantou Bun. The Ramen came out really hot, and was pretty good. Portion size of the Ramen was really large. It was a little oily and was not as spicy or flavorful as I expected, and I found myself using a lot of the red chilli pepper flakes to my Ramen bowl. The Ramen was alright as a whole, but it was not super special. The Shiitake Mantou Bun was really good! The Bun was a little small, but I loved the taste of the mushroom with the sauce in the Bun.The service here was really good, and the waiter was very friendly. However, the price was very steep here for pretty average food; the Ramen bowl costed $14, and the Mantou Bun costed $5 (for a really small Bun!). Not sure if I'll be back, but overall I'll give it 3 stars.

Another excellent experience at Ramen-San.  I'm in Chicago once a year for business and this is now my first stop (2nd stop:  Firecakes, across the street).  The kimchi fried chicken ramen is really out of this world.  The cilantro lime margaritas are very good also.  The dessert - some kind of home cooked waffle with ice cream and berries - is also a must-have.  Best part of our experience - server Jillian, who treated us like family.  A + !

This was my first ramen experience.For someone who is not very adventurous when it comes to food, this was really good and something different to try.I had the kimchi & fried chicken ramen. It was delicious! i had mine with less spice because I would not be able to handle the full amount of spice it normally comes with. I thought the flavors were great and the portion was good.They also sell ice cream cones for $3. Not a bad option! The flavors were a little too unique for me to try though, black sesame and green tea.The service was fantastic. Our waitress was super nice and did a good job explaining everything.

Wandered into here last night after searching high and low for somewhere good to eat near the river. My friend and I were thrilled to discover this place since there seems to be nothing but steakhouses in the area. Looking back now I could have eaten at a steakhouse and probably would have spent the same amount, this place is pretty pricey if you ask me. The cocktail I bought was the same price as my meal ($13).I did enjoy the atmosphere as well as the old school hip hop they were playing.I ended up ordering the Shio and added fried chicken for $4. Overall the meal was good, kinda plain taste wise which is why I am glad I added some fried chicken. I paired that with a cocktail called the blueprint which was honestly one of the best cocktails I have had in a long time. That was worth the $13 but I wish the ramen was maybe 10-11 bucks instead. My friend went with the Kimchi & Fried Chicken and paired that with the penicillin 2 cocktail(which was also amazing based on the couple of sips my friend let me have) and said it was pretty tasty and definitely spicy. He had to go to the bathroom a couple times just so he could blow his nose.We decided to splurge and got some green tea ice cream cones ($3 each) which hit the spot on a very hot summer evening.My friend and I ended up spending way more money then we were planning to but in the end it was a good experience. We just need to get used to spending more money when we are downtown. Everything is so so so expensive.

Overall: As much as I want to give it 4 stars,  the average taste leaves Ramen-san as a lesser ramen option in town.The good: Service was very friendly and there's decent amount of seating. The place is clean and they play good music. Food came out quick and hot and the buns were great.The bad: The ramen was very 'okay'. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. Just average. The waiter screwed up our waters and cokes. Not many refills either. The prices are pretty steep.Atmosphere: 8/10Service: 8/10Food: 7/10

I'm updating this review because I have discovered their donuts, and they are just perfection.  The ramen and service are the same, but I will be coming back to this place again and again for those donuts.  They are creamy, little fried clouds that dissolve in your mouth.  And that CARAMEL cream.  Wow.

Any restaurant that is blaring Gangsta's Paradise while I sloppily slurp up ramen gets a golden star in my book.  I'm no gangsta but the ramen here at Ramen-San sure is "boss".  Ramen-San asserts itself apart from the many other restaurants offering the same traditional dishes by adding a little bit of a funky flair.  It's hard to stray too far from what is traditional at risk of losing what ramen essentially is, but Ramen-San does a fair job.  Although several of the ramen dishes looked appetizing, my fiancé and I settled on ordering the kimchi and fried chicken ramen with black garlic.  It  was good and spicy, but as my fiancé likes to say: "It really clears up your sinuses!"If you are eating the ramen by yourself (instead of sharing it like us goofs) it is plenty big, but that doesn't mean you won't run out of noodles like we did.  If you want extra noodles to soak up all that broth you can certainly ask for it, but at a cost of around $2.00.  Be mindful of this, though: if you want extra broth it will cost you an additional $5-6, and that's on top of the additional noodles.  Apparently, it is more "labor-intensive" to make the broth which is why it costs more.  Moral of the story - savor your broth.  Speaking of money - Ramen-San is a tad bit over-priced, especially when comparing to so many other ramen restaurants, both in and out of the city.One thing I haven't had at other ramen restaurants is the Asahi draft which is said to be served "ice cold", but really it felt as if I took it out of the fridge just minutes ago.  It could just be me, but if something is to be served ice-cold, I'm expecting it to be so cold that I need mittens for my hands.  To me, this Asahi draft was just like an other draft beer.  Although I was a little disappointed with this, I was not disappointed with the other things we ordered: smoked salmon nigiri appetizer and the black sesame seed & caramel matcha ice cream cones.  These were also over-priced, but very tasty.  The ice cream cones are so dainty, but full of flavor...what an oxymoron!Obviously, the food is a no-brainer - it's good, and I think we can all agree on that.  The atmosphere is a different story though.  It'd not that the environment was off-putting, but it was rather boring.  I like the industrial feel of restaurants, but Ramen-San seemed to be experiencing some identity crisis where it didn't know if it wanted to go for that industrial atmosphere or not.  I say, go big or go home and Ramen-San didn't go back with their atmosphere.  Essentially, it left me wanting more.  I did however, love the "garage door-like" windows that allow fluid access from inside the restaurant to the outside patio.By far, my favorite thing was the 90's rap playing in the background.  This seemed like yet another identity crisis (rap and ramen...together???) but I'll let it slide.

The brisket ramen was great--garlicky and smokey. The brisket is slow cooked so it's super tender. So much flavor packed into a bowl. The portions are large so is you're not that hungry definitely share.The drinks are pretty damn expensive ~$14. They are refreshing and tasty but definitely mot worth $14.Also, the fresh waffle and ice cream dessert was bomb! It consists of a warm and soft waffle with a more savory ice cream. So bomb and $8.

For the tonkotsu ramen, I can vouch for the quality of the pork belly, the bamboo/seaweed-infused broth, and the al dente Tokyo wavy noodles. But the price? Ehhh. It was 14 dollars + tax + tip, which is rather pricey for ramen. Everything tasted well together, and it was pleasantly rich (not too much). But I'm not sure if I'm willing to pay that much--yet then again, I'm not a huge fan of ramen.

by far one of my FAVORITE things I ate while in Chicago.  Also, one of the best bowls of ramen I've had.  It was SO good.  The broth was delicious and not oily/greasy.  The portion size was huge and they gave a lot of meat and veggies.  Just thinking about this steaming delicious bowl of ramen is making me SO HUNGRY.We started with the pork belly buns which were de-li-cious.  The buns were soft and everything was just cooked deliciously.  The pork belly melted in your mouth and had a slight crunch too.... drooling.I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen (traditional broth) and husband ordered the Sumo Bowl.  Both were delicious and their broths were very different.  I LOVED mine. The broth was lighter and it had a ton of veggies in it.  The Sumo bowl was heavier and had more of basically everything haha.I WISH there was one like this in DC.  SOOOOO RECOMMEND!

Updating review up one star...We stopped by last night after drinking with friends around 11:00 pm. We were promptly seated but no one had stopped by our table to provide us water or even take our drink order. We must have waited at least 20-25 minutes. The place wasn't busy due to the late hour. The bartender saw us looking around to see if there was a server, and she came over to help us. She apologized, got us some water and put in our order. Food was decent as usual. My boo really enjoyed the chicken wings. Much to our surprise at the end of our meal, the hostess stopped by with our "check" and apologized for the long wait and comped us our entire meal! That was way more than what they had to do (really a free appetizer would have been fine). But we really appreciated it!!! We left a decent sized tip for the bartender who helped us. Thank you!!

The best ramen can be found in Chicago. I really liked the vibe of the place, kind of dark and hip feeling. The waiter was very attentive and friendly.I had my first hot bun with the pork belly. There was a special sauce that was really good. The pork belly was crisp and salty and somehow also chewy, but in the good way.The ramen came out piping hot and with the typical gigantic proportions. Fortunately they all come with extra ingredients besides what is just on the menu. I love the mushrooms! Nothing super stands out about the meal except it was exactly what you want after a long day walking the city. We left full and warm.

I gotta say "not too shabby"!  I do like the texture of the ramen noodles - al dente! The Chasu pork was pretty lean with little fat. The broth is rich and sprinkled with fried minced garlic, which made it really tasty.  They do put a lot of green onions on the noodles, if you're a fan...  Otherwise, hold the onions!Recommendation:Thai wingsChicken GyozasThey do have alfresco dining.  Parking though is pretty scarce in that area.This is a Lettuce Entertain You restaurant, if you're a member, remember to collect your points!

If I could, I'de give it a 3.5 stars. The restaurant's ambiance is pretty great - semi-hipster. It gets pretty crowded after 7 PM on a work-day. I recommend that you call to make a reservation or do it on opentable first. There are outdoor seatings when its warm.FOOD:1. Tonkotsu Ramen (8/10): I added corn and fried chicken into it, rough day at work need some extra calories. The soup was very flavorful, you don't need to add any extra soy sauce in it. The noodles are not authentic though, I think they use instant ramen noodles. Adding the fried chicken really makes a difference, though. The chashu they give are very fatty (I don't like it) but the egg, urgh. so good.2. Kimchi Fried Chicken Ramen (6/10): Very flavorful, they give a generous amount of fried chicken. I'de say its a level 8/10 spicy for me. My level of spice tolerance is pretty bad, though.3. Gyoza (5/10): nothing special for its price, just a fancy presentation of the fried flour added on top. The fillings of the gyoza tasted like nothing.4. Sesame Ice Cream - the cone has chocolate fillings in the bottom, I didn't really like the ice cream in particular, but if I had to order again, I'de choose seseme over green tea5. Green tea Ice Cream - the cone has caramel fillings in the bottom. It tastes like normal bad green tea ice cream, like the ones you get at gyu kaku.Overall, a pretty good restaurant.

I was there at 5 on a weekday and there were two other people seated at the bar and a handful of people sitting at tables when I arrived.I ordered the Sticky Thai Wings. There were five large wings with a lovely garnish of chopped scallions. The wings were hot and very flavorful. For an appetizer, the presentation was very attractive and the overall portion was just the right amount. The sauce was very tasty and the wings were meaty. I would absolutely order it again.Cute bartender greeted me by saying, "Hi, have you been here before?"  I replied that I had not and asked him for some recommendations. He described his favorite drink, the Yuzu Margarita. He then went on to explain that if I like whiskey, their whiskeys are special Japanese whiskeys worth trying.  I ordered the Yuzu Margarita with house made syrups. The margarita was rimmed with salt, garnished with a lime wedge, and served in a tall, sleek glass.I observed a few of the bartenders and servers mingling on the side of the bar. They were watching their tables at the same time. I never observed any tables with empty glasses or any tables that appeared to be waiting for anything.Drinks were great. Wings were fantastic. Service was excellent. I want to go back for Ramen!

This is a super trendy restaurant and the music is loud - not quite what we were expecting for ramen, but it was okay.We started with a variety of bun - chicken, pork belly, and shittake. The pork belly bun were delicious, but quite messy.Our served recommended the special, the dipping ramen, which was served with a 27 hour broth. The broth was more like a thick gravy and it wasn't all that warm upon being served. By the end of the meal, it was downright cold. The noodles were good but very sticky and hard not to get in clumps. Next time, I would definitely order a more traditional broth bowl.
First time here....love the atmosphere. Love the music. The lighting isn't that bad. I came here for a dinner. The soup base of the noodle is delicious.

My husbands cousin recommended this to get a good fix of ramen noodles. We came for an early lunch and were greeted and seated right away.Our waiter was awesome and explained the menu well. The restaurant itself is comfortable and they seem to enjoy what they do. The hubs and I both got green tea and his came in a ninja turtles mug and I got a Ryan Gosling mug. The tea itself was an interesting take as it had puffed rice in the tea.For nosh we all split the scallion pancake with pork belly and egg. The toppings were good but the pancake itself was fluffier and sweeter than I was expecting.We all did the lunch combo. The hubs and his cousin got the beef with rice and pork noodles. I went with the mushroom tempura and pork noodles. The mushroom was excellent. I also really enjoyed the ramen but my egg was overcooked and I didn't get that incredible egg yolk taste mixed with the ramen. I also found the pork broth to be dull and lacking in rich porky flavor. The star was the ramen which was chewy, delicious and worthy of second rounds which we all did.

I'm a sucker for Lettuce restaurants and Ramen-San did not disappoint.Their service - top notch. We'd indicated in our open table reservation that we wanted a booth (there are lots of communal tables here) and for good measure, dropped that we were Lettuce Gold members. The manager made a trip over before we even ordered to welcome up and thank us for our patronage. Major props. Additionally, we were seated near the entrance and at our request, the wait staff was nice enough to move us to a booth in the back, away from the cold.As for the ramen, I would be doing my california roots a dishonor if I didn't remark that it was a little expensive. I ordered the fried chicken and kimchi ramen and had to go digging for noodles and chicken. Not really what you want to do when you're paying ~$15 a bowl + $misc add-ons.I will say though, the smoked salmon appetizer - so money. I'm a sucker for smoked salmon and always a little apprehensive about seafood in the midwest (seriously, where's the sea?) but the salmon were in big chunks, the wasabi caviar was a nice touch, and I just wanted more.

Such a laid back place! We will for sure be back again when in the area, and I have already suggested it to 3 people that will be visiting in the next few months.Full disclosure: I found this place on Yelp, read reviews others wrote and my husband and I headed right over. Only 1 block from our hotel=BONUS!There were about 2 other couples ahead of us in line, but we were sat right away in a booth (our preference). Drink order taken and brought. Waitress gave us sometime to look over the menu since my hubby didn't know what to order. I suggested the kimchi and that's what he went with. He said it was the perfect amount of spice and he loved it. He did add egg, which he said was perfectly cooked. I ordered the Shiro and added wonton noodles. For $5 extra that was definitely not worth it. The dish however was excellent, and made my sore throat disappear.The music playing sounds like it's from someone's iPod shuffle :-) Wu Tang, Salt-N_Pepa, just a great mix of old school hip hop. My hubby and I were jamming and signing while we were eating!

Yo. LATE NIGHT FRIED RICE, Brussels sprouts and shiitake mushrooms, i died, went to heaven, partied with Jesus and came back. This was AMAZING. Wow.I got a "Penecillin" drink, mixed by Jon, incredible.I'm sad I didn't save room for dessert.The 90s hip hop and dim lighting was the icing on the cake.10 stars!Update: went back for dessert, had the donuts and Green tea ice cream, so. Much. YES!

Delicious and fun place for dinner! We started with the kimchi wontons which were absolutely delicious. I wish I had 100 more. They had this delicious oil and sauce on top that I wanted to lick clean off of the plate.For dinner, I ordered the Mapo doufu ramen. It was so delicious and flavorful. I added the chili oil and sesame seeds that were on the bar of each table to add some more spice. My boyfriend ordered the tonkotsu and loved it. I got to try a piece of his chashu pork and loved it. It was soft and basically melted in your mouth. Definitely a great date spot or to go with a small group of friends.

After a long night of drinking, my friend and I needed something good to get back on track. This place was going to be it. Restrooms are small but very clean. There is no outdoor seating, but the entrance is very open so you can choose of the seats next to the entrance and feel like you're outside. The decor looks very modern, with lots of wooden panels and with seating for various sizes of groups.For our appetizer, we decided to get the kimchi wontons dumplings. The dumplings were fresh, hot, and the pork was flavorful. For our ramen, I decided to get the tonkotsu ramen. I decided to add an extra egg. The broth was surprisingly flavorful. The broth was a missing a little fat, but it was light and was exactly what I needed. The portion size was pretty good as I was barely able to finish the bowl. The best part of the ramen was the pork. The pork had a lot of umami flavor and captured the taste of the broth. Overall, i enjoyed the food here.The service here was pretty good. We were greeted with open arms and our server was nice, quick and courteous. Overall, I enjoyed the food here and was able to recover from a very long night.

Best ramen in the city.  Way better than strings.Went for lunch and sat outside.  Hi tables are a little uncomfortable.  Would sit inside next timeAwesome server.  Welcoming and answered all the questions my wife had (ramen rookie, doesn't trust me)We couldn't finish and the server boxed everything up incredibly well which I really appreciate it.He took the time to separate broth and the ingredients so that it heated up perfectly and separately at home.I added an extra cup of broth to go and I'm really glad I did because it was so delicious!

This place is pretty good. The best ramen in the city? No, but I would say top 10, maybe top 5. Go during their lunch special, between 11am and 2pm, and you get a bunch of food for only $15 including a salad, half bowl of ramen and a rice and meat dish.Check it out, great for the River North crowds and people working in the area.

For the record we (still) LOVE Ramen-san. It is unique in the area, more akin to something from San Fran or Diego. This review is based upon several trips and focuses more on something tangential to food and drink. We have been to Raman-san several times since OT made its last, standard request to review a trip back in August. We almost never miss a visit there when downtown. The most recent visit (9/24) was not really for a meal at all and was not reserved via OT (not by our choice; we want our points!)Yes, OT, we may want TWO "dinner" reservations on the same night! As excessive as this will sound, on this amazing day, we had sushi lunch and dinner AND still went to Ramen-san to cap the day. We went there for the ice cold Asahi and their famous (if you read my reviews) black sesame ice cream. So, the visit was for sort of a bizarre "nightcap".My complaint stems from the second "incident" that we have had in the past year surrounding their black sesame ice cream. Clearly, however, unlike the last time, we pissed them off this time. This is what I really want to discuss. The tone and approach of the staff clearly changed after the incident and the manager handled the situation in a very accusational manner, unlike last time.I get that complaining about ice cream sounds pretty petty. However, black sesame ice cream is a rare and wonderful treat! Once before they served us vanilla ice cream covered with black sesame seeds. Their vanilla is good but it is NOT black sesame: something that I have raved about in the past as a "sole source justification" to visit Ramen-san. Like that time, they insisted that it WAS black sesame ice cream. However, with our persistence, during the first incident they eventually discovered that we were indeed correct, that they HAD served us vanilla ice cream and not black sesame, and that it happened because the vanilla was where the black sesame "should" have been (having found the actual black sesame pushed to the back). Not so this time.The approach this time, by the wait staff, manager, and kitchen (we were told) was almost combative. The manager kept telling us that the black sesame ice cream is made from vanilla. Duh! Pretty much all "Japanese flavors" of ice cream (red bean, sesame seed, green tea) served in the U.S. involve adding those flavors to vanilla. The excuse was also lodged that they get their ice cream from a vendor and that they cannot control its quality.The proof is in the flavor and the color. If you go try this (on my recommendation) you are only getting true black sesame ice cream if it is distinctly gray in color (as unappetizing as that might sound). The ice cream (both times a mistake was made) was distinctly white. If you are mixing a black ingredient with a white ice cream you pretty much have to get some shade of gray!My real complaint is with the approach taken by the staff. We made no "demands" and asked for nothing free. We simply wanted to see if the same mistake had been made as before and, if possible, if we could get the real black sesame, as we know it for the past three years. Failing that, we wanted to know if this was the "new normal" so that we did not again make the mistake of coming in specifically to satisfy a craving for black sesame ice cream.We were not accusing them of trying to do anything nefarious. It indeed might be possible that the vendor has changed the manufacturing or formulation or maybe that they simply are really inconsistent from batch to batch. Though, it IS every business's responsibility to accept accountability for the quality of the vendors that they choose.The real problem was the approach taken by the staff and particularly the manager on this night. We have always found Ramen-san to be a "the customer is always right" sort of place. I get it. I've done it. Serving people can REALLY suck. People can be jerks. People can be doing it for nefarious reasons. We were not treated like we were correct this time. In fact, we were treated like we should just leave. Again, we made no scene. We simply made a quiet comment to our waitress. We wanted black sesame ice cream as the perfect end to a perfect day. We didn't get it; instead we got a dose of attitude to add insult to injury.Sadly, this seems to be a trend that I have observed in the Ramen-san staff overall over the past year. The food and drink still rock. The ambiance is still cool. But they simply are not as customer friendly as they once were. Perhaps they don't need to take such a friendly approach anymore? Considering their location in a trendy nightclub area and how full they seem to be on such nights, this may well be true. It would be a disappointment. Part of the awesome experience at Ramen-san through the years has been the awesome staff. We did not leave feeling awesome. We left feeling accused. Clearly, late night stops for black sesame ice cream may no longer be warranted...though the ice cold Asahi sure still hit the spot.

I'm a ramen fiend, as I've stated before, so I was tentatively eager to try ramen in Chicago.The place was pretty empty for lunch on a weekend, which I guess should have been a tip off.The fried chicken bun we ordered was really good- totally tasted like a large piece of popcorn chicken, which I love!The ramen came, and I was a little overwhelmed by all the stuff on top. Yes, I said "stuff." They're clearly trying to fluff up their ramen and make it trendy of whatever, and I don't mind all the extra crap on top as long as the flavor is great. Hubby and I found the broth to be just ok, and his spicy miso had too much cabbage  in it for his taste.If I lived in the area, I'd probably only come for the buns and to grab a beer. Ramen was overpriced too, but the place has a cool vibe and service was good.

What is with the 3 and a half stars for this place??This is my heaven. I LOVE Japanese Ramen and this is my go-to place.Everyone I know, knows my love for this place...heck even the waiters know that. I have to get my craving filled once a week and I live about an hour away from this place. That's how obsessed I am.I always get the same thing - the Kimchi Ramen. I'm dreaming about it now as I type.The service is pretty great too...at least in my experience but that might be because I am clearly so excited as soon as I walk in.My only issue with this place is that they forget the corn for my ramen 1/3 times and whenever I do togo orders, they put WAY too much garlic and green onions.But I still give 5 stars because as I mentioned earlier, this is my heaven.

The service was incredibly slow - we didn't even get menus or water until about 10-15 minutes after we were seated...and the place was empty, literally only one other group in the place. It was also ridiculously hot and humid outside, but barely any AC was happening so I was obviously melting into an unattractive puddle.But hey, the ramen sounded great. We all got the kimchi fried chicken ramen. It was a little lukewarm when we got it and the fried chicken just didn't mesh well with the ramen, to be honest. The broth was delicious with a great balance of spice, but other than that, it wasn't anything memorable - it sure wasn't cheap either.It was an average ramen experience.

Unfortunately, this is not my favorite ramen shop. It is pretty pricey for what you get! Be ready to drop at least $15 on a mediocre bowl of ramen. I don't recommend the shoyu- it kind of tastes like pho and not like ramen. Might be the beef broth, not sure. The kimchi and fried chicken ramen was much better, with the buttered corn, but they are pretty stingy wirh rhe chicken, giving only 4 small pieces.The dessert was really good though! For $5 you can get homemade donuts with a miso caramel dipping sauce. These are light, fluffy, and are just sweet enough. The dipping sauce is definitely worth the calories. Dessert saved the meal for us, otherwise we would have left disappointed.It gets pretty crowded here! You can sit at the counter though for a quick meal. The food comes out pretty quickly. Also, service is friendly and efficient.Sidr note- check out the bathrooms- they have really cool sinks!

90s hip hop heads unite! Let us gather here in this place of worship. And by place of worship I mean a place to enjoy the music of our youth and smoked pork belly ramen.Although I feel as if this was more expensive than other ramen spots I frequent, I would definitely come back. The atmosphere is just... cool. I'll bring a group of friends next time to just chill, enjoy a couple drinks and good food. My husband had the standard tonkotsu, while I was adventurous with the mapo tofu style ramen. Both were sooo good, but what made both dishes stand out was the chashu *smoked* pork belly! It reminded me of the pork belly from Green Street Smoked Meats!I initially thought, based on the reviews, this place would be too trendy to offer good quality ramen. I was wrong - so happily wrong. Can't wait to go back!

Had a 9pm reservation on a Friday night.  The place was packed.  Luckily, we were able to be sat at an actual table instead of the communal table (which I noticed a couple women had to hop off their chairs to get down).  I, too, am vertically challenged at 5'3.  lolIt was a pretty hoppin' environment.  The music was on point.  Old school hip hop, and sports projected on the brick wall next to us.  Started with a small can of chrysanthemum water sake, served cold.  Light floral flavor, and nice to try.  Would I order a second round, probably not.I wanted to try a little mix of their menu, so I ordered the hamachi sashimi with the olive ohba dressing.  Disappointed by the portion size of the hamachi.  For $14 and only 5 pieces of very thinly sliced fish comes to almost $3 per piece, so for the price, not worth it.  The wasabi dots saved the hamachi flavor wise.The absolute highlight of the meal was the fried chicken mantou bun. Perfectly steamed pillowy Chinese bun encasing a juicy on the inside (watched the juice literally drip from my mouth) and crispy on the outside with asian slaw and leaf parsley.  I could see myself coming in here secretly with my drawstring pants and a disguise mustache to inhale twenty of these as a last meal option.Lastly, the braised short rib "shoyu" (my favorite Hawaiian word) ramen noodle bowl.  The bowl comes out with a ladle (though a spoon-fork hybrid would have been a better choice,  combining a broth-cradling spoon with noodle-sticking prongs.  While the taste of the beef was succulent, there simply was not enough of it (in comparison to my friends tonkatsu pork belly portion).  Plenty of noodles, green onion, and enoki (I refer to them as alien looking antenna shrooms).  Needed a smidge more salt, but I used the soy on the table for added flavor.  In my opinion, I think there wasn't enough meat to satisfy the price of the bowl.I would come back for the mantou buns all the way.  Next time I'll have the tonkatsu ramen bowl, much more flavor and priced right.

Enjoyed a wonderful meal here for the first time and our party was very pleased with all of the food we ordered.We began with glasses of Hitachino and Tiger beer.  I haven't had a Tiger in forever and it was just as good as when I last had it in Singapore.We began with salad-san.  Crispy, chilled, and a delightful, homemade light dressing that started our meal off just right.Then we shared an order of the traditional gyoza with crispy angel wing.  Hot, flavorful and perfect for two to share.Our entrees were the tonkotsu ramen and the kimchi and fried chicken. We enjoyed being able to add a few extras of our favorites (egg, corn, bok choy).  I had the kimchi and chicken and it was deliciously hot and spicy plus very large portions.While I always say 'you don't eat atmosphere', it was comfortable and the music added a nice vibe.Overall a very good experience and when the ramen desire hits again, we will be back without a doubt.

$15 LEYE gift certificate + Ramen-San being part of the LEYE group = lunch visit obviouslyThe atmosphere is pretty open. Communal tables are located in the middle of the restaurant while tables/booths are along the edge. We came at 12:00pm on a Saturday, which was not crowded in the least bit. The restaurant was about 20% full at that time. By the time it was around 1:00pm - 1:30pm, the restaurant was so packed!***NOTE: If you come on the weekends before 2pm, you can get appetizers for $6***That's exactly what we did. I ordered the following:- Pork belly appetizer: Very delicious! The pork was tender. It came with pork, scallions, nori, and an egg on top of what appears to be a pancake.- Skirt steak and tonkotsu ramen (from the Express Lunch menu): I really enjoyed both entrees. The steak was cooked to perfection. The tonkotsu ramen had a thick broth consistency and was savory. The salad didn't blow me away, and the cucumber side was okay.- Toasted black sesame ice cream cone: OMG, SO GOOD. I would eat 10 of these if I could, but my body won't allow it.- Shaved ice dessert: There was slightly an excessive amount of condensed milk and only mango toppings. I wish they added additional toppings or at least more mangoes because the ice-to-topping ratio was off.My friend was in disbelief that I ate half the giant pork belly appetizer, my entire entree, and all of the ice cream cone and shaved ice dessert. He asked where it all went. I hide it well, my friend, I hide it well. The food doesn't sound like much, but the pictures prove all!Unfortunately, my lactose intolerance got the best of me, but -- hey -- it was completely worth it! :D
Decently tasting ramen. Chasu was very good.

I really don't know why the reviews are so negative here. I had low expectations but was pleasantly surprised. The shrimp dumplings were great as a starter. The margarita was a bit too sour/not strong... Would recommend something different.The ramen was great. Good flavor..not watery as some said. Fresh ingredients. Watch out the spicy ones are very spicy but you can ask for less spice. The buttered corn is a good add in.Overall it definitely is a bit pricey for ramen but the quality and quantity of ingredients makes up for it. It's hard to find amazing ramen in the city but this place isn't a bad place to get your fix

Came here on a Thursday during their lunch hour so we were seated right away. The space itself is well decorated and they play great music too!My group of 3 all ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen, 2 with the addition of buttered corn and the other with Bok Choy. The Tonkotsu broth was very rich and delicious! The pork slices were also generous and incredibly flavorful, charred to perfection. Every ingredient in this ramen dish added great depth of flavor. The noodles also had a great texture, very fresh and bouncy! The egg was the perfect consistency where it was runny and made the broth just that much more delicious! There was also a slight kick from the chili oil which made me want to eat more!All in all, a great ramen place to try! The service is great, food is amazing, and the rest of the menu looked fantastic as well! I will definitely be back!

Hip Hop Ramenery~Loved the vibe. Service was good. Tasty eats. Pricing is just a tad exorbitant - even for downtown.My friend and I both got the Express Lunch for $15 so we were able to try many things and enjoyed everything we had!Mushroom Tempura - Small portion in the express lunch but absolutely loved them.Panko-Crusted Chicken - Fresh, moist and delicious.Shio Ramen - Chicken broth, molten egg, tofu and nori. Surprisingly good! Really liked the broth and who doesn't love a runny egg?!Yuzu Lemonade $4 - Very Yuzu-y. Yuzu is a different kind of citrus fruit and although it tastes delicious, it has very different flavor from a lemon. I liked this lemonade but it won't be for everyone.Okonomiyaki $6 - Highlight of my meal! They offer three different kinds on the weekends until 2pm and I highly suggest getting over there to give these a go. We had the ham, cheese and kewpie mayo okonomiyaki which was delicious! Okonomiyaki is like a Japanese pancake with batter but mixed with other veggies & often octopus shreddings! Yum yum yummmmm!With our delicious starter and the express lunch, my belly was beyond full plus I took home some leftovers. I enjoyed all of the food greatly, we had respectable service and really enjoyed the mostly 90s hip hop playing. Although not the best ramen in Chicagoland, I was much more pleased than I expected to be and wouldn't hesitate stopping back in.

* review for take out only *i really wanted to give this place at least 4 stars because the food was really good and my order was neatly packed up in tupperware and all clearly labelled with my name and the item, which i really appreciate. however they forget the chicken in my kimchi and fried chicken ramen which is a main ingredient... if i could i'd give 3.5 stars actually.the ramen itself was still really good, very spicy and savory with lots of kimchi and spices.i also got the smoked salmon nigiri which came with 5 pieces and a side salad. if i ever get the chance to go back i would definitely give it another chance and also eat in because when i picked up my food, the service was friendly and i loved the long tables and high chair decor

Holy smokes delicious.  Ordered for pickup and it was fantastic. $15 for lunch for one was a bit excessive,  but I don't do it too often, so no regrets. They packed it so the broth is separate,  so you can heat it up. Just awesome.

It seems like a pattern now...I finish out the year with an amazing Ramen-San foodie-venture.  Last time it was the A5 Wagyu Omakase dinner...this year is was Sunday Brunch.I had seen the IG posts about the Okonomiyaki specials and thought YES!!! That will be mine.  Stopped through yesterday and it was stellar. The staff, like always, was friendly and engaging. Recommended the Berkshire ham & American Cheese option. I was more that happy to take that suggestion because all three combos looked awesome and I couldn't decide on my own.  I added some steamed buns too because A) I'm a fat kid and B) hello steamed buns.I thought brunch wouldn't get better that my teenage mutant ninja turtle coffee mug...but it did. The steamed buns were perfection. Fried chicken was juicy inside and crispy outside and a nice sized piece of meat. The pork belly was fantastic, with just enough acid from the pickles to cut through the fatty richness.My Okonomiyaki was everything I hoped for. It had crazy umami flavor and such a great blend of flavor and textures. I was happy with my choice...I can't wait to try the octopus/brisket version.  Ended brunch with Black Sesame Ice Cream. Great end to an awesome treat yourself brunch.The food is great but on top of that the environment is welcoming and inviting. The soundtrack is top notch. A little Fugees, some bone thugs, add in a touch of Kanye.  I'll be back for sure. Great value for the quality and amount of food you get.

Last December, my Girlfriend and I set out to try all the top Ramen shops in Chicago. Ramen-san was the first place we went, and we haven't cared to venture out from there.Throughout the year, we've tried the Tonkotsu, Kimchi & Fried Chicken, and Sumo Bowl along with their Pork and Fried Chicken Mantou Buns. You absolutely cannot go wrong with the Kimchi & Fried Chicken bowl, the flavor profile is incredible - and it has the perfect "kick". While carry-out Ramen is not ideal, they do it pretty well and it is packaged and labeled clearly. But try to avoid carry-out - the interior vibe and ambiance is incredible, always a great date night.I have to comment on the service here. I have been frequenting Ramen-san every few weeks for the past year and I have yet to have a bad experience. The food is consistently delicious, and the service is always top-notch. Special thanks to Jane for always providing prompt, courteous service. Oh - one last thing, don't skip the doughnuts, at just $5 they have the perfect texture and are absolutely divine. Thank you again, Jane!

I came here with a group of 4 other people last Saturday night with a 6:30 reservation, and the place was completely packed. I believe we were seated at one of the communal tables which also doubled for tables for bigger parties.I ordered the tonkotsu ramen bowl- pork broth, nori, egg, 3 pieces of pork belly, plenty of sliced green onion, fried garlic bits, and pickled ginger. I found the pork broth to be tasty, but not as flavorful as I would have liked. Maybe I should have gone with the other pork ramen bowl (it was a special that night mentioned by the waiter), where the pork broth was said to have been simmering for 16-18 hours instead of Ramen-san's usual 8 hours. The egg was also slightly overdone. I liked the fried garlic and pickled ginger a lot and the pork belly itself was wonderful. I found some of my ramen noodles to be really stuck and clumped together (almost smushed into large dough chunks) instead of the usual individual noodle strands.Overall, decent ramen in the city but there are better places to check out for sure. The service was good, clean bathrooms, and reasonable prices. Solid 3.5 stars, but I'm upping it to 4 for the nice ambiance and service.
Great food, music, and drinks. Went here with some friends, left with another restaurant to add to my regular places to eat at.

Not the best ramen place sadly. The soup was so salty. Well pretty much everything we order was too salty. Was crying for water water water. Drinks were okay. Nothing special. Even the fried rice was salty. I had better ramen. Over price salty food is all I gotta say. I don't think I'll be coming back here
Late night fried rice like none other. Last time we were there they were playing 90s hip hop. It was the most perfect atmosphere in the city at that hour, I'm convinced.Chill-Delicious.

I read the less-than-positive reviews before coming but desperately wanted a ramen shop near my hotel.I was disappointed with the bartender. I'm all for being chummy with your friends, but it's not cool to stare at my emptying beer, offer to tank up your friend's whiskey, and then ignore my beer until it and my bowl of soup are empty. "No, I don't want another."The ramen was, well... For starters, I mistakenly ordered the wrong ramen. My bad, thanks for fixing it. But when I did receive my tonkotsu ramen, I was immediately saddened by the clumps of noodles stuck together. Made me wonder if they'd just emptied a package of Top Ramen into my bowl. Whatever, I mixed them around and moved on. I noticed the bamboo looked and tasted just like the sad canned stuff I used to mix into home-made stir fry. Whatever, onto the rest. What, ginger in ramen?? I read this in another's review, and I was surprised also. Whatever, let me try the pork.Oh my... Prior to this, I was familiar with Berkshire pork but had never tried it. Words can't really describe how stellar it is, other than to say that I'm salivating right now, thinking about it. That layer of thick fat just melts in your mouth. And the flavor in that pork. I'd think such a delectable piece of meat would be lost in a bowl of soup, but it's really what made up for everything else.All that said, I'd consider returning solely for the pork.

Express lunch menu is available for $15, which allows you to have a choice of a main dish(ramen) and one rice plate with a small salad and marinated cucumbers. In my opinion, it is a big overpriced for ramen (but based on location, it's justified).Shio ramen (chicken broth)- almost flavorless.  I had to add chili powder, soy sauce, more sesame seeds, and chili oil to gain some sort of flavor.Tonkotsu (pork broth) - the soup is very fatty and flavorful. I recommend getting this one.Skirt Steak (rice plate) - best item we tried.  Tender meat marinated with a sweet delightful sauce. YUMMMiso Salmon- the glaze is good, but the salmon tasted a bit off.Marinated cucumbers- not sure what it's marinated in, but a little vinegar may make it better.**The place gets busy during lunch**

The after 10pm fried rice is to die for. Everything else is yummy too but, that rice....try it, you'll agree; to die for. My friend pointed out the establishments notice that you are being filmed while in the restaurant. What's up with that? I give it a 4 star rating because of that oddity.

I came with friends during off hours (at 3pm), so the service was pretty quick. We only waited for our food for 10 minutes. Service isn't bad. The ambiance of the place is pretty hip with good music. It's quiet enough to have conversations.One of my friends and I got the Tonkotsu ramen, and one of my other friends got the Kimchi and Fried Chicken ramen. The Tonkotsu broth was very flavorful and thick. The noodles were perfect with the right amount of chewiness. However, there were way too much ginger! At first, I didn't really notice because the flavor of the tonkotsu, noodles, and bamboo shoots covered the taste of ginger. But with each additional bit, my chances of biting a piece of shredded ginger increased until I almost every bite was filled with ginger in the end. Personally, I think ginger should not be added to ramen.The egg was also a disappointment. When the ramen came, about half the yolk was gone already, presumably dissolved in the broth. The yolk is the best part....Overall it was ok. I feel like for the price I paid, I can probably get better ramen elsewhere.
LOVE the fried chicken buns and of course, the tonkotsu ramen.Great food with good service too....and a full bar!

MISO HAPPY OR SLURP UPI was really happy once I finally got my soup. I just need to get this little complaint out of the way. I phoned in my order for carryout. I arrived at the time the food was suppose to be ready, then I waited another 25 minutes past my promised pick up time. Which then meant I wasn't going to have time to fully savor my soup for lunch. I now had to slurp it down like an American in a hurry at lunch. At least, the guy at the host station was apologetic. He told me that after my order was placed a giant party was seated and the restaurant got slammed. The apology still didn't get me my soup on time but at least he acknowledged they had made a mistake.I had ordered the spicy miso with ground pork, napa cabbage & kung pao chilies because the description in the menu reminded me of a bowl I had in Japan. I also decided to add another helping of noodles to the miso. I always hate running out of noodles and that's the Sicilian in me.  Keep giving me pasta and I am a happy person. I even added some fried garlic which really took the dish up in my opinion.  Every slurp was amazing and I didn't want the bowl to end. I also loved the packaging. Taking soup for carryout can sometimes be tricky but they had that covered. No hot soup was spilled prior to eating or writing this review.Once I finally got my food, I took my carryout order over to the Chicago River. I had a great view while I slurped down my miso. I'll say it again, "MISO HAPPY"! It was also a beautiful day which always makes it nicer. This fall has been very pleasant in Chicago and I'm trying to take advantage of every single warm bonus day.I loved how the soup took me pack to Asia and I didn't have to fly anywhere. The chefs here definitely did their research when they prepared this dish. I love an authentic dish. I really enjoy it when I can compare a Chicago restaurant dish to an authentic dish from my travels and the taste was spot on. This makes me a happy foodie. I look forward to another bowl of this yummy spiciness in my future. I am sure it will taste even better during the colder months of our Chicago winter.

The mood was set for perfect Ramen. A windy cold day in March. We made reservations because you know, we are SOMETIMES considerate, we were sat right away. River North is so beautiful and has another wonderful restaurant to add to its repertoire. It was bustling in there. Tables filling up super fast and you can hear that hip hop playing in the background and another wonderful sound.....SLURPING!Our waiter served us right away, SAKE BOMBS!!!! (Don't judge me! We were celebrating and it was a long week). For starters we had some of those buns (Baos) the fried chicken and pork belly- were delectable! Bravo! Of Course I had the tonkotsu (extra chili oil and fried garlic added for an additional price-worth every penny!). The broth was beautifully rich without  it not being too thick and the meat was tender and complemented the noodles so well. I have had many bowls of ramen, some bad, some good...this one was spectacular. It was an amazing bowl of ramen and I can't believe I devoured it so fast.Things can get a little expensive there but I have zero complaints about the meal. There is lots of communal-esque type of seating and a few booths scattered about. On the table they have hot chili flakes, salt and pepper mix to add to this beautiful creation.TVs adorning the walls and a full service bar., Easy to get to via public transportation and pay to park on the street if you can find it. Service was fast and friendly.

My date had reservations at 8 but we got the around like 7.30 and we got seated right away. The place was packed and it had good music playing. I liked the venue it self, it was nice with exposed bricks and projector TV. We shared one kimchi and fried chicken ramen because it was our first time trying. The broth had a kick to it and it was unexpected but it was really good. The fried chicken was still crispy but there were like three pieces of chicken. It was good for a one time try but we wouldn't come back again.
Cool vibes great music. Food was a spin on typical ramen but VERY good! Great service. The manager was nice!!!! Everyone should go.
Overall is just okay. The food presentation and service are good but the food tastes quite bland. However, $15 lunch set is quite good. You will get a small sides of salad, rice dish, and ramen.

The gyoza has a great presentation and was very delicious. The ramen itself is tough. Its not the best I've had in the area but that's a tough comparison with ramen shops popping up all over the place. The food complemented by the great staff and nice vibes though is definitely worth the visit. I really enjoyed the old school music, heard some Biggie Smalls. Trenton, behind the bar, was extremely helpful and really added to the ambiance for a lot of the guests.The brunch looked very unique too. I'm going to have to come back and try!

2.5 stars I guess. As far as the broth went, the I appreciated that they didn't overload with the salt; Very balanced amount of garlic too. That said, the Tonkotsu broth I ordered didn't have the same depth of flavor as some other ramen that I've had, so it didn't really set itself apart on that front. The fried egg I had tasted a little more overdone then I'm used to(aka not perfectly soft-boiled) as well. On the upside, they gave a decent amount of pork belly, and it tended to be a little bit leaner than some chashu pork I've had at other spots; That's a pro or con depending on what you're looking for(and sort of goes in theme with a less fatty and intense broth here). Friends got the Shio ramen and also the Tonkotsu and they seemed to think it was alright.I've heard that the Sumo bowl, which is both a larger portion and spicier, is the real standout at Ramen-san, so if I ever find myself urging to coming back here I'll order that. Otherwise, for my ramen and hip-hop needs, I'm in no hurry to come back anytime soon.

Nice up beat restaurant with a chill atmosphere. The pork bun appetizers really hit the spot. We tried 3 ramen bowls and they were all amazing. My personal best was the chicken ramen dish and one of their crab cake ramen speciality. Nice place to chill with friends, go on a first date and really good vibe.

I am currently still dining here. I haven't even gotten past the drinks, but the service has been friendly so far. They're very hospitable, and the Cilantro Lime Margarita is THE BEST THING I HAVE EVER PUT IN MY MOUTH-HOLE.I am certain that empires will rise and fall because of this perfectly smooth margarita. Tides will change. Mountains will collapse. Suns will explode. But this margarita will be a constant source of tasty truth.

Nice location, sat outside on the patio on a lovely August night. Prices were a bit high for a ramen joint, but we were craving some late evening Sunday noms. I had the tonkatsu with buttered corn; the meat and noodles were top notch, but the broth was a bit lacking.Our server was exceptionally attentive, filling water regularly and not hesitating to help my non pork-eating companion find a filling substitute.3.5 stars

YAS! After a recent visit to Slurpin' Turtle just down the street, I didn't have much expectations coming into here but was pleasantly surprised both by the service and food.We started with their smoked salmon nigiri, which was an excellent starter to get those taste buds movin' & groovin'. Would describe this as a sushi like appetizer which consisted of rice wrapped in thinly sliced cucumber topped with their delicate smoked salmon & wasabi caviar. Unique & tasty!For my main dish, I went for their special which was their "fatty" tonkatsu ramen, basically a double cooked/marinade of their house tonkatsu broth. HELLA PORKY, HELLA GOOD. My only gripe on this was the portion. As explained by our waitress, it comes with 2oz of pork so I added extra chashu pork for $4. I was expecting a double amount of meat, but it came out half with this super tender pork belly and half with this overly crispy pork belly ends that weren't as delicious. The standard portion of noodles is kinda weak IMO for ~$15, but you can add more for an additional charge. Aside from my complaints, overall it was a solid bowl of ramen just be prepared to add in extras to make it an excellent bowl of ramen. Oh yeah, don't forget to ask for a side of fresh chopped garlic to dump in. Our waitress looked at me like I was crazy, since she was explaining how it already came with garlic oil/sauce in there... Manager came thru personally with the chopped garlic as requested. I was a happy camper.I did mention the service here being really good. Upon being seated we were personally welcomed by the manager which was a nice way to start our dining experience. In addition, we were seated at the booth closest to the door however whenever the front door opened we'd get a nice draft of cold air from outside. Upon request of moving, they were able to move us with no problem at all despite it being relatively busy. Much appreciated!Anyways, 'til next time, cheers!

Came by and to pick up some take out. The place was pretty busy when I showed up to get my order. I was told 20 minutes and came around 35 but still sat around and waited. Came around 47 minutes, but they were pretty busy and pleasant about it.Main issue, I didn't not like the tonkotsu ramen. Main problem, the soup came room temperature to almost cool.Hot, the ramen may have been decent. The meat was tasty. The food portion is modest. It comes nicely separated, soup in a separate container, noodles and meat in a paper bowl. I could eat 2 bowls of ramen.Not a great take out place, may be worth another try dining in.
Two for chicken wings, one for the environment. Nothing for the ramen. There was too much oil inside.

Meh, the food's okay. I ordered the shio ramen with fried chicken. It's filling and tastes good enough.However given Ramen-san's popularity (and prices), I expected the flavors to be more complex. The tofu and egg in my ramen soup, for example, weren't even marinated. Do you know what un-marinated tofu tastes like? Nothing! And the chicken broth  tasted like something I could have picked up from Whole Foods for $8. Very disappointing.Overall, I think the culinary experience was fairly bland. I'll attribute Ramen-san's popularly to its location in a touristy, party district. Look elsewhere for really flavorful, imaginative ramen.

I hate to be the bearer of negativity, but this place leaves a lot to be desired,If you don't eat Ramen regularly it might be a good place to start but I found the food uninspired,What was nice it was Friday and we were seated right away by the window ledge,The server was very friendly so it got me excited for what was ahead,We ordered the Sumo bowl and the kimchi and fried chicken Ramen bowls,We hadn't eaten all day so getting full was our primary goal,The Ramen came out quickly much to our delight,And while we ate the food that was something that wasn't quite right,It failed my usual test for things that make me love Ramen like wanting to drinking all the broth,Very bland flavors and noodles is what was off,I feel very very bad for the people that work there are severely understaffed,And it seemed like an eternity to wait for water as well as the check so we could leave at last,The price is fairly expensive and there are other ramen option my friends,Alast this is the place I shan't return again...

The pork belly of the Tonkotsu ramen was delicious! One of the best pork bellies I've had in Chicago ramen shops. The only regret is the most important component of ramen didn't meet to par: the soup base was too watered down. I've had better soup at Strings, Urbanbelly and Slurping Turtle.The ambience of Ramen-san is probably what makes the restaurant trendy and popular. Music reminds you of Au Cheval while lighting and seating come close a mixture of Green Street Meats and The Publican.

I met a friend here for lunch, I was surprised that we were able to get a table so quickly at Noon during the work week. No wait at all, awesome.We ate at one of the high tables in the back, I liked the set-up, but it was not ideal for my larger work bag. The hooks under the table, because of the size of my work bag, crossed over into the next seating area (sorry to the person sitting next to me).I really enjoyed the quick lunch menu. It gave me the opportunity to try a few different things and it was the right portion size for lunch. I had the fresh lemonade, it was way too sweet for me, I prefer a tangy lemonade, but with some water mixed in it was good.The crowd was all work, it wasn't too loud, and the location was great.

I usually really like Ramen-San, in fact I actually think it's better than Slurping Turtle.But last night when I went to there, the server accidentally spilled my soup as they placed my Tonkotsu Ramen (I like to get this with the Chashu substituted for Fried Chicken) down. The server managed to apologize and "kinda" wipe it away. But it was still on the edge of my table and on the seat. They didn't even offer to ask to take it back to put more soup in or ask if I wanted a new one (I would have said no, but it's the thought that counts). Also, because they didn't completely wipe it off the seat, I had a hard time getting out of the booth without getting soup broth on my dress.Kinda disappointed in the lack of service. Otherwise the previous 4 times I've been here, I would have given this place 4 stars.

Overpriced and loud. annoying. too dark. oh my god loudThe kimchi ramen was decent though. For some reason they dunked the fried chicken in the ramen so it was well... soggy... The broth was not overly salted like some other places, so that was nice. Noodles were so so.My main problems were not the food, though the person I was with hated their ramen. The bar tables (of which compose most of the seating) were really hard to sit on for short people and so my back started hurting sort of soon. There are hooks under the table which are a plus, but they're kind of small which nearly negates the point of putting effort into having hooks there. more restaurants should give hooks for bags. everyone has bags nowadays, and i'm sure tired of putting them on the floor. if you can invest in molecular gastronomy or local organic non-gmo whatever the heck food you can screw a hook onto your desk OK+1 : sesame seed grinder and chili oilThe ice cream at the end was good, $3 though, for a borderline offensively sized scoop. I appreciate the black sesame flavor and the chocolate filling was a good idea.+1: nice server- 0.0001: the group of four next to me did a sake bombIt's also really, really loud, like, bar loud in there... I got a headache and had to take an Advil, which was annoying.The hamachi plate was a stupid ripoff. sashimi is the most hilarious scam in the history ofi wouldn't go here again even if ryuichi sakamoto replied to my tweet and said he was in chicago and wanted to get some ramen here. it's too loud hear, damage your hearing loud. maybe he'd agree.verdict: cross the street and buy three donuts from firecaks

I am in love with ramen and coming into Chicago, I wanted to get my ramen-fix. So we went to Ramen-san since it was close to all the other bars.We actually weren't disappointed with the Tonkatsu ramen. The "molten-egg", which is basically the soft-boiled egg was quite on point and the chashu they used, though didn't have a lot, was cut thick and pretty flavorful. The noodles they used are the medium-sized curly noodles similar to the ones at Daikokuya and the broth was a bit on the peppery side.The ramen in Chicago is definitely a lot more expensive than the ramen in Los Angeles, but I am glad I am able to slightly compare the two cities based on Asian cuisine. The Tonkatsu ramen itself was 14 dollars, so my boyfriend and I decided to just share one since we weren't that hungry (after all we did eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner that day so this was our after-drinking snack). We got an extra molten egg, which is the other half of the egg for a dollar, as well as extra noodles, which was a $2.50 charge. Overall, we ended up paying 11 bucks per person, which isn't bad at all compared to how one bowl of Tonkatsu ramen was 14 bucks!

Really good Ramen.  The Hamachi Sashimi was excellent. We also ordered the sumo bowl...immediately after we slipped into our Ramen induced coma.Service was good.  Atmosphere was cute.  They were playing old school rap music.  Based on what I have told you, whats not to like?

Let me just get this out of the way: Ramen-San is not "authentic" Japanese Ramen. Those seeking that should adjust their expectations.I've had Ramen in Japan on several occasions and this is not that. Rather it is more of an American spin on Ramen. They used to have a BBQ brisket ramen and now have a short-rib ramen, both unique and very "un-authentic" but still tasty.I have been coming here since opening and I have always been treated very well. Very good service in a casual, fun, loud downtown environment. I prefer their original drink menu as compared to the new one but beer is probably what you should be drinking here anyway.So sure, you can find Ramen more similar to that in Tokyo elsewhere but it's worth coming for the overall experience, friendly people and service plus on a cold day a bowl of hot ramen can really hit the spot.One last thing, the late night fried rice is generally great. I would love it if they made it available at all hours because it is super satisfying.What to eat: Short Rib or Tonkastu ramen. Both of these are rich and mild. They do have spicier ramen if you prefer that, I do not.What to drink: Draft Asahi beer or a bottle of White Owl beerGet the fried rice if you can and expect a crowded, high energy space.
Love this place! The food, music, service and overall ambience is amazing. I love bringing my friends who are visiting chicago here. They always leave wanting to come back.

My new favorite ramen spot. We stopped in while on a weekend trip. The thing that drew us in was the hip hop tracks bumping out of he large, open garage doors at the front of the restaurant. We decided to have dinner here on our last night and it was killer. We had the Sticky Thai wings which were sweet and spicy and cooked to crispy perfection. Then we each had a bowl of the tonkatsu ramen (added bok choy) and it was some of the best we've had anywhere. Noodles were toothy but not undercooked, ingredients are super fresh and whisky selection (Japanese) was top shelf. All the while we had a door soundtrack to listen to while we crushed some noodles.
Black sesame ice cream cones were great.The broth of tonkotsu was flavorful and rich, but a bit salty.Better make a reservation on a Friday night.

Tonkatsu noodles were ok and the broth was surprisingly not too salty. The char su was actually pretty good. However, the chicken karage was the worst I've ever encountered by far. It was legit a few measly sliced prices of chicken. Like chicken nuggets but worse. Tragedy. See photo.

I arrived just after noon on a Wednesday and was not expecting it to be so crowded.  Make sure you stay safe a make a reservation no matter when you go.  Because we didn't have a reservation, we had to sit at the counter or bar.  Fine by me.Their lunch special didn't really jump out at me, so I went with the pork ramen.  The noodles were not the best.  They state on the menu the noodles are not homemade and you can taste the difference.  The whole bowl was definitely good, but I don't think I'd go out of my way for this bowl over any other in the city.The waitress was friendly but they seemed understaffed.  We barely made it out in under an hour which for a weekday lunch I find unacceptable.  Once we were finished eating we couldn't find her to get the check and it took maybe 10 minutes until she showed up.

nice and spacious enough to accommodate my group of 12 ppl! Most ramen places are super tiny. But very difficult to find street parking. The food was good, broth was delicious. Great variety of toppings. Only downside, why does it have to be $20 for a bowl of ramen!!!!!!

The food was good there is a great deal during lunch time $15 express lunch. I liked our waiter I didn't remember his name though. Everybody there was helpful and friendly from the host to the wait staff.We did the $15 lunch express where you get a choice of a rice plate could come with chicken, steak or salmon and a choice of a ramen noodle soup bowl too. It also comes with salad and a vegetable side dish. I like it the portions were just right and the plates were colorful. It's one the of the better values in my opinion for a lettuce entertain you restaurant.

We stopped in for dinner on a Friday after work and we had a nice time, definitely worth a stop.  The chicken wings are quite spicy, so be careful if you don't like spicy food and order the other option :).  We got two bowls of ramen, one being the fatty pork ramen, which was extremely tasty.  Both ramens had great broth, not too salty as I have often experienced and it was not grey despite Izzy's experience hahah! The shave ice was surprisingly tasty too, I'm normally not a fan. The strawberries in this one were a huge perk!They have a couple of beers to choose from and a lot of Japanese whiskey that you can make a selection from. The pours are a bit expensive for whiskey that is unknown to me, but I assume that's due to import costs :).I was sitting nearby the bar and as the Friday evening crowd started coming in the bar got jam packed and people kept bumping into us. Would have been nice to have a bit more crowd control as the place is more of a restaurant than a bar and people were blocking up the entire area and jostling the people at the tables..

I'm incredibly impressed by Ramen-San! The service and food was all excellent.From the outside, the restaurant is quite simple. Simple black awning with a simple sign. When you walk in, the decór is simple yet urban modern. Open brick walls, intimate lighting, and simple wooden tables. Some were high tops and others were booths. We were seated at a high top and found to our surprise that there was a purse hook!  Now there was a girl behind the scene when designing this restaurant. The tables are high with high bench seats with no backs so space would be limited if there were 4 people sitting at these tables.We started with the raw tuna appetizer. There are 3 larger crackers per order topped off with tuna tartar and poblano chile guacamole.  The poblano gives this app a little kick, and the cracker has savory sesame seeds on it.  This app is savory, fresh, and light. It doesn't fill you up for the main course.I ordered the mapo doufu ramen (excuse my spelling).  Anybody familiar with the Chinese dish, mapo tofu, this ramen captures all essence of it!  Its spicy but not too spicy. The broth is very comforting and the noodle was aldente! There's a great balance between noodle to broth, with lots of tofu and pork! I definitely will order the kimchi fried chicken next! My friend ordered this and the broth was a touch spicier and I really liked the corn and kimchi!They do have a dessert menu however I was too full to try it.  Next time Ramen-San! You got me hooked!
Really good ramen. Kimchi is a must have.5 stars but a loses a couple points for loud music in the back. Would go more often if I didn't have to yell to have a conversation. LOUD NOISES!

If I'm being perfectly honest, when our friends picked this place for dinner, I was more excited about the company than the food. I peeked at the menu and found the pescatarian options erring on the boring side. So why 4 stars? Because things can surprise you when you're least expecting it.The group started out with drinks and the manfriend and I split the raw tuna starter. I ordered a cilantro-lime margarita; I ended up having two of these, not because I loved them, but because nothing else on the menu struck my fancy and I was too lazy to ask for something else. The drink was a little too sweet, the second drink clinched it and I regretted not opting for something different. To me, the drink would've been better with some spice (other than the glass rim) to cut the sweetness. The group also shared the pure dusk and crazy milk sake. At our server's recommendation, we drank them side-by-side and enjoyed their differences.When our server covered the specials, I was delighted to hear a shrimp curry ramen. I don't know a lot about ramen, but I know what I ordered was not a traditional bowl. That said, I enjoyed my meal; I've had better ramens, but I think this one was solid for what it was. At the end of our meal, our server treated us to their doughnuts. They were warm and doughy and the dipping sauce was delectable.Overall, the food was good, but not out of this world. What really knocked my socks off was how great our server was. Friendly, funny, and on point all night. We all loved her.

Lettuce Entertain You (LEYE) has created a trendy, enjoyable ambiance - as they tend to do - with food that's a bit... too safe. Not much complexity in the broth flavors, but overall serviceable execution of ramen.It's the service that distinguishes the restaurant from others though...Amarit- the manager - is incredible and should write the book on customer service in restaurants. He catered to our questions about ingredients and preparation style with an enthusiasm and expertise that cannot be equalled.We ordered 2 ramen bowls- the pork broth and the soft shell crab - which were both pretty good. I preferred the pork and my wife the crab, so it worked out nicely.Our 2 year old was with us and they catered to her very well. She loved the pork ramen as well.

Cool ramen spot in river north with funky musicThe Manhattan was ok, nothing to remember, maybe should have tried their signature drinks.Tried the Chicken and Kimchi bowl, and it was probably one of the best noodle bowls I have had in a long time. Will be back for more

Really awesome presentation for take out even with heating instruction. The tonkotsu was really good. Chewy egg noodle, super rich broth on a little salty side, and half of a pretty egg. I wish they just gave you a whole egg but it what is it right. It was to bring home from along day at work and I even like the hip hop music while waiting. The packing was on point you didn't even need to use your own bowl so it is great place if your are traveling and want to eat in your hotel room.

Went here for brunch and it was stellar. So many options. They accepted an online reservation (!!) Super attentive service - I think we had two managers come over several time and ask how everything was, besides the waitress refilling my water glass and my friend's champagne class every minute or so ;)Everything was on point and you DEFINITELY get your money's worth. Go for brunch! You won't regret it!

Do not order lobster here. Smack Shack has no idea how to handle what is essentially the perfect ingredient and the way they prepare it in both the boil and the "original" roll should be construed as a direct insult to you as a paying customer, as well as the hardworking lobstermen and women fishing off the Maine coast. This place not only made me reconsider the lobster, it has also shaken my faith in the people of Minneapolis.To elaborate, the lobster prepared in the giant boil kettle out front have been cooked so long that the bright red color has already leached out of the shell by the time it hits your table. The meat ends up stringy and waterlogged. Any of the "Easter egg" bits (like tiny strip of meat in the legs) that make eating a lobster a fun ritual have been cooked out.On the original style lobster roll, low quality lobster dregs are chopped to shreds and mixed with a too-salty reddish(?) mayo that is overpowered by tarragon.
