It was still a fun night with some strong drinks. All that was missing was a cigar maybe?

This is the newest restaurant in the Marina City complex, located in the former health club space a bit below street level on the State Street side.  It has been completely reworked with a rather retro mid-century steakhouse ambience:  dark wood paneling, brown leather banquettes, white tablecloths, heavy tablewear, Victorian or Edwardian theatrical prints on the walls.  The overall look is, well, dignified, though not stuffy.We were seated immediately for our early-afternoon visit.  The first thing to appear at the table was a basket of absolutely addictive flatbread, flavored with asiago and black sesame seeds.  We ordered:Tomato soup with goat cheese (the only soup on the lunch menu).  Thick, chunky, and a bit tart.  Bread bits for texture.  Hint of paprika?Arugula, watermelon, and blueberry salad in a citrus vinaigrette.Crab cake sandwich.  On a fresh-baked bun, with arugula and julienne carrots on top.  Good, probably fresh lump crabmeat; the crab taste was so delicate as to be somewhat lost to the toppings.  (Hey, as anyone in Baltimore will tell you, you can't get a perfect crab cake anywhere west of Ellicott City.  This one was still pretty good.)Attentive, rather formal service.Very accessible to transit, two blocks from the Lake station on the Red Line and the State/Lake station on the Loop "L".  On the 36-Broadway and 29-State bus lines, three blocks from all lines on Michigan Avenue.  Parking available at Marina City or a  garage at 401 N. State.

Arrived on a Monday night for happy hour and was greeted with a surprisingly empty restaurant.. no problem though!$1 oysters were a deal.  Fresh, but truthfully not the most flavorful, but I couldn't complain, I still ate a couple dozen.The highlight was the bartender, Gemma (or Emma), who served up some serious cocktails and showed off her mixology skills.  Ask her for a Ruski Rose (vodka, lemon, pomegranate, apple bitters) which I admit is a damn good fruity cocktail or a Dr. Funk (rum, absinthe, pomegranate) if your feeling adventurous.Next time I'm in Chicago, I'm stopping by for a drink or two.
We were not impressed with the service or the food.  A mediocre steakhouse that seemed to rush you through dinner.

My boyfriend and I went to the Tortiose Club for Easter brunch and had a wonderful experience. They were offering a buffet which pulled out all the stops - including a seafood bar, full breakfast buffet with prime rib and pork and a plentiful dessert offering. The atmosphere is old school, sexy with floor to ceiling hardwood and dark, plush booths. I would stop in for a drink after work or to hear the live jazz. A fun place to try!

I checked out Tortoise club on a Friday during lunch time restaurant week back in February. It's a fancy upscale restaurant and we were greeted very enthusiastically. I felt out of place in jeans with the business professional crowd, but the service was excellent. The crowd during lunch was older and it appeared everyone had ordered a lunch time drink. We followed suit and our waitress was able to recommend some drinks based on our likes. The drink my friend got she didn't care for, but they apologized and got her the same drink I was drinking that she liked.I have been an active participant in restaurant week for the last 3 years and have developed a love and hate relationship with the restaurant week menus. I love the fact you can get a three or four course meal and get away with only paying $22 for lunch, but I'm beginning to notice some places are not offering the popular items, but stuff I probably wouldn't want to try anyway. That was sort of the case for this place. My friend and I weren't feeling the dessert option they had listed for restaurant week, so we decided to just order off the regular menu.We both ordered the Steak Frites which is a 6 ounce filet with fries. The fries were not good at all and the steak was rather dry. We both ordered our steak Medium Well, but it was too cooked. I don't think we got our money's worth for the price we paid. Based on the price and the lack luster food I probably wouldn't revisit again, but then I was told they have live jazz...so maybe...just maybe...I would like to go back for that. I will definitely be reading other food recommendations because this place is too pricey to be ordering something that doesn't taste good.

I am in the food service business and it has been a very long time since a restaurant concept has made such an overwhelmingly positive impact on me.In town for a trade show, I dined here two of the three nights during my stay, lured back by an infectiously genuine management and service staff, a warm, comforting atmosphere that just happens to offer superb live jazz on the weekends, and the kind of on point food that you crave but sometimes never really get.As a solo traveler diner, a number of servers around my section made a point to check in on and chat with me in a casual, unobtrusive way.After my first visit, I came back for dinner again two days later and was greeted by presumably the owner who remembered me and addressed me in a way that let me know he remembered our prior conversation. Pretty mind blind lowing. One of the other servers in the section where I was remembered me as well even though he had not taken care of me personally.When my check was presented on my second night with them, I was informed that they had "taken care of" a glass of wine, presumably as a thank you for returning.As a culinary marketing consultant I am forever fascinated by people who get things exactly right. Congratulations to this one.

Exceptional restaurant. Visiting from New York with my husband we were extremely impressed... not only with restaurants delicious menu items but with our waitress, Alison. She really made excellent recommendations of food items... Yummy to the skirt steak, pasta bolognese sided with roasted vegetable medley. Alison's attention to detail was also excellent. Very professional young lady made he experience to Tortoise Restaurant great... As well as chefs wonderful food! A+

I was invited to dinner here so I can't speak for the prices on the menu.The menu choices:1st choice:Quinoa & Beet salad vs TC House salad, both were delicious but I favored the quinoa and I love beets. nice vinaigrette dressing.2nd course:Lake Superior Whitefish vs Pan Roasted Chicken Breast, both scrumptiousDessert:TC Toffee Cake but the bourbon pecan ice cream was the hit!coffee, wine, and service were impeccable and atmosphere nice, but dark.Valet parking available.

I came for a special work dinner in their private room in the back (for once a private room with glass walls so you don't feel like you are not in the atmosphere of the place).   Our experience was lovely given the company of colleagues but made even more so by the attentive dedicated service and broad range of items:   too much to think about but I recall the steak tartare, crab cakes (a little fishy for me but still good), I declined the oysters (not a fan) but they were presented artfully, smoked salmon, grilled shrimp and guacamole. Lest I think that was enough I selected the sweet tasting house salad (one of the best I have had, almost dessert-like), the Lake Superior whitefish (chewier than expected but this was how it was to be prepared), and finally a Hummer ("adult milkshake") for dessert, very rich for the blood but all so great tasting and palatable for a special yearly splurge.

Great steak and oysters! But I have to say...the cherry pie was amazing! Our waiter was unbelievably personable and professional. The hostess wasn't the nicest but luckily the interaction with her was very minimal.

Stopped in for happy-hour (4:30pm - 6:30pm) oysters at $1 a piece. They were excellent. The hand-made cocktails were very good, albeit expensive ($12) as they weren't included in happy-hour pricing. Would go back for the oysters alone.

I stopped by Tortoise Club the other night before an event. I wanted to check out the cocktails and get a little toasty after work. I had a Negroni spritzer which was delicious because they made it not too bitter. And I had a TC Scofflaw cocktail as well, a citrusy rye drink. The wait staff was super friendly and entertained me while I was sitting by myself. I'd love to go back and try the food. It all looked delicious. This review is "in progress" because I don't feel I can give it a 5 without trying the food first!

Warm, inviting, upscale atmosphere.  Good service.  Great food and drinks.  Great place for some after work drinks or a date.I think the Tortoise Club might be my new favorite place for a drink in the loop....

Came in this morning with my Boyfriend and as expected Don's Grill did not disappoint! They were pretty busy and fortunately for us we didn't have to wait long before we got to be seated. Also, as always we were immediately greeted and welcomed!! I gotta hand it to these Ladies, they really know how to brighten up your morning.I ended up ordering my usual, The Veggie Omelette - Side of Hash browns & Wheat Toast. My Boyfriend ended up ordering the Steak & Stack, this meal is pretty hefty, it came with Steak - 3 Eggs - 3 Pancakes!! Check out the photo if you're wondering just how big this meal is!Everything was great! The food is always good, The conversation with the staff always brings smiles and lots of laughs, and the atmosphere is just so welcoming! Seriously, if you're a local and haven't been to Don's Hamburger Grill you're totally missing out!!Check this place out, you will not be disappointed!

Don's doesn't look like much from the outside or the inside, but what it lacks in aesthetics, it more than makes up for in quality, taste, service, and price.Every interaction we had with multiple servers and the owner was friendly and pleasurable. The servers were quick to go above and beyond to make sure everything exceeded our expectations.I enjoyed the eggs, sausage, bacon, French toast, and coffee. While I can't guarantee the ingredients were fresh and high quality, they certainly tasted as if they were. It was a lot of fun to watch the cooks work the grill in tandem like a well-oiled machine and get everything plated quickly and delivered to us within minutes.It appears as though the owner has good control over what is going on here and was present and working with his staff. He was a super nice guy to talk to and filled us in with a little history of Don's. For three breakfasts and three coffees, the total came to under $25. The value certainly can't be beat for the taste and service. I'll make it a point to visit this throwback of a diner the next time I'm in Chicago.

Do you want 2 sunny side up eggs?  Make em at home.  BUT if you want the hash browns and english muffin with some of the best damn ham off the bone then go to Don's.  Stool seating and it gets crowded.  Not fancy but authentic grill food.  You can watch them cook it if you like.   I'm fantasizing about the ham right now........
Great small diner, food ready super fast and delicious. Friendly people and always open. Perfect for late night stops. Amazing bacon cheeseburger.
Best place to come to when you're drunk on a Saturday night. Greasy food is the key and the hamburgers are to die for.

Dons never disappoints. You want a dive, a greasy spoon , a hole in the wall. You want to pay $3-5 for breakfast!! Come here !!!! Best place for breakfast after a long night of drinking!! Yes there are other options , but where else can you eat right in front of where your food is being cooked - food bar!! Always Love it! Will always return!
Solid diner food. Perfect for drunken late night munchies or hungover breakfast.
Again, Not a bad place to go.....After the West Side Italian fest, etc. Not the greatest, But NOT the worst at all. A very good place to take a break, Or have some simple dining.
Food was ok. Ate pattie melt with onion rings.  The server has poor manners.  Theirs my utensils and wasn't friendly.
Love the breakfast!! Very delicious perfect for late night or any time of day . Also cheeseburgers are great.  ;)

This place is a hidden gem. You're driving north on Western through Pilsen, and tucked away in the midst of all the run-down industrial buildings, shady cell-phone shops and dirty strip malls, you spot it -- Don's. Huh, that's tiny. Looks like your typical little diner. But then you notice that it's packed with people. And you think to yourself, "Wow. It's either really good, or really cheap, drawing a crowd like that."Let me tell you, it's both.I stumbled in one morning with a terrible hangover and a craving for some cheap, greasy-spoon munchies. Boy, was I satisfied. And yes, I've been back several times since, with and without hangovers. This place is consistently delicious, and the prices are great. Staff are incredibly friendly as well.There isn't one thing on the menu that isn't executed just right. I can't recommend this place enough (especially for breakfast)! They cook their eggs perfectly. I've had them sunnyside up, over easy, over hard, scrambled, as an omelette -- they nail it every time and they deserve five stars just for that alone.

So my Uber driver told me about this place on my way home the other night. A 24hour diner on 18th and Western.Surely, he was joking.I've been in this area 2 years and haven't known anything to stay open past 10pm. So I walk over and there it is...like a beacon of hope. Don's.I had the 2 x 4 (2 pancakes, 2 eggs, 2 links, 2 bacon) for about $6. This really seems like the first meal you should order in a place like this. Although in other diners in the same arena, I've had the same meal for like $4. I will admit that the others rarely have tasted as good as my food at Don's. There was a guy at the end of the bar who just kept telling his girlfriend, "Look at how fluffy those pancakes are!!! And look at the links!!". Serious business.The place so tiny and out of the way. I felt like I was in a 90's indie movie. I was waiting for Christina Ricci to come out of the kitchen and take my order. The actual waitress was even better - so sweet and attentive and she knew how to HUSSLE. It was only her working with myself and 4 other customers. She took my order, cooked the food and had it on the table before I could even log on to check my Facebook! Mad Skillz lady.So yeah, now I don't have to spend my 3am drunken stupors eating at home alone. Yay!
Clean, delicious, cheap and fast. This is a total throw back that always delivers. Love it.

Terrible Service, with poor Maintenance if any inside. I was first thrilled since it came up right around the area I was visiting but once inside it was my friend and I at the bar and only two other parties at the very end. It was no excuse for the horrible service we received. A late server, cold pancakes, no sides, no refills and food on an dirty plate.

This seems like an authentic-feel of a diner that serves great bacon cheeseburgers with freshly fried fries.  Yum.  The patty is quite juicy and the bacon is fried perfectly. Service is quick, efficient, and quite friendly.  I love sitting at the counter.  There is a lot available, and this place is a few minutes off of the Eisenhower.  Great place to check out.  I can't wait to come back to try their breakfast items as well.  Prices are awesome - two burger meals with an RC costs us about $15.  Wowzers!+bacon cheeseburgers+cute diner

The BEST ham in town! I ordered the ham, eggs, & hash brown breakfast and it was delicious. It's a nice neighborhood diner and the staff is always nice. They acknowledge their regular customers & even though I just moved here about 2 months ago, they know what I want to order. Come check it out, good food, inexpensive, and friendly staff.

One of my favorite places for a late night meal. The waitresses are kind and super friendly.  I love the ham off the bone and the burgers are pretty good to. This place is great after a long night out since they are open 24 hours a day. My only complaint would be seating, it can get packed sometimes and in that case you would have to wait to get a seat.

Don's Diner is fantastic, out of the way, no lines or tourists here. All the fare is traditional diner choices. I had a double cheesburger with bacon and fries both amazing a fresh at prices that will please the frugal eaterEggs anyway you want em, perfect hash browns, bacon sausage toast, biscuits and gravy  and lots lots more! Great Place!
Great prices.  Bigger pancakes please, with tons of butter spread, is my only complaint. The steaks are tasty and affordable!

For a home style grill with great prices and a place where normal people go, this is the place. Nothing fancy about the food except that it's good. I was actually surprised by the waitress. I ordered a large milk with my breakfast and I thought I was going to get one of those small plastic cups that a lot of grills call a large when they're really small.  I actually got a large Styrofoam cup that I was able to drink till I was happy. It may not have the best decor or be in a ritzy neighborhood, but if you want something real stop in @ Don's.  You'll leave satisfied knowing that your food was good and that you paid a fair price.

Working overnights at a hospital can be rough-especially when you don't have time to pack a lunch. There's only so much McGreasy you can eat, but with Don's Grill in the area, I always have a unique haven I can escape to on my lunch break! This is a classic Edward Hopper-esque diner. The only seats are at the counter around the short order cook's work station, nearly everything is made from scratch before your very eyes, and the people watching is fantastic-especially on weekend nights. It's open 24/7 and you can order for pick-up if you are short on time. Plus the food is artery-clogging delicious. Highly recommended!!

Don's is one of my favorite restaurants in all of Chicago. Great Service, friendly staff, 24 hours.Most items are between 4-8 bucks. I usually get the "All the way" omelette. Comes with a heaping side of hashbrowns and toast. Add a large orange juice, and the total is always under 10 bucks I love going out to breakfast, and this is a great place to go if you want great dine-in restaurant quality on the fly. I usually struggle to finish everything...but when I do, I feel accomplished.You can't go wrong here, folks.
Pretty sure I got food poisoning here.
This is one of those great diners where your food looks exactly like the pictures on the menu, and the pictures on the menu aren't very pretty.  It's good cheap diner food, and the people are nice.

If not one of the best places to get grits with cheese, but call your order in for quicker service. You can get the old school foods of way back when, there is a door to the left that used to hold a slot machine way back when. It was illegal back than so they hid it. Wonderful stories to be told and just a great Road 66 kind of joint and food made right in front of you.

Came here last weekend for the PR Fest.After Betty's Blue Star Lounge we came here.  I wasn't hungry myself; they had some breakfast food and I had coffee w/ cream and sugar.Damn good coffee though; perhaps next time I'm in the area I'll try one of those burgers and fries to go with my shake...

classic stool and counter diner with the quintessential friendly cook that serves fast food with a story or conversation. clean, quick, delicious and cheap! white palace is popular, why? we love Don's!suggestion for the mega large French Toast  or the cheeseburgers :)

MAN!  you ever get drunk and you're friends are hungry and you just wanna go to sleep, but the group you're hanging out with keeps on bugging you and you can't really do anything about it, so then you have to submit  to their wishes and go to a restaurant?WELLLLL!  NEXT TIME you go to some lame warehouse party on the south side, everyone is still up from too much coke and you've already done the after after party, and you are nearby Don's, Stop by!  It's not the morning, but you can pretend.It's greasy but you like it. ^_^

He asked me how they liked their bacon cooked.ReallyThat alone would have guaranteed 4 stars.  An omelette of bacon (cooked to my liking) sausage, and grilled ham of the bone sealed star 5.This place is all counter, almost all breakfast, but all top notch.He asked me how I liked my bacon cooked.Yep

This place is great. Went in and was immediately impressed by how clean the place is. We were the only people in there and the server was great and friendly, food was delicious and all ingredients fresh.Can't wait to go back.

I may or may not be biased because I am a regular of about three years at the diner.  Everyone knows that this is 'The Diner,' the one place to go.Anyway, this place has yet to disappoint.  A diner, where you come sit at the counter (because there are not tables) and they cook your food right there in front of you on the flat grill? Awesome.  And the service is always to-boot. And I can say always because I have been probably each and every hour of the clock (That's right - they're open 24x7).  The three standard waitresses are all lovely, and the guys that work later in the day and the night shift are awesome too.The food is delicious.  All very simple breakfast food, cheeseburgers, ect.  I generally cannot steer away from the corned-beef hash; its so wonderful! The pancakes are yummy, bacon is always hot and crispy, and just went in for a burger with fries today.  If you go to either of the three McDonald's in the area you're a fool, because Don's sells a much better burger and fries, and for cheaper!!!Whether you're coming in from the bars, want a quick, hot breakfast before work, or have the taste for a mid-afternoon burger and fries, Don's is definitely the place to go if you're in the area. Heck, if you're in the city, because other diners just don't compare, this one is even clean! and I mean CLEAN. Pure happiness.

It's a shame it's hard to find a OK breakfast spot that not over$8.00.Dont judge me I'm far from cheap.I just don't think breakfast should cost that much.I get the sausage links with 2 eggs and hash browns and two pieces of  toast.And it's under $8.And the food is good.And if you order bacon they really cook it.I'm not a big fan of the service.The tall waitress show favoritism or special attention  to people of the Latin descent.The short waitress is ok.The owner I met a few times is a nice guy.

To those that reviewed this place as good, you must of been intoxicated or drugged up to eat here. We sat there for 10min. before anyone acknowledged us. There we only 3 other customers there. Got to see the cook throw out the garbage and not wash his hands. Finally after 20min and not even a glass of water we just walked out.

This is a great spot especially after the club! It's open 24/7. It's not crowded like hollywood plus the food tastes fresher and better!Typical diner fare. Everything tastes pretty good and they're quick!There is usually one waitress and one cook but late at night they usually have two waitresses.I love the cheeseburgers! Yum!This is truly a hole in the wall place that I'm sure you have driven by a thousand times. There is one counter with stools so space can be limited.Watch out for the creepy trucker guys during the day. I think those guys haven't seen women in a looooong time! lol

This is my favorite diner in Chicago.It has an old school long counter filled with old men on spinny cracked-vinyl stools.It smells like a diner should - of fresh grease and fresh coffee.The staff is colorful and hilarious.The food is perfect greasy spoon goodness.I recommend.....everything. In fact, I'm going to go and get some pancakes right now.

This is just one of those joints in South Chicago that lures you in...I mean counter only service...regulars walk in ordering what they want before even sitting down...everyone is super nice...a total melting pot and great breakfast food...

YUMMY!!!! Where do I begin??? The breakfast sandwich is plenty scrumptous with a side of coffee. If you are a night owl like me and with a place that never closes the pancake stack served with ham off the bone is sure to hit the spot. The establishment is old fashion trucker stop with the spinning stools to sit on. You can watch your food cooked right before your eyes since the kitchen is right in front of you. Did I mention super fast service too!

Great Food, Excellent Burgers and Late At Nite Grits are available.Chocolate Shakes, also good are the biscuits and gravy, and of the Ham Off The Bone is really good.Always someone in the grill, Police Officers, CTA, Folks working on the railroad, and neighborhood folks like me.Recommend putting ketchup on your fries or food if your order it to go, the ketchup is even extra good @ Don's ,The food is pricey, plan on paying about 7-9.00 for a Cheeseburger, Fries  Coke or Shake,  worth the price and Don's Grill are worth keeping around... Better than McDonno's or Booger KingOGC Pilsen

You're the man, Don!  Every time I go to this place I get the same 2 things: great service and a great price.   I have yet to get one thing on the menu that doesn't hit the spot.  The staff is always very friendly and easy to talk to while you're waiting for your food (which is never more than 8-9 minutes).  Convenient for West Pilsen folk as there aren't a whole lot of other 24-hour options around. They've got  yummy milkshakes for dessert.  One downside, it's entirely counter seating so it's not a great place to bring a group.   Another bonus: they serve breakfast all day.  All in all, a great little diner.

The diner food here is good.  The sign is cool.  But my favorite part?  The plywood box they built around the video poker machine (after they got busted for paying out)!  If it's still there, you'll see it on the right by the entrance.  If you're an "insider" I imagine they'll let you into the plywood box and you can gamble away your social security check!

this place is the greatest. its open 24/7 and the waittress is a real number. she looks like grumpy and sometimes she wears a grumpy hat for added affect. the food is super cheap. typical diner shit. really good breakfast. after the bar this is one of the greatest places to go it doesnt have the kitsch of hollywood grill or the old/new white palace.originally the sign was supposed to say dons hamburgers but somebody spelled it wrong and dons humburgers it stayed! watch out for the gang bangers they like to eat late too! ha they wont bother you though. the short order cook is a magician w timing!

This place is definitely a throw back in time! It's one of those trucker's diners that just has a counter around the grill and one cook and one waitress. It's usually a show watching them work...especially the cook, they are such whizzes at the grill. Good food and people watching at this joint. They are open 24/7 so if you happen to be passing through you can just pull up into their parking lot and have some good ham on the bone or pancakes, or greasy cheeseburgers...or oooh their fries. Good eats!
Went for our anniversary... We were not disappointed. Especially dessert!Cocktails fun and fresh.Food to die for. Get the item with the pork belly in it. I'm still dreaming of it...

I ordered the whole deep fried snapper and I'm glad I told the server not to debone my fish, because it was so fresh that I ate the head and cheeks. This chef clearly understands seafood.The prawns were the best I've ever had. They were huge and in a rich, spicy sauce. The sauce seemed like a reduction of lobster or prawns. It was one of the best sauces I've ever encountered. After eating their sweet, meaty bodies, I ate their heads and eyeballs. It was divine!This chef is clearly a genius. I highly recommend this restaurant.

We went here for dinner on a Wednesday night and had a 6pm reservation.  Celebrating a birthday.  Very cool vibe.  Excellent service from start to finish.  The food was exactly as described by our waiter and very good.  The atmosphere of this place is really cool.  Not too loud to have a conversation but not so quiet you have a feeling that you're being overheard.  And they've got candles on tables.  It was a birthday celebration, and for desert they brought out something delicious with the birthday candle too.I was impressed and we will be back.

Superb service at a sexy little Latin spot. ;)My friend and I started our evening at the bar while we waited for our table to be ready. I ordered the "The Crying Game", a potent and manly cocktail from their Bebidas menu. It was served on the rocks and made with overproof rum, 2 other kinds of rum and bitters - with no true "mixer" it's strong. Perfection.Once seated, we started with pan de queijo (cheese bread) - don't think of typical American cheesy bread from Dominos. It's more like a warm pillow of baked dough filled with a soft gooey cheese. Next, we ordered the garlic frites - crispy fries topped with a generous amount of herbs and salt and served with some bomb aoili! We also ordered the coxinha, a smoked chicken croquette - it was pretty good, but not a standout. We weren't too hungry so we didn't get entrees, but we did get DESSERT! The panna cotta was so damn good! Such a complex dish and variety of flavors packed into one amazing dish.We loved the atmosphere here - the bartender that served us our drinks and our server were both amazing and attentive. The restaurant was dimly lit and quiet. It's a perfect date night spot - check it out.

Stopped in here for lunch one day... Its pretty close to my neighborhood.  Directly across the street from Swift & Sons.  It has an appealing decorum.  Tin plated ceilings, drop bear bold lights, old chemistry looking lab stools at the bar.  Very industrial looking.  The bar is made of reclaimed wood as well as some of the bar shelving.  The chairs are reminiscent of woodworking shop chairs.My server is John (who is fairly new here).  I start off with a Pisco Sour. A traditional Cocktail of Latin America.  It's made of Peruvian Pisco, Lemon, touch of sugar, foamy egg white, and Peruvian Bitters.  Despite the small amount of bitters used in cocktail recipes, they have a very definite effect on the flavor profile of a drink, helping to bring the ingredients together. Don't think that because of the name it will immediately make the drink bitter. In this cocktail, bitters works more like adding an herb to a sauce, it is an essential ingredient on any bar.Had the empanadas to start, super flaky and buttery crust, and the meat was tender and super flavorful.I had the Kale salad and added chicken and avocado.  I'm a bit of an avocado head, and could pretty much eat it with anything.  I just Haas to have it!  haha  The salad was very fresh tasting, with big chunks of avocado and chunks of very juicy chicken, thinly sliced radish.  The kales rough texture and slightly bitter taste are the perfect match for citrus notes and the cotija  cheese.The dessert was literally amazing!  I'm a bit of a critic when it comes to desserts (for those that know me and what I do for a living).... The Hibiscus Coconut Panna Cotta.  Topped with honey chamomile toasted meringue, Chartreuse caramel, blueberries, and pistachio.  Every element of the dessert went so perfectly together.  The ultimate in refreshing and not too heavy.  Two very enthusiastic thumbs up!

Nice and dark little gem. Stopped in for a drink and was not dissapointed, so I stayed for another. Love the bar concept. Only tried a few fries and the two types of empaniadas. I'm a meat eater but pick the vegetarian option, won't dissapoint (broccoli and cheese).Will have to come back here to try some food.

Ended up at La Sierna Clandestina one evening and ended up loving it.LOVED the Kale salad - if I lived near here, I'd do pickup just for that salad once a week.The Grilled Hangar steak was good - not great - but good.The chicken thighs were outstanding.The empanadas were just okay.The drinks we're flowing hard  - I'd recommend the cocktails that they make. Bikini Weather was the winner of the night for me.The service was really great. I loved the cozy atmosphere. I'll be back.

We finally got in on Friday and it was worth the wait.  If you can make your way in as a walk in early in the evening (6ish) the wait might not be too long.  Otherwise it is extremely difficult to make a reservation.  We tried to make a reservation for over a month- online and over the phone, and there was never an opening.The drinks are divine.  I had a Bikini weather and it was delicious- coconut, passion fruit, tequila.  Yum!  I had two because they were that good.The food is also delicious.It is a Portuguese tapas bar.  Small plates and dinner portions.  We tried the steak, the spicy cauliflower (OMG delicious!), the kale salad, chorizo empanada, and the Feijoada.  It was so good.  The cauliflower and the empanada were the winners.  Everything was delicious but those two were so tasty that I could have made a meal of the two.The service is also on point.  Even though it was so busy our server always made it a point to come and check in.I'll be back, let's just hope I can make a reservation.

I was super exited to try this place - it's around the corner from our place in the West Loop and I love a good empanada. Finally made it here for lunch:-We ordered the Goat meat empanada's.... was super excited to try it, except --- there was no goat meat in my empanada (**smh**). I pointed this out the manager, you could clearly see that the empanadas was stuffed with nothing but beans. She said "oh it's supposed to be a mixture" and walked away. How are you going to sell a Goat Meat empanada .... with no goat??? I'm speechless.-Fried cauliflower was legit -  definitely the highlight-Brazil bowl was again ... a bunch of beans and some rice/chimchurri.Next time I'll just cook myself 3 bowls of beans at home.

Wheeee hadn't been here in a while and it was awesome! We sat outside & watched the crazy neighborhood go by & it was a glorious, gorgeous evening. Our server whose name escapes me was awesome, super friendly & when I mentioned I was vegan she checked w/the kitchen and came back with a ton of options that could be accommodated.Fried Cauliflower w/hot sauce instead of aoili was super good. Also got the heirloom tomato/hearts of palm salad, and the 2 market veggie sides prepared vegan (collard greens & salt roasted beets w/serranos). Everything was great and per usual, the non-vegan diners at my table ate a good majority of my dishes as well :)I'm excited to go back!

This place has evolved and matured really nicely and I love coming here.  What was scorchingly hot and impossible to get into when it opened, has now become a lively, lovely neighborhood standby.  It is super comfortable and super tasty.My wife, daughter, and I came for dinner on Sunday evening and the place was humming but not overrun.  Service was attentive and excellent and the pace of the meal was leisurely and relaxed, as it should be on a warm summer evening.  Just perfect.Wine and cocktail service is outstanding, if not extensive.  My Caipirnha was terrific and not too sweet but with a good bite.  Too often this drink can be cloying if not handled well.Dinner was excellent. Kale salad was creamy but with enough heat from the jalapeno to stand up to it.  Grilled Asparagus were tender and delicious. Empanadas were good but sort of boring. The whole fresh fish was absolutely delicious with an array of flavors that seemed more Asian than South American.  It was snapper on our evening but I'd order it regardless of the day's fish.  Pork Milenesa was good but a little dry and the hanger steak was expertly cooked and delicious.This place has really matured and I love coming here for a more restrained, comfortable meal when I don't need to live on the edge with some hip newcomer.

I am a HUGE fan of La Sirena. It's a go-to lunch spot when I have colleagues in from out of town. My favorite thing to eat is the Kale salad, but the fried cauliflower is a close second! Service (especially at the bar) is always stellar.The only reason I haven't rated this 5 stars is due to the small protein size - chicken or shrimp is a *lot* extra and I only received three small shrimp the last time I ordered.I'd recommend making a lunch res or planning to sit at the bar during the week.

I was super excited to try this place based on the 4 star reviews and we wanted to try something more intimate. We were able to get last minute open table reservations on Saturday night for 2 at 7 PM. From the outside, I got even more excited because I thought it was so cute!Well as soon as we walked in we felt so awkward because the host was giving menus to people seated right next to the door but was also trying to greet us. Then the manager came by and instead of speaking to us, made it even more awkward by pointing out our reservation to the hostess and it was just an odd encounter. We got seated towards the back away from the window which was dark and a view of the chef standing by the kitchen.The server didn't come by us at all. The manager came to us after 10 minutes asking what we would like to drink. We ordered capirinhas. By the time we got our drinks we still had no server. The busboy came by and we ordered with him. We got the ceviche, empanadas, and flank steak. The busboy suggested we get the rice dish too so we did. 30 minutes went by, no one checked on us and we only got our ceviche. The ceviche was tasteless and very fishy smelling, which only makes me believe it was not fresh. We were starving at this point so getting hangry. 15 minutes later they brought us 2 empanadas, which we described as hot pockets.Still no server by the way. Maybe we got no service because we didn't look bothered or annoyed at all. We were talking and laughing, enjoying our time together but it was annoying with no food and no service. With no service and first 2 dishes being awful and so were our juiced up drinks we decided to let the manager know to please cancel the steak and rice, give us our check for what we had as we would like to go. She insisted that our dishes were coming out but we were over it. She asked if we would like to take it to go anyways at no charge. We paid for our drinks, the ceviche, and empanadas came out to $48. We were there exactly one hour and had only our 2 appetizers without service. We tried the steak and rice and thank Goodness we left. Ended up giving throwing it out unfortunately because the steak was medium rare but tasted like chewing gum. The rice was probably the best tasting dish we had out of the four but nothing to ride home about or give a second chance. It was just mushy yellow rice. Overall everyone should save their money and time. There's plenty other amazing and delicious restaurants around...like next door! ;)
Sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo delicious. Loved the skewers, had all 3 or 4...had some South American sparkling and juicy saladWill return for dinner

the restaurant is situated in fulton market across the street from Aviary, there are a few nearby factory looking buildings, does not look as busy as the Randolph street stretch of the west loop, but it looks like it is definitely up and comingthe food is awesome, we ordered the kale salad to start with, the portion is huge, enough to make a petite girl full. the flavour is also greatwe ordered the moqueca (the clam and shrimp stew) and the hanger steak. really liked the aroma of moqueca and the soup base, we asked for an additional bowl of rice so that we can pour the soup onto of it to enjoy, it was deliciousthe hanger steak is tender inside while crisp outside, the chimichurri makes a good complement to the taste

Solid four stars. We had a group of five for dinner with reservations on Friday. Seated right away!Attentive waiter who had no problem pushing the caipirinhas on us - we happily obliged during our meal.As a table of mostly eaters and all sharers we went family style on this meal. 24 ounce steak special, the bowl of pork belly, beans and rice goodness, both types of empanadas, ceviche, polenta and then the dessert (that ended up being the strange low point) - our savory dishes were all incredibly tasty and filling though. We all enjoyed them and that's saying a lot with this group.I wanna go back now for these dishes - they're yummy!

Hm, I had really anticipated this Brazilian steakhouse to be impeccable given its location surrounded by Next, Roister, Swift & Sons and The Office. However, the price point is overshooting their quality of food. The grilled hanger steak was too tough-- very hard to chew through tendons. $32 for a tiny slab of steak, I expected higher quality

If I could give La Sirena another star, I would! I had a private party here for 25 people which took months of planning. I worked with Nicole at La Sirena and she was SO incredibly helpful every step of the way. She genuinely cared that the party was perfect and did everything in her power to make sure of it. Really, above and beyond. Christian, another La Sirena staffer provided special flowers per my request and they were beautiful. Every person raved about how beautiful and tasty this place was. The food is phenomenal, the decor is lovely, the staff is amazing! I highly, highly recommend it as a space for a private party, but if not, definitely head in for lunch or dinner to taste their delicious food!!

I came in to La Sirena Clandestina for dinner yesterday evening (Thursday) with my boyfriend and his parents. We recently returned from a trip to South America and wanted to try Chicago's version. It was pretty darn good, and I love how creative their menu is!La Sirena Clandestina is located on Fulton Market in the West Loop. The restaurant itself is small and intimate with a bar in the front and high ceilings. Atmosphere is rustic chic. Unfortunately they have a metal ceiling, making acoustics a bit poor. Sound control could have been better, and we were speaking loudly for the first half of our meal until the crowd thinned.We each started with a cocktail. Their pisco sour is to die for. I could drink this all night every night. For dinner, we decided to share all our dishes as a table and we started out with the kale salad. It's a basic salad but the dressing is delicious. Portion size was very generous and there was plenty for the four of us. Afterward, we each ordered an empanada. The flavors of the evening were sweat potato and black bean. I loved the sweet potato, while other members of our group preferred the black bean. We also ordered the cheesy bread. These are really just a small bite each (an order came with 4, one-bite size bread balls), but a nice taste nonetheless.For main courses, we tried the tuna steak, hanger steak, pork shoulder, and the moqueca. We also ordered a side of rice and beans. All the entrees were fantastic. I particularly enjoyed the moqueca, which was a rice and seafood stew with head on praws and clams. The seafood was extremely fresh and portion size was again, very generous. The tuna was served tartare and melted in your mouth. Finally, the pork shoulder was extremely tender and served with some delicious potatoes and greens to top it off. If coming with a group, do keep in mind that portions are quite generous, and you don't necessarily need an entree / person.We finished up with alfajores, and these were delicious. A little different than the ones we had in South America in that the cookies were much thinner. Our experience here was great. I appreciate their menu having lots of different choices and items. I would knock a star based on the fact that I think they use a bit more salt than I prefer, and because of the acoustics. I would definitely return, especially for a Pisco Sour!

In 2016 I want to frequent restaurants within walking distance from my house more often. La Sirena is gonna be one of those restaurants I put at the top of my list while considering diff restaurants for dinner this year. You walk in, it's dimly lit and it's clear, by the smiles on the server/hostess' face that the folks who work here are passionate about making sure you have a delightful night.La Sirena has never failed. I first wanted to check this place out because I heard it was designed by local Chicago artist, Brian Willette. As a big fan of his work, I was hoping the food would be as good as Brian's art. And boyyy it sure is.  I've had some truly terrific and innovative dishes here at La Sirena. Some of my faves include the sword fish ceviche, braised rabbit empanada and duck heart confit. Truly all of which had stand-out flavors and an interesting rather unique twist on Latin cuisine.Yes La Sirena yes!I suggest bringing some cash so you can valet because it definitely is hard to park in the ever-growing Fulton Market District. Please don't be alarmed if there's a wait for dinner, it's very worth it!

Absolutely fell in love with La Sirena Clandestina the minute I took a bite of the kale salad at the Chicago Food and Wine Festival this summer.I made a promise to myself I would get to the restaurant and try more dishes.I can't believe this gem tucked away on Fulton street never crossed my mind and I'm so glad it is so close by!!Fortunate for them and unfortunate for me that they are across from the new Google building and will always be booked solid for a reservation.I had the kale salad with roasted poblano dressing, cotija, pepitas, jalapeño.  The poblano dressing added the perfect kick.  We also tried the beets and burrata which was good but I would have preferred the beets with goat cheese to add a little bit of a bite.  Of course we couldn't leave without trying the baked empenadas.  I had the roasted squash and a broccoli mac n cheese.  Both were unique and delicious.  Although stuffed, our curiosity got the best of us and we had dessert as well.  I couldn't resist the temptation to try the apple cider donuts with the rum glaze and squash mousse.  The mousse was amazing but the donut was dry and lacked the flavor I was looking for.Overall, this is a wonderful restaurant and I can not wait until they open their second concept this coming year!

Very cute place! Dining room is tiny, so we had to sit at the bar without a reservation, but the bartender took great care of us. I started with the oaxacan discoteca, which almost tastes like a traditional Chinese sweet drink (sweet plum juice), loved it! Bf had the pisco sour and peruvian ambassador, the latter of which was one stiff drink. Both were delicious though.We ordered a ceviche, hangar steak and moqueca. While the flavors were excellent, I thought they were a tad stingy with seafood in their ceviche. The moqueca, however, was piled high with delicious shrimps & shellfish. The steak was good but over-salted. Also wished it came with some veggies on the side, especially given the price of the dish (hangar steak is supposed to be budget cut!).I liked the food & drinks enough to go back, but given the prices this is a special occasions place, not for neighborhood weeknight dinners.

Fresh food, consistent service all delivered within a cozy atmosphere. When you visit don't hesitate to step out of your comfort zone and try something new! I can't wait to return for the tastes not readily available via other establishments.

Went to La Sirena for a work dinner 7 people.  Had a reservation and was seated right away.  The ambience is fun rustic decor.  The ceiling is metal so the acoustics are not the best.  The place was full so lots of conversations.The wine list and drink list has great choices and is reasonably priced.  The piso sour is excellent.  The servers knowledge of the menu is amazing, helpful server and very attentive.The kitchen aroma is wonderful.  The dining room is small and you could smell the creations coming from the kitchen.  We started with empanadas chicken and veggie, which were amazing.  The kale salad with jalapeños pleased everyone with a little zing.  The feijoada platter had short ribs, pork belly, sausage, rice and beans-very very good!  Food was tender and very flavorful.This was my second visit and very consistent.

Love me some South American... A Brazilian friend had mentioned this place a while back and I'm glad she did...- Started off with some pao that were cheesy goodness, but were slightly denser than I've had in the past.- I had the moqueca that was a nice spin on the original with cilantro risotto instead of the typical rice.  The coconut milk broth and seafood (red snapper, mussels, shrimp) were delish and had me wanting more- friend had the spring lamb which came 2 ways, sliced sirloin and shredded "lamb cake"... The sirloin was slightly over cooked (needed more pink) but the overall flavor was good- garlic fries came with a spicy mayo based dipping sauce... They definitely weren't stingy with the garlicOverall it was very good, although a little on the pricey side, would definitely return again

La Sirena Clandestina was wonderful. It was a last minute decision to go and SeatMe from Yelp made it super easy to make a reservation. We were seated right away and given menus. I had the Moqueca - the seafood stew - and my friend had the Chicken and sausage. Both were excellent. The seafood stew was bursting with flavors and the seafood was very fresh. It was also a very filling dish. I could barely finish it all. We started with the empanadas as an appetizer. The dough was quite delicate and flaky and the fillings were delicious. We had the french onion and the jambalaya.The restaurant is small and cozy. Loved a lot of the upcycle elements used as part of the decor. I've read about La Sirena on TastingTable and am happy I got a chance to try it.

This is an exceptional lunch place (because the sandwiches are so spectacular) and a great dinner place.  The fried cauliflower is melt in your mouth delicious and very lemony, and a must have off the menu.  The empanadas change on a regular basis and are excellent.  The alfajaodos at $2/each are delicious and a bargain (the Brazilian cheesecake and the non-traditional rendition of tres leches are also well worth getting).  Very interesting food, and a great dining option in a great food town.

Special spot, a notch above the other restaurants in the over saturated Chicago restaurant scene. Most importantly, the food was outstanding! The atmosphere was sophisticated and cool, vintage with a funky urban twist. I would have definitely given five stars, yet the pricing was slightly on the pretentious side. That being said....this location is the hottest restaurant scene in Chicago, so I expected the prices I paid. Ultimately, it was worth it. I had a great time. It was relaxed, it was cool and the food was top notch. I'll be back and if I have the same experience next time, they'll get that 5th star!

This place is very good and might be the best in the neighborhood at its price point. I came here on a Tuesday night at around 9:30 and a Thursday night at around the same time. A lot of the stuff they have is tapas sized. The chicken hearts, empanadas, and cauliflower were ridiculously good. My fiance got a good mixed drink, and they have some good wines by the glass. The desserts are also awesome.

Today this is my favorite Latin fusion in the city. Well done! The reviewers who rave about their Kale Salad are right, it's fantastic. However I was even more impressed with Moqueca sort of a cross between Thai green curry and Bouillabaisse ( outstanding!!! ) and their Short Ribs were out of this world (i don't recommend sharing) Of course these are just highlights! We shared many items as a group of 4 and there wasn't anything short of simply delicious served!The place is very cozy, has a dark rustic feel with a waitstaff who cares. They have a very interesting wine list. Our amazing waiter who's name escapes me (he was a tall dude in a black shirt with giant glittery wings on the back)  knew his wine and his suggestions were excellent. I loved one of the bottles so much I found it online later and I was pleasantly surprised that $60 bottle is only marked up to $80!If you want fantastic Latin fusion in a laid back trendy atmosphere - make your reservation

The food would get three stars but the service was so lousy that I would give it a one star rating.After waiting fifteen minutes for the server to take our dessert order and being ignored by other waiters and after being told by the hostess that the server was the only one who could take our order....I went to the bar and got my check.

Wow. Came here for Valentines night dinner and was very very impressed. Food was a little saltier than expected, but didn't take away from the delicious flavors. Was very impressed with the steak and chimmichurri dish - SUPERB. Asked for a medium steak and got something a little more on the rare side, but the flavors and quality made up for this entirely. I LOVED this meal.  The chicken dish was equally great in its own way, still salty, but chicken cooked to perfection.Atmosphere: 5 starsBathrooms: 5+ starsFood: 5 stars

Easy reservation on a Monday evening - plus. $60 dinner with essentially 4 appetizers and no drinks - minus. Biggest disappointment was the spring lamb. Although the preparation was perfect (especially the terrine part), we expected a lamb entree and pretty much got an appetizer. There must have been 5-6 small cubes of lamb, which for $20 makes sense, but either raise the price and offer a satisfying portion or specify that it is a small dish.Delicious lamb curry empanada, great flavor on the elotes (served on the cob).Loved the ceviche, but you can't really tell the difference between the squid, shrimp, and mahi.We'll give it another try in the winter, when the heavier dishes will be more enticing.

Food was nothing special.Server was a hipster who needed to adjust the attitude and learn the menu. Wines weren't exciting but it's probably not a wine place. Had a few good beers. Cocktails looked ok.Issue is, with this many new restaurants coming, and already existing, this place is nothing special.Service is definitely an issue. Attitude and slow will get you nowhere.

My pastry chef-in-training daughter was in from out of town for the holidays. She and I were walk-ins Saturday night early - around 5:25 p.m. The small dining area was almost empty and the bar was entirely so. Paige was our server and she was attentive and gracious at all times.We split three dishes, starting with the kale salad which is huge but not too filling. Since my daughter is a pescatarian and a "spice wimp," they agreed to put the jalapeño peppers on the side of the salad. Its fresh cotija cheese was a tasty counterpoint to the kale. The poblano dressing was not very spicy.Next was the ceviche with toasted pepitas and a kind of creamy green dressing that set it apart nicely from the typical lime juice ceviches you'd get on a warm beach somewhere. It comes with what the menu calls house made saltines that are actually more like large pieces of flat bread papadams. This was a great combo and disappeared quickly.Paige checked with the chef to make sure they could make the grouper entree without the morcillo (which I suspected and we confirmed was blood sausage.) It didn't need it, as it was served over a bed of white beans and maple glazed sweet potato purée. Small portion but delicious, all the same. We couldn't leave without trying one of their famed empanadas - this one with cream of mushroom filling. The crust was flaky but the filling was unremarkable - the only let down if the night.Several times during our meal, Maria (who seemed to be the manager) came over to check on how we were doing. When we told her about my daughter's profession, she spoke with us at length about other places to try in the neighborhood, spots with good deserts and breads and went out of her way to be helpful, supportive and informative.When we were about to pay the bill, Maria sent over two comped deserts: a shortbread cookie with dulce de leche and a flourless chocolate cake with fresh mascarpone and a gooey, delicious ganache. Try to save room for these. You won't regret it.As we were leaving, the place was filling up and getting quite loud, so it could definitely be "conversation-challenged." That said, kudos to everyone at LSC. Thanks for a great night of dining!

I absolutely love this place.  Amazing Pisco Sours which they will customize with the fresh puree they have on hand for the day.As a lover of the green leafy kind of food, I must say the Kale Salad is to die for.  The daily empanadas are a must as the offer both a vegetarian option as well as a meat (I usually opt for one of each as I can't decide).I love their Open Faced Gravlax, as it is a lunch time spin on a favorite breakfast item.  The salmon is fresh and thinly sliced.  I loved the avocado touch and of course I opt for the side of homemade chips.....too amazing!The staff is always so friendly and helpful and I can't wait to return!

Not one thing to complain about. Great service, great food, great vibe.  Is it a little overpriced, sure.  But they give you what you pay for. My only hope/suggestion for the future is they add a few more choices, particularly in entrees.  Other than that, we will be back

The restaurant itself is at the corner of an intersection, and parking was horrible! We were able to find free parking off Lake St, for those with cars. The wait time was short, given that we went for lunch. The menu is concise, which worried me as I am a picky eater. However, I got the Brazilian Beef Sanduich and it was DELICIOUS! It is spicy, and the garlic frites are also very flavorful. It was a very filling lunch, and would recommend it to anyone interested in trying out the menu.

My family and I had dinner here for my mother's birthday.The food was great! We had the kale salad, the empanadas of the day, the flank steak, the rice and beans, and the rabbit, all of which were great.Not only was the service quick but it felt very communal in terms of how we were taken care of.  Everyone at La Sirena is attentive of their guests.Our server, Daniella was so nice! After mentioning y upcoming trip to Japan, she went out of her way to print out a list of things to do and see that her friend forwarded her. How awesome!Overall, La Sirena provided a great dining experience with great service. The food was on point and I will certainly go back.

The food was fantastic. We had the hanger steak and la bomba rice. Definitely recommend both. Almost better than the food were to cocktails though. We were very satisfied with our meal. Looking forward to coming back soon.

Came in on a Saturday night for a reservation for 10 people celebrating a birthday dinner at 8:15 pm. We were greeted by friendly hosts in this romantic, chatty atmosphere, dark lit, smaller restaurant in the West Loop on Randolph.We were seated on connecting tables on the beautiful dark wood and comfortable dining chairs and booth.The Good:-Drinks are fantastic. I ordered a daiquiri with the seasonal fresh fruit of green apple. It was not a slush, but it was perfectly strong and sweet.-The chicken was flavored fantastically. The outer crust had a char, and it was tender, over chimichurri sauce. The portion is perfect for one person. I decided to split it but didn't need too.The Bad:SERVICE IS VERY SLOW: I understand the meaning of a busy kichen on a weekend night and how group dinners can be challenging to serve warm all at once, but 20 minutes for the appetizers and 30 minutes for the entrees. It was a bit ridiculous. No apologies for wait time or complimentary appetizers for the wait.OUR WAITER:-We asked our waiter to take a group picture. It was 9 ladies, the birthday girl brought her boyfriend. One of our friends asked our waiter if he can also take a group picture using her phone. He made a sarcastic comment saying 'He will text it to you.'-My friend asked for a 'Kale Salad' and he repeated back 'Pear Salad' but my friend hadn't heard it. He came back with a pear salad but there was no pear salad on the menu. That whole thing was weird. He should have mentioned there is no pear salad on the menu. But he 'covered' the pear salad.-He brought out plates for everyone for the birthday girls surprise birthday dessert when we didn't order any dessert or look at a dessert menu. It ruined her birthday surprise.OVERALL: It's sad that not many restaurants have a Brazilian and south american cuisine and this one does. I feel bad for the Chef, really. But the restaurant does stay busy. If you like a drink- come here, it's perfect to sit at the bar and share a dish but I wouldn't schedule a group dinner or come here on a weekend night. I strive for service, and Randolph street is competitive enough with wonderful restaurants so I would just skip it.

This is an absolute gem of a restaurant!  Came here with family based on a colleagues recommendation and was definitely not disappointed!Shared a number of dishes, but was completely blown away by the whole fried fish (yellow tail was the fish of the day) topped with peanuts, cilantro and a serrano hot sauce.  I had never tasted anything like it.  The fish had a crusty exterior, due to the frying, but underneath the crust the meat was tender and flaky, full of flavor.  Definitely a must get dish!We also shared the brussel sprout side with bacon and onions.  Awesome!  My family and I love brussel sprouts and these were amazing.  Crispy on the outside, yet tender when bitten into.  The bacon added a smokiness and complexity to the dish.  We also shared the gala apple and fennel salad.  The salad had shaved golden beets with apples and tossed with a mustard vinaigrette that paired nicely with the blue cheese crumbles.  A nice light side.Of course we had to try the garlic frites, as so many people had raved about them!  They were great.  The fries had a wonderful garlic bite and paired nicely with a  delicious dipping aioli.Empanadas were fantastic as well.  We tried both the veggie and the meat.  The meat had pork belly, bacon, and potato, which was my favorite.The one dish that was lacking and thus the four stars, was the grilled octopus.  I have had octopus a number of times and very much enjoy it, if cooked properly.  This was overcooked.  Tough and rubbery and under seasoned.  The acorn squash romesco that accompanied it was fabulous!  Just wish the octopus had been seasoned and cooked properly.To end the night we all had a bite of the Tres Leches with cashew brittle.  This was absolutely decadent!  It tasted like a bread pudding, soaked in tres leeches and bits of cashew brittle between the layers.  It was light, yet sweet and salty.  I loved how the brittle added crunch to the texture of the dessert and the flavor combinations.Service was spot on and loved the cozy, intimate atmosphere.  A little loud for talking with a large group, but so fun!  Highly recommend!

The rating is based on the overall experience. I loved the food but can't say the same about the service. Everything we ordered was really good. Loved the Kale salad & the goat cheese plate .Our server was a no show for most of our meal time....she explained the menu & took the appetizers order but we couldn't find her after that.

Nice place.  Had a group of 5 with us.  Pretty nice atmosphere and ambience.Wasn't too impressed with beer and wine selection.  Too limited based on trying to keep with the Latin American theme.  I've had Palma Luca beer before but the one they gave me tasted like glue.Empanadas were solid but not outstanding.  I had churassaco which was good but was served Ala carte.  Usually this dish is served with roasted potatoes or something so it was a bit skimpy.  My wife seemed to enjoy her seafood dish.Service was solid - attentive and they brought my wife a small dessert.Overall can't quite go outstanding but it was overall a  very good experience.

We had a business meeting at the Sand Box down the block from this restaurant and walked by on our way to the meeting.  We were intrigued by the name and looks of the place and decided after our meeting that we would try it out - - - what a great experience!!La Sirena Clandestina is a Brazilian inspired culinary delight - - very affordable and amazing dishes and drinks.  We had the Kale Salad...out of this world....  the 3 cheese grilled cheese sandwich and the tomato soup with a base of coconut milk; rich and silky!!For dessert we had the Alfajores, South American sandwich cookies filled with delectable dulce de leche - - amazingly delicious!The staff was friendly and attentive; not overly so but there when we needed them with a smile!!Amazing experience - - we will definitely be back!

We stopped in here for cocktails and empanadas one afternoon. The atmosphere is lovely. Service was ok. The empanadas were pricey. The garlic fries were unreal. The cocktails were tasty. I can't see myself going back when there are so many other wonderful sports in the same neighborhood though.

Cute place, great for girls nights or romantic dates.  I was a little disappointed by the Pisco Sour, sorry to say.  Tanta makes a much better one.   The food overall was good, nothing too amazing.  I would say to try the empanada's but honestly don't remember much else being stellar.The place is definitely a hidden gem and that adds to the ambiance.  It's a cool place to grab drinks but not sure if I would go to have dinner again since the food really wasn't much to rave about.

I'm still trying to figure out what hype is with this place... The best thing that I could tell you is that the venue and the ambience here are pretty fabulous. That being said I can think of about three or four other places that are similar that have a much better value... And I really do not mind spending money on food and drink but like other "must go to" Chicago spots, this one falls flat.

Up front, I've only been here for lunch, but am looking forward to going for dinner one day.With that out of the way... I work in the area and have made this small gem a favorite - especially on a cold day. I am particularly fond of their black bean soup. On a cold day, a bowl of that is the perfect way to warm up and keep yourself going the rest of the day. It does have some heat to it (the type of heat you feel not taste) so if that scares you, you might want to only do a cup or at least ask for extra crema. But if you like beans this soup (and the homemade crackers it comes with) is not to be missed.I've also tried the empanadas, which were great; the cuban and the brazilian beef, which were both tasty but the type of sandwich you need a nap after. Also, I've not tried them yet, but I've heard the Alfajores (a type of cookie) will knock your socks off.The service here has always been attentive and friendly, especially at the bar, and their out door tables are nice for a beer on a hot day.All in all a solid spot that you keep wanting to go back to.
SolidFrom start to finish they were good. Service, cocktails and setting were all top notch.  I deduct a star for value, but that may just bee because I'm cheap...ahem.... I mean frugal.

I was a little disappointed in my visit here this past weekend.  I had read rave reviews about their empanadas and amazing brunch but I was less than impressed.  I started off with a drink, their setenta y cinco, (not sure why it's named 75....) which turned out to be a pretty strong drink and I wasn't the biggest fan.  My dining companion, K, opted to stick to water since he was still recovering from the night before, what a rookie.  For my entree, I had the plantain chilaquiles and he had the steak and eggs.  We also split one breakfast empanada since I wanted to try their empanadas after hearing such good things.  Our food came out pretty quick since they weren't too busy.  My dish was decent but nothing really stood out.  For whatever reason I imagined the plantains to be the thick cut sweet ones, instead they came out more like plantain chips drenched in salsa verde and topped with an egg.  The flavors were there but texture-wise I didn't particularly like it.  As for the empanada, the crust was very flaky and you could barely taste bacon or anything in the filling.  I would say pass on the breakfast one, maybe the other empanadas they serve at dinner are better.  On the bright side, K enjoyed his steak and eggs but then again he's easier to please than I am (I promise I'm really not that difficult!).  I tried a bit of his flank steak and it was a bit chewy and should have been cooked less.  The service wasn't bad but it wasn't exceptional.  We had multiple people wait on our table throughout the night, one took our drink order, another our entrée order, and then the hostess brought me a takeout box at the end.  It was a bit strange but no complaints here.  What I can say I liked was the rustic décor of the restaurant and the lotion in the washroom as weird as that sounds.

Sunday night double date last week. My friends were in town visiting from Michigan, and we wanted to treat them to a nice meal out. All in all it was a lovely experience. I definitele would consider it better for a smaller group, as it was nice to eat family style.Our server was wonderful, friendly and available while still leaving us space to enjoy the meal.  Shared the ceviche, empanadas, tempura fried cauliflower, garlic frites, moqueca, and the off menu meat plate. The ceviche sauce was to die for, I wanted to lick the bowl clean. The empanadas were on the smaller side, but spot on flavor wise (my bf and I shared the "Cubano sandwhich" one). I like that the entrees are really built to share, and that the meat plate offered us a taste of all the meat dishes we were hankering to try anyway (hanger, sweetbreads, blood sausage, and a couple others). The fries serving was huge, which was fine by us with how tasty they were, but a little strange given it was a side item. Cocktails were lovely and I thought their wine selection went well with the food.Ended the night with table cookies they brought out and the flourless chocolate cake with espresso fudge and quince. Perfect end to a great meal. Definitely plan on going back and will recommend.
Ceviche, fried cauliflower, fried catch of the day, and fries were all outstanding.  Highly recommended when in the Fulton Market Neighborhood.  Not as busy as the other highly touted establishments.

You had me at empanada, then at baked, never fried, then at rotating selection daily.  In fact, it's the first item on the dinner menu, top left-hand corner.  The selection for that day was a sweet corn and pepper or a bacon with camelized onion and cheese.  My friend wanted to split them three ways...we ended up ordering one of each when my other friend and I gave her a death look.  Thank goodness since they were delightful puffy pockets of deliciousness.  My favorite of the two was the bacon.We decided to try the Crispy Amish Chicken Thighs and the Grilled Beef Short Ribs along with a side of the Pao de Queijo.  The thighs are apparently the best seller according to our server.  No wonder, there were perfectly cooked, juicy, with crispy skin and a (un)healthy, but definitely didn't mind seasoning of salt.  My friend is a salt fiend and she loved it.  The short ribs were good and the almonds added a spicy kick that complemented the pesto.  I was disappointed in the cheese bread.  They were hard round balls that were a little tough to chew.For dessert we split the Tre Leches and an order of the Alfajor shortbread cookies with dulce de leche filling.  Of the two, I enjoyed the Tre Leches more, it was interesting to see it served in a glass bowl more fitting for an ice cream sundae.  The cookies were not as good as the alfajor dessert at Tanta and the presentation was very simple without any added sauces or ice cream.  The shortbread was on the drier side.  It could have used some ummphDefinitely come for the empanadas, drinks, and cool ambiance.  There's limited outdoor seating, but a nice place to enjoy a quiet meal and watch people waiting to get into Aviary.

If I had a boyfriend, I would make him take me here. The space is cozy, intimate, and full of rustic charm (without looking like a pinterest board gone wrong). More importantly, the food is delicious and served in surprisingly large portions.  My friend and I split an order of empanadas, the pork loin, and garlic fries and were more than full by the end of the meal. Although as someone who has consumed a lot of them in their lifetime, the fries were probably the only underwhelming part of the dinner...but the delicious cocktails more than made up for them.

I was a bit disappointed with my experience because I'd heard such great things.  The food was decent, but nothing impressive.  Everyone at my table had small issues, such as meat being overcooked or dishes being underseasoned.   Service was rushed, the staff seemed frazzled and we had multiple people serving us during the evening, which caused a bit of confusion on their end.  We were not asked if we wanted to order more drinks for nearly 40 minutes, and that really put a damper on our meal.  Where's the party, La Sirena?!The pricing was not unreasonable but everything is ala carte (no sides) and the portions were a bit small, so all in all it seemed more costly than necessary for what I found to be an average meal.  With so many great places to choose from in the city, I won't be returning here.

Food - Very GoodService - GreatEverything we had was very good but the empanada's stood out as something special.  Almost worth coming back just for them.  The service was excellent and friendly. Atmosphere was very good also.  I would recommend that you go try it for yourself and see.

I had a fantastic brunch here awhile back, so the girls and I decided to go here for dinner last night. Let me say we had a feast!!! The interior of this place still stands out to me. Very intimate appeal with the dim lighting and rustic décor.Love the fact that reservations are confirmed through text. When I came previously the place was pretty dead (Mind you I came on Easter Sunday previously). Last night that was not the case. The place was at full capacity. Great place to go with the girls, date, whatever you fancy. Our waiter Jugo (sp) was great! He recommend some really superb selections for us.For drinks I tried to keep it native and went with the Pisco Sour and Caipirninha. Really refreshing and I highly recommend either. My other friend went with the Heritage Daiquiri and was really pleased. I found all the cocktails to be on the sweeter side and I enjoy that, but for those of you that don't like sweet they weren't overbearingly sweet.For appetizers we knew we had to get the Empanadas. They change the selection daily, but hopefully you'll be able to try the ones we got cause they were delicious! The two specials last night were the potato/provolone and the Chicken/garlic/Onion. Both were outstanding and flavorful. I'm a huge fan of garlic and that really aided to the flavor. I would describe the empanadas (no matter which kind you get) flaky goodness :)  For our other starter we got the shaved Brussels Sprout salad. Very beautiful presentation and we really enjoyed the tartness of the ingredients. Having the Brussels sprout shaved versus whole give it a different taste.Entrees: Of course we all ordered something different so we could share- Grilled Swordfish - If you're not into fishy fish..lol. This is the item for you. On its own it's a little bit bland, but paired with the beets and the Feijoada Black beans and Rice it's really really good!- Grilled Hanger Steak - I'm a huge meat eater and was in love with this dish. The icing on the cake was the chimichurri sauce. Excellent flavors. The steak really went well with the Garlic Frites. Fries are not extra crunchy and seasoned to perfection.- Seared Scallops - By far all of our favorite pick. You get 3 huge scallops and the mixture of the corn and chilles salad that pairs with it was mouthwatering!Were we full by now. YES!!!! Did we keep going for dessert....YES!!! LOL...they do have a dessert menu and we had a hard time choosing between the Buttercake, Tiramisu, and the Dolce de leche cookies. We ended up going with the Buttercake. It wasn't anything like we expected, but it was still good. I'll warn you we shared, but the size is more for one person. We were expecting a cake and it was more like a pie slice. Not too sweet and the texture reminded me a little bit of flan. The warm plums on top though were interesting.I love that the menu isn't too extensive and the focus seems more on making each dish the absolute best. They have delivery, so I just might have to check that out in the near future. I was stuff, but I'm looking forward to trying the sweetbreads and la bomba rice next time! A little on the pricey side, but great place to go for a fulfilling Latin inspired meal.

Was really looking forward to this dinner - bummed it was a major letdown! We made Open Table reservations and are glad we did - the place is really small with only a few tables which are really close together.Ordered the Heritage Daiquiri which tasted really good and sweet, however only got a few sips since 90% of the glass is full of ice. For $11, the ice-cocktail ratio should definitely err on the side of the drink.Onto the food: I was looking forward to the kale salad, but was bummed it has gluten so I passed up an app since I was going to order a hearty entrée, the grilled hanger steak. I asked for it well done (which I know some chefs say it won't taste as good overcooked, but I'll take it).Once the food arrived it was so dark I couldn't really tell until after my first bite that my steak was probably at best medium rare. On top of that, it was not the full flank of steak you get at most places when you order hanger steak, it was just about 6-8 small pieces of steak with the oiliest chimichurri sauce I've ever tried. The worst part though was how extremely salty it was seasoned, it was almost inedible. For $31, the steak also doesn't come with any sides or anything.The saving grace with the flourless chocolate cake I ordered for dessert.Really pricey food for the portions you get - and drenched in salt. Add this to the fact that every time you have to get up from your table your bum ends up on someone's table because it's tight quarters and this will be the first, and last time I come here. Just way too many other places to eat at in the city!

Great ambience, didn't eat much more than the smelt (tasty but not too fishy)and moqueca, an amazingly flavorful shrimp and clam stew with a thin ramen like consistency but a richness of coconut and cashew accentuated with  savory cilantro but wished I hadn't showed late for dinner !Coulda licked the bowl. That dish won me over, but my friends enjoyed their dishes as well. Will be coming back
