I was quite excited to try this.  It is quite a small space but cute inside.  They have many whiskey based cocktails and a small but approachable wine list.  Our service was very good.  There were four of us and we opted to share some things.  One complaint I  have is the sizes were definitely very large.  If you are going to share, do not get as many plates as you normally do.  We asked our server who said, for example, that the kale salad was small.  This was huge.  I think the portions could be tweaked  or, alternatively, perhaps arrange the menu from smaller plates to larger so people know what to expect size-wise.We started with the meat empanadas.  For being what they are known for, I was underwhelmed.  They were not crispy but mushy.  We then got the kale salad, which was great.  I would recommend but just keep in mind it is large.  The veal sweetbreads were great.  They were not fried so this was interesting to me.  The veal itself stood out.  The ceviche was very good.  The garlic frites were excellent.  The chicken thighs were surprisingly tender and flavorful.  Overall we felt all of the food was above average to excellent, varying by dish.  Some of the details got lost due to the amount of food so make sure you know the sizes of the dishes before ordering.

Great date restaurant! Portions were perfect for sharing. The kale salad was impressive and flavorful for something so simple. Also recommend the hanger steak, which was cooked to a perfect medium rare. Finished our meal with a delicious horchata rice pudding. Truly enjoyable meal!

Highly recommend this quaint, romantic spot on Fulton! We came on a date night, and had a wonderful dinner! It was restaurant week, but we had not planned on participating.We started with the ceviche, which was delicious and the portion was very generous. I loved the "saltines" this came with - very crisp flat bread. After looking at the menu, I had decided on the stew, which only then made sense for me to participate in the restaurant week menu! We choose the Kale Salad as our starter and this was probably the best part of our meal - it was DELICIOUS! I know that sounds weird since its only a kale salad, but trust me - its amazing.For my main, I had the stew and my boyfriend ordered the Feijoada - a mixture of different beef and rice, beans and spinach. We both were a little MEH on the mains. The first two starters were so great and these just didnt really compare, unfortunately! Dont get me wrong - they were good, but not as GOOD as I would have expected.Finally, we had the Tres Leches, which was the great ending to our meal! I would HIGHLY recommend checking this place out. Maybe next time, I will stick with some of the smaller offerings towards the top of the menu so we could sample more.Side note on the drinks, there seems to be a lot of ice in them and not as much booze for $13. For my second, I ordered a glass of wine to make sure I got more bang for my buck!Lastly, our waiter was GREAT! He was not pushy, knew the menu so well and answered so many questions. He was truly one of the best waiters I have ever had.

I didn't much enjoy a visit to La Sirena Clandestina on a recent weeknight. The food was OK and the service harried but passable, but the prices seemed high and the ambiance (décor, crowding, and especially NOISE) was unpleasant.Foodwise, a kale salad was good (if overly salty and bread-cubed). A meat/cheese empanada was OK, but rather ho-hum. Piri-piri chicken thighs in romesco were tender & tasty (except for the slightly burnt flavor of accompanying onions). Smoked ribs were delicious, though the dish could have used more coconut puree. Overall, A-OK food.The wine list was another matter. To start, price points are too high -- all but one red were $50 or more. There should be more bottles in the 30's and 40's. This is a Latin-themed restaurant with many picante dishes, but the wine list is mostly Italian and French varieties that are not heat-friendly -- lots of tannin, not much juicy fruit. There was no tempranillo, no zin, no primitivo, no shiraz, and just one (pricey) garnacha. Maybe it's a millennial thing: everyone drinks beer or cocktails? Whatever. We tried a couple of wines; one was bad (from two bottles), the other just not very good, and both were overpriced.Regarding ambiance, it's a narrow room with high tin ceilings and exposed ducts, so the crowd noise is awful -- way conversation-challenged. The décor is spartan (hip?): rustic wood tables, no decorations. The tables were crowded together more than I prefer. Definitely not the place for a pleasant dinner conversation.Overall, I'm glad I tried La Sirena, but it's just not my thing. I won't be back.

Dinner began with Campari, so the tone of the meal was right from the start.We weren't looking for anything too heavy - a break from character - so we loaded up on veggie-centric dishes and then, of course, a pork shoulder empanada. Because when you dine at a restaurant that specializes in empanadas, you order empanadas.The Gala Apple & Fennel Salad was light, bright and crisp. It was dressed with a lovely, grainy mustard vinaigrette and sharp Dunbarton blue. Apples carried into the next dish, too, which was a Grilled Spanish Octopus served over acorn squash romesco and apple-celery relish. Ordering octopus can be risky (or maybe that's just my take because I've had one too many pieces that are akin to chewing on a tire), but this was done right - charred with just the right amount of chew. Tart vinegar-y roasted Brussels sprouts on the side paired deliciously with the octopus. Yes, they're greens, but these cruciferous veggies add substance, and the Tropea onions they're cooked with make the dish even heartier. The empanada looked and smelled heavenly, with a golden - and in some parts, just a touch darker - baked exterior.We were talked into dessert, although realistically, it didn't take too much talking. We ordered carrot cake. Unlike most places, where ordering carrot cake means ordering an oversized triangular slab with a 1:1 ratio of cream cheese to cake, this slice was delicate. It still maintained that dense, luscious texture that's a requirement of any true carrot cake. This dessert capped off the meal perfectly, leaving us full and satisfied but not overstuffed.

The restaurant is on the smaller side but the flavors of the food and drinks are on the larger side. In a Brazilian restaurant, therefore, naturally I had to start off with a capirina drink which was perfectly delicious. As for the food; the octopus, bomba rice, hanger steak, heirloom tomato salad, empanadas were all delicious. I do have to mention that the national dish of Brazil feijoradha was delicous, but also, over priced($34).  Especially when you consider that it's mainly a rice and beans dish. The service was friendly and helpful. Overall its a great addition to the other great restaurants on this strip of Fulton street.

Ordered the vegetarian empanada and the ceviche with house crackers. The ceviche mix was zesty with plenty of lemon kick, but not enough to overpower all the flavor. It's a refreshing order, perfect for the summer season. The presentation in the martini cup is cute, but not exactly practical for mixing the ceviche with the guacamole! The house-made crackers had a nice salty pastry flavor, so you don't have to worry about eating the ceviche with some cheap store-bought saltines.I like that the empanada is baked and NOT fried, the pork belly meat option sounded amazing but if you don't want to feel guilty, the vegetarian version is a nice alternative. It's a bit small and the order only comes with one, but at $4 it's not exactly expensive.
Caipirinha -- strong n refreshingKale Salad very yumCeviche Uniquely yumLunch Sandwiches--tastyEmpanada -- solidSevice-- friendlyBeautifully decorated with a rustic feel.Enjoyed my experience.

Another one of these trendy, foodie, new Latin infused, inspired restaurants. We were amused, but not wowed. The four of us gave the short menu a pretty good workout. The deep fried whole fish was good, not great. The steak was good, not great (over seasoned).  I had some pork beef rice and beans concoction, which really was not too satisfying. The ceviche was more like a shrimp guacamole.The winners. The great cocktails and baked empanadas. The carrot cake was great.The room is small. Waitstaff is pleasant. Street parking can be found.  Give it a try, see for yourself.
Really bad service here, the guy look like sir mad and angry all time when he service is, just be happy!

We saw it ob Check Please. Had no reservation for Friday night but were able to dine the bar within minutes.Kale salad was good, empanadas were good.Pisco sour drink - fantastic!The veal sweetbreads were phenomenal! I have never had better meat of any kind - period. Super tender! Smoky, flavorful, light, melted in my mouth:)Almond cake desert - very good. Crispy and warm, sweet with nice sour fresh rhubarb and strawberry dice.Will come back even if the restaurant is very far away from our western suburbs.

So my mom and I went to check this place out and I think someone with a more flexible diet would enjoy this place a lot. We asked for some vegan versions of a few of their apps which they said they could do and it turned out that the kale salad had butter milk in it after all. We found out after we ate about half of it - and basically, I will feel this tomorrow but one thing I must say is the staff handled it very well, comped us some food and was very apologetic. It does count for something. We really enjoyed the fried cauliflower though, it reminded us of Indian pakoras ... I would just mention though that the acoustics are a little wild, I could barely here moms and she was right next to me. So maybe not the best place for an intimate date type situation -

We walked in a Thursday night around 6:30 and were able to get a table immediately due to a no-show. Otherwise we could have easily grabbed two seats at the bar or patio, which are both first-come-first-served and at that point in the evening were pretty much empty.We ordered the fish special, which was American Red Snapper, the elotes, and the pao de queijo (Brazilian cheesy bread balls) - which were as authentic as I've had outside of Brazil.  The food was good, but not mind-blowing. I would recommend this place to friends who want something a little nicer, not obscenely expensive, and who like good food but would be overwhelmed at the super-foodie places.The food came out very quickly, which was nice. Overall though I feel like the server was good, but didn't give us as much attention as her other tables (and we could tell because we were about 10in from the next table). She didn't explain the menu and it took a really long time to get our check and then take our payment. Still, worth trying out, and they have good cocktails!

Let me start off by saying that the creator of this wine list really knows what she's doing.  This is an ultimate geek list.  No trophies, no obvious corporate labels, no douchebag offerings, just a brilliant demonstration of how there is so much more to wine than what you would find at Binny's or a corporate Amex steakhouse, and without having to take out a second mortgage.  Just check out the list on their website and you'll see that there are quite a few labels you haven't tried before, let alone heard of.  That's where the fun is.We selected an "orange" wine from Italy, the La Stoppa Ageno from Emilia Romagna, Italy.  An "orange" wine is made from white grapes, and with prolonged contact with the grape skins.  In this case, the main grape was a malvasia, one of the oldest known grape families out there.  (I like to say that along with muscat, it makes up the Adam and Eve of wine grapes.)  This wine had lots of acidity, and given the prolonged contact with the skins, plenty of tannins.  Tart, fresh, with orange peel and floral notes.  That only begins to desribe the wine, as it was chameleonlike throughout the meal.  The tannins stood up surprisingly well to the meat dish I had, and the acidity did wonders with the spiciness that was constant throughout the meal.Oh yes, the meal, right.  A kale salad to start, that had sliced jalapeno in it, along with a chile infused dressing.  My main was the feijoada dish, which had short ribs, pork belly, and linguica sausage, along with black beans, greens, and diced tomatoes.  I poured on a lot of the spicy vinegar that they offered.  My wife had the moqueca, which is a Brazilian seafood stew that featured mussels, shrimp, and fish (sorry, I don't know what kind it was), along with a risotto.  This was certainly a lot more interesting than the worn out steak emporium format that is so 15 years ago.  For dessert we split the beignets, which had a passion fruit curd and rum caramel.  All this made for a great anniversary dinner.  We'll definitely be back for another adventure, to try new menu items and a another one of these crazy bottles.

Went there for brunch and it was just ok. Nothing that would blow your mind...The ambiance - okThe food - okThe service - okthe ceviche is not that good especially after having ceviche in Peru and other parts of south america.  The chilaquiles was delicious, you add $6 for shrimp and they give you 2 burnt shrimps, hmmmmm, lets think about that.  If you order this dish, don't add the shrimp or the chicken, it is good enough as it is and considering they give you 2 shrimps for that additional price? No thank you!Parking was easy in this area.  I think its good to try this place once but im not a repeat customer.

Nice ambiance. We got 4 different cocktails between us. 3 were okay 1 was really good the pisco sour.We ordered a bunch of appetizers. They were okay. The rice dish and the alfajores were only things I really enjoyed out of 8 things we got.For the price point I was expecting really good food. Service was great.

Friendly and knowledgeable staff, nice environment and one of the best kale salads I've ever had. I've been here twice now and have found myself pleasantly surprised on both occasions. Great variety on the menu and good drinks too.

Tasty Brazilian fare in a hip corner of the Fulton Market with distinctive lunch options.. Excellent black bean soup nicely flavored.We enjoyed a very good Brazilian bowl with avocado and Cuban sandwich with salad that also was first rate. The tres leches cake was creatively prepared and truly excellent. The expresso was a little bitter and nicely strong. $35 per person including tax and tip. Definitely will be back!

We had dinner here recently and everything was fantastic. We ordered many dishes for the entire table and everything was prepared perfectly.  Our server coursed the meal for us as well.The polenta and the la Bamba rice were the standouts. The rice was perfectly cooked. The polenta had great texture and just enough saltiness.We could've passed on the fried cauliflower, but even those were good. The whole menu meshed well no matter what you ordered.Our cocktails were also well crafted.The service was also impeccable. Our server was not overbearing, but she was attentive, honest, and extremely knowledgeable. The ambiance was great for a group. There was nice music and light but nothing too loud or over stimulating.I found this place last minute, but I will definitely be returning.

From start to finish the dinner here was fantastic! Super friendly server and staff.  The menu is slightly tapas style, with really nice sized portions.  The pork shank was amazing! The empanadas were beyond good! Also , the polenta - wow! Ended the night with a $2 cookie on their dessert menu- do not leave without the cookie.  Ambience and decor was rustic chic.  Only negative would be the closeness of tables/ loudness of restaurant.  But go! You will not be disappointed by the food.

Holy smokes this place is everything!!! Delicious food, the empanadas are delicious and the bombo rice is out of this world! Whoa! The service is outstanding they never miss a beat. The drinks are amazing. If I could give 20 stars I would. Go there right now!

Great dinner at La Sirena last night! I think because it was Halloween on a Friday, the restaurant wasn't overly busy. I dined with my husband and we went the shared plates route with our choices.Empanadas--ordered both the meat and veggie versions. The former was cheeseburger themed and the latter was...veggie something. Both were a delicious start to our meal!La Bomba Rice--realllllly good and the chiles give it a nice kick. It's a sizable portion and at the suggestion of our server, we ordered it along with one of the larger entrees. I don't know that it would be good as just an entree on its own though as in that form it might be kind of boring.Lobster tail and chicken--loved this entree. The lobster was nice and buttery, the chicken good and crispy skinned, and the rice both came with had a great flavor too.Cheese bread--I'm not sure what I was expecting, but what came out were 4 balls resembling hushpuppies. They were tasty and I would definitely recommend them. We got them along with our entrees but I actually think they'd be a great as another small appetizer with the empanadas.As far as drinks, we had the caipirinha and pisco sour. Both classics were well made. Service was friendly (and dressed in costumes for the holiday!) and attentive.

Incredible food and great service - highly recommend!! Our server was great, incredibly personable and made stellar recommendations for food as well as cocktails. We tried the kale salad and ceviche to start (which were okay, have had better) but the Pao queso were incredible and the hanger steak as a main absolutely delicious. I would for sure go back- highly recommend !

I hosted my 30th birthday at La Sirena this past weekend and the service and food were absolutely as good as it gets. I've been to the restaurant before and had their regular menu. Everything was delicious then but was equally matched with the group menu. They served dinner family style and I was able to choose from many options.Everything we had was wonderful: an assortment of empanadas, head-on prawns, ceviche, kale salad (a favorite of mine), pan-roasted salmon (holy s*it this fish was perfectly cooked and the skin was on point - I almost opted out of the salmon because I eat it often but am so glad I didn't; chef and his team nailed it), chili-rubbed pork loin, garlic frites, fried cauliflower and...my favorite...alfajores. I ate three, no shame.The service was impeccable. My glass was never empty and there was always food on the table. They also split the check evenly between the guests and ran 14 different cards. La Sirena was also so accommodating, inquiring whether anyone in the party had dietary restrictions and letting me know when the market fish had changed last-minute so I could change courses if I wanted. Thank you to Nicole - Director of Marketing and Private Events - she answered my many questions punctually and set the entire dinner up.I will definitely be dinning at La Sirena again!

Delicious! I am Brazilian so I thought I would be a tough critic, but I was very happy. The drinks are delicious, the moqueca was perfect, the pao de queijo tasted like my mom's! I recommend staking out a seat at the bar - tables are tough.
Kale Salad... the BEST.  I'd rather have this than a cheeseburger.Black bean soup - amazing.Tomato and coconut milk soup - life changing.Thank you Sirena.

Went here on a Tuesday with a girlfriend and was completely impressed. Great wine selection, food was incredible & service was outstanding. Very small, quaint, chic place. Amazing ambiance. Very intimate. Food: Had the empanadas, chicken thigh and garlic fries and I left feeling utterly satisfied. Highly recommend!

I came here with a friend from Italy who had never had south American food before. To be honest this is more like American food with a south American flavor, not particularly authentic. That is not to say that we did not like the food, it just was not what I expected. The best part of the meal was the empanadas. There was a vegetarian option with Mack and cheese and rapini as well as a ham.  They were smaller than I liked. But alas, we survived.The seafood dishes we had were tasty. We had an octopus appetizer as well as a seafood stew that our waitress recommended we order a side of fries with so that we could dip the fries in the broth of the mussles and seafood.Finally, they have fernet and coke on the drink menu!  That was great!!

Best best best best best best experience ever! Server was spot on and professional, food was to die for, ambiance was exceptional and the icing on the cake was my lovely drink that my server recommended. Great night! I will be back and spread the word!

Our experience was just wonderful.  Had the empanadas, they are my new addiction.  Also, the whole fried fish and shared the steak.  All were cooked to perfection, and incredibly flavorful.  Service was on point, from making and changing our reservation, to our wonderful server.  Friendly and very knowledgeable staff, beautiful and fun atmosphere, another new fave of mine!!

Strongly suggest to make reservations as the place is not big. Empanadas were very good; the hang steak with chimichurri very good. The Piri chicken was very tender with great flavor, not spicy. Dessert also good. I would recommend. It is expensive. Coming back while in Chicago.

Great food!! Every dish we tried was full of flavor, the exact amount of spices and herbs, not too overwhelming but definitely edgy. The ribeye special was fantastic. Great ambiance inspire of the fact that it's on the smaller side, we never felt like it was too stuffy. Last and not least, the staff is extremely friendly and accommodating. Definitely going back :)

I don't even know where to start.  This place is AMAZING.  The staff is awesome along with the food.  The 4 of us got the whole fish, empanadas, shaved vegetable salad and the special of the day Ribeye Steak....ALL so GOOD!  Hats off to the chef and bartender...mixologist I should say who didn't only have an awesome beard but REALLY knew his craft and whiskeys.  BEST old fashioned I have ever had.  Our waitress was great and accommodating.  The staff was not only attentive but funny and personable.  We WILL be back!

We liked it! The ambience is wonderful. Dark interior, close company, intimate surroundings. Food was outstanding. We tried a handful of smaller dishes rather than entree plus side/appetizer. The potato leek polenta did not feel especially Latin American. Ceviche was excellent though, and the kale salad, wow. Empanads, always baked, were tasty. Thumbs uo on fried cauliflower. Wanted to try so many other things!  This is not a two $$ restaurant, it's not a $200 meal either.

La Sirena Clandestina is a nice little spot nestled in the Fulton Market area (right across from Next). Its cozy and dimly lit, great for a group of friends or romantic rendezvous.I went with a couple of friends and we shared a bunch of dishes. The cocktails and service were pretty good too.Pros:Kale, garlic cheesy empanadaSeared ScallopsLa Bomba Rice!Grilled SwordfishCheese Bread!Pork Ribs (special that day)Heritage DaquiriCons:Some of the dishes were oversalted, would be way better if it wasn't so saltyThe steak special from Hoosier Farms, it was kind of hard to chewWaiters were attentive but took away dishes too quicklyOverall, I think La Sirena was a good place to try, but could use some fine-tuning.

This review is difficult for me. I went to college down the street, this cafe holds lots of memories. I remember it used to be a place where we had to wait over 45 minutes to get seated, then we got excited for everything that we'd ordered, finally walking up to the cashiers and tell them how great our brunch was.I went back there today, I have to say that the taste isn't there anymore, or it could be that they were busy. My omelet and potatoes were very greasy and unflavored, I hope it was just because they were busy. I ordered a side of French fries, it looked so fresh and delicious, unfortunately it tasted dry and old.Juice and waffles were still good! I was very happy at least something hasn't changed. I would like to go back there at another time, I am hoping that everything will be better.

Stax is one of my favorite places to get brunch at, and I'm always enthusiastically herding my guests here; mainly because it's so close to where I live.Be prepared to wait. The waiting time can easily be 30-40 minutes on weekends. If you've got a brunch itch that can't wait that long, there's always sweet maple cafe down the road.Skillets are the thing to go for if it's your first time here. The portions are huuuuge. I've never left stax without a to-go box! Most dishes come with house potatoes and the option of either toast, mini pancakes or mini waffles. I always opt for the chocolate chip mini waffles. They're equal parts delicious and adorable.The food itself is well made and they're happy to customize your order. I usually swap bacon with turkey sausage. The potatoes and omelettes are really greasy and under seasoned and require a generous sprinkling of salt and pepper. I love their freshly squeezed juices, especially grapefruit and orange. So pulpy, so good!Yes, stax is a little overpriced, but they're super cool about splitting checks, and the service is outstanding. Everyone is friendly and brimming with suggestions for the undecided.Give Stax a try if you're in the neighborhood!

I had a horrible experience with the hostess. She was one of the most unprofessional and unorganized I've ever met. She put my name down, estimated a 25-30 minute wait, and ended up throwing my name and potentially a few others in the trash.Never fessing up to her mistake, she blamed me. Then said I would be put at the end of the list again after already waiting 25 minutes. I ended up walking out and driving to a different restaurant which happily took my business. One can only hope that either owner realizes how badly their front of house treats potential paying customers or they go out of business.

In a perfect world, I would love to tell you that I had a lovely stack of awesome pancakes with OJ and some delicious bacon... but instead I'm going to tell you a tale of woe and tears... my tears.So after walking in and wandering for 5 min to get someone to acknowledge my party, we make eye contact with a short lady who asks how many. After answering and receiving the wait of 30 min, we asked to be placed on the list.This is where our wait should be rewarded with the brunch of the century... but alas... I'll never know what those glorious waffles will taste against my lips because the hostess' epic unprofessional boffo.So apparently 30 min means 2-5 minutes in the alternate twilight zone reality of this hostess. We walked down the block to look at a storefront only to return 5 min later. After this hostess pops her head out calling other names on multiple occasions and about 20 min later (as well as a 3 top that was sat who walked up while we were standing there "because the hostess hooked them up") we approached her again to ask how much time was left. Only to be told that she had already called us.Well, okay. Womp womp... things happen... but you'd think i dunno, you'd apologize and tell us we're next. Or even don't need to apologize.. just maybe skip us... but no... this hostess proceeds to give us another 20 min wait.So while I'd love to regale you with a happy story of awesome food and tasty beverages... I'm just going to the maple cafe down the street to actually get food instead.Tl;dr - bad customer service... don't bother,  head down the block to maple instead.  You're welcome.

My husband and I gave this breakfast place a try today. It was good but not great. I had the Spanish Harlem omelette which was okay. The eggs were a little well done. My husband had the chocolate chip pancakes which he said were okay as well. The star of the show was the adorable mini waffles I got with my omelette. I went for the cinnamon roll mini waffles and they were delicious!! I'd go back for the mini waffles and try something else on the menu.

Oh boy - I thought I did this place before.  I go there for the skirt steak and eggs with tons of pepper.  Nice place, clean and EXCEPTIONAL service not only from the waitress but the manager as well.  I did not get his name and I think my waitress was Mary - made sure I had everything I needed and the manager made sure to ask if if I enjoyed.  I like that.  But I like the skirt steak more!!  Hell I'm getting hungry now writing this even though I polished off a big bowl of menudo.

I ordered the beef brisket hash, and the brisket was kinda dry. The veggies in the hash had a sour taste to it, which didn't mix well with the eggs. Portion size is good, especially if you're really hungry.

I visited Stax Cafe for brunch today. It was my first time here. I ordered the chorizo frittata and po... yeah, which is shown in the photo. I'm uncultured as shit, so I didn't know that frittata was eggs. And I hate eggs. I tried to get something else, but they were only willing to take half off since it was my error (that was the only thing I didn't like, which is actually one reason I gave it four stars... Plus the food was really good, it didn't knock my socks off). So, I ended up just eating it and, like I just said, it was really good. I enjoyed it. And the coffee was absolutely amazing. Forgot to mention that. The service was... good? You know? She was like super nice and helpful, but not the most attentive as we were never asked if we were ready for the check. And like... 45-60 minutes had passed since we finished our food.Overall, it's kinda small, but it's a good place to have breakfast/brunch (NOT for a large group). Food was good. Service was cool. I'll go back.

I had to give 3 stars this time. Our server was Queen. lt seemed like she just wanted to get work over with.I'm in the business where I have to recruit people for customer service roles... It you're not into being chipper, then you should probably go work somewhere else.I had to deduct another star because the temperate of our food was room temperature AND, we were being seated under a vent where it was really cold! It was tough to enjoy our breakfast date.As for the food, I ordered a fresh strawberry and orange juice drink and the beef brisket (which queen did recommend). It was delicious! Just wish it came out warmer.

Brunch is something I don't usually do, but this place sounded good and has a lot of high reviews on Yelp.The place looks nice, it's like a rustic feel like your at home.The food is on the higher price of things, that maybe because only fancy people and divorce moms who are on a reality tv show go out for brunch.The waitress we had was really good and she knew what she was doing. That's always a good thing to have.All in all, this place was alright.

Went here for bunch, it's pretty close to UIC so it made for a nice walk. This place is super cute with a cozy "organic" type feel. They had a lot of food options, exploiting the realms of savory with prosciutto avocado eggs Benedict to the taste of sweet with captain crunch pancakes. You can't go wrong here. I have the Spanish Harlem omelette (under Stax features). It was delicious. I would definitely come back to this place!

I had herd about this place for so long but I was never able to actually go and get a table because it always looked so packed. I'm not one for the hype. Eventually, I made it out here during the week and there was no wait! For the first time, I was able to get inside.I had the breakfast tacos and boy were they worth the wait. The service was great, we were able to get one of the larger tables and nobody rushed us to move or place an order. The wait staff was very polite and friendly, answering questions about the menu or bringing out any special requests (I don't have hot sauce in my bag, swag).The coffee was delicious and I honestly cannot wait to go back to Stax. The menu is small but it is powerful, I can guarantee that you will have a difficult time deciding on only one delicious breakfast item.... To think I haven't even tried the pancake stax amazes me!

Cute place with a decently varied menu, but also somewhat pricey for a breakfast/brunch option. It's also a terrible choice if you're looking for a smaller/lighter breakfast. I ended up going with the veggie skillet (spinach, mushrooms, onions, green peppers, mozzarella, potatoes, swiss) with over-medium eggs and I chose mini waffles as my side. The plate was $14.The mini waffles were on the moist side of dry, but then again I have yet to find excellent waffles anywhere. The over-medium eggs were pretty runny, but acceptable. The skillet itself was drowning in oil, which was the biggest disappointment about what appeared to be a healthy choice. It was a big portion so I only ate about half - the top half since the veggies at the end were so terribly greasy. If we ever return I won't be ordering that again. And with other options hovering around $10-15 I won't hesitate to be very particular about my order (e.g "no oil" or building my own lighter breakfast from some of the other items around the menu).If you're okay with a sugary plate though, the crepes, waffles and pancakes looked fun and unique.

Personally one of my favorite places to grab breakfast/brunch in town mainly because it is very close to where I live. But other then location, the food is always on point and the service is solid. I am a big fan of the various takes on egg's benedict they have as well as the omelettes. One thing to note is the weekend's can get really busy so be prepared to wait for awhile.
The potatoes were a bit too chunky compared to the ones in other skillets out there. Overall, service was great and portions were big.

If you are a brunch guy in the middle of a rush, perfect place to check in. My favorite was lumberjack skillet. Everytime I go, I have that. Not too much costly: apparently they have a dish named 'Starving Student' which comes with 2 eggs, 2 slices of bacon, white or wheat toast or instead of toast, add mini waffles or mini pancakes. Sweet right?

Delicious breakfast!! Ordered a stack of chocolate chip pancakes (very fluffy and just the perfect amount of chocolate) with a side of potatoes and sausage links!! Coffee was great! Wait wasn't that bad for a Sunday morning--20 minutes. Def going back! Our server was awesome!

Stax is chill. I'd go back. The coffee was outstanding. I'm not used to having amazing coffee at brunch places - you know, it's usually fine but it doesn't inspire you to ask the brand like I did yesterday (Intelligentsia, I learned). I had the bacon jam sandwich which was pretty tasty and filling. I don't get full easily and I couldn't finish it! The bacon tomato jam was inventive and tasty! I felt like $25 was a little steep for what I got.
A great place for breakfast in Chicago! I love their egg Benedict and fresh apple juice.

I went with a group of friends to Stax Café after seeing it reviewed on Chicago Best's television show. We got there around 12:30 on a Sunday and it was about a 20 minute wait, which isn't bad compared to most places. Parking was easy to find on Taylor street and better yet free since it was a Sunday. The ambiance of the restaurant wasn't anything fancy, but it was quite cozy. If you check in on yelp you get either two free mini pancakes or two free mini waffles. Most of the meals also come with two free pancakes or waffles. To mix it up I went with a side of two mini white chocolate banana pancakes (a little dry). I also went with two mini chocolate chip waffles and those were very good!For my main meal I had the Spanish omelet and it came with potatoes on the side. They don't have the siracha (sp) sauce sitting on the table, but ask for it! After putting some of that sauce over my omelet my meal was delicious and complete. Prices were reasonable and it'll definitely be on my list of places to come back to for brunch. I don't visit this area often, so I plan on venturing around the next time I'm here.For more pics follow me on Instagram @chiataglance

Breakfast and brunch can be a task in Chicago unless you get to the restaurant early. So, I opted to go to Stax Cafe early on Sunday morning. Fantastic!I ordered banana French toast with dulce de leche, eggs scrambled well with cream cheese, and house potatoes.The French toast made my day. The fact that they didn't require any syrup was all the better. I love the fact that they actually scrambled my eggs with cream cheese rather than sending out a plate of scrambled eggs with dollops of cream cheese. The home potatoes were also good, seasoned with onions, red peppers, and green peppers.Having gotten to the restaurant early, the service was good. Given the area, I imagine the restaurant gets crowded, so I recommend going early enough to enjoy your breakfast, brunch, or lunch without complaint. I'll definitely have to return to see what else is on the menu worthy of gobbling.

Stacks on stacks on stacks at Stax! Yum, pancakes!This cute little breakfast place located near UIC offers up some delicious breakfast options in their cozy building. I love that it's so clean inside and really modern like in design. The menu is on a single sheet and easy to read. From platters, to benedicts, to omelettes, pancakes and french toast, you're sure to find a breakfast treat for you.When I hear "stax" I immediately think of a stack of pancakes. So naturally, I decided that I wanted pancakes. I decided to go with the Healthy Start Pancakes because of the blueberry compote. I love blueberries and was drawn into the blueberry and greek yogurt with honey combination! I was so surprised by the portion size of these pancakes. There were 3 giant pancakes filled with blueberries and on top, a dollop of greek yogurt, blueberry compote, granola all drizzled in honey. The pancakes are made out of oat so it gave an interesting texture and flavor. I really liked it though, being an oat fan that I am. The blueberries bursted in the pancakes and the greek yogurt was tart and refreshing. I could have eaten it without maple syrup, but maple syrup never hurt anyone! I barely got through half of the stack before my stomach caved in.My friend got the Starving Student platter which comes with eggs, bacons, potatoes/veggies and either mini pancakes or waffles. It was a big meal, definitely fit for a hungry student. And trust me, after finishing that plate, you'll leave as a satisfied student!My other friend decided to go with the carnivore omelette. He is a huge meat lover and said that the omelette had so much meat that it was almost too much (can you ever have too much meat?!). I could see all the different pieces of meat throughout his giant omelette. It also came with potatoes and HUGE pieces of toast. I've never seen toast that big ever. This is a hefty portion so be prepared!The pricing is really fair for the big portion sizes. Each menu item is about $10-15 depending on what you are getting. Service here was pretty good. Our server was a little hard to understand but we made it by. She checked up on us here and there and our water was refilled promptly.Breakfast food is comfort food, and Stax embraces comfort.

I can't believe I'm just NOW reviewing my beloved Stax Cafe. My coworkers and I had lunch here this week. I, of course, have eaten here numerous times, but some of my cohorts were new to try it....I was more than happy to offer my suggestions:)First off, they serve Intelligencia coffee, so that's amazing. Also, they have a full juice bar if that's your thing. The menu is rather large with offering both breakfast and lunch options. I've tried many items to include the chiliquiles, fried chicken sandwhich, tuna sliders, mini egg sandwiches, the turkey club, the chicken salad, I mean I could go on....Honestly these dishes are nothing short of delicious. But the absolute best is most definitely the breakfast wrap. It's my "go to" for sure! I highly recommend this dish for anyone who loves bomb food...and cheese! ;)The customer service is always on point. There is sometimes a wait, but that's only because this place is the real deal. It's worth the wait I promise. I have to say, one of the best diners in Chicago! See you real soon Stax!

Cute little breakfast stop that is just ok. I believe my friend enjoyed her meal way more than I did. The skillet lacked in flavor and was slightly bland. The gluten-free pancakes were good but a tad burnt on the edges. I don't know if I'd come back when in town.

I came here with my dad after the Maple Berry Cafe was just too crowded (I think the semester just ended so it was filled with UIC students). I had never tried Stax before, but there were a couple open tables so we were seated right away. I thought the crepes looked good, so I tried the mushroom and swiss crepe. It came with some nice leafy greens on the top and a really nice sauce. The food was high quality and came out quickly. It was a little crowded and the noise level was a little high, but nothing too crazy. I will be coming here again.

Ordered blueberry pancakes and an omelette. The omelette came with toast.The blueberry pancakes came out with the toast with the omelette but no omelette. The pancakes had a hot blueberry compote on it.The omelette came out 10 minutes later. Hot compote was cold at that point. Toast was cold.The table next to me suffered the same fate. They were served their pancakes first and then had to wait quite a while for their actual dishes.Too bad the kitchen/expediter sucks at their job. Food isn't too bad.

Nice cozy interior and our waitress was super nice and helpful with what to order. Got seated right away on Saturday 1:30pm. I had the veggie skillet it was ok, first time here so wasn't sure what to get and many things sounded good on the menu. The skillet was a little plain, veggies with large potatoes and  egg on top but was missing some sort of spice or something. The Raspberry and white chocolate pancakes were very good but I compare all pancakes to Bango room (breakfast place also) as they have white chocolate SAUCE so you don't even use maple syrup and this would have been perfect with these pancakes. Probably won't be back anytime soon.
Delicious!Very good food, worth the usual wait.

I had the fried chicken & waffle salad this morning and all I can say was...YUMMY. I ate the whole full sized salad which I never do on full plate salads. It has this maple vinigerette dressing and this miniture sweet peppers that are pickled...to die for. It is on their special board & I hope that they make it permeant. My waitress was very attentive. I haven't been in the restraunt for some time so it was a real treat because I tried something different this visit.

What a cute, hip little spot!We waited for an hour and a half to get a table for 3, but it was so worth it. The atmosphere is incredible and very enjoyable. The wait was only long because of the hot chocolate 5k going on that morning. We called ahead and got our name on the list so we were able to wait at home and then head over.I ordered the stuffed pepper soup of the day and it was absolutely delicious. It was simple enough that I am hoping I can recreate it at home, that's how great it was. I also ordered the mini egg and ham sandwiches. The eggs were cooked perfectly and the rolls they served them on are really yummy. I wasn't a huge fan of the potatoes that come on the side, but luckily I was full from the soup so it didn't really matter. My friends ordered the breakfast tacos and one of the eggs benedicts. Both of the dishes were presented nicely and tasted as good as they looked.

So I'm finally checking out restaurants in my neighborhood and Stax was high on the list. I love brunch fare so I went in excited. The service was friendly and prompt. I ordered the blueberry pancakes, turkey sausage and coffee. The food was good. Perfectly acceptable. A little mediocre. The coffee was a bust, too mild for my taste. I don't know. The menu looked very standard. Price was ok but no value here. The add on meat is not worth it. Would I go back? Sure. But is it worth seeking out? I don't think so.

I've now been to Stax Cafe on Taylor three times.  Each time I have tried something new and I can say that the food is consistently good.Normally I dine at Stax on a Saturday or Sunday which is probably their peek business days I'm sure.  The wait list seems to move very quickly using the "under promise; over deliver" technique for quoting wait times.The restaurant is a decent size in comparison to other restaurants on Taylor St.  However the lobby or foyer area tends to get quite a bit crowded as patrons waiting for tables and customers paying their bills merge.The service can be a touch slow at time, not sure if servers have table limits or what the deal is but I've had to flag a server down at least twice for a coffee refill and I am by no means sucking them down at a accelerated pace.The food is quite delicious though.  I've had the brisket bennies, raspberry and white chocolate chip pancakes, and the falafel sliders.  All of which are great.  They also do run specials but I have not indulged on any to report yet.Overall Stax is a really good brunch spot, I would recommend for sure.

We met a friend here for breakfast and it was fine, but not exactly mind-blowing.  We were seated after a brief wait, and coffee (Intelligentsia, no less) came out quickly.  However, the poached eggs on my Benedict were bit overdone, and if I hadn't been with friends, I definitely would have sent it back.  The English muffin toast on the bottom was overwhelmingly large -- a theme of their bread items -- and made it tricky to eat, and I could have used more Hollandaise. The potatoes needed a little salt, but were otherwise good.I didn't love it and I didn't hate it.  I'm unlikely to ever be back in this neighborhood, and definitely wouldn't return just for the Stax Cafe.

The people at the Michelin guide must have been high when they came here to eat and decided to recommend it. Totally mediocre breakfast - my French toast had no sugar or spices to be detected,  and the bananas on top were black - not because they were brûléed - they were just old. My boyfriends' frittata had no salt and the worst crime - the coffee was gross. Burned three hours ago. Giving it two stars because service and decor were nice enough. Price is fine, but honestly paying even $10 for that French toast felt like robbery because I would have been better up picking up a bagel at a bakery for $2.But burnt coffee man - you have ONE job if you're selling breakfast - don't give people bad coffee.

Love this place. My family comes here all the time and there isn't anything on the menu we didn't like.Top choices are turkey burgers, oatmeal pancakes, waffles, brisket Benedict, & grapefruit juice.There's usually a wait, but we always thought it's worth it.
Two thumbs up. Brisket Benedict was incredible as were the omelets and lemon poppyseed waffles. Great service too! This place lived up to the already stellar reputation. You won't be disappointed.
Love this breakfast place.  Just about everything I've ordered here is good.Coffee and fresh OJ.  Weekends crowded. Weekday not to bad. I'll be back soon.My son Eric big fan too.
Very cute interior! I ordered the BLT (it has egg on it) and it was GREAT! Would highly recommend. The menu is well priced too... almost everything is under $10.

My fiance and I happened to be driving down Taylor St. after an early morning doctor's appointment this past Saturday and decided to stop and grab breakfast at a little place that caught our eye called Stax. We were greeted and sat immediately by a friendly host, as it was only about 8 a.m. and the brunch rush hadn't started yet. As usual when everything looks good and I get nervously indecisive, my fiance and I opted to order one sweet and one savory breakfast and share. I hemmed and hawed over whether to order the mixed berry crepes or the butter pecan waffles, but decided on the crepe, you know, to be "healthy." By crepe, they meant three crepes stuffed with and topped with strawberries, blueberries, and raspberries, with a raspberry and cream coulis and whipped cream. No skimping on any ingredients here!Once I thought I had decided, I pulled out my phone to check in on Yelp, and was delighted to find a check-in would get you a free order of mini-waffles, and yes, these mini-waffles COULD be butter pecan. You can have it ALL at Stax! The waffles were hot, fluffy, crisp, sweet, and had whole pecans IN and ON the waffles, lots of waffle-y goodness, with whipped cream.My fiance went with the tender beef brisket hash with potatoes and an egg, which also came with mini pancakes. Well seasoned, well cooked. SO MUCH FOOD! Add a hot chocolate with whipped cream and a coffee and we still hadn't even spent $30. Our server was also great  - Merissa, genuine smile, appeared to offer a coffee refill without being flagged down and to check in at the right times, efficient; joked about my whipped cream overdosing, definitely the person you want to deal with before 9 a.m.  We packed up at least half of our meal to go and got Sunday breakfast out of it too, supplemented with an egg or two of our own. With such great food and great service, I imagine it gets pretty busy later in the mornings, but I definitely would recommend Stax to anyone and have added this to my own list of great breakfast spots!

This is a great breakfast place with endless breakfast options.  We ordered the mini breakfast tacos and oatmeal pancakes with blueberries, coffee and freshly squeezed juice.  Everything was great including our friendly server Ozgur.  The restaurant had a nice light and airy feel.  Will be back!!!

Loved everything about this place, the location, parking was free in an open lot(kind of hard to pull into because of the one way streets but it's right across from the bakery off Loomis. Super friendly service. Food was beyond excellent! Can't wait to go back! And the coffee was exceptional! Glad we stopped in (after working our 12 hour shift at the hospital)! The pictures on Yelp are accurate to the meals 100%!

Just left this restaurant so upset and disappointed!!! Was there over an hour and my food still had not arrived!!! I was smart enough to put in my daughters order right when we sat down since she was really hungry...she had long finished her meal and out meal no where in sight...I was told the kitchen was backed up, yet every family that came way after us were eating already...I got up with my family to pay for my daughters meal and management asked what can be done to remedy the situation...I said nothing...I was told that my order was coming out for like the 3rd time, but we decided to leave...I told management I'm still not understanding how so many people were seated after us, and already eating....So upset and disappointed!!! More at myself, since we were supposed to go to Sweet Maple but the line was out the door and decided to try Stax...huge mistake!!!! What a shame because the experience had started out great, the hostess was really nice! I will never return here!!

I live for brunch.  I tried Stax while in town visiting.  I usually go to batter and berries but did not want to go all the way up north.Yummy!  We got there around 9:15 on Sunday and were seated straight away.  Our server, Lauren I think was her name, explained all the specials in detail after first asking if we were interested.I ordered the steak and eggs with a side of cinnamon roll waffles.  Steak was tender and juicy, eggs fluffy, potatoes perfectly seasoned and mini waffles, the perfect touch of sweet.My brother had the spinach omelette or maybe it was a frittata but he loved it and the side of polenta pancakes with blueberry compote.Will definitely add this to my chicago rotation!

My boyfriend and I had the healthy start pancakes and the skirt steak with egg. Their pancakes are incredible! If you are a pancake lover then I highly recommend you to try out their pancakes! And also the steak that my boyfriend had its really tender and the mini waffle that comes with the steak was also fabulous! I love both the waffle and the pancake. I can't choose which one is better!

I've been here plenty of times, stax is one of my favorite brunch spots in Chicago. I totally recommend this place for breakfast and lunch. They have a little bit of everything on the menu. The lattes are amazing. Also, they have a juice bar. The customer service is great but sometimes there is a wait but the food is totally worth it!

Worst hostess ever.Overpriced bland breakfast.Insane wait time, for piss poor quality.Dont come here!I don't really feel the need to wait a while before I write a yelp review but I did for this one. The fact that I still remember the negative experience, is a strong indicator of the long-lasting impact of bad service - and fair warning to choose the other nearby breakfast options over this one.The hostess called our name and we didn't hear it. When we told her that we were overlooked and had been waiting already for twenty minutes, she barked at us and said "Well, you could wait longer then!" and proceeded to call two more groups of two before us. The managers need to train their hostesses better, or get pagers like the rest of the brunch world. Either way, I'm never going back and take it from me, neither should you.

Stax Cafe is a great little spot for brunch. Service is sometimes spotty. I've been here a hand full of times and it seems like they are understaffed. The food and friendly service make up for the waiting time. Good sized portions and great soy lattes. I will continue to come back.

Stax was the first restaurant I ever ordered an eggs benedict, and I've been looking for a benedict to match since. Stax has perfected a dairy-free eggs benedict, and their potatoes on the side are cooked to perfection. Without the use of butter and any other dairy products (after I ask, of course), stax has made the best eggs benedict I've had yet. For several weeks, I would go spinning and then come straight to stax for a filling and satisfying brunch.The menu is short; with limited options and not a lot of variety, I have not been too eager to try anything else. I always enjoyed trying my friends' plates, but I've only enjoyed the eggs.The environment is friendly, and the restaurant is slightly tight, but you can still move around. I haven't always appreciated the staff; I understand that brunch gets very busy on weekends, but I found the service almost negligent sometimes. I also found the hostess slightly rude and combative, and my newcomer friend wanted to immediately go somewhere else because of the attitude. However, I am always willing to come back for the food, and I'm always willing to wait.Overall, I love this restaurant. The servers are competent about the food and are always nice. This place is my go to every time I'm in the area.

Came here for a Sunday brunch as a group of 3 and surprisingly, we were seated and served quickly. Love the menu here and even though the service was great, we were definitely rushed from beginning to end.

Breakfast brunch place wasn't too crowded. Everything fresh. Had an apple juice that was squeezed (crushed) very good! I had the angus burger with tomato jam which was interesting. It was alright. The bacon was fantastic.The one thing I didn't care for was the coffee. Which is pretty big for me. Disappointed.The waitstaff was really great.Food alright.Coffee blah.

I love breakfast and Stax is my latest find in Chicago.  The menu has incredible variety so there is something suitable for any craving I have.  I love savory foods for breakfast but sometimes I like to have something sweet.  At Stax you can order an egg dish and get a side of the amazing pancakes for a small up-charge!  What a great idea!!!The space is clean and comfortable and I found the service to be exceptional.  I plan to go back very soon.Bonus Points...It's on "Taylor" Street :)

We weren't intending to come here, but the other place on Taylor closes on Mondays and Tuesday's during the winter season (sucks to be a Midwesterner; business operations are seasonal as well).  We, of course, didn't want to settle on Starbucks (what a fool if we did). Stax was the next breakfast/brunch we saw.  There were lots of patrons dining in; the lights were shining and bright; servers were working hard.  Yeah, this was it!  Look no further.We were warmly greeted by one of the servers, and then the hostess guided us to the table.  The menu was pretty extensive, not to mention that the daily specials were written on one of the columns which I failed to notice after we placed our order (not a big deal). I ordered the Spanish Harlem (chorizo omelet with diced veggies on the side) with mini waffles.  Hubby, on the other hand, ordered the oatmeal pancakes with bacons.The wait wasn't long at all.  I barely had a couple sips of coffee.  I took a bite of the mini waffle.  Wow, that was the best waffle I've had for a long time.  It was so soft, fluffy...anyways, everything was so lovely about this piece of angelic waffle.  The actual Spanish Harlem entree was well-done.  Everything tasted fresh and flavorful.  Hubby said the pancakes were delicious.  The granola on top weren't overly sweet.  The bacons were cooked right; they had a nice "bark" to it.  Overall, it was a pleasant dining experience.They were fairly busy on a Tuesday mid-morning, but the service was attentive.  All servers and the hostess were working together as a great team.  The total came to $32 after tax.  The prices were better than what you would have in the Chicago loop area, but it's literally one (1) bus ride away (CTA 157-Taylor/Streeterville) to get this place if you want to avoid some over-priced diners downtown.

No wait if you go before 10am! Otherwise Stax gets pretty busy really quickly. Free mini waffles or pancakes with yelp check-in (you can even ask for blueberry pancakes!) = super super awesome.Their giant slices of whole wheat toast studded with sunflower seeds + over easy eggs was perfect for a post-4th of July brunch. It's all I wanted, so I ordered the starving student (which you can sub the bacon for pork sausage for no extra charge! if you want turkey sausage it's $1 extra). My bf got the beef brisket and really enjoyed it. He loved the mini waffles even more, of course. It's their specialtyWe've tried their Taylor Street Frittata before and it's always a good choice. Their potatoes are better than other places since they some add onions and bell peppers!

Really Nice place for a sit down, with GREAT food. However, I cant give this pace 5 stars.When trying to order takeout around lunch hour, they literally WONT answer the phone.Also, if you sit at the bar you can see the the cooks do their thing, which is not good.They dont use gloves and the rag they have hanging off their shoulders they use to clean off things, wipe their hands AND dry off your bacon... :(

The food here is delicious, it's a bit noisy for my liking however everything else wasn't bad! The waitress we didn't pay much attention to us but I guess the food makes up for it!! You'll be in and out quickly.
Not sure why people wait to eat here. It's really mediocre and the neighborhood smells like sewage. There's a reason it only has 300 reviews and been open for several years.
We love stax! Big portions and it includes pancakes if you so choose. Always willing to recommend their favorite.I don't like their coffee much, but all food is delicious! Kiddos love it too!
This is a good place to have brunch, but they don't' offer mush potato or the real steak, and the burger is not very big. Is not cheap for a brunch.

I had the eggs Benedict when I went- it was great, but not revolutionary. I think that Stax is such a popular breakfast place because it is slightly more unconventional than the average brunch place. The eggs were the perfect amount of runny-but rich, and the hollandaise was perfectly seasoned. I think that it's a little bit pricey for what you get, but overall still a great place!

I was surprised when I saw this place had been recognized by Michelin rating. Well, it was worth the recognition! My friend had the breakfast tacos and I had the open face bacon jam and egg sandwich. Both very good! We also got a free pancake when I checked-in using Yelp...not a bad idea! The only concern I had was that it did take some time to get our food. I WILL BE GOING AGAIN to try more things on the menu. The place was also packed which is usually a good sign.

The food is delicious. It was great little place for breakfast. Friendly staff and we didn't have to wait long for our food.  I just wish the tables weren't so close together. I don't like to hear other people's conversations.

The ambience is really nice. I had the weirdest experience for a breakfast. I walked up really early and the waitress had a stupid look on her face. She didn't care to smile. After I finished eating I was asked if I want something more only after the check was kept on my table. They need to definitely teach the service guys. The waffles were great though!!

Oh the joys of sipping on a steaming cup of coffee and enjoying a bounteous brunch while gazing out as the snow descends from the heavens and quietly blankets everything in a pure, flawless, spotless white; white as chastity itself!  I would have you watch me in awe and wonder as I gather around myself the robes of Milton and Shakespeare to sing eulogiums of the marvelous glory and grandeur of the snow-clad Chicago, invoking the help of the Heavenly Muse so that I can do justice to it.  But I suddenly realize that this review is not about Chicago or the snow; and humbly apologize for this digression.I must caution you that this place is not for feeding a hangover because it gets very crowded and noisy, which might even aggravate a hangover.  I've had brunch here a few times, and have always enjoyed the food and the friendly service.  The coffee is strong and serves as an efficacious eye-opener.  The pancakes are fluffy and fulfilling.  My two favorite pancakes are the banana cake (sliced bananas cooked within the pancakes, sprinkled with macadamia crumbles) and the ricotta pancake (which comes with a strawberry compote).  Speaking of pancakes, I must share that you get a free side of pancakes for checking in on Yelp!I had the green chili chilaquiles with scrambled eggs this morning, and found it to be very flavorful; the eggs were perfectly creamy and fluffy, and the diced onions and salsa verde gave the dish a very pleasant piquancy.  I've also had the B.Y.O omelet with onions, sun-dried tomatoes and pepperjack cheese, and it was very tasty.  The breakfast potatoes are well seasoned and are accompanied by just the right quantity of onions and peppers to make a splendid savory side.Contrary to the experience of another Yelper, my check was brought to my table, and I made my payment just like I would at any other sit-down restaurant, so the policy of making the payment at the hostess' desk appears to be no longer in effect.
One of my favorite brunch place on Taylor street.  I been there multiple times. Freshly squeezed orange juice is good and pretty much everything on there menu is decent

IF YOU DON'T WANT THE TRUTH THEN DON'T ASK..... So the manager or hostess asks me on my way out, how was the meal?  I replied "It was ok, I've had better.  But not enough to get my repeat business".  She then gave me the sour candy face and proceeded to tell me that they were recommended by Michelin....Ok, really...I think she meant to say Zagat but I'll give her a pass on that one.Let me tell you what was good and what wasn't so good.The potatoes had a fishy aftertaste - Not goodThe Banana French Toast - Ok but badly presented.  Instead of making it look like baby food, cut the bananas and pour the caramel over it. My suggestion.The Omelet - Normal - Nothing out of this worldThe clear winner here were the MINI WAFFLES - Very goodIn closing I told her that it wasn't bad, but many do it better.  This is Chi-town girl.  You got to come with it!Chicago is second to none and these restaurants need to up their game.
I just fell in love for the food and the customer service. It's a clean, cool and really nice place to have breakfast or brunch.
Pretty good food!

I am coming out of hibernation just to write this review.I have been to a lot of breakfast places and I haven't written a review in years, but today I feel compelled to come out of retirement and warn people about this place.PROS-The place is clean and has a nice atmosphere.-The egg tacos turned out to be pretty solid.CONS-Pricey!!  It cost 40 dollars for my friend and I to eat food that likely cost them 2 dollars tops!-I've received better service at IHOP.  They had you food and they hand you the bill.  That is it.-Water was TERRIBLE.  It had the right out of the sink after taste and was not even cold.  The water comes out of these chic glass bottles they leave at your table(so staff has even less reason to visit your table) and its not cold and takes like crap.  How do you mess this up?-We got served our pancake waffle before our meal...ok so 99% of the world eats sweets at the end of a meal.  So we had to eat our waffle/pancake nice and cold, just how we like it!  (Come on guys, why would you serve pancake/waffle first?)Now for the worst part, the food!!!!!I ordered the egg tacos and lumberjack skillet.  I have a massive appetite and so I usually order two entrees.Let me tell you about the lumberjack skillet first.It costs $14, and it consists of 3 eggs, and a whole potato chopped up, with a slice of cheese and a TINY amount of meat.  WTF!?!The egg tacos were actually decent I can't hate on these, but then half the plate is another potato.Honestly I am not picky.  I'm the guy who eats plane eggs, cheerios, etc for breakfast because they are easy to calculate macros for.So when I FINALLY decide to go out and eat something I get this basura!Seriously, at the start of the meal ask for EXTRA KETCHUP, you will need it to slug this meal down.Ultimately I would recommend this place to anyone with a serious starch deficiency because you will eat a lot of potatoes!I gave it two stars, because despite being VERY ANGRY right now, the place is not a 1 star place.  It is decent, but I put it as 2 stars because I will never return.To all my fellow meatheads out there, NOT WORTH YOUR MACROS, just go to Chipotle for the 100th time!I would have GLADLY told my waitress this in person, but we did not even receive a simple "how was everything?"I was here 7am 5/25/2015.

I've been in the Pilsen neighborhood for 3 years and have wanted to come here for quite some time.  The wife and I finally made it in and we've been missing out!  I'm a big fan of the space, the wait staff were professionals, and the food was really good.Honestly I wanted to come back here a week later, but we're still in the explore phase of all the local brunch joints at the moment.  Stax is now, for sure, a personal favorite.  I'll be back.

Food is really good, my favorite are the mini waffles! They do make orange juice in house for you or if you don't want juice they bring a carafe of water. Coffee is pretty good imo. The only thing is that, it is a very expensive place to be in a college town. I'm sure they would have more business if everything wasn't so overpriced.
Bit pricey but the food is pretty good. Normally super crowded so be prepared to wait.

Came here in the afternoon I had the veggie skillet, it was asparagus mushroom spinach, tomato and Swiss cheese, I asked for cheddar instead..What I liked about it was that the egg was not mixed with the potatoes and vegetables it was served over it ... I asked for scramble but you can get it over easy etc...The skillet was served with two mini waffles (or you can choose toast or pancakes)The potatoes are cubed and served in big portions , and the vegetables were not over sautéed - I took half of my portion home and was still able to reheat it ..,The other thing I liked was that my food was not very greasy or salty , it was cooked with care and not just thrown together ..Our server was very friendly and attentive..I would definitely bring a friend or two .It was pricey $14 and $2.50 for an iced coffee - but considering other breakfast places that's still a deal .

Ordered the Brisket Benedict.Over all not bad. The eggs were over cooked, the brisket was dry, and the potatoes were under seasoned.The coffee was decent.I was excepting much more from the food.Service is exceptional and we got seated quickly.

Love this place!!! Great comfy, cozy and DELICIOUS spot for breakfast! The pancakes are fluffy and perfect... Best crepes I've had in a long time!Best part about this place is the good customer service, cleanliness and comfortable setting it gives off. Will definitely be back!

My first time visiting this place was kool. The atmosphere was laid back & roomy, and The waitress we had was nice & helpful. I tried the vegetarian skillet, with mini waffles on the side, with some oj. I can say this will be 1 of my main picks.

I was here hours ago and I'm still super full, so that's a plus. My friend ordered the 'starving student" and that looked really good and she said it was delicious, so you should take that into consideration if you plan on dining here. Over all, this place was exactly a-ok for me, I had the dulce de leche french toast and the dulce de leche wasn't mixed in the french toast, it just replaces the syrup. For those uncertain of what to order, order a juice and something from their "eggs and bennies" portion of the menu because that's what they're well known for. It even comes with a cute little portion control sized waffle or pancakes to put an end to the sweet tooth craving that many, including myself, walk in here with.

The lumberjack skillet and mini waffles were great. We waited a little bit. We did notice the manager tell the hostess we have been waiting and to get us seated. The hospitality was appreciated. The food came out in a timely manner. However, he asked if my friend was finished and she said no. We were talking a few minutes later and he just took her plate and my empty plate away without asking... she was not even done. He returned with the bill. We felt pushed out.
Very decent food with timely, polite service. Great spur of the moment idea if you're a little village dweller. Will definitely come again since I live close.

Stax oh stax, I love you very much! Stax has been giving me an outstanding brunch experience. Yes, the line is always long and you cannot make a reservation, but they are worth waiting for. The foods are always great, especially the skillets. Nom. Nom. Nom. And their fresh squeeze juice is so good. Their service is awesome, too. The waitress is attentive and kind. I will highly recommend stax to everyone!

Upon many reviews, I finally made my way to STAX.....I went on a wednesday, since I was told that it gets CRAZY packed on weekends. I brought my very good friend along for the tasting of this new place.I had read that there was parking lot across the street, however this is untrue. The parking lot is actually a block down from here and I have no clue if its free. I chose to do street parking.Upon entrance, it didnt seem busy, for a rainy wednesday 10am...AWESOME.Since I checked in, I was able to retrieve the free mini waffles that is available via yelp. My hostess had no clue about this, but my server Josh did. He was awesome. Extremely friendly, happy server. I always love an upbeat server. Who wants to be served by someone who shows they hate their job, not me! However, with Josh, I love his interaction with customers not only with us. He tells us about some entrees that arent on the menu n very descriptive.We both had coffee, a bit strong for me, reminded me of Starbucks (n i dnt like their americana i find it too strong) but everyone is different so def not rating their coffee becuz everyone likes it different.We order, my friend had the Spanish Harlem omlette with potato.... n shared potatoes with me....MAN THOSE ARE THE S&!T AS IN THE BOMB.COM!!! My friend raved about it n was very satisfied. I had the banana pancakes with macademia nut topping. Eh, it was just a regular pancake with banana, nothing to rave about. Regret ordering this lol just because it was too ordinary. Im coming back for that Spanish harlem omlette thats how good my friend's entree was.On my way out, I literally bumped into a detective n hit his vest....HELLO OFFICER LOL...he told me to stay dry n duck under the canopy (it was raining hard when we left).Service was great and I will def come back. Our server checked in on us, didnt hover over us but didnt neglect us either, perfect.Detective if ur reading this, private me lol....ahaha my friend noticed the detective as well ...oops!

I looked this place on yelp before going and the reviews appeared great at first. interesting that the bad reviews are hidden under "not recommended" and probably this one will go there, too. had the simplist breakfast on earth; 2 eggs over easy, potatoes, bacon and toast. the eggs were cooked perfectly but had a man's hair in them. the toast was fine but the potatoes were oily and lukewarm like they were under a warmer at a hotel buffet. the bacon was soooooooo enticing but after eating some my mouth was burning from the salt. it was like chewing sea salt. seriously, I've never had this experience and I eat my weight in bacon annually. maybe the pancakes are amazing....but I won't be going back.

This place is a great little breakfast spot. It is a little pricey but the cuisine is really good.  It has so many choices that check so many boxes.  Staff is on point and always in arms reach.  Hats off to this place for a great all around experience.
Green chile chilaquiles, breakfast tacos, intelligentsia coffee are all incredible. Oh and the Mac and cheese is delicious!

I've only been to this restaurant once but I would definitely return. Went during the week so there was no wait. Waitress was pleasant. I had the chocolate chip pancakes and they were delicious.  The home fries were very good as well.
Great breakfast. Do the Yelp checkin to try a new pancake or waffle. I can't wait to try everything on the menu.

A friend that I was traveling with heard about Stax from a local blogger she's been following. We all decided to take a trip out west to see what all this hype was about.Holy smokes! Portions were huge! The three of us ordered the the chocolate french toast, priscrotto egg toast with corn cakes, and the mixed berry crepe. By far, the best choices made which left the 3 of us full and satisfied.Make sure you check in on yelp to get a little extra something for free ;)
Came in this morning. First time. Food was excellent and the service was great. Thanks Grant! (Server). He was the bomb! Definitely coming back soon.
Nice creations, very good service but over priced in my mind. I liked the ambience and decor but feel they lack value for what I paid.

You can't go wrong with breakfast or lunch here. The fresh-squeezed grape juice is awesome! The first time I ordered the omelet, I wasn't impressed. I went back a second time for lunch, but I tried my sister's omelet and it was great. I must have just caught them on a bad day. The service is good and fairly quick.
We went to eat there today and  felt nausea and ill because your restaurant had such awful paint fumes/stain fumes. So much formaldehyde going through your restaurant. Even your hostess was ill.

After hearing that there was a 25 minute wait at Sweet Maple Cafe, we came here where we got seated right away. The staff here is really great. Refills with the coffee kept coming. She apologized a couple times about not having my chorizo in the order, and I didn't have to wait too long to get it. I have been a couple times now and love the variety and options they have on their menu. I got the Green Chilaquiles with chorizo. My over medium egg was slightly overcooked but my dish was fantastic. It totally hit the spot. I almost finished it all, but couldn't because I think it was an abnormal time for me to eat and have brunch when I usually have breakfast and lunch. The pancakes are yummy as well. I will be back to try their other breakfast concoctions here.
Great little breakfast spot near UIC. I've eaten hear 20-30 times and never disappointed. Fresh food and juice. Great staff and nice ambiance.

This has been my friends' go-to spot for brunch. At least, we see which of the two lines of Sweet Maple or Stax is shorter, but I think we've found a comfort with Stax. I think, and my friends do too, the best part of Stax's menu is that many of their dishes come with the option of the mini-pancakes/waffles/toast with the egg/savory option AND potatoes that you don't find in a lot of brunch spots. So its a lot of food for not a lot!Their mini-waffles are to die for!! So fluffy and perfectly sweet-I eat them plain or save them for later if I can't finish.For my go-to main dish, I almost always go with the Spanish Harlem. The ingredients all just taste so fresh and the chipotle sauce they use us the perfect smoky kick. The side potatoes are always cooked well with the roasted peppers - yum!!My only complaint on food isn't that big of a deal, but their coffee just isn't my favorite. But I still drink it anyway if I need the caffeine.I am also curious to see how their fresh squeezed juices taste like as I have yet to try them, but they always look delicious, as does all their food!Service is always spot on and their servers are great people to ask for suggestions for your meal.One star docked for the coffee and the long wait you can have on weekends - but it is a brunch place, so that is almost always expected.

I can't believe it has taken me so long to write a review.....Stax is one of my favorite places to eat. My husband & I used to frequent this lovely establishment and we've never had a bad experience nor bad food. EVERYTHING is always amazing....fresh squeezed orange juice, turkey burger, fries, pancakes, potatoes...you name it and it's YUMMY!I'm fond of the location, too. But be very very careful with parking (I got a ticket once because the no parking sign was not visible).

Stopped in for breakfast about 10:30 am on Friday. Seated right away. Bright, lively, casual. Appropriate portioned omelette with onions, roasted peppers, and queso fresco. Nice. Skipped the potatoes and got fruit - a good-size bowl of fresh pineapple, cantaloupe, honeydew, strawberries, and blueberries. Great choice on the fruit! (I've had disappointing mini cups if fruit with crazy substitution charges at other places, but not here!)  Also, instead if toast, I went with mini-waffles WITH BLUEBERRIES - NO EXTRA CHARGE! WHAT AN AWESOME CHOICE THERE! Get the mini-waffles!!! The tab wasn't cheap, but not outrageous. Great meal, with iced tea, $17.00 before tip. (Solo diner).

Visited the Fat Shallot at the new Revival Food Hall. The truffle BLT is fantastic!! Delicious crisp high quality bacon, avocado, just the right amount of truffle oil for that gourmet flavor - I couldn't help devouring the whole thing. Just the perfect balance of each ingredient, on lovely challah bread.Be sure to try the bacon slaw. I don't know how they keep the bacon so crisp, but....wow!Their Vanilla Bean Malt - decadent and the vanilla flavor is fantastic.
